sentence: What brings you back into the clinic today, miss?
I came in for a refill of my blood pressure medicine.

It looks like Doctor Kumar followed up with you last time regarding your hypertension, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, hypothyroidism, allergic rhinitis and kidney stones.  Have you noticed any changes or do you have any concerns regarding these issues?
No.
Have you had any fever or chills, cough, congestion, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, chest pressure?
No.
Great. Also, for our records, how old are you and what race do you identify yourself as?
I am seventy six years old and identify as a white female.
How're you feeling today?
Terrible. I'm having the worst headache of my life.
I'm so sorry. Well you are only twenty five, so let's hope this is the last of the worst. Let's see how we can best help you. When did it start?
Around eleven in the morning.
Today?
Um no yesterday. July thirty first.
July thirty first O eight. Got it. Did it come on suddenly?
Yeah.
Are you having any symptoms with it, such as blurry vision, light sensitivity, dizziness, lightheadedness, or nausea?
I'm having blurry vision and lightheadedness.  I also can't seem to write well. It looks so messy. I am naturally right handed but my writing looks like I am trying with my left.
How would you describe the lightheadedness?
Like there are blind spots.
Okay. How about any vomiting?
Um no. I feel like my face is pretty swollen though. I don't know if it's related to the headache but it started around the same time.
Here in the E R, we'll do a thorough exam and eval to make sure nothing serious is going on. While we're waiting for your C T results, I'm going to order a migraine cocktail and some Morphine.
Thank. Will the nurse be in soon?
Yes, she'll be right in as soon as the order is placed. It shouldn't be more than a few minutes. If it takes longer, then please ring the call bell.
Hello, miss. What is the reason for your visit today?
I think I have some warts on my back end where the poop comes out.
I see. When did you start noticing them?
I think like three to four weeks ago.
Do you feel any pain or discomfort?
It itches a little, but I haven't felt any pain yet. Is this normal for a twenty two year old?
I'll have to take a look, but you'll be fine. Are there any other symptoms that you are aware of?
Nope. Just the warts and itchiness.
Are you taking any over the counter medicines?
No, only the ones which were prescribed.
No alternative medicine, naturopathy or anything?
No, only whatever is here in this prescription.
Okay let me take a look...so you were prescribed Salmeterol inhaler-
On as needed basis.
Okay and the other one is Fluticasone inhaler, which is-
Which is a nasal inhaler.
Right.
Hi, how are you?
I burned my hand.
Oh, I am sorry. Wow!
Yeah.
Is it only right arm?
Yes.
How's your asthma since you started using your inhaler again?
Much better. I don't know why I didn't take it with me everywhere I went.
It's important to carry it with you, especially during times where you're exercising or walking more than usual.
Yeah. I think I've learned my lesson.
Besides asthma, do you have any other medical problems?
Do you smoke?
No, I quit before I had my daughter.
Are you currently pregnant?
No, I'm not.
Did you have any complications with the birth of your daughter?
I actually had a C section.
Have you had any other surgeries in the past?
I got my appendix out a few years ago.
Do you have any other issues, like high blood pressure or heart disease?
No.
Do you have diabetes?
No.
Are there any problems with the lungs, thyroid, kidney, or bladder?
No.
So, how long ago did you hurt your lower back?
It was about four or five years ago now, when I was in a car crash.
What kind of treatments were recommended?
They didn't recommend P T, and I didn't really have any increased back pain after the accident.
Any know drug allergies?
No.
Hi there, sir! How are you today?
Hello! I am good.
I would like to start with your family medical history today. What do you know about their medical history?
My mother and father both had heart disease. Well, my mother had complication from her heart disease and that is how she passed.  My father was only in his forty's when he died.
I am so sorry the hear that.

Thank you. I have two brothers, one whom I don't speak to very much anymore. I don't know if he has any health problems. My other brother is healthy with no issues. Both my uncles on my mother's side had polio, I think.
Tell me more about your uncles with polio. They both had polio?
One of them had to wear crutches due to how bad his leg deformans were and then the other had leg deformities in only one leg.  I am fairly certain that they had polio.
Do you know of any other family member with neurological conditions?
No. None that I know of.
Do you have any children?
Yes. I have one child.
Is your child healthy and well?
Yes.
Can you tell me about any diseases that run in your family?
Sure, my brother has a prostate cancer.
Okay, brother.
My father had brain cancer.
Okay, dad.
Then on both sides of my family there are many heart related issues.
Okay.
And my brother and sister both have diabetes.
Okay.
Yes, that's it.
Good afternoon, ma'am. Welcome to A B C D General Hospital. Before we begin, I just need to confirm some background information on you.
Good afternoon, doctor. Absolutely, that's no problem.
First, how old are you?
I'm nineteen, sir.
Good, and your chart says you identify as Caucasian. Is that correct?
Yes, sir, that's correct.
Great, what seems to be problem today, ma'am?
I've had this bunion on my foot for such a long time.
How long has this bunion been present?
At this point, um, I don't even remember how long it's been.
Do you have any other conditions that I should be aware of?
Actually, yes. I have a history of, um, Charcot Marie tooth disease.
That's good to know, thank you.
I would like to have surgery to cut this bunion off, I can't take it anymore.
I hear someone has a birthday coming up, how old are you turning, ma'am?
I'll be ninety later this month, doctor.
You're here for a follow up not very long after your first visit. What seems to be the problem today?
Well, actually, my high blood pressure and right arm symptoms are basically gone.
Great, I saw your blood pressure reading for today, and it's much better. Are you taking the higher dose of Mavik we recommended?
No, I'm not taking that right now.
How did you tolerate the higher dose?
I didn't feel well at all, so I just went back to the old dose.
That was one M G per day, correct?
Yes, doctor. I do think I could have some white coat high blood pressure. Doctors' offices make me nervous.
That does happen. Here, try this sample of Tarka, please.
What is this for, doctor?
Well, since you're taking the Mavik plus verapamil, you can switch over to Tarka, which is the combined version of the two drugs.
I can't take these, doctor. They're too big.
Hello doctor, I'm her daughter. Just so you know, we check her blood pressure at home periodically and it's always similar to that reading.
Good, so back to that right arm, how is that doing today?
Well, that pain is basically gone now, I think it had to do with that muscle problem back in my right shoulder blade.
Did you have x rays taken today?
Yes, the tech brought me back right before you came in.
Good, I have the images right here.
What do they show, doctor?
Well, these x rays of the neck and right shoulder show some degenerative changes, and possibly some kind of rotator cuff injury.
What makes you think there's an injury?
Well, look right here. The humeral head is pretty high in the glenoid in the right shoulder, but do you have any pain here?
No, none.
Then we won't worry about it.
I am having this stomach pain though, doctor.
How has this pain developed and progressed recently?
Well, it's improved somewhat with me not taking Aleve anymore.
What medicines are you taking right now, then?
Right know, I'm just taking Tylenol as needed. That seems to be enough for me.
Do you think this could be acid reflux, or heartburn?
No, but I take Tums, um, three times a day, and Mylanta at night. Oh yeah, I have these sores in my mouth, can you take a look?
I see. How long have you worn dentures?
Oh I couldn't even tell you, it's been many, many years.
Do they come and go, the sores?
Yes, one will come, then it'll heal up, then another.
Okay, we'll keep an eye on it.
And doctor, since I've been taking the Lexapro, I have some tremors on basically my whole body, at least the upper body, like my torso and arms.
It's hard to tell if you have a tremor today, ma'am, but do you think the Lexapro is helping otherwise?
Yes, we think so.
Are you talking any medications?
No, I don't believe in meds.
Oh really, let me check your list.
Yeah never.
Wow amazing.
Any past medical history?
She has a history of peptic ulcer disease and we think she may have had a possible stroke three or four years ago. I would have to double check.
Let me see if I can find it in her records.
Does she see a neurologist?
Um I'm not sure. I can call her son?
Yes, if you could find out that'd be great.
She's also experiencing some memory loss as of one to two years ago. I think that's it for medical history.
How old are you?
I am forty four.
Are you right handed or left handed?
I'm right handed.
Tell me what happened.
I don't know. I woke up over this numbness on my left side of the body. I remember it was on July twenty nineth.
Was there any sensation like having pins and needles? Was there any weakness? Is there any change in your visual or mental status? Were you able to walk?
I was able to walk and there was no weakness or any other thing you mentioned.
When did you first start noticing these symptoms?

There was nothing around Independence Day. It all started after that. At first, I felt that my right hand is very clumsy, and it is kind of stiff. Then I noticed leaning towards the right when walking. It was strange. Happened around July seventh.
Did you recently have any cold or flu like symptoms?
No.
Were diagnosed with a thing called multiple sclerosis?
No.
Did you ever have a feeling where you felt like there's an electric is going up or down your spine?
No.
How about any fatigue or pain? Any frequency in your urination? Any urgency in that?
No.
You had a heart surgery, right?
Yes, that is right.
Pacemaker?
Yes, they did that.
What else? What other surgeries?
I have had a hysterectomy.
Okay.
Yeah.
How old are you, young boy?
I am twenty nine.
And you got right side shoulder pain? Is this something new?
Yes. That is right.
What were you doing when this happened?
I think I was picking up a stack of cardboard, then putting it down on the ground and twisting to the right side. And sometimes I was throwing them a little bit as well.
Okay, and how far you were lifting them or bending?
Around here, till waist level.
Okay.
I heard a pop and since then there is pain in this area. I can't lift heavy items. Basically I have no strength.
Okay. And this all started from June thirty two thousand and four?
Yes, that's right. The pain is in the lateral part of the back of my shoulder.
How did you lose your arm if I may ask?
Motorcycle accident.
When did the nausea and vomiting start?
About a few hours ago. I can't seem to stomach anything.
How many episodes of vomiting have you had?
At least four.
Any abdominal pain, fever, chill, or other symptoms?
Just nausea and vomiting. It's been so terrible.
I'll order you some Zofran to help bring the nausea to bay. One moment while I put the order in.
Good afternoon, ma'am.
Good afternoon, doctor.
Is this your assistant, ma'am?
Yes, she helps me out all day.
Great, do you have your food diary sheets?
Yes, can you give them to her, please?
Thank you. What are you doing for exercise?
Um, right now, I walk around at the mall to get my steps in every day.
Is he currently taking any medication?
No.
Hello, sir. I see your last visit was on July two thousand and seven. What was the reason for that visit?
My asthma was acting up, and it felt like I couldn't breathe.
Do you have a history of asthma?
Not that I know of, but I know I always get this really bad cough where I cough up some nasty phlegm.
I see. I'm looking at your report and it says you have a history of pneumonia.
Do you know about any medical traits in your family?
No, everyone in my family is quite healthy. I'm not aware of any medical problems.
Are you sexually active?
Yes, I am with my boyfriend.
Do you take any drugs or alcohol or smoke?
No, none of them.
Any past medical history?
Um there were a couple times where I noticed my blood pressure was high but that's improved as of late.
When did these episodes occur?
About a year ago.
Did you follow up with your previous doctor?
Yeah, my old doctor knows.
Okay then. Let's see. Have you been checking your own blood pressure as a result?
No not really.
It looks like your blood pressure was normal today, which is a good sign.
Great.
Hm any allergies to medications?
None that I know of.
And it looks like you have gained about fourteen pounds since last year. Any new diet changes or stressors?
I lost my job last January and it took a pretty big toll on me.
I'm sorry to hear that. How have you been coping?
I'm doing better now but I need to watch what I eat. I tend to eat a lot more when I'm stressed. It's something I'm working on.
Are you allergic to anything?
Yes, I am allergic to Penicillin.
Any other drugs that you could be allergic to?
Nope that is all.
Okay.
What brought them in today?
Poor renal sufficiency, possibly due to dehydration or diabetic nephropathy. She also has high blood pressure and low blood sugar as a result of missing meals regularly.
Doc what are you going to diagnose me as?
We are looking at blood born pathogen exposure secondary to needlestick.
Yes, I was also thinking around contamination.
She was in a car crash, correct?
Correct. About two days ago. I believe it was a head on collision.
Any allergies I should know about?
Nope, no allergies for me.
Hello sir. Let me first start by asking your age. How old are you?
I'm twenty four.
So, what brought you here? How can I help you?
I was out for fishing this weekend, I think I got into some poison ivy and I have these rashes all over my chest, legs, arms and also some are on my back.
You seem so confident of it being poison ivy has it happened before?
Oh yes, it has happened several times before. It usually takes some time to get over. Last time I was here Doctor Blackman gave me a steroid injection.
Okay, let me check my records. It looks like he gave you eighty milligrams of depomedrol. How was it last time after the injection?
It worked fine. It did take us some time to get rid of it.
Did you take any medicine or anything else this time?
I took over the counter Benadryl. Also, I'm applying cortisone cream on the rashes.
Did they help you?
I saw a little bit of improvement. But this weekend it seemed to have been worst.
No worries, let's set you up for another injection.
You had mentioned that cancer runs in your family. What type of cancer?
Skin cancer.
Any other health problems in the family?
High blood pressure.
Hi, what brings you here today?
I feel this lump on the upper side of my breast.
Both sides?
No, only on the left side.
Do you feel it deep inside or on the outer side?
Only on the outer side.
I understand that you are new to the clinic. Welcome.
Yes, I am new here. I have lived in Arizona for the last four years. I am from Maine. That is where I grow up and most of my family still lives there.
What line of work are you in?
I am a homemaker. I used to clean house, a while back.
Do you have children?
I have two children but only one of them is still with us. My oldest son passed away from ulcerative colitis complications three years ago.
I am so sorry to hear that!
You okay there?
Uh yeah, sorry. I'm just trying to adjust the stretcher.
Want some help?
No, thank you. I think I got it.
So how're you doing?
Fine, but I have this weird lump in my chest.
When did you first notice it?
It's been there for a while. I'd say almost half a year.
Have you seen anyone for it?
No, not until now.
Is it causing you pain? And has it changed in size at all?
Not really. It's just noticeable when I run my fingers over it.
Have you spotted any swelling or redness to the area? Any drainage?
No.
I see. Okay. Let me take a look and then I'll have you walk down the hall to get an Xray so we can see what's going on.
Hello, so you are here for follow up today.
Yes, very much.
I will ask you some regular questions, okay?
Sure.
Any pain in urination?
Nope.
Any fever or chills?
Neither of them.
Have you noticed any blood while urinating? Any blood in your urine?

Nope. I do leak, especially when I'm changing my positions like from sitting to standing so I do feel there is some involuntary urination. It's more like a urge. I'm loading data in like every one hour in the morning, especially when I take that Lasix.
Does it taper off in the afternoon or night?
It tapers off in the afternoon. And by the night I don't do not feel anything.
Any leakage in the night?
Nope.
Do you apply a lot of force to urinate?
Nope.
How about this stream? Is it good or less? Are you emptying well? And what about the bowel movement?

The stream is good. It does feel like all is out in one go. I do not have any kind of bowel issues. I'm using my vaginal cream. Sometimes I feel difficulty in doing so because I feel that there is still something coming out from the vagina and I'm afraid that there might be a prolapse.
Don't worry, I will look into it.
Have you lost weight?
No, I haven't, you can ask my daughter.
How about anything like fever, nausea, vomiting, pain?
No.
And as we discussed you have problem talking and comprehending.
Yes.
And you get urine infections too?
Yes.
And as discussed, your drainage is similar to past episodes when you had such infection?
Yes.
Do you use tobacco products? Cigarettes, chewing tobacco or vaping?
I used to smoke a pack a day.  I quit that awful habit in nineteen eighty five.
Do you work?
I am retired.
Wonderful. Is your husband retired with you?
Yes. We both are. I cannot imagine working a full time job at seventy six years old.
Hi there, how are you?
I am okay.
So, I see you turned eighty-eight yesterday, happy birthday!
Thank you!
And you are referred by Doctor X, he is your primary physician, right?
Correct! I am also seeing Doctor Y for my leukemia.
Hm he mentioned that it's chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
Yes.
Okay.
And you are also seeing Doctor Z for your heart related problems.
That is correct.
So, tell me what is happening with you?
For the past one week I am having this increased shortness of breath and having difficulty breathing from past few nights while sleeping.
Okay.
And this morning I was having difficulty catching my breath. I am also having wheezing since morning.
Let me examine you, can you come forward and sit-up here? Any chest discomfort or acute chest pain or anything of that sort? Any pain of the left arm?
No.
Any dizziness, feeling like fainting or light headedness or losing control?
No.
Well, I don't think there is any sign of cardiovascular accident or heart attack, so that's that. You do have mild peripheral edema. We need to treat that.
Okay.
Ready to go home?
I just can't wait.
Sure. I can understand.
Bye Doctor.
Yes. See you soon.
Hello, sir. How are you today? Can you confirm your age?
Fifty eight. I feel like my balance is off, and I've been feeling tired and weak.
How long have you been experiencing this?
It's been going on for six to eight weeks.
I see. Did you feel any other symptoms?
I haven't, but this might not be related. I had pneumonia ten days before this all started.
Interesting. Did you take any medication for that?
I did, but I don't know how to pronounce it. I wrote it down for you to read. Here it is.
Let me take a look. I see you took a full course of amoxicillin, right?
Yeah, that's right.
How did you feel after you finished the antibiotics?
Terrible. I felt like I couldn't control my body. My balance got even worse, and I felt even more tired and weak.
Oh, wow. Do you know why your balance and coordination worsened?
I did fall recently, but I know for a fact my balance was off before my fall.
How high were you when you fell?
I think I was three or five feet high when I fell.
Did you fall on your back?
No, I fell on my feet. Just kidding, I fell on my back.
Funny. Did anything hurt after your fall?
Not really, but I've been having some back pain in my lower and mid back.
Did you always have that pain?
No, I haven't. It comes and goes.
Have you done anything to treat it?
I started to see a chiropractor like five days ago. He adjusts my neck and lower back.
I see. Did you start having problems with your balance after this?
No. I was still having problems with that before I saw the chiropractor.
Okay. So, it wasn't the result of the adjustments. Is there anything else that may have caused it?
I was taking this other medicine for ten days, but I don't remember what it was for. Here is the name of the medication. I wrote it on another paper.
It looks like you took Cipro. This is usually used to treat a U T I. Were you aware you had a U T I?
Oh, yeah. I forgot about that. I thought I had one, so I went to another doctor to get some medication.
I see. I have one more question. Do you have any trouble controlling your bowel movements or attempting to go to the bathroom?
Nope. I feel like I'm able to go to the bathroom whenever I want.
Have you had any illnesses in the past?
Nope.
Anything that is worth mentioning?
Nope.
Sure?
Yes.
Good afternoon, sir. My nurse tells me you're twenty eight years old, is that correct?
Good morning, doctor. Yes, that's correct.
So, what happened?
Well, I punched a wall about three days ago.
Which hand is it?
It's my right hand.
Is this your dominant hand?
Unfortunately, yes, it is.
Where does it hurt?
Um, it's right here on the outside of my hand.
What kind of treatments have you had?
I went to the E D, and they pushed some of the joints in my hand back, and they put me in a splint, so I've been wearing that ever since.
How is your pain today?
Compared to when it started, it's much better today.
How would you describe your pain today?
Today, I'd say it's minimal pain.
Good, do you have any numbness or tingling today?
No, thankfully not.
Hello there, how are you?
I am good, thank you.
He is my colleague Doctor Mason, and he will be assisting me today and taking down notes.
Hi there.
Hello.
Is it okay with you if he can join us?
Sure, no problem.
Great, thank you
Doctor Mason can you take down the notes.
Sure.
Patient looks well developed and well nourished. He is alert with not acute distress.
Got it.
Patient had a head injury, but he is fully conscious. G C S is fifty and nontoxic.
Okay.
Anyone sick in your family?
No.
How about anyone with the same disorders?
No, I don't know.
Okay don't you worry.
How did the patient do on the activity test?
Patient was good. I have advised him to continue with his normal activities as long as he is feeling fine.
How old was he when he were first evaluated in the other hospital?
He was seven.
Which hospital was that again?
It was at U I H C.
So what exactly happened?

He was doing all good like seven months before his evaluation, then he started having some dizzy spells, which like stayed for several seconds to a minute. They were not regular, but he was able to continue his activity immediately after these dizzy spells.
Did the intensity change?
Oh yes. This, these spells, they became more frequent, and they were now for longer periods. By the time we came for the first evaluation, they were like two to three times per day.
How long were they in the duration?
They lasted for like two to three minutes.
Was there any other associated disorder or anything?
Yeah, around three months before his evaluation his hands, they started becoming stressed, like stiffer and felt tighter during these spells. He also felt very weak and tired after these episodes.
Do you have major illnesses in the family like diabetes or high B P?
No nothing. No major illnesses.
Okay.
Yes.
Good morning, sir.
Good morning, doctor.
I just need some background information before we begin today.
Sure.
Good, have you ever had surgery, sir?
Yeah, actually I've had it on my knee, a nose job, and, um, carotid sinus surgery.
Are you still working?
No, I am retired now. I used to work for the U S postal service as an electronic technician but took retirement one year earlier due to my disability.
Ah okay. And who is in your family?
Well, I stay with my wife and daughter in our apartment.
Okay. Do you smoke?
No.
How about alcohol?
I use to drink occasionally, that too very rare, but after my symptoms stated I stopped completely.
Any use of recreational or illegal drugs?
Nope.
Did you travel anywhere recently?
No, it's been really long since I traveled anywhere.
Good afternoon, how are you today?
I am good Doctor, thanks for asking.
This is my colleague Doctor White, and she will be taking the notes. Is it okay if she joins us?
Oh sure, no problem.
Thank you.
Hello, I am Doctor White, nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you too.
Okay, can you breathe in and out for me? Deep breaths please.
Okay.
Okay breath sounds are clear. Lung function looks good. Symmetrical rise and fall in chest as patient breathes. I am going to palpate your chest, it's just a routine exam.
Sure.
Doctor White can you make a note, no egophony or tactile fremitus.
Sure.
Where do you live?
I live in a board and care. It is a nice small care home with some very nice and supportive people. It is just next to the Safeway on Village Drive.
Nice. It looks like you love living there.
Oh yes. I feel very relaxed there.
Did you consume alcohol in any way?
No Sir.
Any tobacco consumption?
Never in my life.
Did you ever try any kind of illicit drugs? Any I V drugs?
No. I have always kept myself away from all those things.
Have you had any surgeries in the past?
Actually, yes, I had my gallbladder removed in nineteen ninety two.
Great, any other surgeries? Think back a little further?
Oh yeah, I had my appendix out in nineteen eighty eight.
How are feeling now after the treatment?
I am feeling pretty fair, improving slowly.
Okay?
Okay.
Sir? Can you hear me? Are you Mister Smith's wife?
Yes. I am his wife.
How old is he? Can you tell me a little bit of how your husband's condition has come to this point? His level of consciousness is concerning.
He is eighty five. He took the entire M G of Xanax. He is only supposed to take point one twenty five M G of Xanax.  That is why he is like this.
It looks like your husband was admitted to the emergency room the night before.  How did these injuries to his face happen?
He fell off his wheelchair.
The Adult Protective Services said they found your husband in the home barley conscious. How long had he been that way?
All day.
Do you know what other medications your husband has taken other than the Xanax?
He didn't take his regular medications for two days.
How have you been feeling? Is the Wellbutrin keeping your mood stabilized?
I have been feeling good. The Wellbutrin is working well for me.
It is important to not consume any alcohol or recreational drugs while taking Wellbutrin.
I don't drink or do drugs.
Tell me a little bit about your family history.
My dad and grandpa both had type two diabetes. My son is struggling with type one diabetes at the moment.
I'm sorry to hear that. Does anyone in your family have heart problems?
No.
How about cancer?
Two of my cousins had breast cancer.
Where do you work, miss?
Well, you see, I am a civil engineer. Right now, due to pandemic like everyone else I am working from home.
Are you working full time or is your disability affecting that?
No, I can only work on half time. This disability does not let me work full time. I need to go to physical therapy quite frequently on and off and I also have a baby who consumes a lot of my time.
Do you smoke or drink?
No, I've never done any of them.
Do you know any familiar diseases in your family?
Do you mean like B P, high sugar?
Yes.
No, no one in my family has anything like that.
Great.
Have you had any anxiety attacks lately?
No.
Have you felt depressed or had any mood swing problems?
No.
Any phobias?
No, not really.
Okay.
Do you have a history of mental illness or psychological disease?
No.
Hello sir. How are you doing today? You still look a little uncomfortable. Is there still pain?
Yeah. Still a good amount of pain. I did not take my pain medication this morning though. Not sure if that will make a huge difference.
That is possibly why you are still in pain. How is movement? Can you get out of the house and get around?
Yes. I am quite happy that I can do my daily activities. I can get up with minimal assistance and do many activities out of the house. I think I am gaining muscle from moving around more too.
How is the home exercise program going?
I am loving pool therapy. I really feel like that is helping. I do the home exercises sometimes twice a day. I really want to get back to normal.
Have you had any surgeries in the past?
Yes, I had knee surgery.
Which knee?
Right.
Are you sexually active?
Yes.
How many partners do you have?
Just one.
Is this a monogamous relationship?
Yes.
What gender is you partner?
He is a male. We have been together for three years. He is H I V positive.
I remember you mentioned that you had one operation done in the past.
I had a lymph node biopsy back in September of O three.
Did it come back negative?
Fortunately, yes.

I don't remember the name of the antibiotic, but I know that I have taken antibiotics before and I didn't have a problem.
How long was your antibiotic course?
It was three or four days long. I had to take it three times a day.
Have you ever had any allergic reactions to medications?
No.
Any history of mouth sores?
No.
Are you taking anything to help with the pain of the mouth sores?
I took Aspirin a month ago. I started taking it again because my mouth was sore.
Have you had any other problems with your skin? Any new rashes?
No.
Sorry to side track, but where is your accent from? My family is Cuban and my mom and you speak the same.
What a surprise! I am Cuban. A proud fifty seven year old Cuban.
Hello, miss. How are you feeling today?
Terrible. My allergies are killing me right now.
Do you have a history of allergies?

Yeah, I do. I had them all the time when I lived in Seattle, but they got a lot worse when I moved here. I am a strong German woman and I hate how something as little as allergies gets the best of me.
Why did you move here?
I wanted to experience different cities since I'm only twenty three.
That sounds exciting. Back to your allergies now. Do you take any medication to relieve your symptoms?
Here's a list of past and current medications I'm taking.
Thank you. Let me take a look. I see you took Claritin and Zyrtec in the past, correct? Did those help you?
Yeah, that's correct. They were working for a bit, but then they stopped working after a while.
I see. Your notes say you took Allegra after, correct?
Correct. I tried out Allegra last summer, but I don't know if it was doing its job. I tried it again two weeks ago because my allergies were getting bad, but it still didn't work.
I see. Your notes state you've tried some nasal sprays, correct?
Yeah, I did. I wanted to see if they would work.
Were you prescribed these nasal sprays?
Nope. I bought them at my local pharmacy.
Sounds good. I'm looking at your medical history, and it sates here you have asthma too, correct?
Yeah, I've had it for a long time, but it hasn't gotten worse.
I see. Do you think you need any medication to help alleviated your asthma?
No. It doesn't bother me as much as my allergies.
How are you doing young man?
I'm good. Thank you.
Let's see how your chest is doing.
Okay.
Chest measurements look nice. No issue there. The outline also looks great. Also, there is no hunchback?
I see here that Doctor-
Yes, Doctor X referred me. My thyroid is an absolute mess. I have never been in so much pain in my seventy one years.
I'm so sorry to hear that. I hope we're able to get you the care that you need.
I've been coughing up a storm. It's gotten to be way too enlarged.
It's good that you're here today to get the surgery rolling.
I signed the paperwork and everything.
I'll go over the risk and benefits one more time. Any questions for me?
When is the earliest I can get this done again?
Given your symptoms, I'd like to get you in in the next few days.
Are you allergic to any medications?
No, I am not allergic to any drugs.
Okay. Are you sure?
Yes.
I see here that you're allergic to grapefruit and peanuts. Do you happen to be allergic to any medications you've taken in the past?
Nah, just allergic to grapefruit and peanuts.
Gotcha. Do you carry an Epi pen around with you?
I try to bring it with me everywhere I go.
So, tell me about your family, any illness or anything that runs in the family.
Um, not that I know of.
Okay.
Any medical issues in the past?
No, I have a very clean history.
That's good for you. Any kind of surgery or hospitalization?
No.
Let's talk a little bit about your family, okay?
Does anyone in your family had any medical issues?
Yeah, my parents died of cancer.
Which cancer? How old were they?
I don't know which cancer they had, but my mother was forty two and dad was sixty two.
Who else is there in the family?
Oh, I have a big family. I have four sisters, one brother and two half brothers. One of my half brother's has asthma.
So, tell me something, does asthma run in your family?
No, I think I am the only one who has it. Even my parents were surprised when I developed it, as no one else has it.
Yeah, it happens.
Welcome in, sir. I am Doctor Gray.
Thank you. It's nice to meet you.
What is your past medical history?
I had surgery on my shoulder thirteen years ago and after the surgery I lost my sense of smell. I still can't smell. I also can't see very well in my right eye.
How old are you?
I am seventy six.
Do you get headaches?
No.
Do you have any nasal drainage?
No.
Do you ever experience any weakness or numbness throughout or localized to an area of the body.
No.
Have you had any resent weight loss?
No.
Do thyroid problems run in your family?
No.
Are you taking any medicines?
Just Tylenol for my pain.
Okay.
Good afternoon, sir. Did you see the nurse already?
Yes, I just saw her.
Great, you're seventy eight years old, correct?
Yes, I'm not as young as I used to be.
Who is? What seems to be the problem today, sir?
I have right hand pain, and it's been there for a while now.
Are you having numbness sir?
Yes, and I can't move it very well, either.
Which fingers are you having these symptoms in?
Well, I told you it's all in the right hand, but it's in the index and middle fingers.
Are your fingers catching?
What does that mean, doctor?
Are you having any problems extending your fingers?
Yes, they seem to lock up when I try to extend my fingers.
Have you seen another doctor for this?
Yes, I had an E M G and it showed, um, carpal tunnel on both hands.
It's in both hands, but the right is worse than the left, correct?
Yes, that's correct.
What treatments have you had for this?
I only had an injection so far.
Did this help at all?
Well, some, but it was really only temporary relief. Is there surgery for this?
Yes, I think you'd be a good candidate for surgery.
What are the risks of infection from the surgery?
It's less than one percent. We use prophylactic antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.
Even though it's on my hand, will I be asleep for this procedure?
Yes, you won't feel a thing.
Okay, yes. I'd like to do the surgery.
Hi are you married?
Yes, I am.
Do you have kids?
Yes, I had a son, but unfortunately, he died in a car accident. It was five years ago.
Where do you work?
I work in a pharmaceutical company as a salesperson.
Do you smoke or drink or at any time tried any illicit drug?
No, I've never smoked. I have tried a beer once, but I never liked it.
What about drugs?
No, never did that.
Are you going to visit rehab?
Yes, what choice do I have?
Yes, please do visit Mercy Manor for P T and Rehab.
Yes, I will.
That will help your right side hip pain.
I think so too.
Can you tell me about your Immunizations?
Yeah, I had them all.
Good, looks like you are up to date.
Welcome back to the clinic. How are you feeling today?
Thank you. I am doing better.
It looks like we are following up on your severe osteoarthritis in both knees. And you also have been experiencing some flexion contracture limitations.
Um hum.
How is your physical therapy going?
It is going really well. She kicks my butt but it seems to be helping. Doing my exercises at home is really helping.
Were you not doing them in the beginning?
No, I wasn't. She got on me to start doing them and I have definitely seen the difference.
Have you experienced any worsening of pain since you were last seen?
Well, the right knee is worse than the left? It mostly hurts after physical therapy.
Can you describe what the pain feels like?
It feels achy.
Is it a continuous pain, or?
No. It is not all the time. Every once and a while. It feels stiff all the time.
Any weakness or instability?
No.
Any burning sensations associated with the pain?
No.
How long have you been dealing with this?
Several months.
Have you had any trouble sleeping?
No. When I sit down or lie down at night there's no pain.
So, the pain is when you are weight bearing, right?
Yeah. And it hurts when I move around. It makes it difficult to do things.
Have you noticed any pain with the cold weather change?
No, I have not noticed anything.
I am just going to take a look here.
Okay.
I don't see any swelling or redness. And I don't feel any warmth coming from the area. Have you noticed any of these symptoms?
Nope.
Any radiating pain through the knees here?
No.
Any pain any where else in the body?
No, just the knees.
So, no pain in the hips or back?
Nope.
Hi, what is going on?
She was doing well until this morning, but now she can barely move her right arm and is having speech issues. She can't seem to comprehend words. I think it is a stroke.
We see this a lot at A B C Medical Center. I am glad you came. You just saw Doctor H, right?
Yes. We did a C T head scan and labs.
Okay. Where is she living? With you?
No. She is at the Life Care Center.
Ma'am, do you have headache or chest pain?
What? What? Huh?
She has not complained of anything like that.
Ma'am. Do you have vision issues?
What? I can see. Of course I can see.
Any shortness of breath?
She is breathing fine.
Have your symptoms improved at all? Or have they worsened since this morning?
No. They have stayed constant.
I think you have a muscular strain.
Yeah.
So right side shoulder strain and maybe a little bit of nerve compression.
Oh really!
Maybe. I will do further evaluation and treatment.
Okay.
Can you tell me more about your daughter, ma'am?
Sure, well she's fourteen now, um, she's right handed, and she just started high school.
Has she ever had surgery?
Yeah, she had an, um, lipomyomeningocele repair when she was about three days old, and then again when she was three and a half years old.
When was her last surgery?
Um, it was in March of nineteen ninety five.
How did she do following the second surgery?
She did well, honestly.
So, what brings you in for a visit today?
Well, I've been having some leg pain on the side of my legs.
How long have you had this pain?
It's been several months at this point.
When is your pain the worst?
Um, it's the worst at night, I have to take medicine for the pain.
What do you take?
She takes Advil, Motrin, and Tylenol P M.
Wow, that's a lot. Looks like you have some patch sensory loss in the L four to S one region. Are you going to the bathroom regularly?
Yeah, there's no problems there. I do have some loss of feeling in my big toe and calf though.
How is the patient's condition now?
Well, he has improved clinically but would require acute care.
Oh, I see.
Good morning, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me, please?
Good morning, I'm sixty five years old, doctor.
How are you recovering from your operation?
I'm doing okay. Can you remind me what operation I had?
Um, we did a left upper lobectomy for your stage I A non small cell lung cancer.
Thank you, doctor.
Absolutely, do you have the results of your pelvic C T?
Yes, I have the report right here.
Thank you, so this shows an enlarging simple cyst of the left kidney.
What can we do about this?
Well, that's why we did the barium swallow, which showed a small hiatal hernia with minimal reflux.
Oh, yeah, I remember that.
So, I have your x rays from November twenty third two thousand nine here, we did an A P and lateral view, and they're normal.
Oh, well that's good too.
Are you having any pain with swallowing food?
Yes, I get some chest pain, but I'd say it's pretty mild. Look at my calf, doctor, it's much bigger than the right one.
Chest pain is probably due to tertiary contractions with some delayed emptying. Is it tender?
No, there's no real tenderness.
How long has this calf been enlarged?
Um, it's been several months at this point.
Have you ever had D V T?
Yes, um, in nineteen seventy five, and in nineteen eighty five.
Are you having any abnormal weight loss?
No, everything is normal there, and I'm eating normally.
What about any cold or flu symptoms? Any fever or chills?
No, that's all fine too.
Any new aches or pains?
No, all my muscles feel pretty good.
Have you had a cough, or coughed up any blood.
That's a negative, doctor.
What about shortness of breath while at rest or difficulty breathing with exercise?
No, that's normal too. I'm breathing just fine.
Let's talk about your family's medical history.
Hm, well both my father and my brother had colon cancer. My daughter was detected with breast cancer.
Do you remember what her age was?
Yeah, she was forty.
I see. Anything else?
Well, I have a heart condition and high blood pressure. I also had a stroke.
Okay.
Any fever?
No.
No nausea and vomiting or black stool? Did you notice any blood in your stools?
Nope, nothing like that.
Did you notice any blood in urine or painful urination?
No.
Okay, any chest pain?
Um, no.
Any shortness of breath, cough or cold like symptoms?
Nope.
No diabetes or thyroid problem, right?
Absolutely not!
Looks like you have no history of C V A or stroke.
Correct.
Everything else looks fine.
Cool.
Your eyes, nose, and throat look good.
How are you doing miss? How are your sugar numbers coming along?
I'm doing good. Thank you. Sugar has consistently been one hundred and thirty five or under it.
How are you checking it?
I have a glucose monitor at home I'm using that only.
Nice. Did you eat anything in the morning today?
No, I'm fasting for my test.
Okay, let's see. We have an Accu Chek here in our office. I will do a quick sugar test for you, and this will be a fasting sugar test. It will be just a quick prick on your finger.
Don't worry doctor. I'm used to poking my finger all the time.
Let's see what we got here. Your reading says one hundred and twenty. I will write it down for my record. Are you being active?
Yes, I'm exercising as a rule three times every week. I don't miss it.
Do you feel any tingling or numbness or any kind of cramps?
Nope.
Any kind of blurry vision?
Nope.
Any weight loss?
Not that I notice.
How did your last visit go with the cardiologist?
Good.
It looks like they diagnosed you with sick sinus syndrome. Do you have any questions about this new diagnosis?
No, she explained everything to me. I'm planning to follow-up with her in the next two weeks.
Great. So it looks like your past medical history is the same? Nothing new other than the sick sinus syndrome.
So Mister J, where do you stay?
Oh, I stay at a care facilit. It's very near to your clinic. Have you heard about this place called South Valley Care Center?
Oh yes, I have heard of it.
How are you Mister James?
I have been better!
Oh, tell me what's going on with you?
I have this leg pain on my left side.
Hm, left leg pain?
Yeah.
Have you ever had an allergic reaction to drugs you've taken in the past?
More than once. I've reacted poorly to sulfa drugs, penicillin, and some mycins. I also think I'm allergic to contrast medium.
Hey, do you smoke cigarettes?
Yes I do smoke. Do you?
Nope. Are you planning on quitting?
No, I just smoke one pack per day, it's not bad.
Oh my God. No. It is bad. You should think about quitting.
Okay I will think about it.
Where do you work?
I work at local christmas tree farm.
Are you still working?
Retired some time ago.
What was your profession?
I used to work at a car repair shop called Champion Automotive Company.
Nice. How did you enjoy the work?
I liked it a lot, but there came a time where I knew it was the end of the road for me. I'm really enjoying retirement.
I bet. I have cousin who owns a car repair shop. He's almost always busy.
Yeah, it can be a lot sometimes.
Any smoking, drinking, or hard drugs?
I can confidently say no to each one.
Great to hear.
Do you have his full medical history?
Yes, I confirmed with his wife. He had a CABG done in ninety one. He has a history of radical prostate cancer for which he underwent a radical prostatectomy and nephrectomy.
Any additional surgeries?

Yes. He had lumbar surgery twice before. He suffered from lumbar stenosis many years ago in the sixties and seventies. He's actually due for another lumbar surgery with Doctor Y. He takes Percocet daily for his back pain.  He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.
I think I got it all down.
Do you have any history of major surgeries?
No. Nothing major.
Good morning, sir.
Good morning, doctor.
Before we begin, have you ever had surgery?
Yes, I had a vasectomy some time ago.
Okay, so let's go over your medications. I'd like you to take these to help your muscle spasms.
Sounds good.
I've prescribed eight hundred milligrams of Ibuprofen to be taken every eight hours as needed along with Tylenol number three every six hours as needed.
What does the number three stand for?
Tylenol number three is combined with Codeine.
Okay, I see.
And finally, I'm prescribing Methocarbamol seven fifty milligrams which needs to be taken four times a day for maximum relief. Do you have any questions for me?
No, I think you answered them all.
How are you doing today, sir?
Honestly, I'm pretty sick today. I've got a lot going on.
How long have you been feeling this way?
Well, it's been off and on for about a month now.
Has it been getting worse recently?
Yeah, it has over the last couple weeks.
What are your symptoms?
Well, I'm coughing up this yellow phlegm. It feels like everything is in my chest.
What medications have you been taking for this?
I've been taking Allegra D sometimes, but I'm almost out. I need a refill.
What other problems are you having?
My foot keeps breaking out.
Has this improved at all?
Well, it was for a while, but now it's really bad again.
Have you been diagnosed with any conditions before?
I had, um, tinea pedis before.
How was this treated?
They gave me Nizoral cream.
It has been getting warmer recently, I don't think that this isn't necessarily a coincidence that you're having these symptoms now.
Yeah, I work in the flint and it's really hot and humid down there.
What else are you dealing with, sir?
I have this wart on my right middle finger, are you able to freeze it off?
Have you ever done that before?
Yeah, you have done it before, and it went away.
If we've done it before, we can do it again.
Cool, can we do blood work, too? I want to check on my prostate.
Well, that's called P S A.
Can I have that done? I'm concerned. I am fifty after all.
Sure, we can check your cholesterol too. I know you have history of it being high.
You know, I've been working on that. I quit smoking for a while, but I got back into it.
That's good, it's really hard to quit.
Yeah, I tried chewing tobacco, but it's not the same.
Be sure to keep trying to quit smoking.
Hi, how's it going?
Not too bad, can't complain.
It looks like the weather's been warming up, which is nice.
Yeah, I can't wait to spend some time with my kids this afternoon.
Aw, how many kids do you have?
Two.
And are you single, dating, married?
I've been married to my wife for about ten years now.
Congratulations! That's a decade, my friend.
Hah, it sure is.
Are you from the area?
I was actually born in Oklahoma.
How long-
Moved up here in O seven.
Awesome. I moved here in O nine, so two years after you.
No way! How funny. Where from?
I'm originally from Kentucky. And I have to do the routine ask, but any drinking, smoking, or illicit drug use?
No to all of the above.
Got it.
Looks like the nurse came in and asked you everything. Ah, she has everything documented here, but I will ask one more time. So, tell me, where do you live?
Oh, it's a senior citizen house. They have many nursing aids there.
Do you smoke?
No.
Do you work?
Ah, right now I can't because of this disability, but I used to work as the security guard.

What brings you back to the clinic today, Miss? Patient: I came for a refill of my blood pressure medication. Doctor: It seems that Dr. Kumar followed with you the last time about your hypertension, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, hypothyroidism, allergic rhinitis and kidney stones. Have you noticed any changes or have you any concerns about these problems? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you had fever or chills, cough, congestion, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, chest pressure? Patient: No. Doctor: Super. Also, for our records, what age and race do you identify as? Patient: I am seventy-six years old and I identify you as a white woman.

I'm sorry. Well, you're only twenty-five years old, so let's hope it's the last of the worst. Let's see how we can help you. When did it start? Patient: Around eleven in the morning. Patient: Today? Patient: Um no yesterday. 30 July first. Doctor: 30 July first O 8. Did it happen suddenly? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have symptoms with it, such as blurred vision, sensitivity to light, dizziness, dizziness, or nausea? Patient: I am a blurred vision and dizziness. I can't write as well. It seems so bad. I'm naturally right hand but my writing looks like I'm trying with my left. Patient: How would you describe dizziness? Patient: As there are blind spots.

Hello, Miss. What is the reason for your visit today? Patient: I think I have warts on my back where the poop comes out. Doctor: I see. When did you start to notice them? Patient: I think three to four weeks ago. Doctor: Do you feel pain or discomfort? Patient: It's itching a little, but I haven't felt pain yet. Is it normal for a twenty-two years? Doctor: I'm going to have to take a look, but you're fine. Are there any other symptoms you know? Patient: No. Just warts and itching.

Do you take any counter medicine? Patient: No, only those that have been prescribed. Doctor: No alternative medicine, naturopathy or anything? Patient: No, only what is here in this prescription. Doctor: Okay let me take a look... so you have been prescribed Salmeterol Inhaler- Patient: Based on needs. Doctor: Okay and the other is Fluticasone Inhaler, which is- Patient: Which is a nasal inhaler. Doctor: Okay.
Hi, how are you? Patient: I burned my hand. Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry. Wow! Patient: Yes. Doctor: Is it just the right arm? Patient: Yes.

How is your asthma since you started using your inhaler again? Patient: Much better. I don't know why I didn't take it with me wherever I went. Doctor: It's important to wear it with you, especially during times when you are exercising or walking more than usual. Patient: Yes. I think I learned my lesson. Doctor: Besides asthma, do you have other medical problems?

Have you had any other surgery in the past? Patient: I got my appendix a few years ago. Doctor: Do you have any other problems, such as high blood pressure or heart disease? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have diabetes? Patient: No. Doctor: Are there problems with the lungs, thyroid, kidneys or bladder? Patient: No. Doctor: So how long did you hurt your lower back? Patient: About four or five years ago, when I was in a car accident. Doctor: What type of treatment was recommended? Patient: They do not recommend P T, and I did not really have an increase in back pain after the accident.
No.

What do you know about your medical history? Patient: My mother and father both had a heart disease. Well, my mother had complications of her heart disease and that's how she died. My father was only in his forty years when he died. Doctor: I'm so sorry to hear it. Patient: Thank you. I have two brothers, one of whom I don't talk much about. I don't know if he has any health problems. My other brother is healthy without problems. My two uncles on my mother's side had polio, I think. Doctor: Tell me more about your uncles with polio. They both had polio? Patient: One of them had to wear crutches because of the poor health of his leg deformans and the other had leg defects in one leg.

Can you tell me about all the diseases in your family? Patient: Of course, my brother has prostate cancer. Doctor: Ok, brother. Patient: My father has brain cancer. Doctor: OK, dad. Patient: Then on both sides of my family there are a lot of heart problems. Doctor: Ok. Patient: And my brother and sister both have diabetes. Doctor: OK. Patient: Yes, that's all.

Before I start, I just need to confirm some information about you. Patient: Hello, doctor. Absolutely, this is not a problem. Doctor: First, what age are you? Patient: I am 19 years old, sir. Doctor: Good, and your file says that you identify yourself as a Caucasian. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, sir, that's correct. Doctor: What seems to be a problem today, ma'am? Patient: I have this union on my foot for so long. Doctor: How long has this union been present? Patient: At this point, uh, I don't even remember how long it was. Doctor: Do you have any other conditions that I should be aware of? Patient: Actually, yes. I have a story of, um, Charcot Mary dental disease. Doctor: It's good to know, thank you. Patient: I would like to have surgery to cut this union, I can't take it anymore.
I hear someone has a birthday coming up, how old are you turning, ma'am?
I'll be ninety later this month, doctor.
You're here for a follow up not very long after your first visit. What seems to be the problem today?
Well, actually, my high blood pressure and right arm symptoms are basically gone.
Great, I saw your blood pressure reading for today, and it's much better. Are you taking the higher dose of Mavik we recommended?
No, I'm not taking that right now.
How did you tolerate the higher dose?
I didn't feel well at all, so I just went back to the old dose.
That was one M G per day, correct?
Yes, doctor. I do think I could have some white coat high blood pressure. Doctors' offices make me nervous.
That does happen. Here, try this sample of Tarka, please.
What is this for, doctor?
Well, since you're taking the Mavik plus verapamil, you can switch over to Tarka, which is the combined version of the two drugs.
I can't take these, doctor. They're too big.
Hello doctor, I'm her daughter. Just so you know, we check her blood pressure at home periodically and it's always similar to that reading.
Good, so back to that right arm, how is that doing today?
Well, that pain is basically gone now, I think it had to do with that muscle problem back in my right shoulder blade.
Did you have x rays taken today?
Yes, the tech brought me back right before you came in.
Good, I have the images right here.
What do they show, doctor?
Well, these x rays of the neck and right shoulder show some degenerative changes, and possibly some kind of rotator cuff injury.
What makes you think there's an injury?
Well, look right here. The humeral head is pretty high in the glenoid in the right shoulder, but do you have any pain here?
No, none.
Then we won't worry about it.
I am having this stomach pain though, doctor.
How has this pain developed and progressed recently?
Well, it's improved somewhat with me not taking Aleve anymore.
What medicines are you taking right now, then?
Right know, I'm just taking Tylenol as needed. That seems to be enough for me.
Do you think this could be acid reflux, or heartburn?
No, but I take Tums, um, three times a day, and Mylanta at night. Oh yeah, I have these sores in my mouth, can you take a look?
I see. How long have you worn dentures?
Oh I couldn't even tell you, it's been many, many years.
Do they come and go, the sores?
Yes, one will come, then it'll heal up, then another.
Okay, we'll keep an eye on it.
And doctor, since I've been taking the Lexapro, I have some tremors on basically my whole body, at least the upper body, like my torso and arms.
It's hard to tell if you have a tremor today, ma'am, but do you think the Lexapro is helping otherwise?
Yes, we think so.
Are you talking about drugs? Patient: No, I don't believe in drugs. Doctor: Oh really, let me check your list. Patient: Yes never. Doctor: Wow amazing.

She has a history of peptic ulcer disease and we think she may have had a stroke three or four years ago. I should check it out. Doctor: Let me see if I can find it in her files. Doctor: Does she see a neurologist? Guest_family: Um I'm not sure. I can call her son? Doctor: Yes, if you could know it would be great. Guest_family: She also has a memory loss a year or two ago. I think that's what medical history is all about.

How old are you? Patient: I'm forty-four years old. Doctor: Do you have the right hand or left hand? Patient: I have the right hand. Doctor: Was there a feeling like having needles and needles? Was there a weakness? Was there a change in your visual or mental condition? Were you able to walk? Patient: I was able to walk and there was no weakness or anything else you mentioned. Doctor: When did you start to notice these symptoms? Patient: There was nothing around Independence Day. It all started after that. At first, I felt that my right hand was very clumsy, and it was stiff enough. Then I noticed that I was leaning to the right when you were walking. It was strange.

You had heart surgery, didn't you? Patient: Yes, it's true. Doctor: Pacemaker? Patient: Yes, they did. Doctor: What else? What other surgeries? Patient: I had a hysterectomy. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Yes.

How old are you, young boy? Patient: I'm twenty-nine years old. Doctor: And you're hurting your right shoulder? Is that something new? Patient: Yes. It's true. Doctor: What were you doing when it happened? Patient: I think I was picking up a pile of cardboard, then I put it on the floor and twisted them on the right side. And sometimes I was throwing them a little as well. Doctor: Okay, and how far you were lifting them or thinking? Patient: Here, up to the waist level. Doctor: OK. Patient: I've heard a pop and since then there's pain in this area. I can't lift large objects.

When did nausea and vomiting begin? Patient: About a few hours ago. I can't seem to stomach anything. Doctor: How many episodes of vomiting have you had? Patient: At least four. Doctor: Any abdominal pain, fever, chill, or other symptoms? Patient: Just nausea and vomiting.

Hello, ma'am. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: Is this your assistant, madam? Patient: Yes, she helps me all day. Doctor: Great, do you have your food diary sheets? Patient: Yes, can you give her, please? Doctor: Thank you. What are you doing for the exercise? Patient: Um, right now, I'm walking in the mall to get my steps in every day.
Is he currently taking medication? Guest_family: No.

Hello, sir. I see that your last visit took place on July two thousand. What was the reason for this visit? Patient: My asthma was getting up, and it seemed to me that I couldn't breathe. Doctor: Do you have a history of asthma? Patient: Not that I know, but I know I still have this very bad cough where I coughed a bad phlegm. Doctor: I see. I look at your report and he says you have a history of pneumonia.

Do you know any medical traits in your family? Patient: No, everyone in my family is healthy. I am not aware of any medical problems. Doctor: Are you sexually active? Patient: Yes, I am with my boyfriend. Doctor: Do you take drugs, alcohol or smoke? Patient: No, none of them.

When did these episodes take place? Patient: About a year ago. Doctor: Did you follow your previous doctor? Patient: Yes, my old doctor knows it. Doctor: All right. Let's see. Have you checked your own blood pressure accordingly? Patient: No really. Doctor: It seems that your blood pressure was normal today, which is a good sign. Patient: Great. Doctor: Hm any allergies to medication? Patient: None of what I know. Doctor: And it seems that you have gained about fourteen pounds since last year. Any new changes in diet or stress? Patient: I lost my job last January and he took a big tribute. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. How did you survive? Patient: I do better now but I need to look at what I eat. I tend to eat much more when I'm stressed.
Are you allergic to anything? Patient: Yes, I am allergic to penicillin. Doctor: Any other medicines you may be allergic to? Patient: No, that's all. Doctor: OK.
What brought them today? Doctor: Renal impairment, perhaps due to dehydration or diabetic nephropathy.
Doc, what are you going to diagnose me? Doctor: We're looking at exposure to blood-borne pathogens secondary to the syringe. Patient: Yes, I was also thinking about contamination.
She was in a car accident, wasn't she? Doctor: Correct. About two days ago. I think it was a head on the collision.
No, no allergies to me.

What brought you here? How can I help you? Patient: I was out fishing this weekend, I think I got into a bit of poison ivy and I have these rashes all over my chest, legs, arms and also some are on my back. Doctor: You seem so confident that it's poison ivy came before? Patient: Oh yes, it's happened several times before. It usually takes time to recover. The last time I was there, Dr. Blackman gave me an injection of steroids. Doctor: Okay, let me check my records. Patient: I took a little more Benadryl. Plus, I'm applying cortisone cream on rashes.
You mentioned that cancer is in your family. What type of cancer? Patient: Skin cancer. Doctor: Any other health problems in the family? Patient: high blood pressure.

Hi, what brings you here today? Patient: I feel this mass on the top of my chest. Doctor: Both sides? Patient: No, only on the left side. Doctor: Do you feel deeply inside or on the outside side? Patient: Only on the outside side.

I understand you're new to the clinic. Welcome. Patient: Yes, I'm new here. I've been living in Arizona for four years. I'm from Maine. That's where I grew up and most of my family still lives. Doctor: In what line of work are you? Patient: I'm a housewife. I used to clean the house, a while ago. Doctor: Do you have children? Patient: I have two children but only one of them is still with us. My eldest son died from complications of ulcerative colitis three years ago. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that!

person: I'm just trying to adjust the stretcher. Doctor
sentence: Do you want help? Patient: No, thank you. I think I have it. Doctor: How are you? Patient: Good, but I have this weird size in my chest. Doctor: When did you notice it for the first time? Patient: It was there for a while. I would say almost half a year. Doctor: Have you seen anyone for that? Patient: No, not until now. Doctor: Does this cause you pain? And has it changed from size to everything? Patient: Not really. It's just noticeable when I pass my fingers on. Doctor: Have you spotted swelling or redness in the area? Patient: No. Doctor: I see. Ok. Let me take a look and then I'll take you down the room to get an X-ray so we can see what's going on.

I'm going to ask you a few regular questions, okay? Patient: Of course. Doctor: Any pain in urine? Patient: No. Doctor: Any fever or chills? Patient: None of them. Doctor: Did you notice any blood during urine? Patient: No. I'm fleeing, especially when I change my positions as if I sat down to stand up so I feel that there's a certain involuntary urination. It's more like a craving. I'm charging data as every one hour in the morning, especially when I take this Lasix. Doctor: Do you apply a lot of force to the urine? Patient: No. Doctor: How does this flow? Do you feel nothing. Doctor: Any leak in the night doesn't take place. Patient: No.

Have you lost weight? Patient: No, I don't have, you can ask my daughter. Doctor: How about something like fever, nausea, vomiting, pain? Pattor: No. Doctor: And as we discussed you have problems talking and understanding. Pattor: Yes. Doctor: And you get urine infections too? Pattor: Yes. Doctor: And as discussed, your drainage is similar to past episodes when you had such an infection? Pattor: Yes.

Do you use tobacco products? Cigarettes, chewing tobacco or vaping? Patient: I used to smoke one pack a day. I stopped this terrible habit in nineteen ninety-five. Doctor: Do you work? Patient: I am retired. Doctor: Wonderful. Is your husband retired with you? Patient: Yes. We are both. I can't imagine working full-time at seventy-six years old.

So I see that you were eighty-eight years old yesterday, happy birthday! Patient: Thank you! Doctor: And you are referred by Doctor X, he is your principal doctor, isn't he? Patient: Yes! I also see Doctor Y for my leukemia. Doctor: Hm he mentioned that it is chronic lymphocyte leukemia. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And you also see Doctor Z for your heart problems. Patient: That's right. Doctor: So tell me what's going on with you? Patient: For a week, I've been having this increase in breathlessness and having difficulty breathing for a few nights during sleep. Doctor: OK. Patient: And this morning, I had difficulty catching my breath.
Ready to go home? Patient: I can't wait. Doctor: Of course. I can understand. Patient: Bye Doctor. Doctor: Yes. See you soon.

person: I felt tired and weak. Doctor
sentence: How long did you start this? Patient: He is in class for six to eight weeks. Doctor: I see. Did you experience any other symptoms? Patient: I didn't, but it might not be related. I had pneumonia ten days before all this started. Doctor: Interesting. Did you take a medicine for that? Patient: You have, but I don't know how to pronounce it. I wrote it to you to read. Here. Doctor: I see you took a full course of amoxicillin, right? Patient: Yes, it's right. Doctor: How did you feel after you finished the antibiotics you fell? Patient: Terrible. I felt unable to control my body, but I felt even more tired and weak.
Have you had any diseases in the past? Patient: No. Doctor: Something worth mentioning? Patient: No. Doctor: Of course? Patient: Yes.

I hit you a wall three days ago. Doctor: What's the hand? Patient: It's my right hand. Doctor: Is it your dominant hand? Patient: Unfortunately, yes, it is. Doctor: Where does it hurt? Patient: Hum, it's right here outside my hand. Doctor: What kind of treatment do you have? Patient: I went to ED, and they pushed some joints into my hand, and they put me in a splint, so I've worn it since. Doctor: How is your pain today? Patient: Compared to its beginning, it's much better today. Doctor: How would you describe your pain today? Patient: Today, I would say it's the minimal pain. Doctor: Well, do you have numbness or tingling today? Patient: No, fortunately not.

He is my colleague, Dr Mason, and he will help me today and take notes. Guest_clinician: Hello. Patient: Hello. Doctor: Does he agree with you if he can join us? Patient: Of course, no problem. Doctor: Great, thank you Doctor: Doctor: Clinician: Of course. Doctor: Patient looks well developed and well fed. He is alert with no acute distress. Guest_clinician: Understood. Doctor: Patient has had a head injury, but he is fully conscious. G C S is fifty and not toxic. Guest_clinician: OK.
Someone who is sick in your family? Patient: No. Doctor: How about someone who has the same troubles? Patient: No, I don't know. Doctor: Okay, don't worry.
How did the patient do the activity test? Guest_clinician: Patient was good. I advised him to continue his normal activities as long as he feels well.

How old was he when he was assessed for the first time in the other hospital? Guest_family: He was seven years old. Doctor: What hospital was he still? Guest_family: It was at U I H C. Doctor: What exactly happened? Guest_family: He was doing all right as seven months before his evaluation, then he started to have some dizziness, which as remained for several seconds at a minute. They were not regular, but he was able to continue his activity immediately after these dizziness. Doctor: Has the intensity changed? Guest_family: Oh yes. This, these spells, they became more frequent, and they were now for longer periods.
Do you have major diseases in the family like diabetes or high B P? Patient: No nothing. No major diseases. Doctor: OK. Patient: Yes.

Hello, sir. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: I just need some basic information before starting today. Patient: Well, have you ever had surgery, sir? Patient: Yes, actually, I had it on my knee, a nose job, and, uh, a carotid sinus surgery.

You still work? Patient: No, I'm retired now. I was working for the United States postal service as an electronic technician, but you retired a year earlier because of my disability. Doctor: Ah ok. And who is in your family? Patient: Well, I'm staying with my wife and daughter in our apartment. Doctor: Ok. You smoke? Patient: No. Doctor: What would you say about alcohol? Patient: I drink sometimes, it's too rare, but after my symptoms have declared that I have completely stopped. Doctor: Any use of recreational or illegal drugs? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you traveled anywhere recently? Patient: No, it's really been a long time since I travelled anywhere.

This is my colleague Dr. White, and she will take the notes. Is it good if she joins us? Patient: Oh sure, no problem. Doctor: Thank you. Guest_clinician: Hello, I'm Dr. White, happy to meet you. Patient: Nice to meet you too. Doctor: Ok, can you breathe in and out for me? Patient: OK. Doctor: OK breath sounds are clear. Lung function is good. Symmetric elevation and fall into the chest as the patient breathes. I'm going to palpate your chest, it's just a routine exam. Patient: Of course. Doctor: Doctor White can you make a note, no egophonic or tactile fremus. Guest_clinician: Of course.

Where do you live? Patient: I live on a board of directors and care. It's a nice little care home with a few very nice and supportive people. It's right next to the Safeway on Village Drive. Doctor: Nice. It seems you like living there. Patient: Oh yes. I feel very relaxed there. Doctor: Did you drink alcohol in any way? Patient: No sir. Doctor: Any tobacco use? Patient: Never in my life. Doctor: Have you ever tried some kind of illicit drugs?

Have you had any operations in the past? Patient: Actually, yes, I had my gallbladder removed in nineteen ninety-two. Doctor: Great, other operations? Think a little further? Patient: Oh yes, I had my appendix taken out in nineteen eighty-eight.
How do you feel now after treatment? Patient: I feel fairly fair, slowly improving. Doctor: Ok? Patient: Ok.

Sir? Can you hear me? Are you Mr. Smith's wife? Guest_family: Yes. I am his wife. Doctor: How old is he? Can you tell me a little how your husband's condition has reached this point? His level of consciousness is worrying. Guest_family: He is eighty-five years old. He took all the Xanax MG. He is supposed to take only a twenty-five MG from Xanax. That's why he is like this. Doctor: It seems that your husband was admitted to the emergency room the day before. How did he get these injuries to his face? Guest_family: He fell from his wheelchair. Doctor: Adult protection services said they found your husband in the barley conscious house. How long was he so? Guest_family: All day long. Doctor: Do you know what other medicines your husband took other than Xanax? Guest_family: He didn't take his regular medication for two days.

How do you feel? Does Wellbutrin keep your mood stabilized? Patient: I feel good. Wellbutrin works well for me. Doctor: It is important not to use alcohol or recreational drugs while taking Wellbutrin. Patient: I do not drink or take drugs.

Tell me a little about your family history. Patient: My father and grandfather both had type 2 diabetes. My son is fighting type 1 diabetes. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear it. Does anyone in your family have heart problems? Patient: No. Doctor: And cancer? Patient: Two of my cousins had breast cancer.

Where do you work, miss? Patient: Well, you see, I am a civil engineer. At the moment, because of a pandemic like everyone else I work from home. Doctor: You work full time or does your disability affect that? Patient: No, I can only work half of the time. This disability does not leave me working full time.
Do you know any familiar illnesses in your family? Patient: You mean like B P, high sugar? Doctor: Yes. Patient: No, no one in my family has anything like that. Doctor: Great.
Have you had any anxiety attacks lately? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you experienced depression or mood change problems? Patient: No. Doctor: No phobia? Patient: No, not really. Doctor: Ok.
Do you have a history of mental illness or psychological illness? Patient: No.

Hello sir. How are you doing today? You still look a little uncomfortable. Is there still pain? Patient: Yes. Still a good amount of pain. I didn't take my pain medication this morning. I'm not sure if it will make a huge difference. Doctor: Maybe that's why you're still suffering. How do you move? Can you get out of the house and move? Patient: Yes. I'm very happy to be able to do my daily activities. I can get up with minimal help and do many activities out of the house. I think I'm gaining muscle from more and more. Doctor: How's the exercise program at home? Patient: I like pool therapy. I really feel like it helps. I do exercises at home sometimes twice a day. I really want to get back to normal.
Have you had any surgery in the past? Patient: Yes, I had a knee surgery. Doctor: What knee? Patient: Yes.

Are you sexually active? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How many partners do you have? Patient: One. Doctor: Is it a monogamous relationship? Patient: Yes. Doctor: What sex are you partners? Patient: It's a man. We've been together for three years.
I remember you mentioned that you had done an operation in the past. Patient: I had a biopsy of the lymph nodes in September of O Three. Doctor: Did he return negative? Patient: Fortunately, yes.

It seems that you have a long medical history. Patient: I blame my heart. It caused me the most trouble. I have undergone a coronary bypass in twenty ten with an angioplasty. Doctor: I am sorry that your heart caused you so much trouble. I am glad that you are here with us today and that you have taken the right steps to keep you healthy. Patient: Oh, and I forgot to mention that I had prostate biopsies in the past. Doctor: When did you do biopsies? Patient: Last year. Doctor: Did they come back negative? Patient: Yes, fortunately. I guess my prostate is not as embarrassing as my heart. Doctor: I understand.

Do you have any medical problems? Patient: Let's see. I have diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol and osteoporosis. Doctor: And surgery? Patient: Several. Doctor: Which ones? Patient: I brought out my tonsils when I was a child. I also had my uterus removed with my ovaries and fallopian tubes. The list continues. I had my appendix removed and two or three of my parathyroids removed. Although some of my parathyroids were removed, I still have high levels of calcium borderline according to my endocrinologist. Doctor: Did you experience complications during or after the operation? Patient: No. I forgot to mention that I had two carpel tunnel exits too.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My mother died from the complications of Huntington's disease. She was diagnosed and had undergone treatment at U I H C. My grandmother and two of my aunts also died from Huntington. Doctor: I am sorry. Do you have any brothers and sisters? Patient: Yes! I have a sister. She is 38 years old. She has a lot of metal problems. She tried to commit suicide twice. Doctor: Are you close to her? Patient: No. Not really. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have any children? Patient: Yes. We have two adopted children.

Medical problems on your mother's or father's side? Patient: My father has lupus and his brother has Addison's disease. Hypertension is also in the family. Doctor: Is your father treated for lupus? Patient: Yes, he follows his rheumatologist fairly regularly.

I'm going to do a quick exam on you. Patient: What kind of exam? Doctor: I'm just checking the lymph nodes. Every time there's an infection, these guys are the first to be noticed with the swelling. Doctor: Okay, so we'll first check your neck area. It looks good. I don't feel any inflamed lymph nodes. Your armpits also seem good and the last place to check is your groin area. It's all good. No sign of infection.
What are the medicines you are on? Patient: I am on pain pills. Doctor: Do you know their names? Patient: Yes. Oxycontin and Vicodin. Doctor: Ok it helps.

I'm looking at the list of your medications. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All I can see is Risperdal and Invega. Patient: I think it's correct. Doctor: Don't you take anything else? Patient: Yes, I'm taking multivitamins, but should I mention it? Doctor: Yes, you should. We need to know everything. Patient: Okay.

Hello, ma'am. Patient: Oh, hello, doctor. Doctor: Please tell me about your life situation. Patient: Well, now I live at home with my children and my father. Doctor: I see here that you are not able to climb the stairs well, can you tell me more about it? Patient: Yes, I can't use the stairs without holding the rail all the time. Doctor: holding the rail makes it easier to navigate the stairs? Patient: Yes, but I always move very slowly. Doctor: I see. You smoke? Patient: Yes, I smoke about a package at a package and a half day. Doctor: And the exercise? You work? Patient: No, I don't work regularly, I've never been good.

My doctor has done a blood test. My potassium is high. He recommended me to meet you. Doctor: Okay. I haven't received the blood report yet. I'm waiting for your doctor's office to send it to me. Is it only your potassium that is raised? Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
He was going to buy me a surprise but met this car accident. Doctor: I'm sorry! He has multiple traumas due to the accident, and he will need care after. Guest_family: Yeah.

What is the situation of your family at home? Guest_family: Um, he lives at home with me, and his father. Doctor: Can I assume that you are his biological parents? Guest_family: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Super, does he have siblings? Guest_family: No, at the moment, he's a unique child. Doctor: What's his grade? Guest_family: He's in third year. Doctor: Super, and he's fine at school? Guest_family: Yes, he's fine.

Hello, with which sex do you identify? Patient: Thank you for asking, I identify as a woman. Doctor: Thank you. Do you know chronic diseases? Patient: No, but can you give me some examples of what you mean? Doctor: Well, high blood pressure, osteoarthritis, diabetes, depression, something like that ring bells? Patient: Oh, no, I have nothing like that.

Do you have any major medical problems that I should know? Patient: What, like cancer? Doctor: It doesn't need to be so serious, but is there something you are taking medication for? Patient: Oh, I have allergies and asthma.
