Can you tell me anything about your mother and father? Like all the diseases they had? Patient: Of course, my father died of a heart attack when he was sixty-five years old and my mother died of a stroke when she was seventy years old.
Does anyone in your family suffer from health problems? Patient: No one comes to mind. Doctor: Great.
Tell me, what's going on? Guest_family: She complains of weakness on the right side of her face. Patient: And I feel that the right side is collapsing. Doctor: Okay, let me look.

My file says you're eighty-three years old, is that right, madam? Patient: Yes doctor, that's right, I just had my birthday. Doctor: Happy late birthday! How have you been doing since your last visit? Patient: Well, my cancer hasn't needed phlebotomy for several months now, which is good. Doctor: It's great, you've been treated for polycythemia vera, that's right? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: I also see that you're not attending today, which is so great. Patient: Yes, having some independence is nice.

So, do you have a family history of cancer? Patient: Well, yes, but I don't remember who had what kind. Doctor: Yet, it's useful, thank you. What about heart disease? Patient: That too, there are some history of heart disease, but I don't remember who.
As far as you know, are there any major health problems you know? Patient: What do you mean by that? Doctor: Is cancer, or arthritis, familiar? Patient: Oh, um, nothing like that.

Do you have a medical history that we should be aware of? Patient: I have type two diabetes. My numbers are still high. Doctor: Okay, something else? Patient: I also have a high cholesterol level. Doctor: Ok.

Hello. How do you feel today? Patient: Great. I'm just here for my annual physics. Doctor: Oh, good. I see that your medical past is missing. Do you know, by chance, if you had any health problems before? Patient: Uhm. Let me check my notes on my phone. I knew that this question would come up, but I always forget. Oh, perfect. You can look at them. Doctor: Thank you. I just want to check the information with you. You had asthma, nasal inflammation, and some abnormal growth on your neck, right? Patient: If it's there, then it's true. I don't remember that kind of thing.

How's the baby? Guest_family: She's fine. Doctor: How long was your pregnancy? Guest_family: Thirty-six weeks. Doctor: Was your delivery normal or C? Guest_family: It was a C section. Doctor: How much did she weigh? Guest_family: She had eight pounds and three ounces. Doctor: Tell me what the problem is? Guest_family: Yes, she has a history of seizures. It looks like she's having stomach pain and vomiting. Doctor: What else have you noticed? Guest_family: It looks like she's having rashes. There's vomiting for sure.

What medicines are you taking at the moment? Patient: I take Advair and Allegra. Doctor: Okay, does that help you? Patient: I don't know, I'm not sure that Allegra helps. But I take them regularly. Doctor: But is that better than Claritin? Patient: Yes, I think so. Doctor: Okay, that's good. Patient: Should I continue?
If someone was sick in their family? Patient: Person. Doctor: How about the illnesses that are running in your family? Patient: No, everyone is healthy.
Hi again! How has your acne been since you started spironolactone? Patient: It has improved. Doctor: Have you experienced an increase in thirst, mood changes or unusual fatigue? Patient: No.

Well, I don't think you need restrictions like you're okay. I want to make sure you have a chair and a bed monitor since you have a history of multiple falls. They can help detect falls. Patient: I don't want that, I'm going to manage.
Do you know when the last time you had a tetanus vaccine was? Patient: No, I don't remember.

Hello! How are you today? Patient: Hello! I am good. Doctor: Welcome! Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Let's start with a little social history. Are you a consumer of tobacco or alcohol? Patient: No. Doctor: Are you married? Do you have children? Patient: I am not married but I have a son of two years old. Doctor: You currently see a gynaecologist? Patient: Yes. She is in Bartow. Doctor: Super.
Tell me about your family medical history. Patient: My family is healthy. I don't know any health problems.

Welcome. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Do you smoke? Patient: No, I don't smoke. Smoking is disgusting. Doctor: I agree. Do you drink alcohol? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How much do you drink a day or a week? Patient: When I leave work usually have a glass of wine.
The nurse applied an antibiotic ointment and bandage to your foot. She reviewed how to change the bandage at home? Patient: Yes.

Hello. Before you start, I need you to confirm some information for me. Patient: What kind of information? Doctor: About your family. Do you know if you have certain medical conditions that run in your family? Patient: No. My family is very healthy.

What if you had respiratory problems or asthma? Patient: Actually, I have a history of asthma. Doctor: Oh ok, and was it serious or mild? Patient: Well, it was not serious but still remarkable. Doctor: Hm, OK. Nothing else? Patient: Yes, I also had trouble dealing with a serious acne problem. Doctor: I understood.

How's she doing? Guest_family: She's had better days. Doctor: Aw and why? Guest_family: She's been really crowded lately. Sniffer a lot more, too. She's eleven years old and I think it's strange that she's snoring so much. I took her to see the allergenist and he said that it's not her allergies so we stopped giving her Allegra. Doctor: Is she snoring at night? Guest_family: No, not really. Doctor: Hm. Guest_family: And while we're here, I also wanted you to look at her toe. The good big toe seems a little red to me. The skin around her has peeled for a week and a half. Doctor: Lemme looks. Have you applied anything to the area?
Why do you hold your face? Patient: Ah! Have pain in my tooth. Doctor: Oh, how bad is it? Patient: Oh, terribly bad. Doctor: I am so sorry.

Have you ever had similar symptoms? Patient: Not ever like this. Doctor: Other complaints you have had in the past? Patient: Just some knee pain problems. Doctor: Okay, so chronic knee pain. Patient: Yes.

Can you tell me about a cancer in your family? Patient: Yes, my sister has ovarian cancer, and my father has liver cancer. Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry. Patient: It's okay. Doctor: No heart disease? Patient: My mother and my father both have heart disease. My father is diabetic too.

Can you tell me what problems you've had in the past. Or what medical problems are going on? Patient: You mean my heart problem and things? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay, I've had hypertension and kidney problems for many years. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I get frequent urinary infections. Doctor: Your urine creatinine is normal. Patient: Okay. I also have severe aortic stenosis.
Does anyone else in your family have an aneurysm problem? Patient: Well, my grandmother had it.

What's wrong with your honey back? Patient: Oh, it all started with a little button on the buttocks. I soaked it at home with hot water and stuff, but it didn't improve. I hope it wasn't cancer. I'm only twenty-four years old. Doctor: Okay, what exactly are you experiencing? Patient: I hurt. Doctor: So you came to the hospital first and they did an I & D in E D? Patient: Yes I was admitted to hospital with high blood sugars. My Afro-American father was so scared. Doctor: Ok sugars high. Do you know the number?

Hello! I have the results of your ultrasound. You have kidney stones in the ureter near the bladder. Patient: Oh no. Doctor: This explains the pain you have had on the left side. You still have nausea and vomiting? Patient: Yes, I have been. Doctor: I would like to set you up with a consultation with a surgeon. Patient: Ok.
No.

Your daughter had an exposure to ant bait but we are not sure if she actually ingested any of it. Poison Control confirmed that even though she ingested the small amount with which she was found, it is probably non-toxic. Do you have any questions? Guest_family: No.

Hello, sir. How are you today? Patient: I'm fine. I'm here for a check-up since I feel a little dizzying lately. Doctor: It's not good. How long is it going? Patient: A few months. It happened to my sister too. I think she's still dealing with it. Doctor: Is there any other family medical history I should know? Migraines or cancer? Patient: No. Not that I know. The rest of my family seems healthy enough.
Do you know anyone in your family who had cancer? Patient: No one I know.

Okay, your blood test is back and the cardiac enzyme we were looking for is negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Your blood urea nitrogen level, also known as B U N, is within normal limits and hydrogen is stable. Creatinine is also within normal limits. Patient: Super!
Are you taking medication? Patient: No, don't take medication.
Hi, how are you doing today?
I've been better. Thank you.
So, you are here for your follow up right? Remind me how often are you coming here?
That's right. I'm coming around between a month or two.
Yeah, it's every four to eight weeks.
I'm not taking any medicine now. I just wanted to let you know.

Yeah, I can see it in your record. It says that you are off of all the immunosuppression. So, just let me check. It says here that you do have mild chronic G V H D. It is not that bad that I should be worried about any therapy or anything else. How long ago did you get that transplant?

I think it was around four and a half years ago. I'm feeling much better after that. I do have complaints of blood in my stool. But after you sent me to that doctor, that gastro doctor, I feel good. I know they said that they removed something, but I'm not sure, but after that it has been improved a lot.

Okay, let me see in my chart. You had some rectal bleeding issues because of which I referred you to the gastroenterologist. A complete endoscopy was performed, which was both on the upper and the lower side. There was no evidence of ulcers or any other abnormality. That's  good news, right?
Yeah, I agree. That was a relief.
They did find some polyps and they removed it. They turned out to be benign, so nothing to worry about there.
Yeah, I remember this said they removed something, but I forgot the name.
Is there any other issue that I can help you with?

I don't know. I feel a lot of fatigue and like I'm not able to do things like I used to do before. I get tired very easily. I don't know if it is related to something or not, but things have been weird. I'm not able to do even the minor things like I lift two boxes and I'm done for the day. Is it something that I should be worried about?
It looks like you have a mild iron deficiency. I will work on that with you, don't worry.
Do you feel pain? Patient: No, I feel good. Doctor: Are there any other medical problems that should concern us? Patient: No, I feel young again. I am able to do all my activities.

I understand, before starting, what age are you? Patient: I am seventy-seven years old. Doctor: With what race and sex do you identify? Patient: I am an African-American woman. Doctor: What causes you pain today? Patient: I have had this union on my foot as long as I remember. Doctor: Is the pain getting worse? Patient: Yes, it is so painful, I have tried to avoid the operation for so long, but I want this union to disappear. Doctor: How did you manage this union in the past? Patient: I used anti-inflammatory, rested, changed my activities, I did everything, but this pain gets worse.
Do you have problems with diabetes or blood pressure? Patient: Yes, I have hypertension but not diabetes.

How do you deal with your pain now? Patient: Oh no, I have no problem with my pain. Today, I am here for another cause. I have this weakness all around my left side, especially in my arm. I feel like I can't lift something like a glass of water. It's hard for me to lift it. I can't walk properly, not to mention the balance and everything else. It's just that my whole left side seems weak.

Have you ever had any medical problems, sir? Patient: I have diabetes. Also, I was overweight enough. Doctor: Do you take any medicines for that? Patient: Yes, I was still taking something called Zyprexa, but I stopped it after my last regular weight check. Also, I never took anything for diabetes. I also have chronic bronchitis for... I don't know... many years. Doctor: You smoke? Patient: Oh yes, I'm a smoker. Doctor: How many cigarettes do you take in a day? Patient: Maybe up to sixty a day.

Let's talk about your ears. Any continuous noise of ringing or beating that you can hear? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: Any hearing problems? Patient: Hum, no. Doctor: Any dizziness or feeling of rotation? Patient: No.

Hello, ma'am. You are eighty-two years old, is that right? Patient: Hello, doctor. Yes, that's right. Doctor: Good, and just another piece of background information, with which hand do you write? Patient: I use my right hand for everything. Doctor: Well, then what seems to be the problem today? Patient: Doctor, I have had years of pain in this shoulder. Doctor: What kind of treatments have you had? Patient: Well, uh, I have had anti-inflammatory, and rested, and none of this has helped so far. Doctor: Can I assume that pain affects your daily life? Patient: Yes, it is sure. Pain is unbearable now.

Have you ever had surgery? Patient: What, like a joint replacement? Doctor: Well, whatever it is, joint replacements, removal of the appendix, or sections C? Patient: Yes, I had appendectomy and hysterectomy, actually.

Of course, we can treat them all. What seems to be the problem today? Doctor: I have a pain in my right shoulder. Doctor: Can you remember a wound in this shoulder? Patient: No, not that I remember. Doctor: What makes your symptoms worse? Patient: It hurts when I move my shoulder. Doctor: Do you have a weakness, numbness or tingling? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: OK, back to diabetes, how did it progress? Patient: Well, I can only check it in the morning, and it's usually less than a hundred. Doctor: Did you check your blood sugar two hours after meals? Patient: No, Doctor, I didn't do anything?
What are your family medical history? Patient: None, I know.

person: I want to make sure everything is in his file. Guest_family
sentence: Of course. I'm going to start with his surgeries. If I remember correctly, he underwent back surgery, some knee surgery, and coronary artery surgery by bypass surgery with angioplasty. Doctor: I see. When did he do this? Guest_family: I have to check, but I know he underwent back surgery in O 9. He was recently diagnosed with B P H potentially related to cancer. That's B P H, right? Or is it B H P? Doctor: If it's his prostate, then B P H is correct. Guest_family: Oh, he has high levels of P S A, too. I think it's related to prostate. Doctor: Is he currently experiencing symptoms? Guest_family: He was complaining about pain earlier.

How long have you been living with diabetes, sir? Patient: Oh, it's been about thirty-five years now. Doctor: How long have you been taking insulin for this? Patient: Well, um, I've been taking insulin for about twenty years now. Doctor: Do you have any major medical problems I should know? Patient: Yes, um, prostate cancer. Doctor: How have you been treated for this? Patient: I had radiation.

So what are the stomach symptoms you feel? Patient: I feel an intense burn in my throat. Doctor: When do you feel that? Pattor: It really hurts after eating food, especially junk food. Doctor: It's quite consistent with reflux disease. Pattor: Ah, yes. Doctor: I have the results of your survey as well, let's discuss it. Pattor: Absolutely, please, what does it show. Doctor: According to your answers, it seems that you also have depression.
Trouble swallowing? Patient: No. Doctor: Nausea, vomiting or blood in your vomit? Patient: No, no vomit at all. No problem there. Doctor: All right, stomach pain? Patient: No. Doctor: All right.
Hello, ma'am. How do you feel today? Patient: I am sad and depressed. Doctor: I am sorry to hear it. Why do you feel like this? Patient: My cancer has returned.
What's going on with you? What brings you here today? Patient: I've had loose watery stools for more than two weeks now. I feel very lethargic. I also have pain in my stomach.
Are you allergic to anything? Patient: No.

Are you a smoker? Patient: I used to smoke. I stopped in nineteen sixty-eight. Doctor: Excellent! Have you weighed your self recently? Patient: I weighed myself this morning. I am one hundred eighty-three pounds. Doctor: And how many are you? Patient: I had five feet ten but I think I have narrowed. Doctor: It is certainly a possibility.
Are you smoking? Patient: No, I've never smoked in my whole life.

I had seizures, but they stopped now. Doctor: Was there a cause of seizures? Patient: About seven years ago I had a traumatic accident. They told me that I had bleeding in the brain. After the accident, I was left with this weakness on my right side. Doctor: What part of your body is affected by weakness? Patient: My arm, my hand and my face. Doctor: Do you have any other health problems? Patient: My liver falls. It is because of all the alcohol I have consumed over the years.

What is the race you identify as? Patient: White. Doctor: Are you okay? You have a headache? Patient: No, I have a very bad migraine. Doctor: Okay, can you indicate where you feel it most? Patient: Here, since Monday. Doctor: Agree for most of the right frontal side and it's been forty-eight hours now? Patient: Yes, I feel a lot of pressure. Doctor: I can understand the discomfort. Is it continuous or agitated? Patient: He is agitated. Doctor: On the scale of one to ten, ten being the worst, how would you judge it? Patient: Nine or more. Doctor: Have you ever experienced similar symptoms in the past? Patient: No I didn't. Doctor: Have you hit your head buy a chance? Patient: No. Doctor: Can you tell me if you have fever or chills, congestion, cold cough as symptoms? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you hit your head?
Has the patient signed an order not to revive? Guest_family: Yes, she has. Doctor: Does she have a medical agent or a permanent proxy? Guest_family: Yes, she has both.

I had a lot of cough and shortness of breath even when walking from room to room. All the time I felt asleep, tired, or confused. Doctor: How is it now? Patient: It's better. Doctor: What else? Patient: I was also diagnosed with pneumonia; I was on a journey and there they found it. He also improved a lot now, but the doctor said to keep on taking oxygen for a while. Doctor: Oh wow! Patient: With everything going on, I felt weak and tired and it seems that I lost all my strength and muscles. Patient: I also felt very unstable and I had a fall. I didn't call for help but now I think I should have called someone. Everyone, including my family and nurses, tell me all the time to ask for help.
Were there any medical problems in the past? Patient: Oh, I have a list. I have asthma and sinus problems. I also had urticaria at some point and psoriasis.

You use tobacco products, alcohol or recreational drugs, Mademoiselle? Patient: I have a drink from time to time. Doctor: How many drinks do you drink in a week? Patient: I don't even drink so often. I probably drink one drink a month. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: I was engaged but this is no longer the case. It's a long story. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear it. What are you doing for work? Patient: I'm a metal grinder.

Now that you are eighteen years old, I have a great question to ask you. You smoke? Patient: Never, never. Doctor: That's what I like to hear. You have a good head on your shoulders, buddy. Patient: Thank you. I would like to think so, too. I have some friends who smoke grass, but stay away from tobacco.
Have you ever been diagnosed with a disease? Patient: No, I don't have a disease. Doctor: How about problems with B P, thyroid, diabetes? Patient: No.
A history of drug or alcohol use? Doctor: He was a former smoker and tested positive for cocaine during his last visit in January O eight.

I just wanted to check a few things quickly, let's go together? Patient: Of course. Doctor: Any cardiac condition like heart failure or something? Patient: No. Doctor: Any cardiac catheterization? Patient: Hum, no. Doctor: Any history of irregular chest pain, palpitations or heartbeat? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have high blood pressure? Patient: No. Doctor: Any history of high cholesterol? Patient: No. Doctor: Any excessive or abnormal sweating? Patient: Not really, no. Doctor: Any recent stress test or heart test? Patient: No. Doctor: Ok, thank you for answering these questions. Patient: No problem.

Ha, I will take this as a positive answer then. I have my resident here with me, Dr Helm, she will represent your case today. Guest_clinician: Hello. Patient: Hello Dr Helm. Patient: Doctor Helm. Patient: Doctor Helm. Patient: The patient is a sixty-year-old woman. She received a diagnosis of lung cancer not small cells step one A in the upper right lobe. She was treated with CyberKnife and treatment was completed a month ago. This is her first visit after CyberKnife treatment. Doctor: Thank you Dr Helm. So, Miss Sherry, how are you doing after treatment? Patient: I feel sick. Doctor: How would you define it if you are mild, moderate or severe? Patient: I would say mild. Doctor: What about vomiting? Patient: No, only nausea are there.

person: I think someone called nine a little after the accident. Doctor
sentence: Do you remember the speed you were driving at the time of the accident? Patient: I was driving about forty miles an hour. Doctor: What kind of car were you driving? Patient: A minivan. The car in front of me stopped suddenly and I hit it directly from behind. The front of my car is pretty wrecked. Doctor: Did you wear a safety belt? And did you deploy an air bag? Patient: Yes and yes. Doctor: Passengers in the car with you? Patient: No, just me. Doctor: Did you hit your head anywhere? Patient: No, but I hurt on the left side of my neck. Doctor: Do you think you lost consciousness at any time? Patient: I have a pain in my hand? Patient: No pain elsewhere. Patient: I have a pain in my stomach.
No known allergy? Patient: No. Doctor: No allergy to medication? Patient: No.

Let's talk about your family history. Did anyone in your family have any medical problems you knew about? Patient: I don't think so. My family was healthy enough. My two parents died of old age. Doctor: And your brothers and sisters? Any thyroid or diabetes or blood pressure problems there? Patient: I have an older brother. He's in weightlifting and everything. I'd say he's healthy enough.

Can you tell me more about your parents, please? How are they? Patient: Thank you for asking, they're both doing well. Doctor: How old are they? Patient: My mother is fifty years old, and my father is forty years old. Doctor: Wonderful, do you have brothers and sisters? Patient: Yes, I have two sisters, one is a half-sister, and the other we have the same mother and dad. Doctor: How old are they? Patient: My half-sister and I have the same mother, and she is thirty-four years old. My other sister is ten years old. Doctor: Do they have a history of diseases that you know? Patient: My half-sister, um, no. My other sister has had yeast infections.

person: I'm here for nothing special but I just have discomfort on the right side. Doctor
sentence: We studied electromyography. It was to assess the health of the muscles and nerves in your body. When did you notice this discomfort for the first time? Patient: About five years ago. After my stroke. I was in a neurologist before. Doctor: Yes, I can see that you took different types of medication, but nothing seems to help you. Patient: It sounds good. Nothing seems to help me get rid of this discomfort. Doctor: How many times do you check your sugar level? Patient: I do it at home. Mainly two to three times a day. I increase or decrease the amount of insulin I take according to my numbers. Doctor: Don't consult anyone before doing this? Patient: So many years ago I went home. Doctor: We have recalibrated your symptoms.

It's not in the pain at all. Doctor: How has your mood been? Do you feel a relief of your symptoms since you were on Lexapro? Patient: It helps a little. Doctor: How many Lexapros do you take now? Patient: I take ten M. G. Doctor: How long have you taken the full dose? Patient: About a week ago. I don't take it every day. I don't feel like I need it a few days. Doctor: I want you to take the full dose every day. Maybe that's why you haven't had a lot of relief with your symptoms yet. Patient: OK. Doctor: Your hands are a little soft. Is this a normal event for you? Patient: I haven't even noticed. Doctor: It's very subtle to keep an eye on him for the moment. Your blood pressure is a little better today.
Do you have a medical history? Patient: No.

How long have these psychotic periods stopped? Patient: It's been 20 years. Doctor: So, you're taking Clozaril and other medications? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you feel better with them, sir? Patient: Yes. It was better for a few years. Doctor: These antipsychotics, they were good at you, no? Patient: They were sometimes, but finally there was a new episode.

Has anyone in your family ever had a neurological disorder? Patient: Not something specific, but many members of my family had lazy eyes. Doctor: Who is in your family? Patient: My parents and two little sisters. Doctor: How old are your sisters? Patient: One is new, another is five. Doctor: How are they both wise? Patient: They are both healthy.

I have their surgical history if you want to go. Guest_clinician: Go ahead. Doctor: So they had an exploratory laparotomy in nineteen seventy-seven. Guest_clinician: Okay. Doctor: They had a number of operations in nineteen seventy-five, which include an L five S a lumbar laminectomy, anal cracking surgery, tonsillectomy, and adenoidectomy. Guest_clinician: Understood. Any complications you know? Doctor: None was mentioned by the patient or his spouse.
How do you feel about your foot? Patient: It feels good. Doctor: Any pain or discomfort when you walk on it? Patient: No. I'm a good doc.

And you work? Patient: Ah yes, I drive a delivery truck in the city. Doctor: Okay. So tell me that you smoke or drink? Yes, I do both. Doctor: And how many would you say that you smoke a day? Patient: I smoke about two packs a day. Doctor: Hm, how much do you drink? Patient: I drink three, oh wait, I drink two beers a day. Doctor: And do you do drugs like coke or anything? Patient: No.

Where do you work? Patient: I work in the press, I work in a print press. Doctor: You smoke? Have you ever taken an illicit drug? Patient: No, none of them. Doctor: And alcohol? Patient: I don't take it now. I drank a lot, but I quit in the 1970s.
Have you ever reacted badly to medications taken in the past? Patient: I don't think so. No reaction so far.
Are you taking medication? Patient: Yes, I am taking thyroid medicines and Lipitor.
A medical history like diabetes, hypertension or heart disease? Patient: No, I don't remember anything like that. Doctor: How about surgery in the past? Patient: No. No surgery at all.

I am thirteen. Doctor: Good, and what seems to be the problem today? Mom, can you explain me? Guest_family: Well, if you look, doctor, his back posture is very rounded. Doctor: I think it's around the thoracic spine. Is there a family history of this problem? Guest_family: Yes, on my side, my aunt and grandfather had, um, kyphosis. Doctor: Yes, that's what it is. It's thoracic kyphosis to be specific. Did she see another doctor for that? Guest_family: Yes, we saw another orthopedist. Doctor: What did they recommend? Guest_family: They recommended that we come for a later observation, so we are here for a second opinion. Doctor: Well, is there a back pain, numbness or tingling? Patient: No, I don't have anything else. Doctor: No, there's a doctor, there's a weakness?
Are you allergic to anything? Patient: No, I'm not allergic to anything. Doctor: Okay, no drug allergies. Patient: Yes.

Are you married, ma'am. Patient: Yes, for my husband, I don't even remember how long my husband and I were married. Doctor: It's wonderful. Do you drink or smoke? Patient: Absolutely not, I never used this kind of thing.
Let's see here. Are there any diseases running in your - Patient: Family? Doctor: Yes. Patient: No.

What happened to you? How did you get involved in this accident? Patient: I was just trying to adjust the cable to which my brother's dog was attached. Suddenly, he attacked me out of nowhere. The wound to my leg is V-shaped and the V points towards my foot. Doctor: What type of dog? Patient: German shepherd. But he is up to date on his blows, and he is in full health. Patient: He bit me on my foot, and it seems that his teeth have entered my skin. I went to my P.C.P. Doctor: What did you do there? Patient: They cleaned the wound and made me a bandage with it he gave me a shot of tetanus. Doctor: And he sent you to us? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Ok, let me examine your wound. Patient: Of course! Doctor: It seems that there is a puncture injury after an injury. It seems that one centimetre long and viable.

Do you know any family medical history? Patient: No. My two parents died of old age. They were in the eighties. I don't remember any other medical problems in my loved ones. Doctor: What about memory loss or stroke or high blood pressure, diabetes or any other type of mental illness? Patient: No. Doctor: Has anyone in your family got out of these things? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have children? Patient: Yes, I have five children and they're all doing well in their lives.

Do you have any important medical problems in your history that I should know? Patient: What, like high blood pressure? Doctor: Well, it could be anything from high blood pressure, depression, something as serious as cancer. Patient: Oh, no, I have nothing like that, at least not that I know.

Hi! How are you today? Guest_family: We're fine. I'm tired today. Doctor: Our records show that he's up-to-date on all his two-month vaccinations. Guest_family: That's true! He had his shots the last time we were here. Doctor: Does he have any health problems during childbirth? Guest_family: Nope. He's healthy.

Hello! How are you all today? Guest_family: Not good. We are really worried about our daughter. Doctor: What happened? Guest_family: I turned my back for a second and saw her under the counter in the wardrobe. We have a child protection on this wardrobe. I don't know how she opened it. I took her out of the closet, and she had the bottle of ant bait in her hands. She had poured all the bottle on her. She had the liquid on her hands. I don't know if she had drunk or put her hands in her mouth. Doctor: Do you know what the ant bait was called? Guest_family: No. I know that it was the kind with Borax in it. Doctor: Do you know how big the container was? Guest_family: It was a bottle of eleven ML. I'm not sure if this thing is toxic or not? Doctor: What age is she? Guest_family: Do you know how big the container was? Guest_family: It was a bottle of eleven ML.

Hello. Are you ready for your surgery today? Patient: I am ready as much as possible. This is not my first rodeo. Doctor: I see. Have you ever had any surgery before? Patient: Yes, I have it. I think it is in my relationship that you have with you. Doctor: You are right. It is said here that you have had some vein stripping in your legs, an tonsilectomy, and adenoidectomy.
Is she married? Guest_family: No, she's divorced. Doctor: A history of tobacco, alcohol or drug use? Guest_family: I think she used to drink? But I'm not positive.

person: And tell me, are you allergic to medication? Patient
sentence: No. Not what I know. Doctor: Okay.
I'd like her to come to you next week for her enlarged thyroid. Guest_clinician: Is she symptomatic? Doctor: Yes, she's having more and more trouble swallowing.

Hi! How are you today? Patient: I'm fine. I'm starting a new job on Monday. I've been unemployed for about a year now. It's going to be nice to go back to work. Doctor: Congratulations. Do you use tobacco products, drink alcohol or recreational drugs? Patient: I was smoking a little, but I quit ten years ago. Doctor: Great! Patient: I don't drink or I do drugs.

So tell me about your family's medical history. Patient: Hm, my mother died due to cancer. Doctor: Oh, what type? Patient: Actually, I don't know that. Doctor: OK. Patient: And my father died due to a heart attack. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Ok, I don't see your vaccination record here, you have it? Patient: No, I don't. I came from another country a long time ago with nothing. I don't have a medical record of my past. Doctor: I see.

person: I received surgery with Dr. Yen. Patient
sentence: Yes. I think the surgery is scheduled for July 20th. Patient: How do you feel about the shoulder? Patient: My shoulder is the same. I'm still in a lot of pain. Patient: I'm sorry to hear that. Your operation is coming up soon and it should help. Patient: I hope so. Patient: We also follow the pinched nerve in your upper left extremity C Six. How do you feel? Patient: I had some pain from this same place, and it goes down the left arm in my wrist. Doctor: Did you have a weakness associated with your upper extremities on the left side? Patient: There is only the patient? Patient: There was no pain in the last side of the patient.
You are taking medication at that time? Patient: None. Doctor: Understood.
Hey, how's the patient? Guest_clinician: I don't know, I couldn't examine it. He did special procedures for the last two hours for some medical treatment. Doctor: Oh, I see.

So, you mean it's something simple? Doctor: Yes, it's probably a sinus infection and then the cough secondary to this infection. Guest_family: Is it treatable? Doctor: Yes, it's. Guest_family: OK well.

You have an infection that has become septic. We will have to start you with intravenous antibiotics. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have to treat blood clotting. I will give you an anticoagulant to avoid any other clotting problem. Do you have any questions? Patient: No.

What are you doing to make a living, sir? Patient: At this moment, I am a truck driver, sir. Doctor: Wow, it's hard work. You work now? Patient: No, I can't immediately, I'm on sick leave. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: Yes, my wonderful wife. She helps take care of me. Doctor: Do you have children? Patient: Yes, we have three. We all live together, and for that I am very grateful. Doctor: Are you smoking, sir? Patient: Yes, I smoke about two packs a day. Doctor: What about alcohol? Do you drink? Patient: No, just smoke for me. Doctor: What about more illegal substances, have you used illegal drugs or inappropriately prescribed? Patient: Oh, absolutely not. Doctor: It's good. Do you have any other medical conditions in your family that I should know about? Patient: No, not that I know.

What brings you today? Patient: Well, I think I have a memory loss, like a short-term memory loss. Doctor: Okay, and why do you say that? Patient: I have been under enormous stress for the last five to ten years. I am currently working for mobile customer service T and my job is really agitated. I need a lot of technical knowledge with project delays that add to my stress. Patient: Sometimes I have difficulty absorbing all the technical knowledge and computer skills or client problems. Doctor: Hm. Patient: I have done my M.B.A. in business for a reason, I wanted to have a good career, but this job is very demanding and stressful. I have already worked in a bank in Conway Springs, Norwich. I have worked a lot of work around accounting and management services, but my current job is a high stress.

Hello! Welcome to the clinic. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Doctor Murphy sent your records. I examined the ultrasound, and we found a kidney stone that became stuck in the ureter on the left side. The stone is large enough to block the flow of urine from the kidney to the bladder. How much pain do you have and where is the pain? Patient: I am in a lot of pain. It comes from my left side here. Doctor: Okay. Let yourself be used to discuss your treatment options. Patient: Okay.
Are you allergic to something? Patient: No, oh no.
Do you have type 2 diabetes? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And high cholesterol? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Your diabetes is poorly controlled. Patient: I will keep an eye on it.

Can you tell me more about your daughter's injury? Guest_family: Well, we arrived in November, and she was diagnosed with a chronic right-hand femoral epiphysis gliding. Doctor: Did she undergo surgery on this subject? Guest_family: Yes, let me look at my notes, I wrote it here, um, a situ pinning. Doctor: Remind me, how old are you, dear? Patient: I am thirteen now. Doctor: Thank you. So, um, if you look at her x-rays, it seems that the screw is now going into the hip joint. Guest_family: They haven't seen this before.

What brings you today? Patient: Uh a number of different things. I don't even know where to start being honest. Doctor: I understand. What's bothering you most? Patient: Lemma thinks. I'm uh have really bad pain. Doctor: Where is the pain located? Patient: Hm. It's in a difficult place. Guest_family: Hi. Mari here. Let me help you explain. She's had serious pain in the bottom of her back. She started soft and got worse over a few days. She's also much slower as a result. Doctor: Any recent injury or fall? Guest_family: None. She spends most of her time in bed.

Please represent the patient's case. Guest_clinician: The patient is a man of seventy-six years of age. He complains of generalized weakness and malaise for several months. He has a history of two weeks of worsening orthostatic dizziness. He denies recent symptoms of fever or shortness of breath, cough, vomiting, diarrhoea, haemoptysia, melena, haematochia, bright red blood per rectum, polyuria, night sweats, visual changes or syncopal episodes. Doctor: You said that you feel dizzy, which makes him worse? Patient: It's bad when I try to stay straight. I also have these intermittent headaches where he feels like someone inside. Doctor: Does these headaches change with changing positions or staying straight? Patient: No. Doctor: Does the patient have a known medical history? Guest_clinician: Yes, he has a history.
Have you ever had jaundice? Patient: Hum, no. Doctor: No rash or anything? Patient: No.

person: I didn't have a rash and itching over my right arm. It's so itchy and I scratch all the time. Doctor
sentence: Is it your dominant hand? Patient: Yes, it had particularly bothered me. Doctor: When did you notice these symptoms? Patient: Hum, I think it was in October of nineteen-two. I think it was the twenty-third. Doctor: Did you have any symptoms in other parts of your body? Patient: Hum, yes, I had tingling in both my legs, as on the front, and then it also enters my toes. Doctor: Did your feeling of tingling disappear? Patient: Yes, he left the next day without me doing anything.

How's it going? Patient: Well, can't complain. Doctor: Glad to hear. So today we're going to make a full evaluation. It's going to be a little different from our usual visits together. Do you want your mother to enter the room, too? Pattor: Yes, it's not a problem. Doctor: Okay. I'm going to take her from the waiting room. I'll be right back.

I haven't been able to get her full story and system review. But she's planned for bladder distension surgery. Doctor: Ok. Guest_clinician: Also, I'm not sure if she's out of Coumadin due to surgery. Doctor: Oh yes, she has a chronic AFib and she's on Coumadin. Not sure if she stopped the medication because of the surgery to come. Guest_clinician: The only thing she could say was that she had tremors for the last three to four years and was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease early. Doctor: Okay.

Hello. What is the reason for your visit today? Patient: I continue to have this dry cough and it becomes difficult to breathe at certain times. Doctor: Have you been exposed to anything recently? Patient: Here's a note from an entrepreneur who worked on my house recently. I wasn't sure what that meant. Doctor: I see. It seems you were exposed to asbestos. Patient: Oh, no! Am I going to go well? Doctor: I'm going to take a look, but I want to ask you a quick question. Do you have a family that lived with you at the time? Patient: No. I live alone, so my family wasn't there to be exposed.

How do you feel today, madam? Patient: Honestly, overall, I feel much better. Doctor: Do you still have diarrhea and decreased appetite? Patient: Yes, but I feel even better. Doctor: Have you pissed a normal amount? Patient: Yes, no problems there. I measured it as you said to me at six hundred M. L. Doctor: When did you piss for the last time? Patient: Hum, it was about seven this morning. Doctor: Do you have symptoms of fever? Patient: No, I feel good enough.

You smoke, sir? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you drink? Patient: No. I was a boxer before so that's why I had always stayed away from these things. Doctor: How is your condition of life? Do you live alone or with the family? Patient: Especially I am alone during the day. The family comes to help me on and off. I love this. I didn't have to be in an independent setting soon.

Do you smoke cigarettes? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol or use recreational drugs? Patient: Yes, I have been in and out of treatment. I'm not going so well in staying clean. Doctor: What substances are you using? Patient: I drink, and I made coke today. I have been in the treatment of heroin and alcohol.

Hello how are you? Doctor Mina is a trainee who works with me. She will take notes and discuss your case today. Patient: It's good. Doctor: So, tell me, Doctor Mina, what brings this young man here today? Guest_clinician: He's a 16-year-old boy in the right hand. He's studying in the eleventh year. He has vision difficulties like blur and concentration. He was diagnosed with a suprasellar tumor. Later, January 4, he underwent surgery for his tumor. Biopsy reports said it was craniopharyngoma. Even after the operation, there was a residual disease and his visual device was decompressed. Doctor: Thank you Doctor. Tell me how you are doing young man? Is there any difficulty returning to school? Patient: I'm fine. I get headaches and I feel that someone is ringing in my ears.

Remind me, please, when was your operation? Patient: Well, it was about two and a half months now. Doctor: Great, we repaired that slipped the capital femoral epiphysis on both sides, we call it S C F E. Patient: Thank you for remembering, I forgot the names of everything.

person: Any medications I should know? Patient
sentence: No, no daily medications.

I'm sorry to hear it. Patient: Oh, that's quite good. Doctor: Do you drink or smoke? Patient: No, I don't do either of these two. Doctor: Well, then where do you live now? Patient: I live in Kansas Christian Home. Doctor: You live there independently? Patient: Yes, fortunately. But I can't do a lot of things. I have to be sure to take my medication. Doctor: Have you been driving today? Patient: No, I had a driver today. Can I speed up, I have to go to lunch.

I am good today! Doctor: Do you not feel well on other days? Patient: I have been nervous and I have had some anxiety lately. Doctor: Are your feelings of nervousness or anxiety triggered by something specific? Patient: It varies. I feel anxious when I think about getting back to work or this next trip I have planned. Doctor: How many times do you feel this way? Patient: He comes and goes. Doctor: Have you ever had a treatment or a history of depression, anxiety or mood disorder? Patient: No.

Who lives with you, miss? Patient: I live with my boyfriend. Doctor: Smoking cigarettes? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: And drugs? Patient: Sometimes, but I don't want to talk about it. Doctor: Ok. Everything you want to talk about? Patient: Sorry?
Good afternoon, sir.
Good afternoon, doctor.
Refresh my memory, please, how old are you, sir?
I'm forty nine.
Also, I need you to remind me, when was your lower back surgery?
It was in January of two thousand five. What was the name of the surgery, again?
It was a lumbar disc replacement. So, how are you feeling today?
Truthfully doctor, the surgery did nothing. I'm still in a lot of pain.
Besides the surgery, what other interventions have you tried?
I have them written down, let me look. Um, I did acupuncture, T E N S unit at P T, and I've been to the chiropractor too.
Have you taken any medicines?
Yeah, I have those written down here. I've taken Elavil, Topamax, Cymbalta, Neurontin, and Lexapro.
Are you still taking any of these?
No, I had bad side effects to some, and the others just didn't do anything.
Have you had any injections for this pain?
I've had a few into the, um, piriformis.
Did that do anything?
Um, it provided some brief relief, I guess. I had a Botox procedure done on March eighth two thousand six.
How did this work?
Honestly, it did nothing.
Where is your pain, exactly?
I'd say its seventy five percent in my butt and leg, and twenty five percent in my lower back.
Are you able to workout, or exercise, anything like that?
I've tried to increase how much I walk, but when I do I get spasms in my lower back.
I see, with ten being the worst pain of all time, how would you rate your pain today?
I'd say it's a six out of ten today.
What adjectives would you use to describe the pain?
Um, I'd say its shooting, sharp, and, um, aching.
Specifically, what activities make the pain worse?
Well, lifting, standing for a long time, or, um, squatting. I can't do that anymore.
Does anything make the pain better?
Um, sitting back, ice, and I guess there's some improvement with the pain medication.
Is the pain constant, or does it come and go?
It's constant now, but, um, the intensity of it comes and goes.
Are you able to sleep at night?
Not really, it is affecting my sleep, which in turn affects my mood.
So, overall, I can summarize and say you're not happy with your pain relief so far?
Yes, doctor, that's correct.

Do you have a family history of neurological conditions that I should know? Patient: What exactly do you mean by that, doctor? Doctor: Well, it could be anything from A D H D, epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease. Patient: Oh, no.
Do you take medication? Patient: Yes. I take Abilify to help with my mood. Doctor: Do you think it helps? Patient: A little, yes.

Your culture results have returned positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. This is a bacterial infection. I would like to take a course in antibiotics. This should start to improve your symptoms with in three to four days. Patient: OK. Doctor: Please let me know if your symptoms have not improved or get worse. Patient: I'm going. Thank you.

I had a lung transplant in two thousand and four because of pulmonary fibrosis. Doctor: Okay, how are you doing now? It was, it was for both lungs? Patient: Yes, on both sides. Doctor: You have an irregular heart rate, right? Patient: Yes, I do.
How are you? Patient: Look at this fifth nail on my left hand, Doctor. Doctor: Oh what's stuck here? Patient: I think it's wood splinter. Doctor: Oh, must be painful! Patient: Yes a lot.

Can you move your arms? I would like to see how your range of movement is. Patient: Of course, see. Like that? Doctor: Yes, yes, it seems good for the arms and legs. Patient: Great. Doctor: I do not see any obvious deformation in the neck of the head or in the extremities. Patient: Yes, no problems.
Are you allergic to something? Patient: Yes, I am allergic to eggs and peanuts. Doctor: Oh, okay. Doctor: Anything else? No medication? Patient: No, nothing else. Doctor: Very good.

Do you smoke, sir? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you drink? Patient: Sometimes I take one or two beers. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: For ten years. Doctor: What are you doing to live? Patient: I lay the floor. I am associated with a construction company and my main work is the installation of floors.
Good morning, young lady. Is this your mother?
Yes, this is my mommy.
Good morning, mom. Can you tell me more about your daughter, please?
Good morning, doctor. Well, she's thirteen now, but she's had feet problems all her life.
What's been the problem with her feet?
Well, she had bilateral feet corrections when she was a year old.
Okay, how has she been since that procedure?
Well, just look at her heel, doctor.
Yes, I see. She has pretty significant calcaneal valgus deformity.
What does that mean, doctor?
Your heel is out of alignment, sweetie. Do you have pain?
Yes, I have a lot of pain, doctor.
What can we do about this, doctor?
Well, given all of her symptoms, I think we should do a calcaneal osteotomy and Achilles lengthening procedure.
What does that procedure entail?
Well, in short, we'll go in there and straighten everything out, and get everything lined back up.
What's the risk of infection with the surgery, sir?
Actually, it's less than one percent, so it's extremely low.
How is this possible, doctor?
We use antibiotics to control for infection the entire time.
That's great. Will she be asleep for this procedure?
Yes, we'll use anesthesia the entire time. She won't feel a thing.
Okay, that's good too. What about after the procedure? What's the protocol?
Well, I'll need your help. We have to be strict about her being nonweightbearing for six weeks at minimum.
Will she need a brace too?
Yes, at least for six months, but if she does everything I ask of her, it will be only six months.
Okay, yes, I think we should do the procedure. What do you think, honey?
Yes, I want to get back to playing sports with my friends.

The other risks include bleeding; changes in sensation in most of extremity; hardware failure; need for later hardware removal; possible nonunion; possible failure to correct all the deformity; and need for other surgical procedures.  I would not worry about these issues, though. It is quite rare. So, looking at her radiographs, the spinal arch is definitely collapsed. I think you guys are making the right decision.

Hello, young man. Are these your parents? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Well, can you tell me more about your son, please? Guest_family_1: Well, he is five years old now, and he fell on his right arm on the fifth two thousand seven December. Doctor: After he fell, how was he treated? Guest_family_1: We went to the E D just after he fell, and they said that he had complete fractures of both bones in his arm. Doctor: Yes, I see that here, he also shortened bayonet apposition. Guest_family_1: What can we do for that? Doctor: There are actually some options here.

Hello. Are you a new patient? Patient: I am. I travel a lot, so I don't have a local doctor that I usually see. Doctor: That's good. What's the reason for your visit? Patient: I've had this dark spot on my leg for a long time. Doctor: I see. Do you know if your family has chronic medical problems? Patient: Not that I know. Doctor: It's good. I think I can remove it surgically. Before you go to the procedures, did you have an operation before? Patient: Yes, I did. I had an operation on my back and removed my appendix. Doctor: It sounds good. Other than this dark spot, you seem to be very healthy.

It's the day of surgery! How do you feel? Patient: Not as excited as you. Doctor: Have you ever had an operation? Patient: Yes. It was something with my chest. Guest_family: Hi Doctor. I'm the mother. He had a placement in the chest. Doctor: I see. Thank you for letting me know.

What is your state of life? Do you live alone or with your family? Patient: I live with my boyfriend. Doctor: You smoke? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How long do you smoke? Patient: About ten years. Doctor: How many cigarettes do you take? Patient: Well, a pack of cigarettes lasts about three days. Doctor: Do you drink? Patient: I drink beer. Doctor: How much do you drink a day? Patient: I drink about six bottles once a week. Doctor: Do you work somewhere? Patient: I worked in a herbicide factory.

I want to talk to you about your reproductive history, okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Do you take contraceptive pills? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Do you have a medical history that I should be aware of? Patient: I had both chickenpox and measles when I was a child.
You have nausea, vomiting? Patient: Yes to both. Doctor: How about fever? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: No blood in sputum or chest pain? Patient: Yes, I do.
Well, this is a case of hypothermia. Guest_family: Will he survive? Doctor: Don't worry, we'll take care of him.

Do you take tobacco products? Patient: I used to chew tobacco, but I quit when I was thirty-seven years old. Doctor: What about drinking alcohol? Do you drink? Patient: I have a glass of wine every day. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: Yes, sir. I have been married to a wonderful woman for thirty-five years. Doctor: You still work? Patient: I am used to it. Now I am retired, I was a laboratory director before.

Hello! What brings you back to the clinic today? Patient: I came back because I increased my methotrexate as we discussed the last time I was here. A few days later, I started to have several canker pains in my mouth. They hurt. Doctor: I'm sorry. It's likely that the increased dose of your methotrexate is the cause of the pains of the mouth. Have you experienced a decrease in appetite, nausea, abdominal discomfort or diarrhea? Patient: No. It's painful to eat with the wounds, but I still have an appetite. Doctor: Have you had any new rashes, or hair loss? Patient: No. Doctor: I would like to do a little blood.
Are you aware of any medical problems in your family? Patient: No. Doctor: How about a known heart condition or diabetes in the family. Patient: No, I'm not aware of anything like that.

So I look at his x-ray and it shows no open fractures or any kind of bone anomaly. Guest_family: Okay, I was really worried about my son. Doctor: I understand, but as I said, I didn't see an open fracture in his x-ray report or any anomaly. Guest_family: Okay.
Do you drink? Patient: Yes, I take two or four beers a day. Doctor: Do you smoke? Patient: Oh yes, I smoke. I take one to two packs of cigarettes a day.

Do you live alone? Patient: I would not say that I live alone. I have three cats and they still keep me company. Doctor: Aw, what type of cats? Patient: Two Persian cats and a Chartreux. Doctor: Do you currently work? Patient: I retired a few months ago. I was working as a psychological aid for the state of Pennsylvania. Doctor: Congratulations on your retirement. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: How long have you worked as a psychological aid? Patient: Thirty-two years. Doctor: Unbelievable. Another question. Smoking, drinking or using drugs recreationally? Patient: I drink wine from time to time. I smoked again in the day, but I am five years free to smoke. I do not smoke. Doctor: Always good to hear.

Hi! What brings you today? Guest_family: I think my baby entered the ant bait. I don't know if he consumed it, but he was under the counter and he was in his hands. Doctor: What kind of ant bait did he enter? Guest_family: It's the one with Borax in it. Doctor: Do you have a picture of him? Guest_family: Yes. It's in my phone.

Do you remember how many cycles of carboplatin and taxol you had for your cancer, ma'am? Patient: Uh, I had six, I'm here for a follow-up today. Doctor: Yes, I see here that your last treatment with chemo on January 18th two thousand eight. Patient: Yes, I remember. Can you remember the full name of my cancer? Doctor: It's a uterine nervous carcinoma. Patient: Thank you, Doctor. Doctor: Of course, do you have problems today? Patient: Well, I just have numbness in my right arm today. Doctor: This has worsened recently? Patient: Well, not really.

How long has she had trouble swallowing? Guest_family: A moment now. We programmed her to see an endocrinologist, but she is not able to enter until Monday. I wanted to see if we could get to the bottom now. Doctor: It seems that her thyroids are quite enlarged. I think that's where most of her symptoms, if not all, come from. Guest_family: Does this mean that she will need surgery? Doctor: We will have to see, but the chances are higher since she has symptoms due to her thyroid. Guest_family: When will we discover it? Doctor: I would like to do an imaging and see if we can get a consultation first.

Do you have any important medical problems in your family that I should be aware of? Patient: Yes, I know that some of my parents have had coronary heart disease and, um, high blood pressure. Doctor: And about cancer? Someone in your family has a history of cancer? Patient: No, it doesn't sound at all.
When was your injury, sir?
Um, if I recall, it was on November twentieth two thousand eight.
What do you do for a living, sir?
I work at the Purdy Correctional Facility, doctor.
How did you get hurt?
Well, an inmate broke some of the overhead sprinklers, and I slipped on all the water and I landed on the back of my head, and then onto my back.
Which side took most of the hit?
It was mostly on my left side.
How were you after the fall?
Well, I was pretty stunned, mostly. I didn't want to come in, but my employers asked me to just to be sure.
Who has evaluated you to date?
Um, I went to Gig Harbor Urgent Care, and then they sent me to Tacoma General Hospital. At Tacoma they said I have a whiplash and concussion.
What did they do at the hospital?
Um, they did a C T scan, and they found a dark spot on my brain.
What did they recommend about the spot?
They said I should have another M R I and they diagnosed an, um, recurrent acoustic neuroma.
So, you've had this before? How did they know you had it?
I used to see a chiropractor, and they suggested that I get a scan and that's how they found it before.
When was this?
Um, it was in October of two thousand five.
Did you have surgery on this?
Yes, I'm recovering now.
Are they still considering radiation?
Yes, it's under consideration but there's no final decision yet.
Okay, what does the chiropractor do for you?
You know, the usual, adjustments and massages, stuff like that.
Has there been any improvement?
Overall, my spine pain has improved a lot.
That's good. Okay, so after your fall, what other treatments did you have?
I went to Prompt Care in Bremerton, and saw Doctor X Y Z. She's an osteopathic doctor.
How did she treat you?
She ordered an M R I of my neck, I have the report right here.
Okay, this shows some mild disc bulge at C four C five. Did she let you go back to work?
Yes, she released me back to full duty. I was doing fine after the neurosurgical treatment.
Do you have any other treatment planned?
Some radiation.
What else has she treated you for?
Oh, you know, just general aches and pains on my back and neck. I have been seeing her since two thousand and two.
Past medical problems or operations that I should know about? Patient: No, none of what I can think of.

So I see here in your reports that you have arthritis in both your knees. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And you have a tear in the eye in the past, right? Patient: Ah yes, I have a tear in my retina. Doctor: Yes. It is also mentioned here that you have atrial fibrillation. Patient: That's correct. Doctor: Do you take medication? Patient: Yes, I am on anticoagulants. Doctor: Ok.
Have you had any procedures in the past? Patient: No.

Do you have any medical problems in your family that I should know, ma'am? Patient: Uh, yes, my father had prostate cancer. Doctor: And your mother, or the rest of your family? Patient: Um, my mother's brother had Hodgkin's disease, melanoma and prostate cancer.

Do you drink? Patient: Not really, no. Doctor: Medicines? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have a chance to practice during the week? Patient: I like walking with my dog every day. I also eat much healthier these days. Doctor: It's wonderful. How is work for you? Patient: I was promoted last month so it's okay. I had a lot more time to spend with my family accordingly. Doctor: It's great to hear. Congratulations! Patient: Thank you very much.
Are you allergic to anything? Patient: No, I don't have any allergies. Doctor: Great.

What are you doing in the hospital? Patient: I work as a phlebotomist and respiratory therapist. Doctor: Ok, how old are you? Patient: I am fifty-four years old. Doctor: You are very young. Patient: Thank you! Patient: So, as you remember, I was trying to measure blood gas as I was working with a patient and I accidentally stuck this needle in my right hand index. Patient: I come for a regular screening. Doctor: Did you wear gloves? Patient: Yes, I had gloves and protective clothing. Doctor: Yes, thank you for that.

They took a little liquid from your back do you remember? Patient: Yes, actually. Doctor: We got the results for that and it seems that it was clear then it became bloody. Patient: They checked my urine and blood too. Doctor: Yes, they did. I see the orders for the culture of urine, B M P, C B C, C R P, and the culture of blood too. Patient: I received an anti-fog treatment from albuterol too. Doctor: It's good. but it helped you? Patient: No, it didn't. Doctor: Oh I'm sorry. Patient: It's good. Doctor: I see they gave you antibiotics in A R? Patient: Yes, Ampicillin and Cefotaxime.

I had my tonsils removed when I was a child, maybe about eight years old. I was hospitalized for the heart attack in ninety-six years. They did an operation to check the functioning of my heart and then they did a bypass. Doctor: Did you have a recording of these surgeries? Patient: Oh yes, I had it with me. Here. Doctor: It's great. Let me look. So, according to that, you had a coronary bypass transplant L I M A to L A D. You also had three saphenous vein transplants performed. Patient: Yes I had so many procedures, it's hard to keep track of all these complex names. That's why I keep these papers with me all the time if I go to a new doctor. Doctor: I'm going to add all these surgerys to my file. Thank you.
How is everyone in your family? Patient: My mother, my father and my brothers and sisters are good. Doctor: They are fine, it is good. That is what we want. Patient: Yes.

What are you doing to live, sir? Patient: I work at the shop A B C, doctor. Doctor: It's great, you smoke? Patient: No, I don't smoke at all. Doctor: And alcohol? Do you drink? Patient: I would say I drink socially, as if I'm at a party, or something like that.
Are you taking medication or daily supplements? Patient: No.

person: I had a significant pain with both. Doctor
sentence: Does this interfere with your ability to walk? Patient: Yes, I can walk like, maybe half a mile a day, then the pain becomes too bad. Doctor: Are you able to go up and down stairs? Patient: I have to take them one at a time. Doctor: I see you have a degenerative joint disease of both knees, does that sound like bells? Patient: Yes, but what does that mean? Doctor: You have arthritis in both knees, sir. Patient: Ah, yes. Patient: Did you have surgery on these knees? Patient: Hum, I had surgery on both knees, did I take notes.
Do you smoke? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How much? Patient: Two cigarettes a day. Doctor: Ok it's not bad, but try to stop. Patient: OK. Doctor: Alcohol? Patient: No, I don't drink.

I started to have several other problems. Doctor: Oh really! Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, then tell me about your cough, does it get worse? Patient: It's pretty much the same but not the best. Doctor: Hm. And what about your diarrhea and stomach pain? Patient: No more diarrhea and no pian. Doctor: Bowel movement? Patient: Normal. Doctor: Any pain while you piss? Can you completely empty your bladder? Patient: No pain and no problem emptying my bladder. Doctor: No problem. Patient: No nausea or vomiting? Patient: No, but I developed this strange painful taste in my mouth. Doctor: Oh ok. How long? Patient: Since last week. Doctor: I see. Any loss of appetite? Patient: No, not really. Doctor: Okay and what other problems were you talking about? Patient: Yes, I also had problems with my eyes, I've had very bad eyes.

So, sir, what are you doing to make a living? Patient: At this moment, I work with Chevron as an oil engineer. Doctor: It's fantastic. So, you drink? Patient: Um, I would say I drink socially, as if I'm at a party or something. Doctor: Of course, I do. You smoke too? Patient: No sir, I don't do this.
Is anyone else sick at home? Patient: No. My husband and daughter seem to be doing well.

person: What brings you here today? Patient
sentence: I'm good, thank you. I have this weakness on my left side after the brain, I mean, after they removed my tumor from the brain. Doctor: Remind me when you had your operation for the brain tumor? Patient: It was the twenty-fourth of October last year. Doctor: How old are you now? Patient: I'm sixty-four years old. Patient: He's my husband, Al. Doctor: Hi, happy to meet you. Doctor: Tell me what happened. Patient: They asked me to go to physical therapy for all the problems I had after my brain surgery. I went from November 5th to the fourteenth of last year. I did therapy for about two weeks from November 5th. My problems were not solved so I went to the hospital and then they did some tests and they found something wrong. They said there was swelling in my brain then they called me: When did they admit me?
What medication have you tried? Patient: I took Nexium. Doctor: Pain? Patient: Yes.

Well, I am looking at your test reports and your blood sugars have been running up and down but nothing to be worried about but yeah, we need to keep monitoring. This morning it was perhaps a bit high at one hundred eighty-eight. Last time it was one hundred fifty and in one report it's around one hundred twenty and in lower teens too which is good. So, tell me how are you feeling?

Well, I am doing okay. I am getting treated for hemorrhoids. I am also having some constipation from the past few weeks and I have recently developed this cough which is okay as I kind of get it often.
Oh boy, that's a lot going on!
Yeah.
So, tell me are your hemorrhoids painful?
No, it's fine.
And are you taking anything for constipation?
Well, just prune juice.
Okay, let me write you an order for a laxative that should help. How bout cough? Any pain in the ribs while coughing?
Nah, I am not bothered by it.
Any headache or nerve pain or body pain?
Um, no I am fine.
Any fall or imbalance problem?
No.
Any agitation or any other issues?
Well, I am doing okay! Sometimes if I have pain, I take Tylenol and usually it works for me.
That's good!
Yeah.
So, you have been seeking psychiatric help from Doctor Hudyncia right?
Yes.

She mentioned in her report that you are responding well to her treatment and that your depression is under control and the medicine is working for you. That's good news. Oh, what medicine has she prescribed? Um let me see here in the report, oh okay, got it! It's Cymbalta.
Right.
And no side effects, right?
No.
And looks like the plan is to treat you for a minimum one year.
Yeah.
Lastly, any breathing issues?
No.

So you saw Dr. X? Patient: Yes, seven days ago. I went to do my blood work and then I followed with Dr. Y. Doctor: Yes, I'm going to look at C B C diff and C M P profile. Patient: I'm going to follow with my oncologist, Dr. Z, for my swellings. Doctor: Yes, I couldn't get Dr. Z but here's the phone number. You should book the appointment. Patient: OK, I'm going to do it. Doctor: So I'd like to follow with your endocrinologist who is Dr. A for the adjustments that are necessary in your insulin pump. Patient: And you want me to see my gastric doctor as well? Doctor: Yes, please follow with Dr. B for problems with your J. Patient: Of course. Doctor: Finally, I want you to see Dr. Y if your condition changes regarding colon cancer.

I see you were there for the afib last month. Patient: Yes. Doctor: How are you? Patient: Everything is under control for now. Doctor: It's good to hear. Do you always take Metoprolol and Premarin? Patient: Yes.
Any health problems I need to rate? Patient: Diabetes. Doctor: Type one or two? Patient: Type two. Doctor: Are you on insulin? Patient: Yes. I'm also trying to manage it with exercise.

Let me examine your leg. Well your x-ray looks good. No fault there, I don't see any mass or swelling. Are you able to walk or use this leg at all? Patient: Oh yes, I use it. I also started to return to my regular walk. Doctor: Well, so your muscle strength is good, no loss of muscle tone there. Patient: Yes.
Hello, how are you? Patient: Hello Doctor, I'm fine. Doctor: So, what's going on with you? Patient: Well, I have nausea and I just want it checked. Doctor: Okay.

How long do you have this cough? Patient: Three weeks past, Doc. Doc.: Do you raise something when you cough? Patient: No. Doctor: Any shortness of breath or chest pain? Patient: No. Doctor: How about fevers or chills? Patient: None of this.
Let's go over your history.
Okay.
I see that you had an appendectomy.
Back in the nineteen forties. I also had an ankle resection in nineteen seventy five.
Any complications with either surgery?
Uh nope.
I also see that you have a recurring history of pneumonia.
Yeah. Started around age twenty and stuck with me ever since.
How often have you had pneumonia?
Once every five years or so.
Have you ever been hospitalized due to pneumonia?
Uh I'm usually given antibiotics and then discharged.
I see.
Unfortunately, I've had more episodes in the past year than ever before.
Any history of inherited lung disease, bronchiectasis, or other chronic pulmonary cause for repeated pneumonia?
Not to my knowledge.
And you recently saw the urologist, correct?
Yes. I had a catheter placed for urinary retention. He told me he thinks it's due to an enlarged prostate.
Do you have a history of diabetes or other medical problems?
Uh no. I've lost about eighteen pounds in the last month but other than that everything else seems to be fine.

Do you still feel nausea or vomiting? Patient: No. I feel better now. Doctor: Have you had shortness of breath or chest pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Were there painful or burning urinations? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have a history of convulsive disorders? Patient: No.
Tell me about your family medical history. Patient: No one in my family has any health problems.

Your son made his circumcision here at the children's hospital, is that right? Guest_family: Yes, doctor. Doctor: Do you remember the date of this procedure? Guest_family: Um, it was on September 16th, two thousand seven. Doctor: Well, the procedure went well. He had a bit of phimosis, but the operation was quite smooth otherwise. Guest_family: What is the phimosis? Doctor: It's the sealing of the foreskin. Sometimes it makes the procedure more difficult, but everything went well. Guest_family: Oh, it's good to hear. Doctor: He also had a bit of bleeding when he woke up in the recovery room, so we had to put extra sutures. Guest_family: Ok, thank you to take care of him. Doctor: It's my pleasure. Did he take his medication for pain? Guest_family: He took them for a few days, but it seems really normal now.

Is this something new? Or have you ever had it? Patient: No doctor, it's new. Doctor: What exactly do you feel? Patient: I feel like my tongue is swollen. Doctor: Okay. How old are you? Patient: I'm fifty-four years old. Doctor: Okay, let me see how we can evaluate this.
So I think we should start you with antibiotics for this ulcer on your right foot and possible osteomyelitis. I'll send a prescription to your pharmacy. Patient: Of course.

person: Your condition is improved, and you look pretty stable. Patient
sentence: Yes, I feel a lot better.
Do you have any allergies to medication? Patient: Yes. Penicillin.

It looks like you have a U T I and I have to give you antibiotics to treat it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I'm going to write you a prescription for Macrobid. You're still using Walgreens pharmacy in Thrashers Corner? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Are you taking any other medicines? Pattor: Yes, I'm taking a lot. I'm still wearing my medication list, let me tell you the names. Yes, so I'm taking Dilantin for my seizures, Toprol for my high blood pressure and Pravachol for my cholesterol. Doctor: Pravachol for my cholesterol. Wow, thanks for that, it helps a lot. Let me take note of it. Pattor: Of course.
Have you had any operations in the patient: No. No surgery. Doctor: How about injuries or past diseases? Patient: No.
What's going on? Patient: I've had a pain in my jaw since morning. Doctor: It's serious? Patient: Not so bad.
Have you taken any medicine in the past? Patient: You mean prescription, or on the counter? Doctor: One or the other. Patient: Oh, I haven't taken anything in the past.

Any changes to your diet? Patient: I have been following diet A D A online and max. at about 18 hundred calories a day. Doctor: How do you feel since the beginning of this diet? Patient: Much better in fact. My blood sugar level is not as high as it was before.

Tell me about your medical history. Patient: I was diagnosed with stage three ovarian cancer two years ago. They found a tumor in my upper abdomen. I underwent surgery and they removed everything. Dr. King is my oncologist. Doctor: Are you still under treatment? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have any other medical problems? Patient: Do you have a heart murmuring. It was not a problem. I also have acid reflux. Doctor: Do you take any medicine for G E R D? Patient: Yes. I am taking omeprazole.

person: Before you start your physique, could you check your age and ethnicity for me, please? Patient
sentence: I am forty-two years old and I identify as white. Doctor: Thank you. I also see that you are here for a follow-up of your asthma, correct? How is your asthma? Patient: That's true. My asthma has worsened in the last three months. My allergies also recur. Doctor: No. Has something changed that may have worsened your allergies? Patient: Well, my husband has transported more corn since he was busy season. I think it may have worsened. Doctor: Do you take medication to relieve your asthma and your allergies? Patient: I use my inhaler every day for my asthma. Here are the other medicines and treatments I started to use?

I am sorry to hear it, sir. And your brothers? Patient: Thank you, doctor. My two brothers are fine. Doctor: Please remind me how old are they? Patient: One of them is sixty-eight years old, and the other sixty-seven years old. I am in the middle. Doctor: It's great. Do you have medical conditions running in your family? Patient: Well, I'm not sure if that counts, but I had a brother and a sister, they were twins, they died at birth. Doctor: Oh no, thank you for telling me. Patient: Yes, I thought it would be important. Doctor: Do you have children, sir? Patient: Yes, I have two sons, they are both very good. Doctor: How old are your sons? Patient: One of them is fifty-four years old, and the other is fifty-seven. Doctor: In addition to neonatal deaths, do I have two children, they are both very good.

person: I didn't have any nasal infections. Here's my report from my previous doctor who sent me back to you. Thank you. Let me look. I see here that you had severe sinusitis two to three months ago, is that correct? Patient
sentence: Is that what they call my nasal problems? Doctor: Yes, it is true. Sinusitis is the inflammation of your nasal airways. Patient: I see. Thank you for describing it to me. Patient: No problem. Could you describe to me what you felt two to three months ago? Patient: Yes, I can. My face would be uncomfortable, my nose was stifled, my eyes hurt, and I felt something you left in the back of my throat. Patient: Have you ever received any medicines?
Is there anyone who lives with you at home? You're going to need someone to help you take care of your injury. Patient: My wife lives at home with me. She can help me change my bandages.

person: I forgot what the operation was, but he says it in my report. Doctor
sentence: I'm looking at it right now. It looks like you've had a PermCath inserted three times and you've received peritoneal dialysis.
So, what's going on with you? Patient: I had the knee replacement for my two knees three years ago and now I have some pain. Doctor: OK and in one or two knees? Patient: Both. Doctor: OK.
Hi! Patient: Hello! Doctor: How do you feel now? Patient: I feel good. Doctor: Yes, it seems that your condition is improving. Patient: Yes, I think so too.

And who do we see today? Guest_family_2: He complained about severe belly pain and he was crying all the time. We are worried as he is a special child. He has autism. Doctor: How long? Guest_family_2: Autism? Doctor: No, I mean when did he start complaining about belly pain? Guest_family_2: He started last night. Doctor: Oh ok, let me check it out. Did he have nausea or vomiting? Guest_family: Yes, he threw a lot and refused to eat or drink anything. Doctor: And then he complains about belly pain? Guest_family_2: He started last night.

Hello, nice to meet you, miss. I'll take care of you today. Before I start, can I get to know you a little? I like to know who I'm dealing with. Patient: Hello, happy to meet you. Of course. Hum, what can I say? I'm a recent widow. My husband came by when we were married for only eight years. I'm also retired and I love every minute. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that, but I'm glad you're happy after retirement. You celebrate your endless days with a drink or cigarette? Patient: No, I don't smoke. I drink occasionally, but it's very rare. Doctor: Do you have children with whom you spend your time? Patient: I have three wonderful children.
What are your treatments to treat your asthma? Patient: I use my Albuterol inhaler.
Do you eat three meals a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you think these meals add up to about two thousand calories a day? Patient: I would say yes.

Do you still take Micronase every morning? Patient: Yes, I take um two points five M G once a day. Doctor: Great. Keep taking Micronase by mouth every day. As for your infection, I want you to start taking Bactrim twice a day. I will prescribe thirty pills. It will be Bactrim four hundred M G and eighty M G tablets.
Do you consume any type of tobacco? Patient: No. Doctor: And smoking? Patient: No, I never did. Doctor: Any kind of alcohol consumption? Patient: No.

How long have you had these headaches? Doctor: Where do you feel your headaches? Patient: Here, between my eyes. Doctor: How would you describe your symptoms? Patient: I would say it's like a feeling of pressure. Doctor: What is the intensity of these headaches? Patient: Uh, they're relatively severe, I guess. Doctor: Do these headaches interfere with your ability to do your activities? Patient: Yes, they do. My regular activities are much more difficult now. Doctor: Do you have an congestion of the sinuses? Patient: Yes, I do. I also have a slight sensitivity. Doctor: Are you stressed at work? Patient: Yes, I have a very stressful job. Doctor: Are you sleeping well? Patient: Do you have a congestion of the sinuses? Patient: Yes, I do it.
Do you have any medical problems that I should know? Patient: No, not that I know. Doctor: So there is no history of depression, cancer, or high blood pressure? Patient: No, it doesn't sound at all.
I have stomach pain. Doctor: Hm, nausea or vomiting? Patient: Yes, both.
Have you experienced any mental difficulties or confusion? Patient: No. Doctor: No hallucination? Do you see a hearing thing that is not real? Patient: No.
