Hello, with which sex do you identify? Patient: Hello, doctor, thank you for asking, I identify as a woman. Doctor: Very good, thank you. Have you ever had a surgery on this knee? Patient: Yes, I actually did a C L reconstruction in March of two thousand eight. Um, it didn't work well, so they did a review at the end of this year, in December. Doctor: I see, thank you. And your body top? Is there a history of surgery there? Patient: In fact, yes, I had surgery on my arm when I was six years old.

What are you doing to work? Patient: I am a university professor at the top of the hill. Doctor: What are you teaching? Patient: I teach history and the Bible. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol or use tobacco products? Patient: No. I do not participate in any of these activities.

Do you have any major medical problems that I should know? Patient: Yes, I have a history of thyroid problems, in fact. Doctor: I see here that you also have a history of allergies, is that correct? Patient: Oh yes, that's correct too.
How is the patient? Doctor: It is stable. Heart rate sixty-five. Normal rhythm. Oxygen ninety-seven percent on room air.

I think three weeks ago for recurrent urinary infections. Doctor: Yes, it says here that you have bladder problems for a long time, mainly related to tone and ability. Patient: Yes, that's why they put me in catheter. Doctor: Okay and you have recently had the right side C V A? Patient: Yes, because of my heart problems, they had to put pacemaker in it. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I have hereditary diabetes. Doctor: Okay and your neuronal problem is also associated with that. Patient: That's true. Patient: You have pains on the right side now? Patient: Yes, because of my stroke. Doctor: And you are also taking thyroid medications? Patient: Yes, for my hypothyroidism. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Yes. Patient: What procedures have you had in the past? Patient: I have had many exact surgerys. They've taken my bladder, and now they've been put out of the biliary bladder.

Do you have any major medical problems in your family history that you know? Patient: No, there's nothing to report. Doctor: So, there's no history of arthritis or cancer you know about? Patient: No, not what I know.

So is high blood pressure in your family? Patient: Uh, no, it's just me. Doctor: Okay and it was your first time? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Because I'm looking at your previous graphics and I don't see it mentioned before. Patient: Oh yes, the first time he's reached that level. I've never had a high blood pressure problem before.

Now, let's talk about your family history. Have they had cancer? Patient: In fact, yes, I know that some family members had it, but I don't remember who had what kind. Doctor: It's good. What about heart disease? Can you remember someone who had it? Pattor: Yes, it sounds like a few bells. Doctor: Thank you, someone in your family has had a joint replacement? Pattor: I know that a lot of my family has had arthritis in the past, but I don't remember whether or not they had joint replacements, honestly.

So, what brings you here? Patient: Um, I developed this painful ulcer on my hip. Doctor: Oh, let me look at it. On what side? Patient: On my right hip. Doctor: Okay, I see it. It looks like you've developed a pressure ulcer.
Okay, tell me what's going on and what's brought you here.
I am her mother. She has this blister on the side of her head right above her ear, here. I was just worried and concerned about my baby.
How old is the baby? When did you first notice it?

She is just fourteen days old. Let me tell you from the beginning. On Friday, when I was taking her for a bath, I noticed a blister near her umbilicus area. We went to our doctor on Saturday, and they did a test.
Did you get the test result?
I got it today. Here is the report.
Okay, let me have a look. It says she is having a growing M R S A.
Yeah, I've been diagnosed with that too. And I am on medications. I had it on my buttock area.
Okay, so you know about it, and I don't have to explain it more.
Yeah.
So how is the blister on the umbilicus now?

She has been doing good. We put on some bacitracin ointment, and it almost healed up. But today I noticed that another small blister on her head. It really scared me, and I did not want to take any chance. That's why I reached out to the Infectious Disease center. I know it is private. But still, I don't want to take any chance with my baby's health. I called the center directly and they asked me to come to the hospital.
You did good. I will start the treatment. How are her eating and sleeping habits?
She hasn't missed any of her meals. She is taking around two ounces of milk in every feed. I don't think I have any issues with her eating or sleeping.
Did she have any fever?
Not that I noticed.
Has she been lethargic or crying more than normal?
No.
Any other changes in her daily routine that you might have noticed?
No, I didn't notice any changes.

I suffer. I receive these frequent episodes of pain and discomfort in my head. Doctor: Is it on any side of the head or is it on the whole? Patient: Sometimes it is on the whole and other times just on one side. Doctor: This seems to be a migraine.

person: I had problems with his appetite. Doctor
sentence: Well, can you tell me more about your son, madam? Guest_family: Of course, he's six years old now, and we're here to follow his medication A D H D. Doctor: He took Adderall, right? How long did he take that? Guest_family: It was about a month ago. Doctor: How did he respond to the Adderall? Guest_family: The first day he took, honestly, he was wonderful. There was a lot of improvement in his behavior, and it went really well, so far. Doctor: It's great! Guest_family: Yes, but I have two concerns. When he takes the first thing in the morning, it seems to take some time to get home, and then he got two P M and he has problems in the evening. Doctor: He had problems with his appetite?

What are you doing to live? Patient: At this moment, I am a temporary employee for A B C A B C C, I have worked for A B C D, too. Doctor: What are you doing here? Patient: Mainly, I have loaded and unloaded furniture and appliances for people's homes. Doctor: It is a difficult job. When have you been injured? Patient: About two and a half weeks ago, in October. Doctor: Do you have a history of back problems, as before this injury? Patient: Yes, I have had pain in my back for a long time.

Is there a family medical history? Patient: I have a complete list. See, my aunt had a stroke. My doctor had heart problems like my mother, who died of a heart attack at sixty-three years old. My father had some kind of cancer. I don't know exactly what. And my sisters have problems with blood pressure. Doctor: Wow, that's sure it's a list.
Does he have known drug allergies? Guest_family: No.

Does he still have any problems with his hypothyroidism and his onychomycosis? Guest_family: Yes, he is the right doctor. Doctor: Has he remained in complaint with his Lamisil? Guest_family: Yes, he took six weeks of that without any problem. Doctor: Well, so we will do a blood test at L T today. Guest_family: Why is it this doctor? Doctor: Well, on his last appointment in April, he had a high level of T S H. So we should check it today. Guest_family: Yes, I remember. Doctor: Did he take his Levothroid every day too? Guest_family: Yes, he does, he does not like that, but I should help him, and he eventually takes it.
Do you have any questions about your surgery? Patient: Yes, I do, multiple. Doctor: Go ahead, shoot. Patient: I wrote them all about it.
What about drugs, alcohol or tobacco? Patient: No, no, no, no.
So you no longer have nausea or vomiting? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: How about acidity? Patient: I think it's better. Doctor: Great.
How are you? Patient: I am good. Doctor: This is great. You are stable. Patient: Can I go home now? Doctor: Yes, you can. Patient: Thank you!

Can you tell me more about your son, please? Guest_family: Well, he's seven years old, and he's had diarrhea for four days, and he's been vomiting for three days. Patient: Yes, my brother did this too. Guest_family: We had a little chicken one day, and then we had more of it the next day. After they ate they started to feel bad and still feel bad. Doctor: How many times did he have diarrhea a day from that beginning? Guest_family: Well, it was about five or six times a day during the last four days. Doctor: How many times did he vomit a day? Guest_family: Um, it was frequent. Doctor: Has he vomited today? Patient: No, I didn't have it today. Doctor: Did he go to the bathroom today? Patient: Yes, I pissed this morning. Doctor: He had symptoms of fever?

Welcome to the clinic! I would like to start with your medical history. Patient: I have high blood pressure and macular deterioration. Last year I caught pneumonia but it became clear. Doctor: Okay. What brings you today? Patient: I had this cough and pain on the right side of my abdomen. Doctor: How long did it last? Patient: Two days. I had bodily pain and felt sick too. Doctor: Did you have a fever? Patient: I think so. I was cold and my forehead was hot. The cough is a dry cough. Doctor: Did abdominal pain occur during one of these cough episodes? Patient: Yes.

person: I need how long this knee hurts you? Patient
sentence: Well, since the fall of two thousand seven. Doctor: Have you seen another doctor for that? Patient: Mom, can you tell the doctor? Guest_family: Yes, we actually went to another orthopedist in November of two thousand seven. Doctor: I see, and what did this doctor recommend? Guest_family: We have an MRI, I have a disk with the images, and the report as well here, if you want to take a look. Doctor: Thank you, yes, it shows left patellar chondromalacia. Was it much harder to eat at P T?
What brings you here today? Patient: I have pain in my stomach. Doctor: When did you notice it for the first time? Patient: He suddenly started around noon.

What brings you to see me? Patient: I have had pain and stiffness on the neck and shoulder. Doctor: How long does it last? Patient: Perhaps for about four months. Doctor: During the last four months, your symptoms have worsened or improved? Patient: Pain has worsened at night. It wakes me up at night. I have not had a good night's sleep in four months. Doctor: Have you had pain or numbness in your arm, wrist or hand? Patient: Yes! About two weeks after the beginning of the pain, I had some numbness and painful cramps in both fingers. Doctor: The right hand and the first and second finger? Patient: Yes.

How many times have you been pregnant, including miscarriages or abortions, if any? Patient: I have been pregnant twice in total. No miscarriages or abortions. Doctor: When have you been your last period? Patient: About a month ago. Doctor: And how would you describe your period? Light, normal, heavy? Patient: Nice normal. Doctor: No abnormal smear of Dad? Patient: No, fortunately they have all been normal. Doctor: It's wonderful to hear. And my last question for you is if you have ever had a mammography? Patient: I haven't had one before. Do I have one? I have just been thirty nine years old. What is the recommended age again? Doctor: It depends. For example, the recommended age would be younger for someone with a family history of breast cancer.

person: Okay, I want you to follow our doctor X therapist to his office A B C D in one to two weeks. Patient
sentence: Okay, I'll make an appointment today.

person: I would like to know how you maintain your blood sugar. Patient
sentence: I checked my blood sugar level once or twice a day. Patient: Yes, but I need to be better. Patient: Do you have the newspaper with you today? Patient: Yes, actually it's just here. Let me catch it for you. Patient: Very good. Patient: Thank you. Patient: Thank you. And have you looked at your cholesterol intake since blood work? Your labs show that your cholesterol levels are a little high. I would like you to monitor your cholesterol and go to another set of laboratories before our next visit. Patient: Do I need to fast for this? Patient: Yes, you will need to fast. I would recommend that you go early in the morning before eating a breakfast. Patient: It sounds like a good plan. Patient: And like your sinusitis, how do you feel since you finished your course on antibiotics.

What brings you today? Patient: My back started to hurt last night. I have stomach pain. I have had pain with urination for two days. Doctor: Do you have any other symptoms? Patient: I just coughed and now I have fever. Doctor: Do you have a history of kidney stones? Patient: Yes. I had kidney stones less than a year ago. I had a urinary infection at the same time. It was horrible.

When did she have lumbar discrimination? Doctor: A little over a year ago. She received an anti-biotherapy and ended up having a debridement and instrumentation with Dr. XYZ. Guest_clinician: How is she today? Doctor: Really good. Guest_clinician: She also had an EP with this previous hospitalization, right? Doctor: Yes.

Do you have problems with sugar or blood pressure? Patient: Oh, I have high blood pressure, but it is well under control. I make sure to keep it in a normal range. Doctor: Good. Other health problems? Patient: Yes, I have a history of high triglycerides.

Hello, Miss. The nurse who sat you tells me that you are here for a second opinion on surgery. Patient: Hello, Doctor. Yes, I was told that both eyes need cataract extraction. I came for a second opinion because I will only have surgery if necessary. I am nervous. Doctor: What is the reason for the extraction? Patient: I am not exactly sure because the other doctors said a lot of medical terms. I had a laser in my eyes however. It was for macular degeneration. Doctor X said that I had age-related neurovascular macular degeneration. Doctor: Do you know which laser you had on your eyes? Patient: No. I just know that the laser was made by Dr. X four times to the macula on the right and twice to the left.

person: I'm trying to remember the name. It's an analgesic that starts with an L. Oh Lortab. Doctor
sentence: What happens when you take Lortab? Patient: Really bad urticaria. I've never taken it once. Doctor: I'll take note of this in your file so that we have it in your files.
Do you have known drug allergies? Patient: No, none I know.

I was smoking like a fireplace. I quit smoking some time ago. I had been smoking for about sixteen years. Doctor: It's great! When did you quit? Patient: I quit in nineteen-twenty-four years. It's also the year I stopped drinking. Doctor: What was the reason I stopped drinking? Patient: I had an alcohol problem. I'm in A. I'm in A. I've been in A since I stopped. Thank God. I've been through treatment all those years. I started going to A and I had my life together. Doctor: Do you have a history of recreational drug use or I V? Patient: Yes. I was taking pills, but I never had injectable drugs. Thank God. I've been through treatment all those years.

Hello, tell me about your family? Has anyone had any medical illnesses? Patient: My two parents were in good health, but my maternal grandfather had a stroke. Doctor: Has anyone in your family ever had any headaches? Patient: No, not that I know.

Do you have any chronic medical problems that I should know? Patient: What do you mean by that, Doctor? Doctor: Well, it could be anything from high blood pressure, depression, cancer. Do some of these familiar sounds? Patient: Oh, yes, I have some things like that. I have anaemia, high cholesterol, and, uh, hypothyroidism.

You are here today because you have difficulties of vision? Tell me what is happening, madame. Patient: Yes. It all started a year ago. It started with losing color in my vision. Doctor: Was the loss sudden or progressive? Patient: Gradual. And now I'm starting to have a blurred vision. Doctor: When did this start? Patient: I noticed it two months ago. Doctor: Is the blurred vision all blurred or is there a blind angle of blurred vision. Patient: It's a blurred vision and then I have a blind angle in my right eye. Doctor: Have you had any fluctuations of your symptoms over the last year? Do you have a vision back? Patient: Some days, I feel like a little better, but not much.
How do you feel today? Patient: I had trouble breathing. I had a oppression in my chest after climbing the stairs. Doctor: Let me listen to your lungs.

person: I didn't have a problem today. Patient
sentence: Well, I had a history of systemic lupus erythematosus? Patient: How were you treated for that in the past? Patient: Um, I went to a rheumatologist about four months ago, I had discomfort in both my hands. Patient: What hand was worse? Patient: My left was worse than my right at that time. Patient: Did you see anyone else for that? Patient: Um, I came on October 30th two thousand seven. I had the same problem. Patient: What did they do for you at that time? Patient: They did a trial of Elavil because they thought your patient was, uh, ulnar or radial neuropathy. Patient: Did they start to have topical creams? Patient: Yes, they gave me a prescription for Zostrix but I couldn't fill it because you had another patient.
Do you remember the name of the medication you are taking? Patient: I have two, but I don't remember their name or why I'm taking it.

I wanted to talk to you about your family medical history. Patient: Okay, how will it be useful? Doctor: Family history plays an invaluable role in your health. It provides us with important clues and insight to predict and detect diseases before obvious symptoms appear. Patient: My mother had a long time with anxiety and stress disorder.

Does anyone in your family have high blood pressure or high cholesterol levels? Patient: My two parents have high blood pressure. Doctor: Are they treated for this? Patient: Hum yes. Oh they also have E T. Doctor: Does one of your brothers and sisters have it too? Patient: No. Doctor: Does anyone in your family have an autoimmune disorder. Patient: Hm. Give me a second to think. Does lupus count? Doctor: Yes. Who do you know who has lupus? Patient: My cousin. Doctor: On your mother's or father's side? Patient: Uh mom.
What do you take as maintenance treatment? Patient: Oh, I take Flonase. Doctor: And do you have a lot of problems after taking this? Patient: No. Doctor: That's good.

I stayed relatively the same. My main complaint is that I feel tired throughout the day. The C P A P is doing well and I wake up refreshed, but I don't like how I crash. Doctor: Okay. How are the thyroid problems? Patient: I seem to be fine. My thyroid gland doesn't seem enlarged and I can breathe as normal. No fever or anything. Doctor: Have you experienced any of the following situations: temperature intolerance, palpitations, muscle weakness, tremors, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhoea? Patient: Nothing like it. Doctor: How was the weight? Patient: He was stable. Doctor: Any muscle weakness closest to the center of the body? Patient: No, nothing at all. Not bad for forty-five.

So I understand that you had a fainting episode yesterday? Patient: Yes, I did. Doctor: Did this happen to you before? Patient: Yes. It happens when needles are involved. Doctor: You had a Syncope Vasovagal. How do you feel today? Patient: I feel normal today.
Hello, how are you? Patient: I'm not so good. Doctor: Oh, what's going on with you? Patient: Well, I have a lot of swelling in my legs. Doctor: Hm, okay.

What brings you to see me today? Patient: I had this pain in my finger and wrist for about a month. I had some numbness too. The numbness started in the finger and is now in the wrist too. Doctor: What wrist and what finger is it that hurts? Patient: The left finger and the middle finger, here. Doctor: How long was the procreation of the numbness of the finger to the wrist? Patient: It started when I woke up and then at the end of the day my wrist was numbed too. Patient: When did you begin to feel pain in the wrist area? Patient: A few days after the numbness started. Patient: What hand is your dominant? Patient: I am left-handed? Patient: What are you doing for work? Patient: I am cook.
Hello. How do you feel today? Patient: I feel good, considering. I slept well last night. Doctor: Do you exempt from pain or discomfort? Patient: No. I feel good.

person: I hope things will come back to normal soon. Doctor
sentence: So you're here for your breast exam. Patient: Yes, it was due for so long. Doctor: I'm going to touch both breasts one by one to check for any mass or mass. OK? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Both of them look good. Do you feel any pain while I touch? Patient: No, I don't feel any pain. Doctor: It's good, no mass, no pain and I don't feel anything in your armpit.

person: I think the last time I saw her was two weeks ago. She told me about the renovation that you did around the house. Patient
sentence: She's fine, thank you. Oh yes, the renovation was a lot. I didn't think it would take as long as it did. Patient: Yes, it can take a bit of time. We remodeled our kitchen three years ago and it turned our lives backwards. So tell me, how is the training going for you? I think you were telling me that you have a five k coming in. Patient: Yes, two weeks ago. I did jogging and cross country track about five times a week. I also raise twice a week on my best days. Doctor: It's great! And I don't like to smoke or drink, right? Patient: No. Doctor: How does the work treat you? Patient: Quite good in fact. I go to the allergy and immunology clinic four days later. I like my hours to be flexible.

My nurse told me that you were thirty-four years old, is that correct? Patient: Yes, I just had my birthday, doctor. Doctor: You identify yourself as African-American, correct? Patient: Yes, that's correct, sir. Doctor: Are you here for a follow-up? What brings you back today? Patient: Well, I don't really have an acute complaint, but I have a muscle sprain on my upper back. Doctor: Is there an injury associated with this pain, ma'am? Patient: I think it has to do with me by lifting weights. Doctor: Yes, it's common. Is it spoiling your ability to work? Patient: No, it's not really. Doctor: What are you doing to live? Patient: I am a householder, it's my profession. Doctor: Do you have trouble sleeping at night? Patient: Yes, it's not serious, but I'm taking problems.

When did you have your last menstrual period? Patient: My last period was the first two thousand and four months of June. Doctor: Are you sexually active? Is there a possibility of pregnancy? Patient: No! There is no possibility that I was pregnant. I did not have sex in two years. Doctor: How old were you when you had your first menstrual period? Patient: I was ten years old when I had my first period. My cycle was never regular. It works on my mother's side of the family. Doctor: What are your family history of reproductive health on your mother's side of the family? Patient: My mother and aunt both had total hysterectomys. Doctor: Is there any other personal medical history I should know? Patient: I see Dr. X Y Z Allen for my abnormal heart valve disease.

person: I've been constipated since I was here. Doctor
sentence: I'll notice that. Vomiting since February nineteen out of two thousand seven. I'm sorry to hear that. I'm going to make a change to the medication and bring you something for the constipation problem. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Have you had a shortness of breath, chest pain or a cough of blood? Patient: No. Doctor: Any joint pain, headache or skin rash? Patient: No. Just a rash where the bandages are as I said earlier. I also want to discuss this acne while I'm here. I've had it for about two years.
Does anyone in your family have a neurological disorder? Patient: No, not to my knowledge.
Are you smoking, sir? Patient: Well, I did it a long time ago, but I don't do it anymore. Doctor: Well, and alcohol, you drink? Patient: Well, my wife and I have a drink or two a day.
Have you had any medical problems in the past? Patient: No, nothing major. Doctor: You didn't say anything major, so, what was there? Patient: I had a little curve in the spine. It wasn't major.

Do you have any medical problems I should have? Patient: Yes, I have chronic diarrhea, and C O P D. Doctor: Are you a smoker? Patient: Yes, I have been a long time. Doctor: How would you characterize your level of smoking? Patient: Hum, I would say it's quite heavy.
Do you have atrial fibrillation from the past? Patient: Yes, the rhythm problem is bad. Doctor: And no dizziness? Patient: Yes. I do. Doctor: Ok well...
Do you have allergies? Patient: No allergies. Doctor: Nothing? Cat skin, pollen? Patient: No.

Do you have children? Patient: We had six children all together, but two of them died suddenly. Doctor: I am sorry to hear that. How old were they? Patient: One was forty years old and the other was forty-five years old. Doctor: Wow, they were quite young. I offer you my most sincere condolences. Patient: Thank you. It's really hard for my family, but we try to manage ourselves. Doctor: That's all you can do. It's important to spend time with others every chance you get. Patient: Exactly. Doctor: I have a few questions to ask before ending today. Patient: Go ahead. Doctor: Do you have a family history of medical problems? Patient: No. Doctor: You smoke or drink? Patient: Never.

So let's see here. A history of high blood pressure or diabetes? Patient: No, sir. Doctor: What about heart disease? Patient: No, no heart disease. Doctor: And no cancer? Patient: No and for that I am grateful.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My father had Alzheimer's disease. He's in an institution that looks after him now. Doctor: I'm sorry it must be hard. Patient: She's my aunt, her sister helped me put everything in place for him. She had a stroke last month. Doctor: Oh no. How's she doing now? Patient: She's home now but her husband needs to help take care of her. Doctors said it's good for her to have a complete or almost complete recovery. Doctor: It's a relief. Patient: Yes, it's true! Doctor: Any other family health problem you know? Patient: No what I don't know.

How long are you in prison, young man? Patient: I have about three weeks left, sir. Twenty-five days, if you want to be exact. Doctor: Well, the time to do your best to get out, right? Patient: Absolutely, I don't want to go back. Doctor: Good. You smoke, young man? Patient: No, absolutely not.
Hello, I am Doctor Rez. I will ask you a few questions about your personal and family history, okay?
Yes, that's okay.
Did any one in your family get diagnosed with any medical conditions?
My mom has lumps in her breast but it is benign, however my granny on my father side had cancer.
What kind of cancer, do you know?
Well, it was breast cancer don't know if there are types for it.
No, that's fine. Did you ever have palpitations?
What do you mean by that?
Um, Palpitations means the sensation when you feel that your heart is racing or pounding really fast even without doing any strenuous exercise or anything.
Oh, got it. No, I never had that.
What about any uncontrolled urine leakage? Any accidents?
No.
What about any recent sudden hair loss or any other concerns?
No, nothing like that.
Any other treatments in the past?
Yeah, I recently got treatment for my sinus.

On average, how many packs a day have you smoked? Patient: Uh if I guess, I would say one pack a day. Doctor: Other medicines? Patient: I used to do coke, but I stopped that in two thousand five. Doctor: And any story of drinking? Patient: Um I used to drink one pint a day, but I stopped drinking more than ten years ago.

I'm sorry to hear that, ma'am, how old were they? Patient: Well, my father was eighty years old, and my mother was sixty-seven years old. Doctor: I'm sorry, do you have brothers and sisters? Patient: Yes, I had a brother, he died, too, from bone cancer and throat. Doctor: I'm sorry, how old was he? Patient: He was seventy years old, doctor. Doctor: Do you have children? Patient: I have four, two of each. Doctor: It's wonderful, how are your sons? Patient: They're thirty-seven and thirty-eight, and they're both very good. Doctor: It's great, what about your daughters? Patient: They're sixty-eight and fifty-eight years old, and they all have cancers.

Are you married? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Where do you work? Patient: I work as secretary in a law firm. Doctor: Do you smoke or drink? Have you ever tried an illegal medicine? Patient: No, none of these.

It seems that E M S found you in bad condition? Patient: What? Guest_family: My mother is hard of hearing. She is eighty-five years old. They found her on the toilet. Doctor: Did your mother tell you about her condition before the arrival of E M S? Guest_family: She said she vomits just before they came and she had diarrhea. Doctor: Ma'am. How do you feel now? Patient: I was sick of my stomach. My stomach was injured. I vomit. Doctor: How many times did you vomit, ma'am? Patient: I don't know. Doctor: Do you remember the color of vomit? Have you seen blood or notice the color of vomit? Pattor: I don't know.

Do you have children, madam? Patient: Yes, I do. I have two sons and we adopted a daughter. Doctor: Where have you adopted? Patient: Right here. Doctor: and you are married right? Work? Patient: Yes, I have been married for a long time. I have retired from Avon. Doctor: Do you smoke cigarettes or drink? Patient: I do not smoke or drink alcohol.

How's the little guy? Guest_family: He has fever and bad congestion during the last two days. He's had fever for one. I'm trying to suck the discharge through the nose. Doctor: I guess he has some breathing problems during the diet. Guest_family: Yes, that's right. He drinks milk every two hours, only ten minutes instead of twenty minutes. Guest_family: He has fever too, so she gave him Tylenol. Guest_family2: He's very restless. Doctor: Is he sleeping well? Guest_family: Yes, he's sleeping. But he's not able to breathe well even with albuterol. Doctor: What's wrong with diarrhea and dirty diapers? Guest_family: He pisses less because he had between eight and ten wet diapers, but now it's up to four hours a day.
Do you take Benicar? Patient: Yes, twenty a day. Doctor: And what else? Patient: I take multivitamin, glucosamine, vitamin B complex, vitamin E and low-dose aspirin.
Do you smoke? Patient: Nope. Doctor: How to take alcohol? Patient: Nope. Doctor: What about any form of drug use? Patient: Nope.

Do you have bone pain or problems around it? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: So they gave you a dose of Tylenol here in the emergency department to treat your pain. Is your pain under control? Patient: Yes, with drugs I feel it's better, but I want to be removed from the back part. Doctor: Okay, we're going to take you down. Yes, your C T scans from the abdomen appeared normal. And there was no sign of bleeding. I think you just have a contusion and abrasion to the abdomen of the seat belt and probably airbag as well. Patient: Oh ok. Doctor: It's good that you can stand up and walk in the emergency department without difficulty. I don't see any abrasion or laceration. Patient: Yes, nothing like this and I can walk.

Let's talk about your family history, do cancer run in your family, ma'am? Patient: Oh yes! My family has a history of lung, liver and prostate cancer. Doctor: Oh wow! Patient: Yes. Doctor: And you mentioned that your mother had Alzheimer's? Patient: Well, I'm not sure about Alzheimer's, but she had a dementing disease. She started when she was in her eighties. It was a kind of mild case. Patient: And she really died in her eighties because of her age. Doctor: Ok, and your brothers and sisters, do they have Alzheimer's signs? Patient: No, they're fine. Doctor: Ok.

What are their medical history? Doctor: Here I have hypertension, diabetes, diabetic retinopathy, and elevated lipids. They are in post C V A. Guest_clinician: Do you know their neurologist? Doctor: I can have the nurse or scribe enter and ask again. Guest_clinician: Great.

Did you get a story from her? Doctor: I tried, but I failed. She is very out of him. Guest_clinician: Does she have a history of alcohol abuse? Doctor: According to her records, she has a long history of alcohol abuse.
The patient has a history of C A D. Guest_clinician: Are they followed by a cardiologist? Doctor: Not to my knowledge. I can check their electronic medical records. One second.

Hello sir, how old are you? Patient: I am thirty years old. Doctor: We are following your moderate to severe apnea today, aren't we? Patient: Yes, that's right, I still can't sleep. Doctor: Okay and you've done the CPAP? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, let's go over it today. Patient: Of course.
Are you married? Patient: Yes, I am. Patient: I have three stepchildren and one of my own children and I work for A B C D.

Do you have cramps or clots? Patient: No, fortunately, I don't. Doctor: What is the color of your discharge, ma'am? Patient: Well, it went from red to brown, and now its kind of yellowish. Doctor: Okay, have you ever had sex again? Patient: No, we wait a little longer. Doctor: Do you go to the bathroom regularly? Patient: Regularly? Yes, but I suffer with it, and then from time to time I have some sharp red bleeding. Doctor: Are you constipated? Patient: No, I'm not too much. Guest_family: She didn't eat her vegetables as she should. Doctor: This will also do. Patient: Well, well, my eyes are constipated? Patient: No, I don't have too many allergies.

Do you have any major medical problems in your family that I should know? Patient: What do you mean by that? Doctor: Well, it could be anything, from diabetes to hypertension to cancer. Patient: Oh, yes. My brother had prostate cancer.

I'm so sorry. Tell me about your back. Patient: Three nights ago, I fell on my steps bringing back the car races. Doctor: How did you land when you fell? Patient: I fell and fell on my right hip. I hit my bottom on the ramp. Doctor: I would like the imaging to be done today. Patient: OK.

Have you seen the results of your laboratory? Patient: No, do you have those of today? Doctor: Yes, I have them right here. They are essentially negative, except it seems you had C difficult in the past. Do you remember? Patient: Yes, I had it when I worked in a hospital after I graduated. Doctor: Yes, it is unfortunately more common there.

person: Breathe in breath, let me tap and see. Well, your lungs seem clear. Patient
sentence: Okay.

Do you still take Trizivir? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How much do you take? Patient: I take one pill twice a day. Doctor: Do you take other medicines? Patient: I take Ibuprofen for body pain from time to time, but that's all.

I fell with my two arms stretched out, but I fell mainly on my left shoulder. Doctor: Where is your pain in the left shoulder? Patient: Above all, he is in the back of my shoulder. Doctor: He moves a little back, what about the right shoulder? Patient: He really hurts yesterday, but it's gone now. Doctor: Well, do you have a pain in the front of the shoulder? Patient: No sir, I have nothing there. Doctor: Well, why not a weakness? Is there a weakness in the shoulder? Patient: No, it's not very weak at all. Doctor: Well, do you have a pain in the shoulder? Patient: No sir, I have nothing there. Doctor: Well, what's the weakest thing?

person: I made an appointment with the behavioral specialist of the lower syndrome that you recommended from the last time we were here. Doctor
sentence: It's great. Keep me informed of his progress. His blood came back showing a subactive thyroid. This explains the recent weight gain and fatigue. I would like to start with a medicine called levothyroxine. We'll have to check his leeches again in a month to see how his thyroid responds to the medication. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have any other concerns today? Guest_family: Yes. She has this toenail that looks strange and discoloured. Doctor: Let me look. Can you remove your socks for me? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Is this nail? Guest_family: Yes. Doctor: It's very common. It's called Onychomycosis.

Have you ever had an operation, ma'am? Patient: Actually, yes, I did a skinning operation on both my ears. Doctor: Do you remember how old you were when you had an operation? Patient: Uh, I was five or six years old. It was when I was a child, I know it well.
Do you have allergies? Patient: Not what I know. Doctor: Okay.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My father has high blood pressure. My mother has had a ton of skin cancer removed. Doctor: Do you know what type of skin cancer she has removed? Patient: I have no idea.

Yes, of course. Doctor: I just want to check if you have symptoms that can possibly raise the alarm. Patient: I come to you during the last fifteen of my seventy-eight years on Earth. I know how a follow-up works. Doctor: You are a seasoned veteran. Okay. So how is your chest? Any pain or oppression? Patient: No, fortunately I don't have that. Doctor: Does your heart beat well? Do you feel that it beats too fast or hard? Patient: No. I can't really feel my heart rate normally, but I guess it's better than feeling it beat constantly. Doctor: You're right. You shouldn't notice it. How do you sleep? Patient: Sleeping was good. I sleep all night. Doctor: Super. Any shortness of breath that makes you wake up? Patient: No. I don't have breath at any other time of the day.

My name is Doctor X and I will take care of you today. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I was told that you would like a refill on your Xanax prescription and something to help you break your habit of smoking. Patient: Yes, I feel like I've tried everything in the book and I still can't break the habit. One of my friends was talking to me about this medication called Clantix or something like that. Doctor: Yes, I've heard about Chantix. We can look in there and see what's best. Patient: Okay, great. Since I came home, I've been out of Xanax. Doctor: How long have you been taking it? Patient: Almost a year now.
Are you allergic to anything? Doctor: Like any medicine? Patient: No, I'm not allergic to anything. Doctor: Perfect! Patient: Hm.

person: I mean, I'm so happy to see your report today, your blood pressure seems much better. It's amazing since your few past visits your BP was out of control and even with changing your medication we had a hard time dropping it. Patient
sentence: Yes, I feel much better, I read about my condition and it's called something like um refraction or-- Doctor: Refractory Hypertension. Patient: Oh yes! Doctor: But the good news is that it's better. Patient: Yes. Doctor: The last time we talked about seeing the internal doctor there in your upper center, no? Patient: Yes, I made an appointment last week, uh, no week before, but I completely forgot that.
Have you ever visited a hospital for any operation? Patient: No.
How are you today? Patient: I'm doing well. Doctor: How did you keep your hemoglobin levels between four and five precent six points? Patient: I'm doing well. I was able to keep it in this fork.

So, are you married, ma'am? Patient: Well, no, I'm not. My husband and I have a divorce. Doctor: I am sorry to hear this, do you have children? Patient: It's good, it was for the best. Yes, I have two. Doctor: Do you live with any of them? Patient: Yes, uh, I live with my son right now. Doctor: Do you smoke or drink? Patient: No, I don't.

What is the problem today, young woman? Patient: Well, I have a lot of headaches, I feel it in my face. Doctor: Does it look like pressure? Patient: This, and I have the sniffs. Doctor: What other symptoms did you have? Patient: Hum, well, last night I had a sore throat, and I coughed up phlegm. Doctor: Interesting, anything else? Patient: Um, I had a rash on my face, back and arms for about three days. Doctor: Is it it it itching? Patient: Yes, so we take a lot of Benadryl. Doctor: I see, you go to school? Patient: I was, there was a lot of fifth disease this year.

Have you had any surgery in the past? Patient: Yes, I had a partial withdrawal of my ovaries and then I also had my appendix removed. Doctor: OK something else? Patient: Yes, I also had my belly sewn. Doctor: OK.

Hello, young man. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: How old are you, young man? Pattor: I'm thirteen, sir. Doctor: Thank you, then, what happened? Pattor: I sliced my right finger with a piece of glass while I was playing with my friends. Doctor: You have to be more careful, young man. What kind of symptoms do you feel in this finger? Pattor: You're right. I have a lot, uh, numbness and tingling in it.

Hello. How do you feel today? Patient: Not so good. I went to a party last night and my chest and body suffered a lot. Doctor: I see. Did you smoke at the party? Patient: No. I never smoked in my life. Doctor: Great. Where on your body does it hurt? Patient: Like my upper right side of my stomach. Doctor: I see. Did you drink alcohol last night? Patient: I had to drive some people home, so I was sober.

And I have to restrict my movement or my activities? Doctor: Um, I've removed the plaster and your foot looks good. I don't want you to restrict your activities, but you're the best judge of the situation. So, I'll advise you to take it slowly and do as much as you can tolerate. Patient: Understood. Thank you, Doctor. Do I need a follow-up? Doctor: As long as you're okay, having no pain, I think we're fine. Patient: Very good bye then. Doctor: Bye.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My father had stomach cancer. Doctor: How old was he when he was diagnosed? Patient: I think he was seventy years old. My sister has breast cancer. She is in her 50s. Doctor: Any family history of cancer of the uterus, ovary or colon? Patient: No.
Do you drink or smoke? Patient: No, I don't. I have to take care of my daughter. She is a widow. Doctor: So do you live with her? Patient: Yes, she lives at home.

I think I need help. Doctor: I'm here to help. Tell me what's going on. Patient: I'm making mood swings, sometimes I feel super happy and sometimes I'm just sad and angry with myself. I find myself in tears thinking about things or situations that are not even real. Doctor: How old are you? Patient: I just finished five decades of my life. Doctor: Did you try to hurt yourself? Patient: No, this thought never came to mind. I just feel sad, like no one cares even if I exist. Sometimes I can conquer the world and do anything that I put my heart and mind on.
Anything else? Patient: Yes, I also remember that I had more fat in my blood.

person: I think this is our first meeting. Patient
sentence: Hello, doctor. Yes, this is my first time. Doctor: Great, how old are you? Patient: I am fifty-five years old, doctor. Doctor: Thank you, what seems to be the problem today? Patient: Well, I have a list of the symptoms of laundry coinciding with my allergies. Doctor: Like what, ma'am? Patient: Well, my sense of taste is diminished, dry mouth, um, acid reflux, and G I problems, and then I have asthma, and reactions to things like aerosols. Doctor: I see, do you have food allergies? Patient: Hum, I think.

What are your family history? Patient: My two parents have died. Doctor: I am sorry to hear it. I am very sorry to hear it. Patient: Thank you. My father died 75 years of leukemia and my mother was a victim of heart problems and alcoholism at 38 years of age. Doctor: Does anyone else in your family suffer from leukemia, heart problems or alcohol abuse? Patient: One of my uncles on my father's side has recently been diagnosed with leukemia. Doctor: Oh, wow. I see.

I have had vomiting several times. Doctor: Have you observed blood? Patient: No. Doctor: All right, any diarrhea? Patient: No, on the contrary, I have constipation from time to time, it really bothers me now. I feel swollen all the time and I do not feel fresh in the morning or all day long. Doctor: Oh, how long have you had this problem? Patient: Two months now. Doctor: Hm, I see, it hurts you to pass the stools? Have you noticed blood? Patient: No. I use suppository. Doctor: Oh, it's great. You do what it takes. In addition to that I give you a strong laxative that you can drink in the morning that it should help. Patient: Ok! Doctor: Any complaint of heartburn or acidity or stomach pain? Patient: No, not really.

Do you take Diovan, Estradiol, Norvasc, Wellbutrin? Patient: Yes, and Wellbutrin is an inhaler. Doctor: Ok if SR inhaler? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you take oxygen therapy at home? Pattor: Yes. Doctor: Ok.

Hello, ma'am. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: How long have you been married to your husband? Pattor: Oh, at that time I don't even know how long it was. Doctor: I guess you live together? Pattor: Yes, we do. Doctor: What are you doing to make a living? Pattor: I'm a school nurse for the school department. I love working with children. Doctor: It's wonderful. Do you drink or smoke? Pattor: No, I don't drink, and I quit smoking cigarettes about twenty-five years ago. Doctor: Good for you.

Any past surgery? Doctor: It seems she had an appendectomy with a total abdominal hysterectomy and a bilateral oophorectomy of salpingo some time ago. Guest_clinician: Ok, noted. Doctor: Oh and it seems that she had a fracture of the right hip in O five after a fall.
Before we begin today, sir, I just need a few pieces of background information. I see here on my chart that you're thirty years old, is that correct?
Yes doctor, that's correct.
Okay, and which hand is your dominant hand?
I use my right hand for everything.
Now, take me through the timeline of your symptoms, please. When did everything start?
I was doing well until July of nineteen ninety three.
What were your initial symptoms?
I began having weakness in my right arm, and there was some neck pain too.
Okay, when these symptoms began, how did you manage them?
At first, I went to a chiropractor, but after a while my arm started atrophying, and my right hand felt tight. I couldn't extend all my fingers out.
Once you noticed the atrophy and contractures, that's the tightness you were experiencing, how were you treated?
After that, I went to a neurosurgeon close to my house, and he ordered an, um, C T scan of my neck.
Okay, do you have the report of that C T Scan with you today?
Yes, doctor, I have it right here. They were one on the twenty fifth of September in ninety two.
Thank you, okay, this shows an intramedullary lesion at C two three, and an extramedullary lesion at C six seven.
That means tumor, right?
Yes sir. Did you have neck surgery?
Yeah, I have the op notes right here.
Okay, just so you know, you had a C six T one laminectomy, and they decompressed the spinal cord. How did you respond to this surgery?
Well, honestly, I improved for about three months following the operation, but after that I just got worse and worse.
Once your symptoms worsened, what happened?
Um, I started having this burning sensation on my left side.
Did you have any weakness, sir?
Yeah, I had weakness in both my arms.
Was one side worse than the other?
Yes, my right side was worse than my left.
In addition to the burning and weakness, did you have any other symptoms?
Um, I had really bad balance, I felt nauseous, like I was going to throw up at all times, which I did do some, and, um, my heart was beating really fast, and my blood pressure went up really high.
After all these symptoms began, how were you treated?
On, um, August thirty first nineteen ninety three I had an M R I of my neck, and I have that report right here, too.
Thank you, this shows diffuse enlargement of the cervical and thoracic spine and multiple enhancing nodules in the posterior fossa.
Sorry to interrupt, what does all that mean?
Well, that's more tumors in the spine. Did you have another surgery for this?
Yeah, I had brain surgery. I have those notes right here, too.
Okay, so you had a suboccipital craniotomy with tumor excision, decompression, and biopsy. The biopsy showed hemangioblastoma.
That's cancer, right? This was all done on September first of nineteen ninety three.
Well no, not exactly, it's a benign tumor. After this surgery how were your symptoms?
I felt good, the doctors said I stabilized out. I went through some radiation procedures from September of ninety three to January nineteenth of ninety four.
How have your symptoms progressed since?
I went to the NeuroOncology clinic on October twenty sixth nineteen ninety five because I was having weakness in both arms and both legs, as well as trouble swallowing food.
How much weakness was there?
It was so bad I couldn't even put on a shirt, or raise my arms, or even feed myself.
Can you go up and down stairs?
No, not really, but I can climb them.
How about going to the bathroom, is everything normal there?
Yeah, no problems there.
Good, and what did the doctor at that clinic recommend?
They were considering doing chemo.

Other allergies than penicillin? Patient: Um no. Doctor: I see here that you have already tolerated cephalosporins without any problem. Do you remember when you were last prescribed penicillin as an antibiotic?

Where are you hurting? Patient: My left elbow. I hit him against a ramp when I was trying to take another ride on my skateboard. Doctor: Did the pain happen gradually? Patient: Yes. I even tried to ice him, but I think it's just getting worse. Doctor: Did you hurt any other parts of your body? Patient: Only my elbow. Doctor: How long did it take? Patient: About a week ago. Doctor: I see. Did you take anything for that, like Advil or Tylenol? Patient: No. I try to deal with the pain as best I can before resorting to medicine.

How long have you been smoking? Patient: No, doc. Doc. Doctor: And how do you smoke? Patient: In truth, I have no interest in doing it with my age. Doctor: I see. I would recommend you to consider nicotine patches because smoking brings with it a lot of health problems. Patient: Tell me something I don't know. Doctor: I understand. Why not another drug use? Patient: I know you won't like to hear that, but I'm fat on the grass. I know, I know, I'm going to regret all this at some point. It's just becoming a habit that's incredibly hard to break. Doctor: Ok. I prefer you to smoke grass than cigs. How many packages per year do you think you smoke on average? Patient: I go through a package every two weeks.
How about surgery? Patient: No, I didn't have surgery. Doctor: Are you sure? Patient: Yes.

Welcome to the clinic. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: It seems that you have been referred to us by Dr Jones. Patient: Yes I have been. Doctor: Great! The chart indicates that you are twenty weeks pregnant. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, I am. Doctor: Do you have any other children? Patient: Yes. I have a son of two years old. Doctor: Have you ever had pregnancies? Including miscarriages or abortions. Patient: Yes. I had a miscarriage before my son was born. Doctor: I am sorry to hear that. Patient: Thank you.

Are you married? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Who do you have in your family? Patient: Me, my spouse and three happy children. One of them is ready to go to university. Doctor: You work? Patient: Yes and no. Doctor: What does that mean? Patient: I was a lawyer but I retired from my official post two years ago. I couldn't stay home and did nothing, so I just joined a private company and worked part-time. Doctor: Sounds good. You smoke or drink? Patient: No. Doctor: I don't know any drugs either? Patient: Correct.

When did you quit smoking? Patient: About thirty years ago. Doctor: Ok. How about alcohol or drugs? Patient: No ever. Guest_family: Mom, please inform the doctor of the time you had it in the past. Doctor: Yes, please tell me son. Guest_family: She used to drink a long time back and took a lot of prescription drugs. Patient: Ok. Yes, that. Doctor: Thank you for this information. How long ago? Patient: I may not remember more than twenty years.

Have you ever had an operation, madam? Patient: No, not that I can remember, and I have a good memory. Doctor: Not even a section C when you had your son? Patient: No, I had all my children naturally.

person: No sudden gain or loss of weight? Patient
sentence: No. Doctor: No headache, bleeding of the nose, coarse voice, blurred vision or loss of vision. Patient: No, not at all. Doctor: No fever or chills, not at all. Patient: No fever or anything. Patient: No pain in the chest, shortness of breath or shortness of breath during sleep? Patient: No palpitation, swelling or varicose veins or pain in the legs? Patient: No pain in the throat or cough or cough with mucous membrane or sputum? Patient: I have this cough prolonged, but not anything. Patient: No breathing? Patient: No wheezing. Patient: No heart burn, nausea or vomiting? Patient: No pain in the stool or urine? Patient: No pain in the back or abdominal pain? Patient: No pain in the back or back. Patient: No pain in the back. Patient: No pain in the back.

Did you or did you use tobacco products, sir? Patient: No. I was never a smoker. Doctor: Do you have a history of alcohol use or recreational drugs? Patient: I was never a drug user, but I was drinking a little, but it was never a problem. I don't drink anymore. Doctor: What are you doing to live? Patient: I am retired. I used to be an insurance vendor.
Any old or new medicine I should know about? Patient: No.

person: I was wondering if Cialis could help you. Doctor
sentence: What makes you think that, sir? Patient: Well, I did a quiz online on the site of Cialis and I didn't notice in the normal range, so I thought I was going to come in. Doctor: Is there anything else to note, sir? Patient: Well, there may be a decrease in desire, but honestly, I don't think this is the main problem here. I would like to have my erections longer, Doctor: What did you look like? Patient: Well, on the quiz, I said that less than half of the time I am able to get an erection and keep an erection after penetration. Doctor: Do you have any difficulty maintaining an erection until completion? Patient: Well, I don't know patient?

We haven't been able to find the cause of your pain right now, but in the future, we're going to do some extra tests and then we can have a diagnosis. Patient: Will you give me medication for my stomach pain? And what about this feeling of vomiting all the time? Doctor: Yes, I'm going to write a prescription. This will help you both with your pain and nausea.

What came out in the vomit? Patient: These were brown things like coffee. Doctor: But nothing, not true? Patient: Yes I'm better. Doctor: Great! Patient: They told me I could go home. Doctor: Yes, your blood level seems good, I just want you to keep Nexium forty MG once a day. Patient: I'm going to do it.

How long have you been feeling about weakness and fatigue? Patient: Well, I would say it's much worse this week. I don't have much appetite either. Doctor: Have you lost weight as a result? Patient: I've lost about eight pounds, which is the most I've ever lost in a week. Doctor: Wow, it's worrying. You're feeling nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea or abdominal pain? Patient: No. Doctor: How about chest pain, shortness of breath, cough or heart stroke? Patient: No. Doctor: Any neurological symptoms, such as numbness or tingling? Patient: No. Doctor: We'll get to the bottom of this.
I see here that you have no surgical stories. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, indeed. At least for now. Who knows what the future will bring.

So, sir, tell me about your knees, how long have they been bothering you? Patient: Well, I'm sixty-nine now, so I'm not as young as I was. But these old knees have been bothering me for two years now. Doctor: What kind of symptoms do you notice in these knees? Patient: I hear clicks, which really bother me when I get on the stairs. There's also stiffness when I try to move them. Doctor: Were you a fairly active man? Patient: I was absolutely, and I had no problem, but now this pain affects my daily life and my activities.

Do you smoke or drink? Patient: No, I have never done such a thing. Doctor: No drugs? Patient: Never. Doctor: Do you still work? Patient: I am retired. I was working in the Morse chain. I was also used to delivering newspapers. But now I am retired, and I love life. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: I was happy married. But then my husband died. Doctor: Do you live alone or as a family? Patient: I live alone. I have a family that lives very close to the neighborhood. I have a niece who lives with his family in my house on Temple Street.

As far as you know, is there a family history of cancer? Patient: Yes, in fact, my mother told me that someone had cervical cancer. Doctor: What about heart disease, does it seem familiar to you? Patient: Yes, I know that someone had a heart disease and someone else had a heart failure. Doctor: Good to know, what about the lungs, history there? Patient: I know that someone had a C O P D. Doctor: Do you know anyone with dementia or Alzheimer? Patient: Yes, my uncle has a dementia right now, actually.

Can you give me a quick short circuit of her medical history? Guest_family: Of course. It's a little long, sadly. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear it. Guest_family: She's recently been diagnosed with dementia. She's also had high blood pressure for some time now. Doctor: When was she diagnosed with dementia? Guest_family: Six months ago. Doctor: Any history of heart disease, diabetes or stroke? Guest_family: No, but she's not in a position to properly control her bladder that leads to frequent accidents. Oh and she's had back pains for several years with degenerative changes to her spine.

person: What brings you both to the emergency department? Guest_family
sentence: Hello, Doctor. We're both fine. I brought my daughter today because she feels sick. Doctor: I see. Let me ask your daughter a few questions before you start. Hello, ma'am. I understand you feel sick. Before I start, I just want to confirm some information with you. Where is your main residence? Patient: My mother can give you the address. I still live with her. Doctor: Thank you. One last question. You smoke? Patient: No. My mother banned smoking at her home.

Are you married, sir? Patient: Yes, I am lucky to have, and to live with my beautiful wife. Doctor: That's very nice. Have you spoken with the nurse before I come here? Patient: Yes, she was also charming, I hope you pay them well. Doctor: We take good care of them. They will be happy to hear that. Let me look at it, she should have left me some notes, uh, yeah, these beautiful ones, I agree with all that. It seems good. Patient: Thank you, Doctor.

The nurse told me that you were incapacitated for work now. What happened? Patient: I was injured at work and now I'm incapacitated. Doctor: What did you do for work? How long ago did your injury happen? Patient: I worked on the pipeline. The accident took place five years ago. Doctor: What condition led to disability? Patient: I don't really know. I sent all the notes for my doctor for assessment and they approved the disability. Doctor: Okay. Do you live alone or in family? Patient: I live with my wife. Doctor: Do you smoke or have you ever been? Patient: I used to smoke. I quit years ago. Doctor: How long did you leave? Patient: Oh, about twenty years ago. Doctor: How many years have you smoked? And how many years have you smoked? Patient: Probably twenty years ago. I was up to two packages a day.

How are you today? Patient: Overall, good enough. Doctor: Any project for the weekend? Patient: No, not really. Just dog sitting on my friend's gold. Doctor: Gotcha. It's still nice. We used to have a gold when I was a child. These are the softest dogs. Patient: They are very nice. Doctor: Okay, so you're here for a follow-up for your neck and back pain. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Have you been in charge of pain? Patient: Yes, I'm leaving about once a week. Doctor: How's your pain going now? Patient: Managed, I suppose. Doctor: Does the pain always keep you up at night? Patient: Not like before. Doctor: Good, great to hear.
Let's see. Are you taking medication? Patient: No, none yet.

Do you smoke cigarettes? Patient: Yes. I smoke. Doctor: How much do you smoke a day? Pattor: On one pack or two a day. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol? Pattor: No. It is very rare that I drink a drink. Doctor: What is your family medical past? Pattor: Well, I don't know much about my father's family side, but my father died of kidney cancer. Doctor: I am so sorry for your loss. Pattor: Thank you. Doctor: What about your mother or your brothers and sisters? Do they have health problems? Pattor: No. They don't have any health problems.

So, ma'am, what are you doing to make a living? Patient: Actually, I'm retired, I don't work at all. Doctor: Congratulations on your retirement. Where did you go to university? Patient: Oh, I didn't go to college, I stopped after high school. Doctor: It's understandable. Do you have any children? Patient: Yes, my husband and I were blessed with three wonderful children. Doctor: Fantastic, do they live at home? Patient: No, we all got them out of there. They're all raised now. Doctor: Do you drink or smoke? Patient: No, I never had any more. Doctor: What about the toughest substances? Patient: No, absolutely not.
You are five feet four inches. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Weight one ninety-seven. Patient: Ok. Doctor: Your blood pressure is one twenty-five out of seventy-five. Patient: Ok.
Do you smoke or drink? Patient: Never smoked a cigarette a day in my life. As for alcohol, I will drink socially with friends and family.

How does he feel today? Guest_family: I think it's the worst he's felt all week long. Doctor: I'm sorry to learn that he's not feeling well. What are the symptoms he's had? Guest_family: He's been very crowded for a long time and seems to cough much more than usual. He also suffered a fever yesterday. Doctor: I see. What was his temperature? Guest_family: The thermometer read one hundred and one degrees Fahrenheit. Should he go to hospital? Doctor: Let me evaluate and see what we can do for him today. Guest_family: Thank you, Doctor. Doctor: I suspect he has a superior respiratory infection, a possible whooping cough.

Okay, let me examine it quickly. Mom gives you permission? I will quickly check his genitals. Can you pull his pants down? Guest_family: Of course, you can check it out. Doctor: Well, everything looks good, his penis and testicles are the normal shape and size for his age. No accumulation of fluid or swelling in the scrotum area, no evidence of hernia there.

We can free you from the hospital today if we have a safe place for you. Is there a parent or guardian where we can release you? Patient: I am a foster family. My foster mother will leave the city from the 19th to the 20th third. Doctor: In this case, we will have to keep you in the hospital until your foster mother returns from her trip. Patient: Can my mother and my grandmother come to visit me here Thursday? This is the day they usually come to visit me at my foster home. Doctor: Yes. I think we can make arrangements for this to happen.
Do you know any medical problems in your family? Patient: Yes, almost everyone was diabetic.
Do you have past or current medical problems? Patient: No.

Do you have a family history of lung disease, thromboembolism, pulmonary embolism, stroke or heart disease. Patient: No. My parents are healthy without any medical problems. Doctor: How many children do you have? Patient: I have five children. Doctor: Do your children have any health problems? Patient: My children are all healthy without any medical problems.
Do you smoke or drink alcohol? Patient: No.

Do you know any medical problems in your family? Patient: I have no idea of being very honest with you. My parents have never shared their medical history with me or their parents with them either. I don't think they want us to worry. Doctor: Oh wow, I understand. It can be difficult for many people to share intimate details about their health with others, even when it comes to disclosing medical information to their own children. At the moment, I'm going to put unknown but please let me know if anything changes. Patient: Will do. Thank you for understanding. Doctor: Of course.

I know you are an established dermatology patient here and was last seen in our office on July 13, two thousand and four. I'm going to ask you a few questions just to check if the entry in our file is updated or not. Doctor: How old are you now? Patient: Twenty-nine. Doctor: Where are you originally from? Patient: I am from Vietnam. Doctor: I see you today as a reference of A B C for re-evaluation. Patient: Yes, for my eczema in hand. Doctor: So let's see what you were treated with. Your file here says with Aristocort cream, ceaphil cream, increased moisturizing cream and lotion. Do you work well for yourself? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Do you wash your hands in this cleaning lot? Patient: Yes, I do all this.

You've been diagnosed with allergic rhinitis, haven't you? How many years? Patient: Hum, I'd say about four years now. Oh my God, it's so, so many medicines I had to take for that. Doctor: Yes, it's hard to control. Are you diabetic? Patient: No, I don't have such conditions. Doctor: So no hypertension or kidney disease? Patient: No. Doctor: Every case of tuberculosis, asthma or lung disease has been diagnosed? Patient: No.
How would you describe her diet? Doctor: Does she eat solid food? Guest_family: Most thin liquids and minced meat. Doctor: I see.

Hello, I'm Dr Nathan. Patient: Hello. Doctor: How old are you? Patient: I'm 48 years old? Doctor: Do you have regular rules? Patient: No, I didn't have a period for the last year after my surgery. Doctor: Hot flashes? Patient: Yes, it's been going on for several months. Sometimes I feel warm even in a fully air-conditioned room. Other times I just feel like opening the refrigerator and standing in front of it. Doctor: Other symptoms? Patient: I've also felt a lot of mood swings for a few weeks. Doctor: According to all the symptoms, my assessment would be mood swings with post-surgery menopause. That would be the cause of your hot flashes.

Any change in appetite? Patient: Hum, no. Doctor: Any pain in the stomach or any change in the movement of the intestine? Patient: No. Doctor: Any bowel problem? Pattor: Any hernia problem? Pattor: No. Doctor: Any stomach ulcer problem? Pattor: No. Doctor: Have you noticed rectal bleeding? Pattor: No. Doctor: Any liver or jaundice problem? Pattor: Hum, no. Doctor: Ok.

Do you drink alcohol? Patient: No! I'm used to the occasion a long time ago. But no more. Doctor: Okay and how to smoke cigarettes? Do you smoke or vamp? Patient: No, none of these. Doctor: And no drugs and everything, right? No snoring, I V or something else good? Patient: Yes, I don't do drugs either, never.

I will check your neck, it is beautiful and symmetrical. Your thyroid seems normal, it is not enlarged. Doctor: It hurts you when I press on your neck? Patient: No. Doctor: The neck is not sensitive. Doctor: Okay, I don't see any swelling of the external jugular vein. Patient: These medical terms that I don't understand. Doctor: Oh, I'm talking about the vein in your neck, it doesn't show any swelling. No abnormal masses present. Can you turn your head from left to right and from right to left, any pain in your neck or difficulty in turning? Patient: No. Doctor: Can you turn your head clockwise and clockwise. Patient: Of course. Doctor: Any pain? Patient: No. Doctor: All right, let me just make a note here full range of movements without pain.

person: It seems that you are here for your annual physics. How is it? Patient
sentence: Great, I think. I just had a mammography and nothing appeared. I always take my multivitamin and low-dose aspirin. Doctor: Great to hear. Did he have any changes in alcohol and smoking? Patient: No change. Check the picture, I answered this last time. Doctor: Great. It looks like drinking and smoking is off the menu. As far as mammography is concerned, you make sure to do breast exams? I think I showed you how to do it this last time. Patient: No, I don't see. I don't see a point if I come and do mammography. Doctor: I strongly suggest you start doing it. Sometimes people don't get mammograms anymore for a few years and it's important to make sure that nothing grows. Patient: Yes, I know. I'm just lazy. Recently, it's been hard to do a lot more of my own workouts.

Hello. How are you today? Patient: I want to get surgery on my leg. Doctor: Have you ever had surgery. Patient: I did it. Here's a list of them. Doctor: It looks like you've had eye surgery, cataract surgery, and lumbar decompression, correct? Patient: Yes. So, what options do I have for surgery? Doctor: I need to see what the problem is first.

Hey guys, how are you? Patient: I'm good, he's my stepfather. Guest_family: Hi Doctor, how are you? Doctor: I'm fine, thank you. So she gets seizures? Guest_family: Yes. Doctor: And when did he start? Guest_family: She was fourteen or thirteen years old. I think fourteen. Patient: Papa I was fourteen, when he started. Doctor: Quatorze, okay. Do you take something for that? Guest_family: Yes, she's under treatment. Doctor: Anyone else in the family has a similar problem? Guest_family: No, but her sixteen-year-old brother suffers from N S V T and he sees a specialist. Doctor: Okay, any other brother or family member with medical conditions? Guest_family: Other children in the family are fine, but her maternal grandmother suffers from high blood pressure and diabetes.
Do you have known allergies to medication? Patient: None.
Have you had your vaccines? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Have you forgotten? Patient: No, I had them all and I am aware of my vaccinations.

All right, but tell me what's going on and we can understand that. Patient: Okay, so my right hand and my left foot were very swollen and very painful, and that's why I came to the emergency room. Doctor: Do you have a bag of urine? Patient: Yes, I couldn't go for them to put it in. Doctor: Yes, it seems that five hundred ML have come out. So much possible urinary obstruction. Also, they started you on steroids and colchicin. How do you feel now? Patient: I feel a little better, my pain is getting better, and the swelling is getting better. Doctor: Okay, that's good. Any fever and chills? Pattor: No, no fever. Doctor: Any urine problem like pain or frequency or blood in the urine? Patient: No, but I'm not able to empty my bladder well, the pipi has decreased a lot, I couldn't urinate. Doctor: All right, I'll evaluate that.
Does low blood pressure flow into your family? Patient: No. As far as I know, no one else has it. Doctor: Okay.

Have you ever been diagnosed with any type of cancer in the past? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you ever had rashes? Has there been a change in your moles? Patient: No. Doctor: Sudden history of weight loss? Patient: No. Doctor: What do you think about your energy level how you feel? Patient: I feel good, my energy level is good enough.
What medicines are you currently taking? Patient: I am diabetic, so I am taking insulin. Doctor: How much insulin do you take? Patient: It varies from day to day.
Okay. Patient: I have nothing else. Doctor: Okay, no fever, no nausea, nothing like that? Patient: No.

Did you have the right or left hand? Patient: Okay. Doctor: When were you diagnosed for the first time with Parkinson? Patient: September of 19 years. Doctor: Do you remember who diagnosed you? Patient: A local doctor I saw at the time. A year before my diagnosis, I had some falls and episodes of lightness. I also noticed that I was much more stunning when I was walking. Doctor: Did you lose consciousness during one of your falls? Patient: Not that I know. I had noticed that I was losing my normal voice to one degree. In addition to losing my normal voice, my writing became smaller and smaller. I never remember writing so small. Something seemed really bad to me. Doctor: I am sure it was difficult to experience a patient. Patient: It was very difficult two months before I was diagnosed, I started moving much slower than before.

Hello! How do you do today? Guest_family: I am fine, but my son is sick. He is two and a half years old. Doctor: What are his symptoms? Guest_family: He has a bad cough. He has been sick for three or four days. There seems to be a phlegm that swings there when he coughs. He had a bad cough this morning. I was nervous and I decided to bring him. Doctor: During his cough episode this morning, did you notice a loss of breath or gas for air? Guest_family: No. Doctor: Did he have a rough nose? Guest_family: No. Doctor: No fever? Guest_family: No. He didn't eat much. Doctor: Was anyone else in the house sick? Guest_family: No.
Illnesses in the family? Patient: Yes, mainly heart problems. My father died of a heart attack. Doctor: What about your mother? Patient: She had the second type of diabetes.

Do you drink or smoke, ma'am? Patient: No, I don't do any of this. Doctor: Well, what about harder drugs? Patient: No, none of this either. Doctor: Very good. Do you have a history of S T D that you know? Patient: No, there's no history of all that there.
What medicines are you taking? Patient: I take Prilosec and Tramadol when I have back pain.
No.
Can you think of something that is related to this? Patient: Just when I eat raw carrots and celery. Doctor: Do you have stomach pain? Patient: Yes.

Hello, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me? Patient: Well, doctor, I am now sixty-six years old. Doctor: Thank you, how is your knee going today? Let's hope that the osteoarthritis improves. Patient: It's so bad, doctor. Doctor: Have you had any improvements with the rest and anti-inflammatorys we talked about before? Patient: No, they didn't help at all. Doctor: I see, you would be a good candidate for knee replacement. Patient: What is the risk of surgery infection? Doctor: Historically, it's less than one percent, we use prophylaxis antibiotics to control infection all the time. Patient: Great, and will I sleep for that? Doctor: Yes, you won't feel anything.
How old are you? Patient: I am twenty-four years old. Doctor: What brings you today? Patient: I have had this back pain for a long time.
Do you know anyone in your family or family members who have ever had diseases such as diabetes or heart problems? Patient: No.

What is the reason for your visit today? Patient: I have had a lot of problems recently, so I decided to have it checked by you. Doctor: I see. What kind of problems do you encounter? Patient: Oh, it's a long list. Here. Doctor: Thank you. Let me take a look. It looks like you have general allergies and food allergies, a loss of taste, problems with your tract G I, asthma, G E R D, and a dry mouth or xerostomy. Patient: Yes, it sounds good. I think I forgot to add it, but I also have bad allergies in the spring. Doctor: Oh, I see. I would describe this as inhaling environmental allergies.

Are you a smoker? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you consume alcohol or recreational drugs? Patient: I have already been in treatment for heroin and alcohol. Doctor: Any current use of drugs or alcohol? Patient: I made some coke today. Doctor: Okay.

Do you take anything- Patient: Meds? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes. I take Allegra for seasonal allergies. I also take something that starts with a P. I empty myself on the name. My other doctor prescribed it to me for asthma caused by exercise. Doctor: Oh, do you mean Proventil? Patient: Yes, that's it! I keep this in hand in case my asthma is no longer controlled. Doctor: Is it up to date? Patient: Do you mean expired? No, I don't think so. It hasn't been long since I visited the pharmacy. Doctor: Good. I still like to advise my patients to check the expiry dates.
Welcome to the office. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Let's start with your family medical history. Patient: This will be difficult. I have been adopted and I do not know any family medical history.

person: I took a little time and then we will continue with the result. Patient
sentence: So you came to our lung clinic, and you were suffering from dyspnoea even with minimal effort. At that time, we assessed you and realized that there was evidence of irregular sleep and day fatigue. At that time, you also complained about night choking episodes that have been less intense in the last few months. Patient: That's true. I was then programmed for night sleep study to be evaluated for interruptions in my sleep and we are here to discuss the results. Doctor: Of course. But first, how is your sleep routine? Patient: It's consistent. I'm going to sleep for a few weeks and I'm waking up for two hours.

So I see you were diagnosed with acid reflux and high blood pressure 20 years ago? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And then you also have arthritis and Parkinson's. Patient: Yes, both. Doctor: Also, you had a cerebral stroke? Patient: Yes, mini-AVC! Doctor: Ah, yes. We also call him T I A. Patient: OK. Doctor: And now you're taking medication? Patient: Just Coumadin, for my chronicle A Fib. I've been there for three years. Doctor: Yes, atrial fibrillation. Patient: Yes.
Hello, ma'am. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: How do you feel today? Patient: Honestly, I feel a little better. Doctor: It's good to hear, ma'am.

I see here that he may need antibiotics for a possible cellulitis of his lower limbs. Doctor: According to the patient, his symptoms have begun to worsen gradually over the last two days. Guest_clinician: Does he have a history of cellulitis? Doctor: No.

person: I was born and raised in North Carolina. I am the sixth of nine brothers. Doctor
sentence: Tell me about your family's medical history. Patient: My family has a lot of diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure, thyroid problems, autoimmune disease, multiple sclerosis and depression problems. Doctor: What are your medical history involving your parents? Patient: My father died because of complications of his diabetes. He passed by when he was sixty. My father was a leader. My mother is fine. My two parents have never finished high school. My father was a third-year student and my mother was a fourth-year student. She was an intelligent woman she never finished school.

Hello, young man. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: How old are you, sir? Patient: I'm thirteen years old. Doctor: What brings you today? Guest_family: Well, at the beginning we went to Sierra Pacific Orthopaedic Group, and he had an MR that I showed, um, O C D in the left knee. Doctor: Yes, I see that in the report. Guest_family: So we're here for a second opinion on this. Doctor: Yes, we should do surgery on this knee. There's a serious instability of the fragment, and we don't want that to get worse. Guest_family: Ok, that's about what we've heard so far. What are the risks of infection of the procedure? Doctor: It's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control the infection.

I'm not here, and your last P.D. was negative, but we'll do another one today. Patient: OK, that's good, doctor. Doctor: Did you comply with all the medicines that were prescribed to you? Patient: Yes, I took exactly as you told me. Doctor: Well, do you remember when your last appointment with the dentist was? Patient: Yes, it was in November of two thousand and seven. Doctor: What did they do for you on your last visit? Patient: They pulled two teeth for me. Doctor: Good, and when was your last papal smear? Patient: Yes, it was about a year ago. Doctor: I guess it was negative? Patient: Yes, fortunately. Doctor: You had two teeth for me. Doctor: Good, and when was your last appointment with the dentist?
