Patient: Yes, it was in November of two thousand and seven. Doctor: What did they do for you at your last visit?
Hello, I'd like to physically examine your rectal area, okay? Patient: No, I'm not comfortable with that. I don't want you to do it.

Hello, what brings you here today? Patient: I fell four times the third of this month because my leg suddenly gave. Doctor: How old are you? Patient: You do not ask the age of a lady. She will never tell you the truth. Doctor: I know that I am in the wrong profession. I must do it every time I meet someone. So how old are you? Patient: It is true. I am teasing you. I am fifty one. Doctor: Do you have the right hand or the left hand? Patient: I am the right hand? I am the right hand. Doctor: So you said that your legs suddenly gave out.

person: Diabetes and high blood pressure are running in my family. Doctor
sentence: What else? Patient: Yes, my mother suffered from a stroke when she was in her 70s.

Are you married, madam? Patient: No, I am divorced. Doctor: Do you live alone? Patient: Yes, so I have no support at home, it is difficult. Doctor: Do you drink or smoke? Patient: No, I never have. Doctor: And no more illicit substances? Patient: No, absolutely not.

What are your family medical history, sir? Patient: We have heart problems in my family. My sister died in a heart surgery two years ago. Doctor: I'm sorry. Patient: Thank you. My mother died of a heart attack. Doctor: How old was she when she died? Patient: She was 70 years old? My father died of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was only 49 years old. Doctor: Your family had suffered a lot of loss. Patient: Yes, we have it. Doctor: Do you have any brothers and sisters still living? Patient: I have another sister. Oh yes. She is diabetic. Doctor: Do you have any children? Patient: Yes, I have a daughter. The only health problem she has is high cholesterol. Doctor: Do you know anyone else in the family with neurological disorders? Patient: No. I don't think so.
Do you have known allergies? Patient: Not as I know. Doctor: Allergies to a medicine? Patient: No.

Are you married? Patient: Yes, I am. Doctor: Is the baby your first child? Patient: See, I am a missionary. I have four children. My eldest is seven years old. Then the others are five and three years old and this one is the youngest. She is only six weeks old.

Before you start, ma'am, how old are you? Patient: I'm thirty-nine years old, doctor. Doctor: What is the problem today? Patient: I've had this union for a few months. Doctor: Does pain worsen? Patient: Absolutely, I can't take it anymore. Doctor: How did you manage this union so far? Patient: I have larger shoes, and it didn't do anything. Doctor: I see. Patient: Is there an operation or something you can do? I can't take the pain.

You're here for the food consultation. Is this your first pregnancy? Patient: No, it's my second pregnancy. I had gestational diabetes with my first one too. Doctor: Did you take insulin at that time? Patient: Yes, I used insulin the last time too. I'm just here to understand if the diet can help me with my gestational diabetes. Doctor: Of course. Patient: My gynaecologist said something about ketones, I don't know what they are. She asked me to talk about them with you. Doctor: Of course, I'm going to explain everything to you. We also have a brochure to explain it. Here's a look. Patient: Thank you. Patient: Doctor: Do you do the exercise? Patient: I walk with my daughter every day. I'm going to drop her off at school and then I go home. Doctor: How much is the walk at school? Patient: It takes about 20 minutes on one side.

Do you know any family history of kyphosis? Patient: I'm sorry, what is it? Doctor: It has to do with the rounding of the spine. Does anyone in your family have a rounded posture? Patient: In fact, yes, my grandmother had this, and my mother was talking about my second cousin, he also had it.

When did you retire? Patient: About eleven years ago. It was really nice. I am able to spend more time with my grandchildren. Doctor: Aw, how many grandchildren do you have? And do you live alone? Patient: I have four grandchildren between two and eleven years old. I live in the county with my wife and dog. My wife and I have been together for thirty years now. Doctor: It's wonderful to hear.

How has your weight been since your last visit, with phentermine? Patient: Well, since the last visit I have won about a book. Doctor: Well, it could be worse, but we're at a plateau, I'd like to see you lose a little bit more per month. Patient: Yes, I've worked very hard, but I haven't been able to get the lower weight so far. Doctor: What was your lowest weight? Patient: My lowest? It was one hundred and thirty six. I'm as frustrated as you, Doctor: Well, if this tray continues, we should interrupt the phentermine. Patient: Why is it? Doctor: It should not be used to maintain your weight, but only to get the weight. So, if it doesn't serve this purpose, we should not use it. There is no real advantage. Patient: Ok, yes, I agree.
No one in the family had a stroke? Patient: No, no one had a stroke in my family. Doctor: How about someone in the family with heart disease? Patient: No one I remember.

Yes, I always knew how to speak English before I was even a teenager. So, when I moved to America, I didn't have a language problem. Doctor: Okay and did you move with your family? Patient: No, my family moved to the eastern side of Germany that was occupied by Russia at that time, but I decided to move to America in nineteen fifty-seven years. Patient: I had a high school diploma from Germany, and I could speak German and English fluently. Patient: As soon as I landed here in America, I started working. I started as a secretary in a private company and later I worked at I B M. Now I am retired for almost twenty years because of my complications of cancer. Doctor: Your Mesothelioma? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and who are all there in your family? Patient: I am alone without a companion. I am a son who lives in Santa Cruz, he doesn't drink a lot.

What brings you today? Can you also indicate your age? Patient: Yes. I am forty-five years old. I really have stomach pain on my right side since last week. Doctor: On a scale of one to ten, what is the pain at his worst? Patient: I should say one seven. Doctor: How would you rate it now? Patient: Oh um this is five for now. Doctor: Have you taken your diabetes medication? Patient: Micronase? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes, I took it every day. Doctor: Super.

Your cholesterol seems to be high today. Is this the first time you've been told that your cholesterol level is high? Patient: No, unfortunately. I have some medical problems so maybe it's to blame. Doctor: I see here that you have diabetes and high blood pressure. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Are diabetes or high blood pressure running- Patient: In the family? No, but heart disease does.

How did the study of sleep go? Patient: Not bad. Although I admit it was difficult to stand up in preparation for her. Doctor: I can imagine. It's always difficult. It looks like the evalence of your diurnal fatigue and insomnia was sent. Let me print a copy and we can go over it together. How old are you again? Patient: I'm forty eight years old.

When did you take your temperature for the last time? Patient: Just before I drive here. Doctor: I see. Did the nurse take your temperature when you entered? Patient: Yes, she did. Doctor: Did you experience a cold like symptoms such as cough, nasal congestion, headache or nausea? Patient: No, not really. Doctor: Did you try to take a medication to help with fever? Patient: Yes. I took Tylenol and it helped a little. Doctor: Have you had any recent sick contacts? Patient: I don't think so. I live with three other roommates and they seem good.
What's going on? Patient: No. What do you mean? Doctor: I mean something from the headache to the toes you'd like to add? Patient: No everything's fine. No other problems. Doctor: OK. Okay.

How was the procedure? Patient: It was good. I was nervous to go under the knife at first, but it turned out to be better than I expected. Do you know any other people who got hysterectomies that are close to my age? Doctor: Yes, actually. It's a fairly common procedure. I'm glad to learn that you didn't have any complications. Patient: So am I.

Hello and welcome to our dermatology office. What is the reason for your visit? Patient: I have these rashes on my arms. Doctor: Let me take a look. Do you have any previous reports on your history? Patient: Yes, I do. I gave it to the nurse. Doctor: Let me go very quickly. I read the report and it seems that your family is positive for atopie. Patient: Oh, yeah. We all usually get a certain type of rash. Doctor: I see. Do you know if you have psoriasis? Patient: Uh. What is it? Patient: It is a skin disease that usually has scalar patches. Patient: Uhm. I don't think so. Doctor: Super. Before prescribing medicines to treat your eczema, are you allergic to medication? Patient: Not that I know.

Do you drink? Patient: Well, I'm going to call myself a social drinker. I admit I'm addicted to caffeine. Doctor: How much coffee do you consume every day? Patient: I would say three to five cups. Doctor: A history of sexually transmitted diseases? Patient: No. Doctor: How are your eating habits? Patient: I would say I'm a good eater and follow a healthy diet. Doctor: Do you exercise? Patient: I walk every day around five miles. Also, I'm very regular in my sprint training.

Hello sir. Do you know how you arrived here? Patient: Yes, I passed out and the paramedics took me to the hospital. It's coming and going. Doctor: Did you take something for pain? Patient: I took Advil, but it doesn't seem to help. Doctor: Did you have the same pain in the past? Patient: No, I don't think so. So it looks like you have stones in your C B D. I'm not 100 percent sure but probably its stones. Patient: C B D? Doctor: Yes, short for a common biliary canal. It's a small tube like the structure that connects your liver canal with the gallbladder. Patient: Oh! Doctor: Yes, and because of that you have inflammation in your gallbladder. Patient: Oh, I see.
Has he had a blood transfusion in the past? Doctor: No, it's his first. Guest_clinician: Okay, understood.

Sure, he's ten years old now.
How long has he used his walker?
Well, he's been using that since he started walking.
How old was he when he started walking?
He was about a year old.
Good, what seems to be the problem today?
He keeps complaining about the back of his legs being tight.
Can you sit on the table, young man? Yes, I'm bending his legs, we call this the popliteal angle, and both sides flex to only about twenty.
Where should that be normally?
He should be able to get to ninety.
What can we do about this?
I think we should do surgery on this leg. How does he walk? Can I see?
Well, just look at him.
Yes, he does not walk with a crouched pattern, but he is toe walking.
Can we correct that instead of the hamstring tightness?
Well, I believe he should have surgery on the hamstring, as well.
Okay, right now we want to do surgery to fix his walking. What are the risks of infection?

They're low, historically, they're less than one percent. The risks include anesthesia, infection, bleeding, changes in sensation and the motion of walking, and it may also not always cure the toe walking. There is also possible stiffness after wearing the cast and other cast issues.
Okay, and will be under anesthesia during this? Is this worth it?
Absolutely, he won't feel a thing. It is worth it because the chances of the risks happening are low.
Yes, we'd like to do the procedure. Let me text my husband really quick. Okay, yes, my husband agrees.

Patient: I also have a pain in my knee of a boat when I was out fishing with water. Doctor: Was it serious? Patient: It was a complete spectacle. A helicopter came down and threw me to X Y Z infections?

Yes, I'm going to be seventy-seven years old. Doctor: Dr. Kim's notes say you had pain in your left flank. Can you tell me more about the pain? Patient: Yes. The pain started four or five days ago. He was in my stomach and back on my left side. Here. Doctor: Okay. Did you have nausea or vomiting? Patient: Yes. I had nausea, and I vomited a few times. Doctor: Did you notice any blood, pain and/or burns during urination? Patient: No. Doctor: Any fever or chills? Patient: No. Doctor: I have the ultrasound results that Dr. X ordered the other day.
Good afternoon, ma'am. You're forty one years old, correct?
Good afternoon, doctor. Yes, that's correct.
Thank you, have you followed up with Doctor X since your surgery?
Why would I do that?
Oh, just because she referred you to me.
Oh, no, I haven't yet.
That's fine. Have you heard the details behind your surgery?
I heard it once, but I can't remember anything. Can you remind me?

Well, you had a complicated case, but we did an anterior cervical discectomy, two level corpectomy, with a spinal decompression and fusion with fibular strut and machine allograft in your large cervical plate.
Oh, that's a lot, doctor.
Yes, how are you doing today?
Well, I've felt good for the last two days.
Have you been able to move your arms and legs for the last few days?
Yeah, I can actually move all four.
Good, are you having any issues breathing?
No, nothing of note there.
Okay, today, I think you'd be a good candidate for a halo vest placement.
Yeah, doctor, I'm not going back to the O R.
Okay, we can do it here.
Okay doctor, I'd like to do it here.
Let me get A B C to help me with this. Also, we're going to move you to S I C U room one.
Can you tell me the details about what you're going to do?
Well, this is a P M T halo, I like this one better than the Bremer halo vest, and I'll use morphine and Versed.
Are you going to use anesthesia?
Yes, I have local anesthetic, it's xylocaine and epinephrine, um, it's somewhere between fifteen and twenty C C.

If I had to guess, I smoked about two packs a day. Doctor: Did you smoke only cigarettes? Patient: Cigars, too. Doctor: What would you say about alcohol? Patient: Rarely ever. Doctor: Super.

Do you have a family medical history of migraines? Patient: I know my brother has them too. Mom, do you know if anyone else has them? Guest_family: Your grandfather had migraines. Doctor: Ok.

Are you allergic to anything? Patient: No, I'm not. Doctor: Are you sure? Penicillin or sulfa? Patient: No nothing. Doctor: It's good.

Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have headaches, hallucinations or visual disturbances? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have open wounds or wounds? Patient: No.
Did you do any surgical procedures? Patient: Yes, actually I had a hysterectomy in March of ninety-nine. I think it was done the twentieth of the month. Doctor: Understood.

How old are you, sir? Patient: I'm sixty-five years old. Doctor: You have the right hand or the left hand? Patient: I'm the right hand. Doctor: When did you have your last stroke? Patient: Well, it was January 17th. I had these episodes where I was always so confused and I look like I'm losing everything. All my memory and everything. And then they did a scan. It was checked that I had a stroke on the same day. Doctor: Did they put you on medication? Patient: They gave me an anticonvulsant and aspirin. Doctor: Are you taking them regularly? Patient: A few times like a day or two I forgot to take my, uh, dyphenhydramine, but even when I take it regularly, I'm still having all these symptoms or these oblivities, confusion and everything. Doctor: Are you feeling something like an emergency or something else with these episodes?

Medical disorders in the family? Patient: Yes, my father had a special type of tumor, which doctors said is very rare. Doctor: Do you know the name of the tumor? Patient: I don't remember the exact name of the disease, but it was a great name and it started with something with V.

Oh, is it like the last time you had it? Patient: Oh, I remember it. It took me almost three cycles of treatment to be solved. Patient: Yes. They always say I have a part hidden in my spine. Patient: Yes, I recently celebrated my thirtieth birthday just sitting in my wheelchair all day. Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry expensive. So, how long since you had this ulcer? Patient: There have been several weeks, so I thought I should have checked.

Your chest x ray showed diffuse pulmonary edema. This means that you have fluid in your lungs. This would explain your chest pain and difficulties with your breathing. I would like to start with a course of antibiotics to prevent any possible infection. I will also send a prescription for Furosemide. This will reduce the accumulation of fluid in your lungs. Do you have any questions? Patient: When should I begin to feel better? Doctor: You should start to feel better within three to five days.

Headaches? Patient: No. Doctor: A history of seizures or epilepsy? Patient: No. Doctor: A sudden loss of consciousness or have you fainted? Patient: Hum, no. Doctor: No weakness? Feeling tremors in your body? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: A history of stroke or brain-related illness? Patient: No, no such history.

Is there a known disease in your family? Patient: My father has high blood pressure, and he is taking medication for her. He is now eighty-two years old. He had a stroke about two years ago. It was his second stroke. He was a first to forty-five years old. Doctor: And your mother? How old is she? Patient: My mother is eighty years old. She has problems with sugar.

What are you doing to live? Patient: I've been working as a plumber for five years. Doctor: Nice. Where do you work? Patient: Especially in the city. Doctor: You drink, smoke or inject drugs? Pattor: I drink and smoke here and there, but I never tried hard drugs. Doctor: Any recent trip? Pattor: I was in Mexico earlier this year. Doctor: It looks good. How was your trip? Pattor: Relaxing. Much needed. Doctor: Great to hear. I have some questions I have to ask with me. How is your sexual history? You are sexually active? Pattor: I am sexually active with women, but my sex life is not as good as that of Japan. There I would mix and mix with prostitutes. Doctor: Have you used your protection? Pattor: I don't really remember.
Good afternoon, champ, how you holding up?
Good afternoon, Doctor, I have a lot of lower back pain.
Oh no, before we begin, how old are you, sir and which hand do you write with?
I'm seventy five now. Right.
Great, so tell me, how long have you had this lower back pain?
It's been about ten days now.
Have your symptoms improved at all since they began?
No, they keep getting worse.
Does the pain radiate into your legs?
Yes, it started radiating down my right leg three days after the lower back pain began, and then the left leg three days after the right. The next day I could barely walk, the pain was so severe.
Do you remember the initial date of the beginning of your low back pain?
Um, it was on December third nineteen ninety five.
Have you seen another doctor for this pain?
Yes, I saw my local physician, um, it was on December eleventh, but he wasn't able to pinpoint what was going on.
What kind of treatments did he recommend?
He gave me some antiinflammatories and sent me on my way.
Did you drive yourself?
Yes, I did.
How did the antiinflammatories work?
Um, by the time I got home, I could hardly walk due to the back pain, and I had weakness in my legs. I was, however, able to feed my dogs, and I fixed myself some dinner.
Was there any leg numbness?
Yes. Since December eleventh.
Have you seen an orthopedist for this pain?
Yes, I saw one the day after my primary care physician, but my legs gave out and I fell while walking to my car because of the leg weakness and back pain.
What kind of imaging studies did that orthopedist do?
He did a C T and x rays of my lower back, but he didn't see anything wrong. He recommended I follow up at U I H C. The imaging was on my L S Spine.

person: Your wound is complicated by methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus cellulitis. Patient
sentence: Is there a treatment for my right leg? Doctor: There is. It will be more aggressive, but we can do it.
What's going on with him? Guest_family: He complains about chest pain.

I've seen it for years. Doctor: I just need to confirm some demographic information before starting today. So, you're a white man of twenty nine years old, right? Patient: Yes, doctor. That's good. Doctor: Super, thank you. So, what seems to be the problem today? Patient: Well, I was stung by a yellow jacket Wasp yesterday. Doctor: Did you have a lot of swelling? Patient: Yes, it's in my right hand and right arm. Doctor: Did you all get stung by wasps before? Patient: Yes, it wouldn't be the first time. Doctor: Did you have similar reactions before? Patient: Yes, I did. I had a severe reaction. I came because I wanted to make sure that he didn't get to that point. Patient: Yes, it wouldn't be the first time. Doctor: Did you have similar reactions before? Patient: Yes, I had a severe reaction.

When did you get your last menstruation? Patient: Um, it was around June 3rd of two thousand nine. Doctor: Okay, he says you had an abortion recently? Patient: Yes, but I'm not sure if it's over, because I'm still bleeding. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Do you want me to do a pregnancy test? Doctor: No, I would like you to see our gynaecology and our obstetrician. Patient: Ok.

My nipples are cracked, and they bleed. Doctor: Oh, I'm really sorry to hear that. Guest_family: He has a little fluid coming out of his belly button as well as his penis. Doctor: Okay, I'm going to look at it. But other than that, everything else looks good? Any other problem related to circumcision? Guest_family: No, no other problems.

person: I had high blood pressure, asthma and sleep apnea. I had blood clots in my left leg about six months ago. I also have cancer. Doctor
sentence: What type of cancer do you have? Patient: I had stomach cancer. They also had total abdominal hysterectomy. Doctor: Did they put you an anticoagulant medication for blood clotting? Patient: Yes. I took it for six months. I stopped taking it and then I had stroke. Patient: Did you have any other surgeries? Patient: Yes. I had a colonic resection to remove benign polyps. I had another back pain used from my chest?

They gave you Proscribed for your anaemia? Patient: Yes I think so. That's how they treated her in the past. Doctor: Ok. Are you married? Who do you live with? Patient: Oh I'm all alone. Doctor: Ok, and you smoke or drink alcohol? Patient: No I'm not. Doctor: Super. Patient: Ok.

person: I'm here to help me. Doctor
sentence: Tell me how I can do this? What's bothering you? Patient: I have gestational diabetes at home and I'm here for a consultation related to my diet. No matter what I eat, I'm afraid that it will raise the numbers. Doctor: Wait, wait. First, tell me how old are you? Patient: I'm sorry. I'm 38 years old. Doctor: Okay, tell me what you're afraid of? Patient: No matter what I eat, my number goes up and I'm just, I'm afraid to eat anything now. Doctor: Do you work? Patient: I'm doing it, in Walmart. I'm trying not to eat anything when I'm on the third guard. Doctor: Tell me about the eating habits of young people.

person: I'm here for this pain in my legs. It hurts especially in the night. Doctor
sentence: Does changing your position help you? Patient: Yes, it helps. Every time I'm standing, it just leaves. Doctor: Is it only in your legs where it starts there and goes elsewhere too? Patient: Normally starts in my hips and then it goes down my leg and sometimes in my ankles too. Doctor: When did you notice a first? Patient: Everything started after taking this medication. What does he call? Something with L? Yes, Lipitor. Doctor: Have you ever noticed night sweats? Patient: Sometimes I sweat at night. Doctor: Any other problem? Your body temperature is a little on the upper end. Patients: Yes, I feel feverish and nausea too. Doctor: How are your sugars? Patient: They have been low for a while.

Are you married? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have children? Patient: Yes, I have seven. I have a handful. Doctor: Do you work? Patient: Yes, I am a driver of FedEx. Doctor: Have you ever smoked? Patient: No. Doctor: What about alcohol or any other type of drugs? Patient: No. None of this.

Is the patient allergic to a drug? Guest_clinician: Yes, in fact he is allergic to a number of medications. I wrote them down, here's the list. Doctor: Okay, so he's allergic to Lamisil, Equagesic. Oh, he's allergic to Bactrim too. Guest_clinician: Yes, and Dilatrate and cyclobenzaprine. Doctor: That's a lot, we have to be careful while making his treatment plan. Guest_clinician: Yes.

Hello! It's nice to meet you. Doctor: Let's start with your family medical history. Patient: My mother had breast cancer. My father had lung cancer that ended up taking his life. He was seventy years old when he died. My mother also died but not of an illness but of an infection that she had after having had elective surgery. Doctor: I'm so sorry for your loss. How old was your mother when she died? Patient: Thank you. She was eighty years old when she died. I'm an orphan now. My only alive brother died at the age of forty. He had a difficult life. He had a mental illness. Doctor: How did your brother die? Patient: He had pancreatitis. Oh, my father had glaucoma. Doctor: You had a lot of loss. Patient: Yes, I have. My good friend died a year and a half ago.
I will ask some simple questions, okay?
Hm
How old are you and how would you define yourself in terms of ethnicity?
Well, I am forty seven and would proudly call myself as Latin American.
Great. What brings you to the emergency room?
I had a blood test before and then it came out to be high potassium. I also went to a regular clinic the other day as I was feeling very weak and extremely tired.
Okay.

My potassium came out to be seven and it was highlighted in red. That really scared me, so I wanted to know everything what's going on inside me. I told the emergency doctors too that all these weakness and tiredness is going on for more than half a year.
Did you noticed any other symptoms other than weakness?

Yes, there was the fever and chills. I was sweating a lot in the nights, and I also had weight loss of around twenty pounds. During that time, I sometimes have nausea and was throwing up a lot. I was not eating. I always felt dizzy every time I tried to stand.
Did you have wet cough?
No, not wet cough but I did notice back pain gets intense on the upper side whenever I coughed, like in my ribs. I normally massage that area and it gets better.
Any shortness of breath?
Nope.
How about while sleeping or doing something else?

Not while sleeping, but I did notice that if I'm walking for two to three blocks then I get out of breath easily. Previously it was not like this. I used to jog for two to three miles without even a single breath loss.
I noticed one more thing. I feel like my balls on one side are getting big.
Which side left or right?
I think its left.
For how long?
I guess over the past year. I did see someone when all of this started, and he put me on some antibiotics, but nothing changed. For last few months there is yellow fluid coming out of it too.
Did you ever get any type of injury in the area?
No.
What about your bowel movements?
Nope everything is as usual.
Any change in urinary habits?
Nope.
Any changes in your skin? Any rash? Any kind of eyesight issue?
Nope, no changes.
What about pain? Like headache or any joint pain?
Nope, no pain anywhere.

Have you ever had an operation, madam? Patient: Yes, I have had some. First, I had, um, tubular ligation, and three milk ducts removed. Doctor: What year was it? Patient: It was in, um, nineteen seventy-nine. Doctor: Thank you. What else did you do? Patient: I had a breast biopsy in nineteen ninety-nine, and a colonoscopy in two thousand seven. Doctor: Thank you, have you children? Patient: Well, doctor, I was pregnant four times, but I had three children. Doctor: I am sorry to hear that. Did you have a section C with one of them? Patient: No, doctor. I had a natural birth for all of them.
Have you had an operation in the past? Patient: No.
Allergies? Patient: Yes just molds. Doctor: So okay with mould reactions.

Hello, how are you expensive? Patient: I'm fine, thank you. Guest_family: Hello Doctor, I'm his mother. Doctor: Nice to meet you. So I see you have been referred by Dr. X. Guest_family: Yes, she's our family doctor. Doctor: Okay, so you've noticed some behavioural problems with your daughter and reported to her, is that correct? Guest_family: Yes, I've noticed them for a while. She quickly loses her attention. We also have some complaints from the school about her behavior. We also met some other doctors but they diagnosed her with a attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Doctor: Well, looking at her reports, I'm afraid she has a DD, but the good news is that we can treat her, so don't worry. Guest_family: OK. Doctor: I'm gonna prescribe some medicines that will help her treat this. Guest_family: Thank you. Doctor: I'm going to write her a prescription for Adderall and Clonidine.
He had circumcision? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you remember the date? Patient: No, I don't. But he should be in the picture.

Yes, that's right. Doctor: Very good, and you identify yourself as a Caucasian, isn't it? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Thank you, do you have medical conditions that I should know? Patient: Yes, I have diabetes. Doctor: How do you treat your diabetes? Patient: Well, I have diabetes for a long time, but I have never been treated for it. Doctor: Okay, thank you for telling me. Doctor: What seems to be the problem today? Patient: I have worked in my garage these days, and I have this redness and swelling in my right foot. Doctor: Do you have itching or pain? Patient: Yes, and it gets worse. Doctor: Have you seen any other doctors about it? Patient: Yes, yes. I went to the hospital A B C D General E R and they gave me an evaluation there.

Hello, sir. How are you today? Patient: I am sick. I brought my wife so she can speak for me. Doctor: Hello, madam. What is the problem with your husband? Guest_family: He had some problems with his skin in his private area. He is too shy to talk about it himself.
Does he help you in the house? Patient: Yes, you drink or smoke? Patient: No, I do nothing of this. Doctor: And if you use more illicit substances? Patient: No, absolutely not.
There's something else going on from head to head? Patient: No doctor, everything's fine. Doctor: Are you sure? Patient: Yes, I'm sure.

How's my husband? Sorry, I had to take an outside call. Doctor: He's going much better. He's going home today with a prescription for Zithromax. Guest_family: I'm glad he can go home and rest. Doctor: However, I'd still like to see him in the office next week for a re-evaluation. Guest_family: Great. Can we make an appointment now? Doctor: Yes, the reception can help you.

Did you take anything for fever? Patient: Tylenol and Advil. I take them interchangeably. Doctor: When did you take your temperature for the last time? Patient: An hour ago. The thermometer read an O one point four. Doctor: Do you feel any other symptoms, such as shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or others? Patient: I had a stronger desire to pee much more than usual. Patient: I don't know if it's related. Patient: It could be. We still wait on your urine results. Do you have a history of cataracts or glaucoma? Patient: No. Doctor: Very good. Any signs of pneumonia or valley fever? Patient: Nothing like that.

person: It seems that some information is missing for your profile. Is it well if I ask you a few questions? Patient
sentence: Of course. Go ahead. Doctor: Are you currently smoking? Patient: No, I finally stopped smoking cigarettes. Doctor: Have you smoked before? Patient: I did it. I smoked half a pack for about twenty years. Doctor: Well, it's good to hear that you stopped. I encourage you to continue not smoking. Patient: I agree. I have to change my lifestyle. Doctor: Last question. Do you drink alcohol? Patient: No, I don't like what has alcohol. I can't stand the taste. If I do it, it's rare.

person: I had about four months. I was just fifty-nine years old. Doctor
sentence: And just to refresh your memory, we made a percutaneous fixation to the screw of a fracture of the Shatzker I V tibial plateau, and we handled these toe fractures in a non-operative way. Patient: What toes did I break? Patient: You broke your second and fifth toes. Patient: Do you have x-rays? Can you see where the fractures are? Doctor: Absolutely, if you look here, that's where the fractures are.

Do you currently smoke? Or have you smoked in the past? Patient: Leave in nineteen seventy-two. Doctor: Good to hear. Do you work now? Patient: Yes, I work in a nursing home. Doctor: Does your work allow you to take time for yourself? Patient: Yes, my work is very favorable. I have actually tried to lose weight. So far, I have lost a good amount since the beginning of a new diet several months ago.

Hello. Are you ready for your operation today? Patient: Can we report? I'm too afraid to do it. Doctor: It's gonna be okay. Don't worry too much. Have you ever had an operation before? Patient: Never. What if something is wrong? Doctor: You have nothing to fear. I have done this procedure several times, and everyone was fine after. Patient: Thank you, Doctor. Let's start then.
What is your family medical past? Patient: I don't really remember someone with major health problems. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Everyone is healthy. Doctor: It's a chance. Patient: Yes, it's true.

How's it going? I haven't seen you in a long time. Patient: Hey, Doctor. My headaches have worsened. Doctor: Remind me again. Does your family have a history of migraines. Patient: I don't think so. Doctor: Okay. Let's do some tests.

Your prescription is two hundred MG twice a day, that's it. Doctor: Do you have a report on your eyes with you today? Patient: Yes, doctor. That's it. Doctor: Well, thank you, what's the problem today? Patient: Well, I have some pain in my hands and elbows. Doctor: When did you start this pain? Patient: It's been a few weeks now. Doctor: Is there a related trauma? Did you fall? Patient: No, no falls or anything. It just started one day, and it really bothers me. Doctor: Do you have fever or chills, or symptoms of cold or flu like that? Patient: No, I'm not. Doctor: How do you get a swelling? Are your joints swollen? Patient: No, everything is normal there.

So I know that technically you don't have the right to drink, but I have to ask that anyway. Do you drink at all? Patient: No, actually. I'm trying not to drink during the training for my marathon. Doctor: When is it actually? Patient: Next summer. Doctor: Wow, good luck. This will be another great achievement. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: And what would you say to smoke of any kind? Patient: No.

I have a lot of diabetes in the family. Doctor: Who has diabetes? Pattor: My father has diabetes. He died. Doctor: I am so sorry. How did he die? Pattor: He had breast cancer. He did have breast cancer. Doctor: It's incredibly rare. Your mother is still with us? Pattor: Yes, she is. She just had her eighty-ninth birthday. Next year, we're planning a great birthday present for her. Doctor: Do you have any brothers and sisters? Pattor: Yes. I have a sister. I also have diabetes. Doctor: Do you know any family members with neurological disorders such as MS, epilepsy or Huntington? Pattor: No. I don't know anything like that.

How are your other children? Guest_family: Not so wonderful. They're all on antibiotics. Doctor: For the same thing? Guest_family: Yes. They all have ear infections and chest colds. Doctor: Your hands are full then. Guest_family: Talk to me, doctor. I can't take a lot of breaks. Doctor: It's certainly a difficult winter for you and your family.
Do you use tobacco or other drugs? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you drink? Patient: No.

Is that your mother with you today? Patient: Yes, it's my mom. Doctor: Great, welcome, what did you do with that ankle, young girl? Pattor: Well, I was running when I twisted my ankle. Doctor: What ankle did you twist? Pattor: It was my right ankle. Doctor: Where does it hurt the worst? Pattor: Right here, outside my ankle. Doctor: Do you have a primary care doctor? Guest_family: Yes, we go to Dr. Brown. Doctor: Do you have any other injuries to talk about? Pattor: No, it's just my ankle.

I'm in college, uh, I'm in eighth grade. Doctor: Do you play sports? Patient: Yes, I like playing basketball. Doctor: Well, are both of your parents at home? Patient: Yes, I live with my mother and father. Doctor: Do you have brothers and sisters? Patient: Yes, I have a little brother, uh, he's nine years old now. Doctor: Great, did you start your period? Patient: Uh, yes, my first was in September.

How many children have you, madam? Patient: I have been blessed with four beautiful children. Doctor: It is wonderful. Have you had any complications with pregnancy? Patient: In fact, I had two sections for my two sons.

I'm on the right hand. Doctor: Tell me what brings you here, sir? Patient: I have these cramps in my feet, in my hand and I just wanted to get checked. It's like six months. I develop muscle contractions in my toes and both feet. It only happens at night. Doctor: How often is it? Patient: About three times a week. Doctor: What do you do when you have these cramps? Patient: I try to stand up and it helps me relieve some of the discomfort. I noticed that my toes are quite wide. Every time I walk on the floor, it seems to get in place. With all these cramps, I started to have pain in my calf. Sometimes because I couldn't sleep, or it wakes me up in the night.

Is there a change in your social history or any other symptoms that arise or, or is it the same as before? Patient: Your follow-up? How are you doing so far away with Lamictal? Patient: Yes, it's follow-up. Lamictal was correct. There was no side effect with that. But I had contractions in my muscles a lot of times. It wasn't generalized, but I was very afraid that it would happen. Doctor: What time of day was it? That you had these episodes. Patient: Especially in the morning. Doctor: I have your recent E E E G report. It has shown multiple peaks and some complexes on both sides, but it is more important on the left. Patient: I have taken my medication very regularly and I have received a good amount of sleep too. Doctor: Are you able to drive? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Is there a change in your social history or any other symptoms that arise or, or is it the same as before? Patient: seems the same.
What kind of operations have you had in the past? Patient: I had gallbladder and appendix surgery then they also pulled out my ovaries.

Have you had any operations in the past? Patient: Yes, I have it, I actually had it to fix an indecent testicle. Doctor: Oh, wow, do you remember at all? Patient: No, nothing about it, I had done that when I was a baby.

Do you smoke cigarettes? Patient: I don't smoke cigarettes but I have one on rare occasions. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol or use recreational drugs? Patient: I don't drink but I occasionally smoke grass.
Do you smoke or drink? Patient: No, neither. Doctor: A history of addiction? Patient: No, I have never used illegal drugs in my life.

Is the patient admitted for a disseminated C M V infection? Doctor: Yes. I suspect that there is also a possible C M V pneumonitis. Guest_clinician: Are they immunosuppressive? Doctor: Yes. They have polymyositis and they take Prednisone and Methotrexate. Guest_clinician: I understand.

Okay, we've already talked about your medical history, everything you could add? Guest_family: Oh, Dad have you also talked about your depression? Doctor: Depression? I don't think we talked about it. Patient: Yes, we didn't, it slipped out of my mind. Guest_family: My father has a history of depression and anxiety.
How are you? Patient: Not good. Doctor: What brings you here today? Patient: This ulcer in my ankle does not heal. Doctor: Is it on both sides? Patient: No, just on the right side.

Do you remember the details of your operation, sir? Patient: No, can you remind me? Doctor: We did a left inguinal hernia repair. Patient: Thank you for reminding me. Doctor: You also have a history of prostate cancer, correct? Patient: Yes, they said it was Gleason, um, three plus four. Doctor: Yes, it seems familiar. What medications are you taking now? Patient: I am taking Lupron, currently.

How many people do you have in your family? Patient: Well, I have four children, all in good health without disease. Doctor: Wow, that's great! Patient: My father died at the age of sixty-nine years because of C V A. And my mother died exactly ten years later, her heart suddenly stopped. She was seventy-nine years old. Doctor: Ok. And do you have brothers and sisters? Patient: Well, believe it or not I had eleven brothers and sisters, including me twelve. Doctor: Wow! Patient: Yes, I lost six of them. Four of them with diabetes, one of my brothers died at the age of seventy-two and we were never able to determine why my sister died. Doctor: Hm ok.
Are you fired for a right abdominal infection? Patient: Yes, they told me I could have C Diff? Doctor: Yes that's why we're going to evaluate you.

person: I'm an American farmer by blood, so it happened before. Doctor
sentence: Oh, when did it happen, sir? Patient: Yesterday night around four P. Doctor: Okay, what did you do? Patient: So I tried to remove it with clamps at home, but it didn't come out. So, I would like you to take it off. Doctor: Okay, let me see. Patient: Yes, here. Doctor: Okay. Can you tell me when the last time you had a tetanus shot? Patient: Oh, it's been so long. I'd say it's been over ten years since I had a tetanus shot. Doctor: Okay, and are you allergic to something? Patient: Oh yes. I'm allergic to horse serum.

Have you had a recent vaccination? Patient: I had an influenza vaccine last winter but I didn't have and recent vaccines. Doctor: Did you plan anything in the near future? Patient: I was going to have another influenza vaccine but I don't think I'm due for that for another three months. Doctor: Super.

How old are you? Patient: Seventy-two years old. Doctor: Are you right hand or left hand? Patient: right hand. Doctor: What exactly happened? Patient: I had this bad migraine on November 5 and then I had a big sneeze, as if it were too loud. I had--it was going on for three to four days. Then, on the seventh day, I had this severe pain on my left eye and I kind of lost my vision there. Doctor: When did you see changes in your eyelid? Patient: Yes, the next day, it seemed to be swollen and then my eyelid, it started as falling down and down.

I see you're here for a refill of drugs. Is that correct? Patient: Yes. I came out of Klonopin a day or two ago. Doctor: What are you taking? And how long have you been on it? Patient: Panic attacks. I have very bad episodes without that. Um I think I started about four months ago. I could be wrong. I lost track of the time. Doctor: Who usually prescribes it to you? Patient: My doctor is back in Georgia. Doctor: Can you check the dose? Patient: No, unfortunately. Doctor: How many Klonopins do you take for your panic attacks? Patient: I take a rather low dose. I think I'm on zero point five milligrams a day. Can you check the dose? Doctor: I can try to consult it online. When did you receive the last dose of Klonopin? Patient: Two months ago. Doctor: I'm going to do a search on the dose now and see if you have it.

How are you? I haven't seen you in a long time. Patient: I'm fine. I hurt my hand the other day. Doctor: How did this happen? Patient: My husband and I moved into our new house, and we were building an office. I tried to nail something, and I hammered my hand. Doctor: Oh, no. So you and your husband live together now? Patient: Yes. We just got married.

I was driving my little sports car through an intersection when another car hit me on the left side. The impact forced my car from the road and into a utility pole. Doctor: I'm so sorry to hear that. I'm glad you're here in one piece. Did you wear your seat belt? Patient: Yes, I had my seat belt and everything. Patient: Good. Patient: Unfortunately, the driver was drunk and threw a traffic signal. Doctor: It's a shame. Do you remember how fast the car went when she hit you? Patient: If I had to guess that maybe eighty miles an hour. It seems that the driver who hit me was already quoted by the police. Doctor: Have you lost consciousness at all? Patient: Yes, I briefly lost consciousness when the help arrived at the scene.

How are you? Patient: Good for the most part. I'm still tired enough for most days, but I'm trying to stay more active. I wonder if it has to do with my sugar levels? Doctor: Hm let's see. I'd like to check your glucose and lipid signs and bring you back here again. Patient: Oh I noticed blood in my stools. I'm not sure if it's connected. Doctor: How long is it going? Patient: Maybe a week? Doctor: Do you have any other symptoms? Black or tarry stool? Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea? Lightness? Patient: No, none of this. Doctor: I would like to order a hemocculture then. He's going to check if you still have blood in your stools. Patient: Can I do it about blood work? Doctor: Yes, they will be able to help you and answer other questions that you might have. Patient: Ok. I'm going to try to go there tomorrow.

Life becomes difficult at seventy-two years. Doctor: I am sorry to hear it. Have you ever had pain in your knee? Patient: I have. Both knees are ruined. Doctor: Are you able to do any activities yet? Patient: No. I sit all day. Doctor: I see. We can offer to do arthroplasty to repair your knees. Patient: What is it? Doctor: It is like a reconstruction of your joints. This will help you increase your ability to do daily activities. Patient: I am ready to go. I have to make my life. Doctor: It sounds good. I just want to confirm some information. Do you want to say that your quality of life and your daily activities are declining? Patient: Oh, yes. These knees make my life terrible.

How long has he been since you noticed behavior changes? Guest_family: A few days ago. Doctor: Did he complain about any pain? Guest_family: Yes, he was- Doctor: Was he? Guest_family: Sorry, my phone was on vibrates and I had to turn it off. Doctor: No problem. Guest_family: He pointed to his stomach and said it hurts. Doctor: Does he have any other symptoms? Guest_family: He told me he was feeling calm. I took his temperature the other night and he was running a fever of an O two. Doctor: Everything vomited with nausea? Guest_family: Yes, he vomited a few times.

Very well, and just to remind you, you had a withdrawal of the Ex Fix from the right knee with a M U A following O R I F of a fracture of the right tibial plateau. Patient: Yes, it looks familiar. What is M U A? Doctor: This is manipulation under anesthesia. We folded the knee in order to break by force some scar tissue. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: Yes, it's great, eliminates a certain need for P T in fact. How do you do it today? Patient: Overall, my pain is under control. Doctor: You have an influenza like, or symptoms of infection? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: So, no fever, or chills, or sweating during the night. Patient: Yes, nothing like that. Doctor: Super. I see you have no drainage of the pining sites, but it doesn't bother me too much. Pattor: Ok, good, no sweat.

I had a fall. And I was told to consult you for my heart conditions. Doctor: Okay. Uh? Can you tell me a little bit about everything you've experienced before or diagnosed before? Patient: Yes, I have high blood pressure. And they also diagnosed me with other heart diseases. I can't say all the names I don't remember. Doctor: That's good. Let me pass your medical record first. Doctor: Let's see what we have here. Your file says you have high blood pressure, high blood pressure. Besides, you have a history of severe tricuspid regurgitation with mild pulmonary hypertension that has had the heart.

So, just a few questions before you finish. Do you smoke or drink? Patient: I drink sometimes. I never smoked. Doctor: No drug use? Patient: No. Doctor: Are you sexually active? Patient: Uh I was back in Haiti, but it was back in eighty-two. I had several male partners, but no sex since you moved here. Doctor: Did you use protection during your previous meetings? Patient: Most of the time, yes. Doctor: Any history of S T Ds? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you currently work? Patient: Yes. I work for an automobile dealer on the street.
Are you taking medication for your pain? Patient: Yes, occasionally. Doctor: Which one? Patient: Just a regular pain medication.

person: I had a patient, but I developed an iron deficiency with blood in my stools. At least that's what she said to me so far. Doctor
sentence: Do you have diarrhea? Patient: Yes, I am. Doctor: How would you describe the frequency? Patient: I would say it's chronic at this time. Doctor: How long have you known you have an anaemia? Patient: Uh, it's been a few months now. Doctor: What markers have been assessed to diagnose this? Patient: I had, uh, an unusual pruritus, and I had a C B C Doctor: Do you have the results of this? Patient: Yes, just here. Doctor: Thank you, it shows a new hemoglobin, and M C V of sixty-five. Patient: Were these two patients raised?

Hello, before we start, what are your pronouns? Patient: I identify as a woman, and I use her pronouns. Doctor: Thank you, then, have you ever had a surgery? Patient: Yes, I actually have a list of them written. Doctor: It is really useful, can I see it? Patient: Absolutely, you go. Doctor: Thank you. So I see that you have had several intestinal surgeries, including, um, hysterectomy, rectoceal repair, and appendectomy. Do all these familiar sounds. Patient: Yes, I have this list of all the surgeons. Doctor: Is there any other important conditions I should be aware of? Patient: Yes, I actually have another list, um, I have rhematica polymyalgia. Doctor: It's all a great information to know, thank you very much.

person: I only had one case of polycythemia with secondary myelofibrosis. Also, you are J A K two positives. Do you remember when you were diagnosed? Patient
sentence: It was sometimes between two thousand five and six. Doctor: They did phlebotomy and then you transferred here in our health care. Patient: Yes. Doctor: You were on hydroxyurea and interferon, right? Patient: Oh, it was a terrible time, I was not able to deal with anyone of them. I had nimble and tingling with burning pains in my hands. Doctor: You don't have brothers and sisters that you can eat weeks of transplant. Patient: That's true! Doctor: You were also considered for Unrelated Transplantation, but you could not be on the list because of the social condition and health you also had more days than you did not receive it.
Do you have a family history of neurological disorders, such as multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's or dementia? Patient: No. Fortunately, nobody in my family has neurological problems.

How long have you had this rash? Patient: Not long. Less than a day if I had to guess. Doctor: Does this cause you pain? Patient: No, it's just really itching. I tried to apply Cortisone to it, but it didn't help much. Doctor: The rash is located on the left arm? Patient: Yes. I only noticed it on my left arm.

Hello. How do you do today? Guest_family: We are doing very well. The ED told us to come here. We are here to see if we could get things out in his leg. Doctor: I see. Did he have a fracture before? Guest_family: Yes, he did. Here is the report of the October surgery two thousand seven. Doctor: Great. Let me look. It seems that he had a lateral fracture of distracted condyl. He then underwent a screw compression to repair the fracture, correct? Guest_family: That's right. Doctor: Perfect. So now we have to remove the material that was used to repair the fracture, correct? Guest_family: Yes, that's correct. What are the risks of surgery? Doctor: The risks include the risk of anesthesia, infection, bleeding, change of sensation and movement of the end, failure of removal of the material, inability to relieve pain or improvement of movement.

I look at her x-ray ratio and she had a sternotomy in the past. Guest_clinician: Yes, and we placed an I C D implant and a mechanical implant of aortic valve. Her pleural effusion was really disturbing causing an opacification on the left side of her diaphragm. Doctor: Oh I see!
What happened to your right leg? Patient: I had a little accident with a dog, he bit me. I was really scared.

person: I did something that might have caused it? Patient
sentence: No, not that I know. Doctor: Did you take the Flomax for your B P H? Patient: Yes, I was. Doctor: What is the Coumadin? Patient: Yes, I took this too. It was recently retained, but I take it normally. Doctor: Remind me, I don't have my file with me. What conditions did you take the Coumadin? Patient: I have an F I B and a stroke. Doctor: Thank you. Isn't this your second appearance of brute hematuria this month? Patient: Yes, Doctor. You're sure you haven't had any falls or news of the leg yet x. Patient: Yes, I actually fell a week ago. Doctor: Where is your pain this fall? Patient: I know the patient is a little stronger than the patient.

Hello. Patient: Hello, Doctor. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: No sir, I am happy single. Doctor: Good for you, what do you do to make a living? Patient: I don't currently work, I go to university full time. Doctor: Even better for you, then drink or smoke? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: What about more illegal substances? Patient: Absolutely not, nothing like that. Doctor: Do you like to work? Patient: I play tennis and swimming every week, I love it. Doctor: It's very good, you keep very healthy.
Is there any other medical history in your family? Patient: My mother died of a stroke. Doctor: How old was your mother when she died? Patient: She was sixty-two years old.

When was the last time you had a cigarette? Patient: Seventeen years ago. Doctor: All right, and how much did you smoke? Patient: About one pack a day. I was smoking for forty-four years. Doctor: Okay, what would you say about IV drugs? Patient: No, I didn't do that.

person: I noticed that his eyes were really swollen before going to bed and that's where I gave him Benadryl. At that time, he also seemed nasal. Doctor
sentence: Sorry to hear that. Did he have a fever? Guest_family: When I took his temperature last night, it was an O. Doctor: And did you give him anything for the fever? Guest_family: I was worried to give him something on top of Benadryl. Doctor: I see. And how did he feel differently? Guest_family: It seems more loose than usual. Fortunately, he eats and drinks well. Doctor: Did he cough at all? Guest_family: No, but his voice was a sort of raspy. Doctor: Any shortness of breath? Guest_family: Hum no. Doctor: Why not episodes of vomiting, diarrhea, or stomach pain? Guest_family: No, I don't think so.

Do you have any major medical problems that I should know, sir? Patient: Maybe I could. What exactly do you mean by that, doctor? Doctor: Well, it's wide, but it could be anything from depression to high blood pressure, cancer. Patient: Okay, that's what I thought. I have high blood pressure. Doctor: And your mental health, is there anything remarkable there? Patient: Uh, yes, I have anxiety, too.

Are you a student? Patient: Yes, I am. I go to university. Doctor: What field do you specialize in? Or do you know yet? Patient: Yes! I study biology. Doctor: Excellent! Do you live in dormitories? Pattor: Yes. Doctor: Are you from the region? Pattor: I'm from Breckenridge. That's where my parents live. Doctor: It's a nice place to be from where. Do you use tobacco, alcohol or recreational drugs? Pattor: I smoked grass with friends, but not much. I have a few beers at the occasional dormitory party.
Do you have a history of surgery? Patient: No, none.
Hello! Patient: Hello, how are you? I have a bad migraine so can you please turn off the lights, it is too bright and uncomfortable. Doctor: Of course. Let's see what happens here.

Okay, let's talk about your family history. Patient: Oh, I have a very disturbing family history! Doctor: Why do you say that? Patient: Well, my mother died because of a heart attack in the late sixties and my father had liver cancer and he died of it. Doctor: Oh- Patient: Oh, that's not all. My only son suffers from hypothyroidism and my daughter's two children have cerebral paralysis to be born prematurely. Doctor: Oh, that's so unhappy. Patient: Yes.

Yes, it's been a while. Doctor: So everything I should know again? Patient: Uh, I had stuff on my chest for which I saw a dermatologist. Doctor: What kind of things? Patient: I think they were cysts. Doctor: No reason to worry? Patient: No, the dermatologist said everything was okay. Doctor: Happy to hear that. Patient: I too. I'm actually here to see if you can write me a PD slip. Doctor: Is it for a job? Patient: Yes, my last one was negative, but I need to have another one. The last one I did was in nineteen ninety.

Did you notice her strangled behavior in any way? Guest_family: No. She works perfectly normally. Doctor: Did she spoil, cough, vomit or any other symptom? Guest_family: No. The only thing I noticed was that she spilled the liquid on her clothes, the floor and on her hands. Doctor: Did you see her ingesting the liquid? Guest_family: No. We didn't see her putting it in her mouth. I looked in her mouth and I didn't see anything.

person: I am forty-three years old and this is the first time that I have had a major problem. It is only this month that I have felt weaker than usual. I am much tireder and short of breath every time I move. Doctor
sentence: Recent weight loss? Patient: Yes, I have lost about fifteen pounds in less than two or three months. Doctor: How is your appetite? Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea? Patient: The appetite is good enough. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Doctor: How is fever, chills, sweating, cough? Patient: No, ma'am. Doctor: And all chest pain with your breathlessness? Patient: No, ma'am.
Do you have allergies? Patient: No I am not. Doctor: Are you sure? Patient: Yes I am.
What are your family medical history? Patient: Nothing I know.

Did you have a full-term delivery? Guest_family: No, he was born prematurely. Doctor: Was he hospitalized? Guest_family: Yes. Doctor: Was he on any machine like those that help to breathe? Guest_family: No. Doctor: Was he hospitalized after? Guest_family: No. Doctor: Had he had an operation? Guest_family: No.
Do you have allergies? Patient: No I don't. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Ok. Patient: You only ask for medical allergies? Doctor: No, I want to know about all allergies.
Someone smokes in the house? Guest_family: Yes, we do. Doctor: You two? Guest_family: Yes, but outside, not inside. Doctor: OK. Guest_family: We are careful.
Do you use tobacco, inhalation or recreational drugs? Patient: No.

I had a headache all week with the neck and the pain of the lower back. Doctor: How would you describe the headache? Patient: Is it constant? Patient: He comes and goes for the most part. Doctor: How would you judge him on a scale of ten with ten being the worst? Patient: One seven or eight. Doctor: Do you have a headache now? Patient: No, not well this second. Doctor: Did you take - Patient: Nothing for pain? Doctor: Yes. Patient: I took a little Ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. Doctor: Any other symptoms associated with headaches, such as fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision or sensitivity to light? Patient: No, not really.
Do you have any other problems? Patient: Actually, I have a degeneration of the back disc. Doctor: Oh really? Patient: Yes. Doctor: When were you diagnosed? Patient: Maybe twenty-ten?
Family history of illness? Guest_family: To be honest, I'm not sure. Maybe? I should check and return to you.
Do you have a history of surgery? Patient: I remember a child surgery, but I don't know what the surgery was for. It was so long ago.

Who are all there in your family? Patient: Well, it's just me and my brother now. My mother died because of a stroke at the age of seventy-nine years. Patient: My father had a good life without any medical condition. He died because of old age, he was ninety one. Doctor: Wow! All the family history of heart disease or diabetes? Patient: My other brother had prostate cancer but that's all. No diabetes or heart problems. Doctor: Ok.

And are you allergic to medicines? Patient: Oh yes, I'm allergic to what you call Cipro- Doctor: Ciprofloxacin? Patient: Yes! And also, Asprin but the coated one, what's the name? Doctor: Oh, you mean enteric coated Aspirin? Patient: Yes, yes, this one!
Hi, I'm Dr. Chandler. Patient: Hello Doctor. Doctor: So tell me what's going on? Patient: I have a headache.

In the past, I was treated for the osteomyelitis of my fifth right toe with antibiotic I V. Doctor: Oh, how long was it? Patient: Ah, about five years ago! I was treated for six weeks. Doctor: Oh, okay. You also have a history of diabetes mellitus? Patient: That's right.

Do you have any major medical problems that I should know? Patient: Oh, yes, I have a complete list of things that are happening, doctor. Doctor: Like what, madam? Patient: Well, I have high blood pressure, hypothyroidism, arthritis, and G E R D Doctor: I see, what about mental health, or neurological diseases? Patient: Um, I have an anxiety disorder, and I had migraines about thirty years ago. Doctor: Thank you, I see also on my picture that you have already had Morton's neuromas, is it true? Patient: Yes, I have one on both feet.

I'm going to ask you a few questions about your medical history. Have you ever received a medical diagnosis? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you ever received a diagnosis of diabetes or heart disease? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you ever taken medication for a long-term illness? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you ever had surgery? Patient: No.

Who is in your family? Patient: Well, my mother, my father and I have four brothers aged eighteen, sixteen, fourteen and twelve and I also have a younger sister. She is only three. Doctor: Wow, and you all stay together? Patient: Yes, and we also have two dogs and two cats. Doctor: Okay. And everyone at home is doing well? Guest_family: No, not really. Everyone at home is sick with a cough, a cold and a rough nose, except Patient: Except for my mother! Guest_family: Yes, except for me gracefully. Doctor: Hm, and have you traveled anywhere recently, especially during the holiday season? Patient: No, good mom? Guest_family: Yes, we haven't traveled anywhere recently. Doctor: Ok. Anyone in your home smokes? Guest_family: No. Doctor: No exposure to smoke, right? Guest_family: No.
So are you currently on a medication? Patient: Yes, I am taking Atenolol and Mevacor. Doctor: Hm, and no allergy to any medication? Patient: Not what I know.
I think you're good to go home. I'm going to prepare your exit paper. Patient: That's great!

So how long have you been married? Guest_family: We've been together for twenty-seven years now. Doctor: Oh wow, it's wonderful to hear. How did you meet the guys? Guest_family: We met in high school. We've been dated for a while and then we took a break, but we ended up getting back together. Doctor: Aw, the high school lovers. I have a few questions to ask. Guest_family: Shoot. Doctor: All tobacco, hard drugs or alcohol? Guest_family: She doesn't do anything about it. Doctor: Super. And do you know any medical problems that run on her side of the family? Guest_family: Nothing major. Doctor: I see.
According to your chart, I see you have C O P D and hypertension. Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Okay.
Do you use tobacco products? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol or use recreational drugs? Patient: No.
Hi! Patient: Hello, how are you? Doctor: I'm fine. Patient: I think I'm fine now. Doctor: Yes, looking at your results, I think your kidney failure is also resolved.

How old are you, young man? Patient: I have twenty others. Doctor: You have the right hand or the left hand? Patient: I am the right hand. Doctor: So tell me what brings you here today? Patient: Everything started the fifth of November. Then after I saw the progressive increase in my symptoms. So, everything was like numbness. I couldn't feel my legs. They felt numb all the time and there was no coordination between them, and it also affected my walk. All these symptoms were at their limit just like a half-day or more. It continues the same way since then. I also have the impression that someone is putting pins and needles on my legs halfway from the calf on both sides. Doctor: You have felt a diminished coordination or less between your legs, right? Patient: Yes, it is true.

What brings you to the clinic today? Patient: Well, I had a progressive loss of vision in my right eye. My eye doctor told me that I had to come to a neurologist. So I'm here. Doctor: Ok. How long did the loss of vision progress? Patient: About two months. It seems that it progressed very quickly. I always had a bad vision in my left eye. It started about two years ago. Doctor: Can you still see out of your left eye? Patient: No. I'm considered blind in this eye now. Doctor: Have you had any other symptoms associated with your loss of vision? Patient: No. Doctor: No headache? Patient: No. Doctor: What do you dominate your hand? Patient: What do you want to say? Doctor: What hand do you write with or use in a dominant way? Patient: Oh! I'm a right hand. Doctor: And what age do you have? Patient: I'm a sixty-two years old. I would like to do a test. Doctor:
Do you have a history of rheumatic fever during your childhood? Patient: No. Doctor: A history of other usual childhood diseases? Patient: No.

So tell me a little more about your family history, please. Patient: Of course, I know that my grandmother on my mother's side had pancreatic cancer, and my father had prostate cancer. Doctor: Apart from cancer, are there other conditions that you know run in your family? Patient: Hum, I know that my father had heart disease, as well as diabetes.

What are you doing? Patient: I am a registered nurse. Doctor: That's nice. Doctor: And you smoke or drink? Patient: No sir. Doctor: A history of drug abuse or something else? Patient: Absolutely not! Doctor: OK, good.

Hello, sir. How are you? Patient: I'm fine, thank you. I'm just trying to come to you more regularly to make sure my lungs and my heart are okay. Doctor: It's great. Previous notes say you stop smoking. Are you still on leave? Patient: Yes, I'm leaving in nineteen-six years. I come to the doctor's office every year to make sure that the damage I caused to my lungs is monitored. Doctor: You have a great attitude. I appreciate when the patient takes his health into his hands. We can only do the same, but it's the patient's to get there. Patient: Yes. I was smoking for a long time and I know it was bad for me. It was just the norm in the day. Doctor: You drink at all? Patient: I do it.

Hello Doctor. I am from the assisted living center of High Hope. I am the designated assistant of Mister Rath. Doctor: Good. What brings you here? Guest_family: I have some Mister Rath food journal sheets here. He has already lost fifteen pounds in the last three months.

Your condition and all your vital signs seem to me stable at the moment. You have to be very careful because your condition can become poor or it could also improve. Patient: Okay, so what do you recommend? Doctor: Do you have a support system? Is there anyone at home to take care of you? Patient: Yes, my son and his family live with me. They are very attentive. Doctor: That's good. Take care of yourself and let me know if your condition gets worse.
Where do you work? Patient: I am a truck driver. It is a large construction company. I work for them. Doctor: You smoke? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Cigarette or something? Patient: I do Cigar.

I don't smoke, I drink, I would sometimes say. Doctor: What about the tougher drugs, you use one? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: Yes, to my wonderful husband. Doctor: It's great, what do you both do to live? Patient: I am a social worker, and my husband is a chemistry teacher from high school. Doctor: What do you both do. What kind of people do you work with a social worker? Patient: I love, I work with adults and neglect problems. Doctor: Yes, it's great. Do you have children? Patient: Yes, we have two sons. Doctor: Do they live at home? Patient: No, they are both adults and now alone.

Your two parents had heart complications. Patient: Unfortunately, yes. My mother died from a heart attack at seventy-three and my father at eighty. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Patient: I also lost my brother. He died from a brain tumor when he was nine. Doctor: I can't imagine how difficult it must have been. Patient: It was a dark time in our lives, but we survived like a family.
I'll write you a prescription for a stimulant. His name is Cylert.

Are you married? Patient: Yes. I have been married for twenty-two years. Doctor: Do you work? Patient: No. I am unemployed. I have not yet completed my collage diploma. I have been in school for two years. Doctor: Continue.
Nurse, do you have a report on my patient?
I do. She has a two year history of small cell lung cancer, which spread to both femurs, lower lumbar spine, and pelvis.
Oh, no. Did she get chemotherapy?

She's had chemotherapy and radiation treatments multiple times. She can't remember how many times she had those treatments because she lost track. She also said she finished a series of ten radiation treatments for pain relief.
How are her symptoms now?
She's currently having severe pain.
I see. Does she have any imaging done?
She does. A C T scan was done to check for metastasis.
Thank you, Nurse. I'll go see her now.
No problem.
Hello, ma'am. What is the reason for your visit today?
I wanted to see if I could get some treatment for my pain.
What kind of pain are you having?
I feel like it's a burning feeling? I don't know. I can feel it one spot and then it spreads down.
I see. Where do you feel the pain?
I feel it mostly on my lower right side of my back.
Do you feel it anywhere else?
The back of my right leg and knee.
Would you said the pain radiates down from your back to your knee?
That's it. Radiating. I forgot the word.
No problem. On a scale from zero to ten, with zero being no pain and ten being the worst pain of your life, how would you rate your back and leg?
They're both a ten.
Oh, wow. Do you feel pain anywhere else?
Yes. Could you check my feet?
Let me check them. I'll feel around your left foot. Let me know what you feel.
I feel like the bottom is numb. Ouch. It also feels sharp at times too.
I see. The nurse stated here that you had some pain spreading to your mid back too. Let me feel it really quick. Let me know how that feels.
Ouch! It hurts a lot. I feel a sharp and dull pain. Most of the time, it's just aching.
I see. When do you feel like the pain in your body gets the worst?
I'd say when I'm sitting in a car for a long time.
So, just sitting for long periods of time?
Yeah. When I stand and walk, too.
Have you ever taken anything for the pain?
I am on a load of narcotics for the pain.

You have observed blood in your stools or in your vomiting? Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: Okay, well. Have you noticed an increase in your frequency of urine or your emergency? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you feel muscle weakness or fatigue? Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: None of the known history of arthritis? Patient: No. Patient: And no fever due to fungal infection or something, is it not? Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: None of the history of pneumonia? Patient: No. Patient: And I am looking at your record, so no antecedents of stroke, C V A, or a convulsive disorder. Patient: That's right. Patient: No problem related to thyroid or hormone? Patient: No. Doctor: And you have no blood problems, that's correct. Patient: No problem with thyroid or hormone.

person: I have had episodes of nausea or vomiting? Patient
sentence: No. Doctor: Have you noticed any blood in your intestines? Patient: No. Doctor: Even if you are taking medication without problems, for about ten years, methotrexate may be the cause of the wounds of the mouth and inflammation in the small intestines. These are two common side effects of the use of methotrexate. I do not know as well the wounds of the mouth of NSAID. The use of aspirin can cause gastrointestinal disorders. I think the most likely cause of the wounds is methotrexate and not the use of aspirin.
Are you on insulin? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Are you on metformin too? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And glucotrol? Patient: Yes I take this. Doc: Are you on lipitor? Patient: Yes.

What did he give in the E R? Doctor: Epi one M G, zero point three M L subcutaneously with fifty M G of Benadryl intramuscularly. In about fifteen to twenty minutes, he reported that his itching had improved. The eruption itself faded a little and he began to feel much more comfortable.

So, what brings you here today? Patient: Well, I have a lot of medical problems and I see Doctor X for them, but I wanted a second opinion, so he sent me back here. Doctor: Yes, he's a good man! Don't worry, we'll take care of you. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: So, let me start by getting your medical history. Patient: Of course, I had skin cancer that was treated by the withdrawal of this part. Doctor: Ok. Patient: Other than that, I have an anaemia and an acid reflux problem. I also have a history of C O P D. Doctor: Very well. Patient: I also suffer from sciatica that was caused mainly by my arthritis. Doctor: I see.

What is the problem today, sir? Patient: When is the pain the worst? Patient: Honestly, it starts with the first stage of the morning. Doctor: Does it get worse throughout the day? Patient: Yes, it gets worse all day with activities. Patient: What treatments have you had for that? Patient: Well, nothing to this day. Patient: Where is your heel pain? Patient: It's on the right heel, then it's on the lower part of the heel and inside the heel. Patient: Have you changed your medical history since your last visit? Patient: No, it's the same old as you. Patient: Do you have symptoms like flu? Patient: Like fever or chills? Patient: This, or vomiting or headache? Patient: No, it's the same old doctor as you.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My family has a high blood pressure. I have a family member who had colon cancer. My daughter has a tremor. They don't know what caused it? Doctor: Okay.

person: I had problems with your hand eczema. Patient
sentence: Yes, it was inflamed. Doctor: Can you confirm your age for the files please? Patient: Of course, I'm twenty-nine years old. Doctor: If I'm not wrong, you're from Vietnam, aren't you? Patient: Are you married? Single or with a partner? Patient: I'm single. Patient: You're working somewhere? Patient: No, I'm currently unemployed. Doctor: Okay, since you're a patient in our dermatology department, let me update all your information in the files. Doctor: According to my records, we saw you here in our office on July 13, two thousand and four. Patient: Yes, I think you've had a lot of trouble washing your hands.

Have you applied the triamcinolone zero point one for a hundred three times a day to your rash? Patient: The one on my left wrist? Doctor: Yes. And the Bactroban ointment is also three times a day as necessary for your insect bites. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you always use Nystatin on your lips once a day as needed? Patient: Uh yes. I used it much less now. Doctor: So let's see, your other medicines are the same as July 30th O four with the exception of Klonopin? Patient: Yes, I mean I take four MG in the morning and six MG at night instead of the six MG and eight MG that were recommended.

So, I'm looking at your reports, you don't have anemia or any other blood disorders. Patient: Well, it's a relief! Doctor: Yes. Doctor: Let me check your lymph nodes. They're not palpable. I don't see any swollen glands or anything. Patient: Great!

person: I see that he has eight pounds and thirteen ounces, and that he was born by...? Guest_family
sentence: Yes, section C. Yes, he was never hospitalized. He was born a week earlier. Doctor: Okay, I would like to ask you a few questions about pregnancy and other history. Guest_family: Yes, of course go there. Doctor: Great, did you have infections during pregnancy like G B S or S T D? Guest_family: No, I didn't, I only had infections to the thumb and toes and we treated this with alcohol. We had boils in the family, so I'm not afraid of minor infections like this one. Doctor: Did you smoke during pregnancy? Guest_family: Yes, I did, but I stopped after five months. Doctor: Sir, did you have D's while she was pregnant? Guest_family_2: No, I wasn't diagnosed with anything.

I smoke cigarettes. I work on quitting. Doctor: I am glad that you were trying to stop. We have a lot of tools now to help with cravings. How much do you smoke a day now? Patient: I smoke about one pack a day. Doctor: You drink alcohol or use recreational drugs? Patient: I drink but I don't do drugs. Doctor: How many alcoholic drinks do you drink a week? Patient: I drink about four drinks a night. I drank a lot more than that. I drank a lot more than that. Patient: I am a network engineer. I work for Shepherd Prattt. Doctor: Are you physically active? Patient: I was very athletic when I grew up. Now I was not married to my wife on a regular basis. Doctor: What are you doing for the job? Patient: I am a network engineer.

You live alone? Or do you have children? Patient: I live with my girlfriend, and we have a child together. I also have three other children of my ex-wife. Doctor: You smoke? Patient: I used to smoke. But I resigned fifteen years ago. Doctor: And alcohol? Patient: Yes, I drink beer. Around one to two beers a day. Doctor: You work? Patient: I am retired at this moment, but I was working in an iron company.
Would you like to go home? Patient: Yes, I can? Doctor: Yes, you can.
Are you studying? Patient: Yes. I do my computer major. Doctor: Do you live alone? Patient: No, I live in my family. Mainly my parents and sisters.

Have you ever had an operation? Patient: No, not what I know. Doctor: So, no removal of the gallbladder, or replacement of the joints? Patient: Unless they did it while I was asleep, but none of which I remember.

I remember you mentioned that one of your family members had bone cancer. Are there any other medical problems in your family? Patient: Unfortunately, yes. Brain accidents and dementia are the other two major problems.
Are you allergic to medicines? Patient: Me? Doctor: Yes. Patient: No, I'm not. Doctor: Are you sure? Patient: Yes, I'm sure. Doctor: Very good!

What brings her today? Guest_family: Oh, doctor. She didn't do well at all. Guest_family: I think she's getting worse. Doctor: I understand. I'm sorry to hear she doesn't feel well. Let me see what we can do for her today. Guest_family: I haven't taken her temperature since this morning. It was one hundred three degrees when she woke up. Doctor: What time did she wake up today?
