Guest_family: Um, about eight I think. She also suffers from apnea. Doctor: It looks like she has a superior respiratory infection. Guest_family: Will she get better? Doctor: Yes, she should feel better once we start treating the infection.

And you have had recurrent abscesses for two years, is that correct? Patient: Unfortunately, yes. Doctor: Where have they been located? Patient: Um in the public area and my thighs. Doctor: Did you ever need a drained abscess? Patient: Yes. I had about four I and D.
How is your overall health? Patient: Well, I guess. I'm being treated for I B S by my G I. The last time I was in, they told me my white blood cell levels are not where they were supposed to be.

Do you have a family history of chronic diseases that I should know? Patient: What do you mean by that? Doctor: Well, it could be anything from depression, arthritis, cancer. Patient: Oh yes, my mother has arthritis.

How do you move? Are you able to perform your daily activities? Patient: A little, not so much. Doctor: So listen to your body and do as many things as possible. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don't stress too much. Patient: Okay, I can do it.
Are you allergic to anything? Patient: No, I'm not allergic.

person: I think he did quads on October 10, two thousand and seven when he was thrown away. Doctor
sentence: Yes, and we have O R I F on his fracture dislocation of the left elbow. Guest_family_1: Yes, he also fractured the neck of his right glene, um, if I remember correctly. Doctor: With what hand he writes? Guest_family_1: He writes with his right hand. Doctor: Okay. This fracture seems to have healed very well; the children usually heal quite well. How does he feel today? Guest_family_1: Yes, he is only ten years old. He was stiff enough, so he went to P T, and using his Dynasplint. Doctor: It's good that he is already at P T. His fracture of the left elbow is still cured, so we should do another operation to remove this material. This can help to reduce irritation with the extension of the elbow.

Since you have a family history of coronary heart disease, let me check you for its risk factors. Patient: Yes, my father had it. Doctor: Any history of high blood pressure or diabetes? Patient: No. Doctor: How about smoking, smoke? Patient: No, I don't smoke. Doctor: And in the past, did he mention any other doctor that you might have signs or symptoms that you might have coronary heart disease? Patient: No. Doctor: Ok.

Who are all in your family? Guest_family: It's me, my husband, my two older children and this little baby. Doctor: Everyone lives together? Guest_family: Yes Doctor: She goes to any day care? Guest_family: No, she's home all the time.
Do you drink? Patient: Oh, I do it but sometimes. Who doesn't like a good cocktail! Doctor: Okay. And cigarettes, do you smoke? Patient: No, I don't smoke.
I'm fine. Patient: I have bad nausea. Doctor: Oh, so sorry. Patient: And I feel very dizzy as if I'm going to faint. Doctor: All right, let me see what's going on. Patient: All right.

What brings you into the office today? Patient: I had a stroke about a month ago. The right side of my face is still not moving. Doctor: Is it only the right side of the face that is affected by paralysis? Patient: Yes. It has improved a little since I was in the hospital. Doctor: This is a good sign.
Are you using tobacco? Patient: What, like smoking cigarettes? Doctor: Yes, ma'am? Patient: Oh, no. I don't do anything like that.
Have you ever had an operation, madam? Patient: Yes, I had it as a melanoma some time ago. Doctor: I see here that you had a hysterectomy too, is that correct? Patient: Oh, yes, that's true.

person: You don't remember anyone in your family with a history of neuromuscular diseases, do you? Patient
sentence: No, no one I can think of. Doctor: Do you know anyone who has had deformities of the feet or neuropathy in the arms or legs? Patient: No, not a person doesn't come to mind. Doctor: Great. Does anyone in your immediate family have a high arch? Patient: No, at least nobody I know. Doctor: And you said your aunt or sister has type two diabetes? Patient: Aunt. She's had it for some time now.

So what I think is that you might have a short-term memory loss due to high stress, but I also think it's probably due to your current situation. The other impression I have is that you have anxiety problems and again it's related to stress. Patient: Yes, I have anxiety problems.

What is the problem today? Guest_family: Well, it's a vegetarian but it has a high cholesterol level and it's on a medication to control it. Doctor: Has he changed his diet? Guest_family: Yes, he did it when he received a letter saying that his fat levels were high in the blood. Doctor: What types of foods did he eliminate? Patient: Oh, you know, all the fun foods. Like cappuccino, quiche, croissants, candies, vending machines, all that. Doctor: You take your lunch to work? Patient: Yes, I do about three or four times a week instead of eating so much. Doctor: Do you exercise now? Patient: Yes, I can work about six or seven days a week. Doctor: What kind of doctor do you like to do? Patient: Well, I swim, I cycle, then I raise weights?
The patient looks free in his diaphragm. Guest_clinician: How old is the patient? Doctor: Seventy-six. Guest_clinician: Medical history? Doctor: Unknown now.

Of the ten, ten being the most serious pain imaginable, how would you rate your pain today? Patient: Today it is about six or seven, and it is usually quite constant there. Doctor: Does the pain change with time? Patient: Yes, when it is cold outside it is ten out of ten. It is better when it is hot outside. Doctor: Does the pain change throughout the day? Patient: Yes, it gets progressively worse as the day continues, but I also have trouble getting out of bed in the morning. Doctor: Of the ten, how would you rate your pain at night? Patient: Oh, there are ten out of ten. Doctor: Does the pain wake you at night? Patient: If I sleep at all. I don't sleep well, and when I do it for less than one hour at a time.

As long as I take care of her, she's had this tracheal tube and she barely talks. She says especially if she needs anything. Doctor: Okay. It's mentioned in her report that she has a smoking story. Guest_family: She signs yes. Doctor: Well, it's good. I think it'll be hard to take all the medical information from her past.

Did you take anything for high blood pressure? Patient: Yes, I started taking Toprol and, uh, the one that starts with an A. I forget what it's called. Doctor: Hm you're talking about Avalid? Patient: Yes, that's it.

Before you start, can I ask you how old you are? Patient: Hello, doctor. I am fifty-six years old, now. Doctor: Great, thank you. What is the problem today, madam? Patient: Well, I need some support for food recommendations for a healthy diet for my husband and me. Doctor: Why would that be, madam? Patient: Hum, I have a lot to do, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, acid reflux, and I just want to lose weight. My husband also has a high cholesterol level. Doctor: Tell me more about your eating habits, please. Patient: Well, we live alone now that our children are gone, but I'm used to cooking very large portions. Doctor: Do you have trouble doing food for only two people? Patient: Yes, that's a good way to say it.

Hello! What brings you to the office today? Patient: Hello! I couldn't go pee, and I had this acute pain in my left side. Doctor: Have you recently had surgical procedures? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have a history of an enlarged prostate or kidney stones? Patient: No. Doctor: I would like to do an imaging. Patient: Ok.

Has he ever had problems with mental retardation in the past? Guest_family: No. Doctor: Has he attended general education? Guest_family: Yes, he graduated from high school last year. He had an IEP. He has a job now. Doctor: Oh really. It's great. Guest_family: We have followed a program for people with disabilities to find him the job.

And you are- Guest_family: Hi, I'm her nurse. Doctor: So, do you know about her medical past? Guest_family: I have very little information, because I have very recently started working with her. She has dementia and that's the main reason I was hired. Her family wanted someone to look after her twenty-four seven. Doctor: Oh, I see. Guest_family: But I have her medical records. You can take a look. Doctor: Yes, it will be nice. Let me check her reports quickly. She has a history of schizophrenia, chronic anaemia and hypothyroidism and she also suffers from asthma. Guest_family: Yes. Doctor: Oh, I also see here that she was tested positive for PD, was she diagnosed with tuberculosis? Guest_family: I don't know, but I didn't say it. Doctor: Ok.

Your last visit took place on April 7, two thousand five, that's right. Patient: Ah no, it was April 8, two thousand five, Doctor. Doctor: That's right. So, something has changed since? Patient: No, it's really the same.
nausea, vomiting or diarrhoea? Patient: No.
What do you think doctor, what does she have? Doctor: Well, I think she has hay fever. Otherwise, she looks like a good two-year-old girl. Guest_family: Hm, okay.

Hello, sir. I will be your doctor today. How do you feel? Patient: Um who? Where am I? Doctor: You are in the emergency room. Patient: I am where? Doctor: The police found you outside the local bar. Do you remember what happened before you arrived here? Patient: I am no longer at the bar? Doctor: No, you are here because someone was afraid you needed medical care. Patient: I don't know what's going on.

How's your husband? Patient: He's good. He usually comes with me to my appointments, but he had to do some shopping this morning. Doctor: Happy to learn he's going as well. Patient: Me too. Doctor: I just have another question for you about your social history.

How do you feel today? Patient: I do well, considering. Doctor: Are you sleeping well? Pattor: Yes. I could have a good sleep last night. Doctor: Were you able to eat without any problems? Pattor: Yes. I ate a little breakfast this morning. Doctor: Were you able to have a bowel movement again? Pattor: Yes, I did this morning. Doctor: Have you experienced any difficulties with your movement? Pattor: It was still a little difficult and difficult. Doctor: Ok. Continue the fiber-rich diet that we discussed, and it should improve.
Are you allergic to medicines? Patient: No

So do you remember when your last papa smear was? Patient: I wrote it here in my notes. It was in October of two thousand one. Doctor: Great, do you have children? Patient: Yes, I have a beautiful daughter. Doctor: It is wonderful. Have you been pregnant only once? Patient: Yes, I just got pregnant once and it was with my daughter.

Did you undergo surgery? Patient: I had my two tubes attached in O one and I had a polyp removed when I was fourteen years old. Doctor: And he was a patient: Oh, sorry I didn't want to interrupt. Doctor: It's okay. I just wanted to know if this polyp was found in your colon? Patient: Yes, it's true.
Doctor, can you check my baby? Doctor: Yes, it is. Guest_family: He has fever.

When did you notice him for the first time? Patient: Well, he started on my back and then he made his way to my torso and arms. Doctor: Did you find itching yourself? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Any potential trigger for rash, such as food changes, new drugs, or unknown exposures? Patient: No. I mean I removed some insulation in my basement a few days ago, but I didn't feel itching that day. Doctor: Any shortness of breath, wheezing, swelling of the face, swelling of the tongue or lips, or other associated symptoms? Patient: No.

Are you allergic to something? Patient: As in medicines? Doctor: Yes, sorry. I was talking about drug allergies. Patient: Oh yes. I'm allergic to Sulfa medicines. Doctor: What happens when you take Sulfa medicines? Patient: Get out in a terrible rash. I remember I had to go to the E R the first and last time I took it. Doctor: Wow, I'm sorry. Rashes can be very uncomfortable and sometimes require immediate attention. Patient: Yes, so more Sulfa medicines for me. It's sure.
Are you smoking? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How much do you smoke? Patient: Honestly, I smoke every day.

Is a member of your family having major medical problems? Patient: Yes, my mother died of a heart attack. She was seventy years old. My father died of cancer; it was prostate cancer. He was about eighty. Doctor: Something else? Patient: Hm, my brother had both a heart disorder and prostate cancer and he died about seventy-four.

Where is your pain? Patient: Just above my belly button. It has bothered me for three weeks now. Doctor: Does the pain come and go? Pattor: Um is quite constant, but it seems like it gets worse at night. Doctor: Do you find that sitting or lying in some positions helps the pain? Pattor: Not really. I can't really seem to get comfortable since he started. Doctor: Have you taken any pain medications? Pattor: I uh- Doctor: Yes? Pattor: Um I took Pepto Bismol a few times, but it didn't do much. Doctor: Have they already brought you back for your C T scanner? Pattor: Yes. Doctor: We should get the results of your scan pretty quickly then. In the meantime, I'm going to put some extra orders.

Hello, doctor. Doctor: So I've reviewed your past notes, are there any other diagnoses I should know about? Patient: Well, I've had a depression for a while now. Doctor: Thank you for telling me about it.

What are you doing to make a living? Patient: Now, actually, I don't work. Doctor: It's good, I'm not here to judge. Are you married? Patient: No, I'm happy to live right now. Doctor: Good for you, do you have children? Patient: No, I don't have, it's just for me. Doctor: Do you drink or smoke? Patient: No, I don't do anything about it. Doctor: Good, and you use something harder? Like illicit drugs? Patient: No, I don't do it at all. Doctor: Good, and with ten being the most stressful day every day, how would you assess your stress level in ten? Patient: Today, I would say it's about eight out of ten.

Hello. How are you today? Patient: My head hurts a lot. Doctor: I see. Did the nurse come to ask you about the medical history? Guest_clinician: Sorry, Doctor. I was looking for you. I reviewed his story with him, and nothing changed. Doctor: Perfect. Let's do some tests to see why your head hurts. Patient: I'm ready for less pain. Let's go.
We're going to check around your knee now. Patient: Okay, it sounds good. Doctor: It looks like your deep tendon reflexes are the same on both legs. The feeling looks great and intact.

Can you tell me anything about your family? Illnesses in the family? Patient: My father's mother has diabetes and hypertension and my father's father had emphysema and he was a smoker. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Is there a history of child death that was perhaps less than a year old? Patient: No, there isn't. Doctor: Okay. That's great. No diseases for small children? Patient: No.

person: You have an infection of the urinary tract. Patient
sentence: I knew it was an I U T. I have already had it, but nothing so painful and severe. I feel like I'm going to die! Doctor: Oh yes, it's because you have something called acute cystitis and its usually very painful and can cause serious complications. Patient: Well, is it because of my diabetes? Doctor: I'm afraid I don't have any better news for you, but your diabetes is out of control. It's way too high and you need to be really careful. Do you take your medication? Patient: Yes! Doctor: How to eat? Patient: Yes, sometimes I don't care about my diet. Doctor: Well, you have to monitor your diet, you can't just be careless. I'm going to change your treatment for diabetes. And let yourself take care of the antibiotic that should relieve you.

Hello, ma'am. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: Before I started, I just have a few questions. Do you remember the diseases you had when you were a child? Patient: Yes, I had some. I had my throat, mumps and, uh, chickenpox growing up.

Hello! I'm Doctor Sherman. Patient: Hello! It's good to meet you. Doctor: It seems your P C P sent you for a possible prostate problem. Patient: Yes. I'm nervous. Doctor: Don't be nervous. We'll start by discussing the symptoms you've experienced, a physical exam and then we'll get a urine sample if you're able. Patient: Ok.
What do you take for allergies? Patient: Claritin. Doctor: Ok. Patient: For my allergic rhinitis.
Do you have known allergies to medication? Patient: No. None I know.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My father had a heart attack and died at sixty-one years old. Doctor: I'm really sorry to hear that. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Do you know any other major health problems in your family? Patient: No. None I know. Everyone is relatively healthy. Doctor: That's good.
Hello, sir, how do you feel today? Patient: I feel terrible. Very sick and I can barely move. I feel so weak.

So we looked at your previous blood results, now let me see what these reports say about today's C B C exam. Patient: Of course. Doctor: Okay for your haemoglobin levels to look within range, the white counts are thirteen point three, then seven point six lymphocytes and twenty-six thousand platelets. Doctor: Ok? Patient: Ok.

You're back for a follow-up on your right arm pain, aren't you? Patient: Yes. Almost a year ago since the beginning of the pain. Doctor: How does your arm feel? Patient: I still have this dull pain in my upper arm? Patient: How long does the pain last? Patient: He comes and goes, but now the pain is more persistent since I saw you the last time. Patient: Remind me again. You're right to the hand. Patient: Yes. It's hard to do things with persistent pain. Patient: I bet you do. Do you experience a feeling of numbness or tingling in your arm or hand? Patient: No, but I have had this feeling of pain in my hand that was transmitted to my fingers.
What kind of surgery have you had in the past? Nothing big or small? Patient: I had a section C for my child and a D and C. Doctor: Okay.
Are you currently taking medication? Patient: No.
So, are you allergic- Patient: Medicines? No allergies here.

Hello again! Patient: Hello! Doctor: The results of you M R I have shown nothing worrying. Growth factors were normal with normal cellular function and no sign of decreased blood supply to the brain. Patient: This is good news. Doctor: Yes.

person: I saw it a week and a half ago because I had another fall. Maybe by the end of December since today is the seventh January. I had problems with my right hand. It's like I'm clumsy on my right side. I ended up falling because my right hand missed the ramp that you took for the head of the stairs. Doctor
sentence: Did you leave or to the right hand? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Can you tell me a little more about the problems you have with the right hand? Is it located in the right hand? Patient: Yes, M made problems with my right hand.

Do you smoke? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: How much? I mean, can you tell me the approximate amount? Patient: Yes, sure, I smoke half a pack a day. Doctor: What about alcohol and drugs? Patient: No, I don't drink or consume. I have a five-month-old baby.

With ten of the greatest pains imaginable, how would you rate your pain today out of ten, madam? Patient: Well, out of ten, I would say it's about seven. Doctor: How would you describe your pain? Patient: Um, I would say it's deep, and it really hurts. Doctor: Where's your pain? Patient: It's in my lower right back, then in my buttocks. Doctor: What activities are making your surgery worse? Patient: I can't go up and down the stairs without a lot of pain, and it hurts when I sit down for a long time, like when I drive. Doctor: Before this pain, how would you describe your level of activity? Patient: I was very active before all this started. Doctor: Are you able to do any of your previous activities? Patient: Not really, I have a lot of problems with things around the house, like all the chores and projects I was able to do.

Welcome! Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Let us have some experience. What is your medical history? Patient: I have some memory loss problems. Doctor: What kind of memory problems? Patient: Well, I have seizures. Doctor: Do you know what type of seizures you have? Pattor: I have temporal lobes seizures. Doctor: Do you have any other health problems? Patient: I also have high blood pressure. Doctor: OK.
Have you had any medical problems? Patient: No. Doctor: What about surgery. Patient: No, I never had any surgery.

person: It was taken care of by the doctor. It was taken care of by the doctor. It was taken care of by the doctor. It was taken care of by the doctor. I see that the main complaint is memory loss and cognitive decline. What exactly happened, and how did you notice the symptoms? Let me document that today it is January 12th of nineteen years. Guest_family
sentence: We noticed it the previous week at Thanksgiving last year in nineteen years. We have a family tradition where we play a game and this time we took it to Vail, Colorado or play "Murder She Wrote" at one of our family gatherings.
Aren't you allergic to anything? Patient: No, I'm not. Doctor: Any food or other pollen? Patient: No, I'm not allergic to anything.
We saw that he got up in the morning and in the evening. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes.

person: He didn't have a problem with his pregnancy. My job was very spontaneous, and it was a normal delivery. Doctor
sentence: Is he the only child? Guest_family: No, I still have two children. Doctor: How much did he weigh at birth? Guest_family: He had about eight pounds and ten ounces. Doctor: Do you remember his steps? Guest_family: Yes, I wrote everything for all my three children and I brought this with me. He sat alone for seven months. He was able to stand by eleven months and crawled around sixteen months but he didn't walk until eighteen months. Doctor: What are the problems he faces now? Guest_family: He can't walk properly.

What brings you back to the clinic today? Patient: I have had severe bruises. I have been taking Coumadin for three months now. Do I take a lot of Coumadin? Doctor: You take a normal starting dose. Some people do not metabolize the medicine as well as others. I would like you to test for hypersensitivity. After getting the test results, we will be able to adjust your dose accordingly. Patient: Ok.

person: There is no chest pain on the exercise or shortness of breath normally or when you are trying to sleep? Patient
sentence: No, no chest pain and shortness of breath. Patient: Let me see your legs. They look good. I don't see pedal oedema. Usually this happens due to excessive water retention. Patient: No. Doctor: Any feeling of numbness or tingling? Have you fainted or lost consciousness at any time? Patient: No, well! Doctor: Any double vision or blurred? Patient: No. Doctor: Any difficulty of hearing or all of its continuous hearing that you hear? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you received urine from the mouth or blood?
Are you all right? Patient: Yes, it's all right. Doctor: It's great. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I think you can go home now.

I review my notes from your last visit. Your last visit took place on May 10, two thousand four, that's right? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Have there been any changes since your last visit? Patient: Well, I have a certain increased paranoia. Doctor: Have you been treated, and are you taking medication for that? Patient: Yes, and it's actually much better with the medicine than another doctor gave me.
I have just met one of my patients who, I believe, has pertussis. Guest_clinician: Second case of the day. What is their name and date of birth? Doctor: Hm give me a second to get their information.

Have you ever had a psychiatric or psychological treatment? Patient: Uh no, no treatment whatsoever. I mean I find myself in a bad mood from time to time when I'm faced with some stressors, but moods rarely diminished ever long-lasting.

Do you remember when your last influenza vaccine was? Patient: I don't remember what month, but it was in nineteen-nine. Doctor: Good, and you remember your last vaccine against pneumonia? Patient: Let me look at my notes here, um, it was in nineteen-sixteen. Doctor: Thank you, now tell me about your parents. Do you know their medical history? Patient: Let me think, my father is still there, he had a stroke. Oh yes, and he has high blood pressure. Doctor: How old is your father? Patient: He is seventy-nine years old now. Doctor: Good, and your mother? Patient: She died when she was seventy-four years old, she had a heart failure and an emhysema. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have brothers or sisters? Patient: Thank you doctor, no, he's my only father and I now.

How are you today, madam? Patient: I am very well. Doctor: Any kind of alcohol consumption? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you ever taken some kind of illegal drug? Patient: No. Doctor: And smoking? Patient: No. Doctor: Are you still working? Patient: No, sir. I had problems with my knees, and they had to put in the new ones. I was somehow disabled and that's why I retired.

Do you have chest pain? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: No shortness of breath? Patient: Yes, I don't have breath only when I have to make a form of effort like walking long or running. Doctor: Ok. What about bowel problems? Patient: No, I don't have stomach problems except I have to go use a bathroom often. Doctor: Ok frequency. What about prolonged bleeding problems or something like that? Patient: Nothing like that.
Does she live with someone? Guest_family: Yes, we all stay together, so just the immediate family. My parents, me and my sister.

person: I had a little sun? Patient
sentence: Yes I actually came on. Doctor: Very good way to get a little exercise. Doctor: OK, what's going on? Pattor: I have a stomach pain. Doctor: Since when? Pattor: Oh, it's been a while now. Doctor: Can you tell me more about your pain like it started and what exactly do you feel? Pattor: Ok, the pain started like a stomach pain but it's constant here in the middle upper part of my stomach. And sometimes it moves towards the back. Doctor: Can you tell me if it's stabbed pain and if it's related to a specific time of the day? Pattor: Of course, I'm getting stabbed pain episodes but they're not related to meals. Once the wave comes to you, you don't have any other solution than you've had one day.

A specific family medical history that I should be aware of? Patient: No. Physician: In your family, even grandparents, if you know them, were they suffering from diabetes or high blood pressure? Patient: No. Doctor: No one else sick at home? Patient: No.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My mother has a high blood pressure, and she had a stroke last year. Doctor: Your mother is still with us after stroke? Patient: Yes. She's fine. Doctor: Good. And your father's medical history? Patient: My father died in a car accident when he was 40. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Patient: Thank you.
Anyone in your family has a history of drug or alcohol abuse? Patient: No. Doctor: Any other health problems that may occur in your family? Patient: No.
Do you drink? Patient: Like, every day? Doctor: No, just in general. Patient: No, I don't drink at all. Doctor: Do you smoke? Patient: No, I don't do that either.
Drug allergies? Patient: Oh yes, I'm allergic to... what's the name of the drug? It's called Napro- Doctor: Naprosyn? Patient: Yes, Naprosyn.

person: I'm a great old Swedish fool. Doctor
sentence: Ha! Not so old! Patient: I've had episodes of vomiting and I feel very nauseous. Doctor: Oh I'm so sorry to hear that. Patient: I also have pain in the urine, I think I could have UT I? Doctor: Let's see here. So, you already have a right hip problem, bone disease, hypertension, depression, and heart rate disorder for a long time. Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Let me see what we can do here. Patient: Thank you doctor.

Are you drinking? Patient: No, never! Doctor: Have you ever smoked? Patient: No. Doctor: How about drugs? Marijuana or something else? Patient: Well, I've always stayed away from drugs. Doctor: Good. And what is your living arrangement? Stay with your children? Patient: I live at home. My children visit me but especially I live alone. Doctor: Ok.

What kind of patient do you identify? Patient: Thank you. What are the symptoms you feel in your right hand? Patient: I have numbed and tingling in my right hand. Doctor: Are there specific fingers in which you feel it? Patient: I really feel it in my fifth, fourth and third fingers. Doctor: What kind of treatments did you do for this pain? Patient: I took anti-inflammatory drugs, I stayed away from sports and stuff like that, and I rested. Doctor: That helped at all? Patient: No, not at all, its numbness and tingling. Doctor: It sounds like a carpal tunnel, there's a quick, minimally invasive surgery that I can do on this hand, since it hasn't responded to non-operative treatments. I think it's really going to help. Patient: I'd like to do this, what's the name of the procedure? Doctor: It's a carpal tunnel.

Congestion and cough. Doctor: Oh, how long? Guest_family: It's been three weeks now. Doctor: Ok. Guest_family: It's been like this for so long, but nothing else. Doctor: How about sick fever vomit diarrhea? Guest_family: No fever, no vomiting, nothing else. Doctor: Ok great.
What are you doing? You work or at school? Patient: I am at school. Doctor: Good. Patient: Thank you.

Do you have any children, madam? Patient: Yes, I have a wonderful little girl at home. Doctor: Wonderful, have there been any complications with your pregnancy or childbirth? Patient: No, everything went very well. I am grateful. Doctor: Well, have you ever been hospitalized for any problem whatsoever? Patient: No, fortunately. Doctor: Well, so I can assume that you never had an operation? Patient: Yes, I never had.

I had a hip replacement years ago. Doctor: Both hips? Patient: My left. Doctor: Total? Patient: Yes. Doctor: I had my uterus and appendage removed. I was young when I brought out my appendage. Doctor: Do you remember who did your most recent operations? Patient: I would like to do it. I should look at my files and come back to you. I have everything at home. Doctor: It's not a problem.

Where do you live? Patient: I live with my mother at the corner of the kitchen. I have been there for a few years. Doctor: Are you the patient's mother? Guest_family: Yes, I am the mother. Doctor: How do you deal with everything? Guest_family: We just want what is best for him. We want to support him in every possible way. He only has an older sister. She lives in Texas and she also wants the same for him. Before starting to live with us, he lived in places A B C D and some were in very bad condition.
Are you taking medication? Patient: Yes, I am taking Accutane for my acne problems. Doctor: All right, other medicines? Patient: No, just that. Doctor: All right.

I had a craniotomy. I had a cerebral hemorrhage and there was a hemorrhage inside and outside the brain that they had to repair. Doctor: How was the cure for that? Patient: I took some time but the doctors said I had a normal time of recovery. Doctor: It's good. Did you have any other surgeries? Patient: I had surgery on my leg for a fracture. They put some pins in my leg. Doctor: Ok. Patient: I did some sort of surgery on my stomach when I was a child. I'm not sure what the operation was. All I know is that it was a very common procedure without complications. Doctor: Ok. Is that all? Patient: Yes. That's all.

Do you have any medical problems I should know? Patient: Well, what exactly do you mean by that, Doctor? Doctor: Well, it could be anything D H D to depression in epilepsy. Patient: Oh, no. I have nothing like that.

So, let's talk about your family, anyone in your family has neurological problems? Patient: No, I don't think so, my parents experienced some memory loss but it was when they were in their '90s. And I guess it was mostly from old age rather than any neuro problem. Doctor: Yes, it's true. And what about your brothers and sisters, do you have? Patient: Oh yes, I have five brothers and sisters and they're pretty healthy! I mean they're all doing well, nobody has memory problems as much as I know or neurological disease. Doctor: Ok.
Do you have a family history of heart disease? Patient: My mother has a coronary heart disease.

Hello, Miss X Z. Dr X and I will pass your report with you to make sure everything is correct. Then I will ask you a few questions. Patient: It sounds good for me. Doctor_2: Hello, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me, please? Patient: I am seventy-six years old. I am also resident of A S D F if that counts. Doctor_2: Thank you, ma'am. Doctor: Doctor A B C asked you to see us, that's right? Pater: That's right. Doctor: Perfect. Doctor X, could you pass over his previous diagnoses? Doctor_2: She is diagnosed with hyperlipidemia, hypertension and atherosclerosis of cerebrovascular films. Is that all correct, ma'am? Pater: Sounds good? Doctor: you have also undergone surgery.

Hum, should I follow a special or mild diet? Doctor: No, nothing like that. You can have a normal diet. Everything you like to eat. Patient: At this age, my diet is very limited. I'm going to be eighty-two next month. Doctor: Well, I don't think you need to restrict your diet. You can follow your regular diet. Patient: Very good, thank you.
Are headaches running in the family? Patient: My mother receives migraines and she told me that she runs on her side of the family.

Do you work? Patient: No. Doctor: What is your highest degree? Patient: I have been in high school. I lived alone for fifteen years until December of ninety-four. Doctor: How is your living situation now? Who takes care of you? Patient: My daughters started taking care of me on a shared basis. Doctor: Do you smoke? Or drink or have ever used drugs. Patient: No.

Do you smoke, or have you smoked in the past? Patient: Yes, I quit two years ago. But before, I used to smoke two packs a day. I started smoking as a teenager. Doctor: Do you drink at all? Patient: I used to drink six packs of beer plus two extra drinks a day for many years.

Yes, the last time I was seen at Pulmonary Medicine Clinic was March two thousand and four. Doctor: It was long enough. How do you feel? Patient: I was actually hospitalized for psychiatric problems and I now live in a nursing facility. Things have not been too big. I don't like living there. Doctor: I understand frustration. When you live in a nursing facility, you lose a lot of your freedom. Patient: I want to live in my apartment, but I know I'm too ill to take care of myself. Doctor: Despite all this, how are your breathing problems? Patient: I feel quite stable. I still have little breath when I do activities, but with my condition I feel like something I won't have to live. Doctor: Unfortunately, it's the nature of the disease. I'm glad to see that lung disease hasn't changed since your last visit.
You can continue to work, I just want you to be careful. Patient: Thank you Doctor. I will be. Doctor: Great.

Can you confirm your age for me, madam? Patient: Of course, I am fifty-six years old. Doctor: Well, what brings you to see me today? Patient: Hum, I piss a lot, and I have a little blood in this urine too. Doctor: Have you ever had a cystoscopy? Patient: Yes, it was impassable, that's what they said to me. Doctor: When are your episodes for the most part? Patient: Um, usually during the day. I don't have them at night. Doctor: Do you have a pain with urination? Patient: No, no pain. Doctor: Apart from the little blood, can you say if there is pus in your urine? Patient: No, I don't have this, it's just the little blood. Doctor: Have you taken any medicine for that? Patient: Hum, I had Ditropan, and it didn't do very well.
Health problems on your mother's or father's side? Patient: No, we're a healthy family.

Hello sir, how are you? Patient: I don't know, I don't know if I'm good, or my problem gets worse and that's why I went to your clinic for a neurological consultation. Doctor: Hm, don't worry! We'll take care of you, let me start by taking some details. Patient: Of course! Doctor: So, have you been referred by someone or- Patient: Oh, no I referred to your clinic. Doctor: Okay. And what's your age? Patient: I'm sixty-four! Doctor: Ah, that's smart, you certainly look very young. And what's your dominant hand? Patient: I'm right hand.

You can stay with your friend and make sure you take good care of yourself. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Make sure you follow Dr. X on Monday or Tuesday. I know that Dr. Y has already discussed his plans. Keep taking your medication except Prozac. Okay?
Are you smoking or drinking? Patient: No, I've never touched a cigarette and I never planned to.

What brings you to the clinic today? Patient: I received a diagnosis of binocular diplopia twenty-five years ago, but I didn't have much trouble with it until about a year ago. Doctor: What did you notice up to symptoms? Patient: Suddenly, I started having a double vision. Doctor: Did the double vision take place more than once? Patient: It happened almost every day and throughout the day. Doctor: How long do episodes last? Patient: They only last a few minutes at a time.

What's the problem? Guest_family: He has a lot of pain on both feet, and if you look at him, he looks like his feet rotated inward. Doctor: All right, let me see, okay, um, he has low feet rocker. Guest_family: All right. Doctor: I think he would benefit from a subtalar arthrodesis, a possible autograft, and an achille elongation. I'll review the details of this procedure right now. Guest_family: Can we do surgery soon? Doctor: Yes, we can. But we'll probably need another procedure until his foot matures further.

person: I know we're doing a disability test today. Patient
sentence: Yes, that's right. Doctor: And we're evaluating your injury to the right shoulder. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Was it an injury to the job? Patient: Yes. I was working as a C N A at the Veterans' House. Doctor: How did the injury to the job occur? Patient: I was transferring a patient from a wheel chair to a bed, and I was hurting my shoulder. Doctor: What's the date of the incident? Patient: January first, two thousand and two. Doctor: Do you currently work? Patient: No. I haven't been able to return to work yet. Patient: I have to ask some specific questions to the L and me paperwork.
Are you up to date on your vaccines? Patient: I've never been vaccinated before. My parents don't believe in vaccines.
What are your medical history? Patient: No. I don't have any health problems. Doctor: Do you have a front-line doctor? Patient: No. I don't have health insurance at the moment.
Are you married, madam? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you smoke, use alcohol or recreational drugs? Patient: No.
In the past I was very fat! In fact, I was morbidly obese. I also had high blood pressure, but after my surgery it was solved. Doctor: So everything is okay now? Patient: Yes.
So you've been referred by Dr. X. Patient: Yes. Doctor: According to him, I don't see any change or correction to your current illness, do I? Patient: Yes, I think so.

Do you have a related family history? Patient: You mean like heart problems in the family? Doctor: Yes, something like that. Pattor: My brother died of a heart attack. It was suddenly everyone was shocked. Doctor: How old was he? Pattor: He wasn't so old; he was just in his fifties.

When did he start? Patient: This afternoon. Doctor: Hm, so your blood pressure is one eighty-five out of eighty-three and your heart rate is twenty-one that is quite high. Doctor: We started you on I V Metoprolol. This will help you lower your heart rate. Doctor: And you said you were sixty-six years old? Patient: Yes. Guest_family: My mother stopped taking her medication. Doctor: I can say her reports. Her blood pressure is quite high. Guest_family: It's been several months since she took her medication for the last time. Doctor: Well, it's not good! Doctor: And she drinks and smokes? Guest_family: Yes, both. Doctor: How much do you drink Ma'am? Is it occasional? Guest_family: She drinks a lot!

Hello, how are you today? Patient: I'm here for breast cancer screening. Doctor: Have you ever obtained a mammography? Patient: Yes, I have. I'm also trying to follow my self-examinations every few weeks. Doctor: It's great. I'm glad to see you in addition to your preventive care. Patient: I'm trying to be as careful as possible since my sister had breast cancer.

What is the problem today, sir? Patient: Well, I have had toes problems in the past. Doctor: I see, and the rest of the lower body, problems there? Patient: Actually, yes, I have left knee problems in the past, too.

Do you have a history of health problems that I should be aware of, ma'am? Patient: Uh, yes, I had a mastectomy and a chest tube placement. Doctor: Oh, wow. Do you have any chronic problems? Patient: Yes, I have a chronic A F I B.

I have had side effects. Doctor: Have you had side effects? Patient: No, not yet. Doctor: Good, can you describe your erections for me, sir? Patient: Well, they were firm now, and I can enter again for about ten minutes. Doctor: Well, do you have chest pain? Patient: No sir, I stopped using my nitroglycerin too. Doctor: Good, do you have fever or chills? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: Do you have pains with urination, or blood in the urine? Patient: No, nothing like that, sir, everything is normal. Doctor: How many times do you urinate during the day? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: Do you have pains with urine, or blood in the urine? Patient: No, nothing like that, sir, everything is normal.

I'm afraid, I don't have better news for you, your reports confirm cancer. Patient: We suspected it all along, but now, as it is confirmed, it's just hard to accept. Doctor: I'm sorry, I totally understand. Do you want some time? Patient: No, I'm fine. Doctor: Hm, you also have hypertension and diabetes. Patient: Yes, I know. Doctor: Have you had chest pain or shortness of breath or discomfort? Patient: No, I don't have heart disease.
Are you married? Patient: Yes. I am happy to live with my husband and four children. Doctor: Oh, do you smoke? Patient: No. Doctor: What about alcohol or any other type of drug use? Patient: No.
Someone in the family had medical problems? Patient: Oh yes. Doctor: Can you please specify? Patient: So my mother's family had heart problems. My father's sister had a sugar problem.
And you are not allergic to anything good? Patient: It is true. Doctor: Medicines or pollens or anything? Patient: No nothing. Doctor: Good.

Has redness worsened in the last few days? Guest_clinician: I think so. His right toe seems worse to me. Doctor: Is she in good health otherwise? Guest_clinician: Um besides her toe and nasal congestion, she does well.

Did you have an operation on your breasts? Patient: Yes, they removed a mass from my left chest. Doctor: Okay, and what other operations did you have? Patient: I don't have a gallbladder, then I had a breast augmentation, I had cardiac surgery three times and they removed half of my pancreas. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And knee surgery also, on the left side. Doctor: Okay. What type of cardiac surgery did you have? Patient: Cardiac Ablation.

What happened? Guest_clinician: She was brought urgently by her son. Apparently, she is doing well, no distress. She is alert, and I was able to communicate with her and take her story, she was cooperative and calm answered all my questions.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My family has high blood pressure and diabetes. Doctor: Do you have a family history of nervous system disorders or diseases such as multiple sclerosis, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, epilepsy or stroke? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have children, Mademoiselle? Patient: Yes. I have a son, he was born on October 30, two thousand eight.

Have you ever had any heart problems in the past? Patient: I remember that I had something heart, but I don't know what it was. I don't understand the medical terms. Doctor: Okay, that's good, I totally understand. We'll try to look for your medical history. Patient: I have hypertension and diabetes, you know that well? Doctor: Yes, type 2 diabetes. Do you know any other things you've had in the past? Patient: Yes, four years later I had a pulmonary embolism. I also get frequent infections in the urine. Doctor: Ok. And I can see on the record that you have a high cholesterol level and a gastric ulcer too. Patient: Yes, that's pretty right. Doctor: Ok. What surgery did you have in the past? Patient: I've had my appendix, then Section C, cataract surgery and repair of hernia in the past.

Yes, fortunately for my husband. Doctor: What do you do to live? Patient: I work as office manager right now. Doctor: Do you smoke? Patient: Yes, I smoke. I smoked one pack a day for the last twenty years. Doctor: Do you drink? Patient: Actually, yes, I drink every day. Doctor: How much do you drink every day? Patient: Well, it varies, but usually anywhere from three to five drinks a day. Doctor: Ok, do you do illicit drugs? Patient: No, absolutely not. Doctor: What do you do for exercise? Patient: Well, I'm going to do walks, and as a low impact cardio. But, I like to play softball with my friends too. Doctor: Very well, how many times do you exercise? Patient: I work a few times a month.

I'm going to make a list of symptoms and I'd like you to tell me if you've experienced it. Patient: OK. Doctor: Headache? Patient: No headaches. Doctor: Do you cough at all? And if so, then you bring blood with your cough? Pattor: No cough. Doctor: Any chest pain or shortness of breath that wakes you up in the middle of the night? Pattor: No. Doctor: Do you feel short of breath when you move? Pattor: No. Doctor: Any visual, auditory or swallowing problems? Pattor: None. Doctor: And finally any changes in your bowel movements or urinary habits? Pattor: No. All normal.
You're looking at your medical history now. No change since your last visit? Patient: No change.

person: I learned to take my health more seriously. I have to start catching things before they come, not after. Doctor
sentence: I couldn't agree more. From your last check notes, it seems that you had a good knee and back surgery about eighteen months ago. How are you doing? Patient: Yes, I had a good knee replacement. I'm fine so far. Nothing complains about you. I can do almost everything I want now. It's such a good way of life that you changed before the operation. Doctor: What are you doing with your new body? Patient: I travel all the chances I get. I come back from a cruise. Doctor: I hope to be as agile as you when I retire. Now, I see only the patient traveling.

And when did you get your last tetanus shot? Patient: Um, I don't remember correctly, but it should be in my reports. I had one back, just don't remember when exactly. Doctor: Ah, no problem. I see it here in your reports and it's up to date. So it's good. Patient: Cool.

So where do you stay? Patient: I stay close to my apartment. Doctor: Alone? Patient: No, I stay with my boyfriend. Doctor: Ok, and you smoke and drink? Patient: Both. Doctor: And how many say you smoke a day? Patient: Well, I smoke a lot. Seven to eight packs a day. Doctor: Oh! And for how many years? Patient: I don't remember exactly but for many years, I have a long history of smoking chain. Doctor: Hm. And alcohol? Patient: Even I drink a lot. I drink for many years. Doctor: Hm.

How are you, sir? Patient: One under sixty years of age. Doctor: What happened? Patient: I was visiting my son in Cheyenne, Wyoming, and then on October 10 when I was taking a shower, I felt a pop in my head. I don't know what happened after that. Guest_family: We thought he was taking a long shower that day. Then about an hour and a half later, my son suspected something was wrong and we were going to check it out. There, we found him unconscious on the floor of the shower. Our son then brought us back to Iowa and since then he complains about these headaches and that he doesn't feel well.
Is this your first operation or have you had any other operations in the past? Patient: This will be my second. I had a hernia repair back in O 10.

Where do you work? Patient: I work at the Hilton as a chef. Doctor: Smoke or consume any form of tobacco? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you drink or have you ever used an illegal drug? Patient: No, none of this.

Where do you feel the most pain? Patient: I should say to the heels of my feet. I spend a lot of time on my feet at work. Doctor: I see. What kind of shoes do you normally wear at work? Patient: Regular tennis shoes. Doctor: Are they cushioned? Patient: Not really, but they are durable enough. Doctor: I would advise to get an orthotic for your shoes to help with heel pain and rest your feet when you are at home. In the meantime, I would like you to see a specialist to make sure that nothing else happens. Patient: Okay, I'm good with this plan. Doctor: Do you have any other problems? Joint pain, difficulty walking, nausea, vomiting, or other symptoms? Patient: No, just heel pain at the moment.

person: I've tried all the methods, mainly I used inhalation and I V drugs. Doctor
sentence: Right now, you're on methadone, right? Patient: Yes. I'm also going to the department of psychiatry for my depression and these drug problems. Doctor: What's your life status? Patient: I live with my roommate.
I'm going to ask you a few questions about your family history, sir. Patient: It's okay. Doctor: Does anyone in your family have any medical problems? Patient: My two parents had diabetes.
What about your paternal family? Patient: I do not know my father. No idea of his family. Doctor: What about your mother? Kindergarten? Patient: I have no idea. I am not in contact with her.

Hello, sir. Before you start, how old are you? Patient: Hello, doctor. I'm forty-one. Doctor: Thank you, and how long have you had this left knee pain? Patient: It's been about two years now. Doctor: Is there an injury? Patient: Yes, I sprained my MCL playing hockey at the time. Doctor: What kind of symptoms have you had in this knee since then? Patient: Well, the knee closes on me, I can't stretch it, and it really hurts if I try to do it. Doctor: Do you feel instability? Patient: No, not at all.

Did these symptoms start at the same time? Doctor: I think so. Doctor: Where does your chest feel the most crowded? And how would you rate the pain at the moment? Ten being the worst. Patient: Both sides. I would say it's three at the moment. Doctor: Is he sending pain or numbness or tingling in your arms? Doctor: Does this improve the jaw pain as a result? Patient: No, but it gets worse when I cough. Doctor: Is this your first time you feel this type of congestion? Patient: Oh no. I have something like this about ten months ago. Doctor: Did this improve on my own? Patient: No, but it gets worse when I cough. Doctor: Is this your first time you feel this type of congestion? Patient: Oh no. I have something like that about ten months ago.
Are you aware of medical problems in your family? Patient: No. Doctor: Anyone with heart disease or diabetes? Patient: No.
In addition to the pain in the left eye, do you have any other problems? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have a history of eye problems? Patient: None.

person: I have a C P A P at the moment because I have been told that I have an almost severe apnea of sleep. Doctor
sentence: Yes, I see on your card that you have received ten centimetres of H two O nasal pressure and that you are suffering mainly from hypopnea. Hypopnea is shallow breathing. How did the device work? Patient: He certainly reduced my snoring, but my partner continues to wake me up in the middle of the night because the mask takes off. I wear it around five to seven nights a week, but for whatever reason he falls or I want it at random in the night. My wife must always keep the time to sleep.

How do you feel today? Patient: I have a lot of anxiety. Doctor: Another thing? Patient: I have a lot of pain in my chest too. Doctor: You drink? Patient: Yes, I can't stop. I've tried several times but it's hard to control.

So, do you smoke? Patient: No. Doctor: And alcohol? Patient: I drink, but just normal. I have no alcohol problem. Doctor: Okay. So, no history of drug abuse or alcohol, okay? Patient: No, not at all. Doctor: Okay.

I think it's atrial fibrillation. Doctor: Oh yes. You're not on Cardizem and your heart rate is a little rising today. Patient: It's true. I moved it. Doctor: Okay. Let me see. What are the symptoms you're experiencing right now? Patient: I feel very dizzy. I have dizziness and dizziness. Doctor: You're on blood diluents, right? It's Coumadin's therapy? Or I'm wrong here? Patient: No, you're right, but please stop the Coumadin. I'm tired of these regular blood prints. Doctor: See, I understand that it's difficult to control it. It's difficult to regulate it. Patient: Yes exactly. That's why I don't want it.
Good morning, young man.
Good morning, doctor.
Who is this young lady, is this your grandmother, or sister?
Oh doctor, yes, I am his grandmother.
Good, my chart says that you're fourteen years old. Is that correct?
Yes sir.
Good, so what seems to be the problem today?
I've been having pain in this knee for about a month now.
Can you remember a specific injury to this knee?
Um, yeah, I was playing basketball when I jumped, and then when I landed I felt this knee pop.
Do you remember the date of your injury, young man?
Um, it was on December twenty second two thousand seven.
Good, so how have you been treated for this so far?
We went to another clinic first, and they put me in a splint.
Yeah, and then they referred us over to Children's.
Have they taken x rays yet?
Yes, I got back a few minutes ago.
Let's have a look. Well, you broke your leg.
What, where? Can you show me?
Right here, this is a tibial tubercule avulsion fracture with patella alta.
What does that mean, doctor?
Well, he's broken his leg, and pulled some bone off by doing so. We'll need to do surgery on this.
Oh no, what's the name of the procedure?
It's called an O R I F. We'll go in there with some hardware to put everything back together, and he can get on the road to healing.
Let me call his father while we discuss this. What's the risk of infection from this surgery?
Historically, it's less than one percent. We use antibiotics to control for infection.
Okay, will he be asleep for this?
Yes, he won't feel a thing.
That's good too. Will he need this hardware out in the future?

We can remove everything once he has healed up nicely. Other risks include bleeding, changes in the sensation of the leg, hardware failure, need for post op rehab, need for hardware removal, and failure to restore extensor mechanism tension. But I would not worry about these things. I have been doing these surgeries for years and things like this rarely happen.
Yes, his father agrees. We're going to do the surgery.

I am sixty years old. Doctor: What brings you to a visit today? Patient: I have a few notes here with me, but I have a history of polyarteritis nodosa multiplex mononeuritis. Doctor: Is it in your legs, or arms? Patient: Um, it's in my legs. Doctor: I see here you also have sleep apnea. Patient: Yes, I was involved in a night sleep study on C P A P and oxygen. Doctor: Why did they do this? Patient: It was to determine why I had trouble falling asleep and sleeping. Doctor: Did you have any other treatments? Patient: Yes, I did an examination while I was in hospital about two weeks ago, I have the results right here. Doctor: Thank you, so how was your leg pain managed? Patient: Um, I'm taking quite important doses of opioids: I'm a dead patient.

person: I brought her to the emergency. She lives in a competent nursing home. Today, when I went to meet her, I found her with the good side of her face falling down. I immediately rushed her here. Doctor
sentence: Oh, you did what it takes. Ma'am, how do you feel? Guest_family: She has dementia, most of the time she doesn't even remember me. Doctor: Oh, okay. How old is she? Guest_family: She's eighty three years old. She also has a history of stroke after which she developed this condition where she knows what she means, but is not able to make the word or sentence. Doctor: Oh, I see. She has an expressive aphasia, right? Guest_family: Yes, that. Doctor: Ok, let me check it.

Hello, do you translate for the patient today? I'm sorry, but I don't speak Spanish. Guest_family: Yes Doctor. Doctor: My file says that this man is fifty-two years old, is everything correct? Guest_family: Yes Doctor, that's right. Doctor: Well, then, what seems to be the problem today? Guest_family: He injured himself a moment of return when he slipped on a grape while he was at the grocery store. Doctor: Oh no, when was it? Guest_family: It was the second October two thousand eight. Doctor: What knee did he hurt? Guest_family: Doctor, it was his left knee. Doctor: How was he treated for it so far? Guest_family: He went straight to the ED immediately, and he saw his P.P. Doctor: What did he recommend? Guest_family: He only sent him back to P.T., and gave him a bribe.

Do you smoke cigarettes? Patient: I smoke about three packs in a month. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol or use recreational drugs? Patient: No. Doctor: What are you doing for work? Patient: I am an editorial assistant in the local newspaper.
Have you had any side effects on the medicines you have taken in the past? Patient: No, fortunately.

I ask you as you look a little pale. Patient: No, I'm fine. I've always been healthy all my life. Just a little tired now. Doctor: Ok it won't be something we can't fix. Patient: Yes, but I'm fine. Doctor: Yes, I don't see any problems with your past. Patient: As I said, I'm healthy.

person: I have a patient who has been treated by Dr. X for two thousand and two. She had a shunt Codman Hakim set at ninety MH two O. She arrived for the last time at our clinic in January two thousand and eight. At that time, she was recommended to follow with Dr. Y for the medical management of her chronic headaches. She was also recommended to see a psychiatrist for her depression. Doctor
sentence: Have you been to a psychiatrist? Patient: I agreed. Doctor: What brings you here today? Patient: My headaches are back. They are very severe this time.

Tell me about the medical problems you've had in the past or still. Patient: Well, I have asthma, sinuses. I also have hives and there is a history of psoriasis. Doctor: Wow, okay. Any known allergies? Patient: Nothing I've ever known.
No.

person: I had a little time in May in two thousand and eight. Doctor
sentence: Okay, I'm going to go through your painting. It seems you haven't felt well for about two weeks now. Patient: That's true. Doctor: Tell me exactly what's going on. Patient: At first I thought it was just stress and anxiety, but then I get worried that it's something really different or something bad. Doctor: What exactly do you feel? Patient: He started with a lot of palpitations at first. My heart was beating so fast that he was ready to go out.
To check, you're not taking medication? Patient: You got it. Nothing since last year.

What brings you today? Patient: I have this nasty cough and my nose has been super suffocating. Doctor: Do you bring anything when you cough? Pattor: Not really, no. Doctor: Do you have any other symptoms, such as chest pain, headache, nausea, or vomiting? Pattor: No. I had a slight headache last night but I took Advil and it has become better since. Doctor: Do you take something for cough or suffocating nose? Pattor: Just drink tea and take drops of cough here and there. Doctor: All right. Let's take a look at you.

How do you feel today, sir? Patient: I feel pretty weak now, but I'm doing fine right now. Doctor: I've reviewed the notes that were sent to me by the nursing home. They also sent me your medical history. You've been through a lot recently. Patient: Yes, I have. They moved me to the nursing home after I was released from the hospital. I hope it's just temporary. Doctor: I understand that you had a seizure and that's why you were taken to the hospital. Patient: I had multiple seizures. After I was stabilized from the last seizure on this side of my body by not working properly. Doctor: Okay, so you have a partial weakness on this side? Patient: Yes. That's why they moved me to the nursing home. I can't stand up. I'm too weak. I can't take care of myself.

How do you sleep? Are you sleeping well? Patient: Yes, without any disturbance. I sleep like a log! Doctor: Good. Any oscillation of mood or have you felt that your emotions are out of control? Patient: No, just the normal mood swings around my menses or no problem at all. Doctor: Any depression as feeling, sudden change of mood or feeling of sadness or despair? Patient: No! Doctor: OK.
How's he doing today? Guest_family: I think he might have the fifth disease with sinusitis. He's crawling at his school. Doctor: Oh, wow. Let's see what we can do.

Help! I need help! I need to see the doctor! Doctor: Yes, what's wrong? Where's your pain? Patient: My stomach! It hurts so much! I never had this kind of pain before! Doctor: When did he start? Patient: At ten years old! I don't know. It started to hurt from nowhere. One second I drive home and the following thing I know I had to call- Doc: Yes? Patient: Pain is so bad!

Do you have problems like headache, fever, rash, mouth ulcer? Patient: None. Doctor: A problem with vision? As unable to see or double vision? Patient: Um no, I can see everything. Doctor: Okay. Do you have palpitations, as you know about your own heart? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: What about breathlessness while you lie down or you have to get up in the middle of the night to breathe? Pattor: No, I don't feel anything like it lately. Pattor: It's great. Any diarrhea, constipation, or red blood coming out in the stools? Or pale stools? Like any change in the color of the stools? Pattor: No, it's okay. Doctor: All right. Any jaundice recently? Patient: No. No. No jaundice. Doctor: Do you have appetite problems? Patient: Yes, I want to say less that you are hungry.

What is the problem with your knee? Patient: I have had pain in this knee since I stumbled on an ice on March 10, two thousand three. Doctor: How old are you now? Patient: I am forty-seven years old. Doctor: What kind of symptoms have you had since the fall? Patient: It is difficult for me to get up without significant pain, and it seems to me that my knee will yield. Doctor: Was this knee given before? Patient: There is swelling in this knee? Patient: Yes, I also feel like I'm jumping, as when I climb the stairs. Doctor: What kind of treatments did you have for this knee? Patient: I had anti-inflammatory and P T, but I didn't respond well at all. Doctor: Have you had an operation on this knee in the past? Patient: Yes, but I don't remember the name of the operation.

I see you recently celebrated your seventy-second birthday. Patient: Yes. My children and grandchildren made me a surprise. It was really nice. Doctor: Surprises are always fun. However, I am sorry to hear that you are not doing this well today. Patient: Yes, I too. The other day, I had a lot of difficulty getting up from my chair because of weakness everywhere and a lightness that I cannot seem to explain. Doctor: Is this new to you? Patient: Uh, I mean I had spells several times a month during the past year, but I was always able to get up in one way or another. Doctor: Do you remember to lose consciousness during any of these episodes? Patient: Not that I remember. I noticed that I am much weaker than before then maybe I fell more frequently. Doctor: I see.

And where do you live? Patient: Well, I live in this little town called Fayetteville in Tennessee. Doctor: Ah, I see. And you have many friends there? Patient: I have few. Doctor: Ok, and you drink? Patient: No. Doctor: How about smoking? Patient: Never!

What happened last night? Guest_family: She went out at a party last night. She came home drunk and high. Doctor: What did you take? Patient: I took the ecstasy. I only took two drinks. Doctor: How many ecstasy did you take? Patient: I didn't take them all at once. I think I took six tabs. Doctor: What time did you start taking the tablets? Patient: We started taking a little late. I think it was midnight. Guest_family: When she came home, she was agitated and physically agitated.
Do you have a support system? Patient: No, I'm single. Doctor: OK, so live alone at home? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you smoke or drink? Patient: No, I don't.

So are you married? Patient: No, my wife and I divorced a while ago. We have three children together, however. Doctor: Okay, and do you have someone who manages your case? Patient: Yes, I have a lawyer who manages everything. Doctor: You smoke or drink? Patient: No, I never really smoke or drink.
Have you ever undergone surgery? Patient: No, not that I can remember. Doctor: No gallbladder or removal of appendices, c sections, or joint replacements? Patient: No, never done anything.

I just need to confirm some information from my nurse before starting today, sir. Patient: Of course, no problem, doctor. Doctor: Great, so it says here that you're forty-five years old, and you identify as a Caucasian. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Thank you, then what seems to be the problem today? Patient: Well, I have this pain in my right knee, sir. Doctor: Where is your pain? Patient: It's right here, inside my right knee. Doctor: Is there an injury associated with this pain? Patient: Actually, yes. I twisted it while I was at work.
Good morning, sir. Can you confirm your age for me, please?
Good morning, doctor. I'm fifty nine years old.
Great, and which hand is your dominant hand?
Um, I use my right hand for everything.
Great, thank you. So, what seems to be the problem today?
I have had this weird feeling in both of my legs for about three weeks now.
Have you been treated for this so far?
Um, I went to the E R about a week ago.
What did they tell you there?
They said I had progressive sensory and motor deficits in both legs.
Can you describe your symptoms for me, please?
Um, I have numbness, like here starting at my trunk, and then over the last month or so, it moved into my legs.
I'm going to apply some pressure right here at the nipple line, can you feel that?
No, I'm numb from there down.
Have you had any weakness in your legs?
Yeah, I have for the last week or so.
Is it getting worse?
Yes, it is.
When did you start using the cane?
Um, about five days ago, now.
Why did you begin using it?
I'm having trouble walking and going up and down stairs.
Are you able to stand without it?
No, I'm not.
Have you had any loss of bowel or bladder control?
No, thankfully not, but at the same time I haven't had a bowel movement in about three days.
When was the last time you urinated?
It was about twenty four hours ago.
In addition to the numbness, how else would you describe your leg symptoms?
Um, I'd say it feels cold, at least I've felt that for the last day or so.
Do you have any back or neck pain?
No, nothing there.
Do you have any shortness of breath?
Well, I've had it chronically for a while now, but I think it's getting worse.
Have you had any lightheadedness or feelings of faint?
Um, yeah, when I try to stand up.
How long have you had that feeling?
I've had it for about two days now.
Do you have known allergies to medication? Patient: No.

I thank you, I am a fifty-year-old man. Doctor: Thank you, what happened? Patient: I fell from my lining, and I landed on my left foot. Doctor: How far did you fall? Patient: Hum, it was really about ten feet. Doctor: Oh, yes, I see. I have good news for you, there is no gross deformation in this ankle. Patient: What exactly does that mean? Doctor: I don't see any ankle dislocation, which is good. Patient: Oh, that's good news. Doctor: Have you had your dead body with your rays? Patient: Yes, the technology just brought me back.
What medicines are you currently taking? Patient: Augmentin, Detroal LA and lisinopril.

person: Have you ever had an operation? Patient
sentence: No.

Hello, Miss. How are you today? Patient: I have this massive migraine. Doctor: I see. Do migraines usually run in your family? Patient: They do. Everyone has it. We have it for many years. Doctor: Oh, wow. I look at your blood reports, and it shows that you have high blood sugar. Diabetes also runs in your family? Patient: Yes. We all eat too much rice for dinner.

What brings you today? Patient: I have had a terrible toothache. I can't stand the pain anymore. I have never felt this pain for fifty-eight years. Doctor: Where do you feel the most pain? And when did this pain begin? Patient: It started about three weeks ago. It's mostly on the left side of my mouth. A little on the lower side. It goes from my jaw to my left ear. Doctor: It doesn't seem to be the least comfortable. Let's go feel better. Do you think it's related to your tooth? Patient: No, I don't think so. I'm good enough to make appointments with my dentist, although I haven't been in this new pain. Doctor: I see. When did you visit the dentist for the last time? Patient: about two months ago for a clean routine. Doctor: Have you noticed a swelling of the face since all this started? Patient: No, no swelling.

Have you seen another doctor for this pain? Patient: Yes, I saw another guy a little while ago. Doctor: Do you have the records of the visit? Patient: Yes, actually they're right here. Doctor: Okay, so I see you have a trigger finger, a mucous cyst, and this other doctor has given you injections. Is that correct? Patient: Yes sir. Doctor: Did the injections help at all? Patient: No sir, honestly, they didn't do anything. Doctor: So your finger is still locked today? Patient: Yes sir, the other doctor sent me back here to see if there was anything more we could do.

Hello, I am Dr James. Guest_family: Hello Doctor, this is my daughter Miya, and I am Jena. Doctor: Nice to meet you ladies. So, Miya, how old are you? Patient: I am fifteen years old. Doctor: Okay, then tell me what's going on with you? Patient: Well, I have serious headaches. Guest_family: She has been complaining about it for almost six hours now. Doctor: Oh wow. Can you tell me exactly where the pain is? Patient: Um, it started from my neck and then it went up to the back of my head. Doctor: I see. Did you get hurt or hit in the head? Patient: No. Doctor: Can she have a history of headaches? Guest_family: No. Doctor: All right, nausea or vomiting? Patient: I have nausea, but it's going without vomiting. Also, I can't tolerate the light at all? Doctor: Are you capable of seeing any fever? Doctor: Are you correctly? Doctor: Are you able to see all?

And you said you were right, right? Patient: Yes. Right. Doctor: Okay, great. I took note of it in your painting. I have another question to ask about tobacco and alcohol. You smoke or drink? Patient: I don't do either. I can't even think about the last time I took a sip of alcohol.
What brings him today? Doctor: He's here for sepsis and I suspect that he may have spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Guest_clinician: Let me take up his chart.

person: I don't see any swelling or mass. Is there any pain when I touch you? Patient
sentence: No pain. Doctor: I don't feel any kind of bump in your throat. It's a good sign. It seems very flexible and symmetrical.

I am sixty-nine years old, doctor. Doctor: Thank you, what is the problem today? Patient: Oh, I have had pain in those knees for years, but it gets worse a lot in the last few months. Doctor: Did the pain ruin your ability to do activities? Patient: Absolutely, sir, yes. Doctor: What kind of treatment have you had so far? Patient: Another doctor called this conservative treatment, um, I took anti-inflammatory drugs and I had some injections. Doctor: Do you remember what type of injections you had? Patient: It was, um, cortisone, and Synvisc. Doctor: Did this release the pain at all? Patient: Well, there was only temporary relief.

Oh, I'm sorry to hear it. Let's see. Guest_family: He told me again and again that his left ear was hurting him. He was here on April 14 and prescribed Amoxicillin. Doctor: Did this seem to help? Guest_family: He first did, but the pain came back. Doctor: Did he suffer fevers? Guest_family: No, no fever. Doctor: He looks a little crowded. Guest_family: He is. When he blows his nose, he makes very thick mucous membranes rise. It never really disappeared even with antibiotics. He also coughed a good amount. Doctor: Is his cough productive? Guest_family: Yes. Doctor: He seems to keep it at night? How the mucous membranes look? Guest_family: No, I don't think.

How do you feel today, sir? Patient: I am much better today, doctor. Doctor: How is your strength and muscle pain? Patient: They both improve. Doctor: Do you have any other complaints today? Patient: No, I'm fine, honestly.

You have cholesterol problems, don't you? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. I see. Gemfibrozil? Does that seem familiar to you? Do you take this? Patient: Yes, I think this one. But I'm not sure. Doctor: Okay. Do you remember taking them at all as an external patient? Patient: I mean I don't remember.
Are you taking a drug? Patient: No.

It seems that you are here today for a noticeable foreign bodily sensation in your eye. Patient: Yes, my left eye. It never happened to me in my forty-one years. Doctor: First time for everything I suppose! When did you notice the sensation? Patient: Um when I was at work this morning. It was like something was in my eye. I went to the bathroom mirror to check it out, but I didn't see anything. I ate my eyes with water in the hope that it would help with the weird feeling. Doctor: Hm, do you feel eye pain, blurred vision, or sensitivity to light? Patient: The pain has definitely worsened since this morning. My vision is beautiful and the bright lights don't seem to be a problem.

When did it start? Patient: About two weeks ago. Doctor: Have you noticed an abnormal discharge? Patient: Not really, no. But there were great itchings there. Doctor: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting? Patient: Uh no, but I have pain here. Doctor: Near your pelvis? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Have you started new lotions or products? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you tried something for pain or itching? Patient: No, not yet. I thought it would go away all by myself. Doctor: If it was good with you, I would do a pelvic exam. Patient: Very good with me. Doctor: Have you been sexually active before or after you noticed these concerns? Patient: Uh once this week, but it was quite painful. Doctor: I see.
Do you have allergies? Patient: No, I don't have allergies. Doctor: So don't agree with any medically relevant allergies then. Nothing? Patient: No.
Have you had any medical problems? Patient: No.
Known allergies? Patient: Oh yes, I can't take Sulfa. Doctor: Let me add this to your file.

How do you feel? Patient: I feel good. Doctor: Any illness or fever? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: Any headache or nausea? Patient: No. Doctor: Any vomiting or upset stomach? Patient: No. Doctor: All right, all numbness tingling or loss of sensation in the hand? Patient: No, not at all. Doctor: Otherwise feel good? Patient: Yes.

What led you to see me today? Patient: I think I may have had a stroke. Doctor: What made you think you had a stroke? Patient: This morning, I felt like something in my throat. It was a strange feeling. Then I felt really dizzy. My left hand and jaw felt numb. Doctor: Have you lost consciousness? Patient: I don't know. It's a bit confusing. I woke up this morning and was so disoriented that I thought it was the middle of the night. My hand was numb. I also felt numbness on the left side of my neck and face. Doctor: Did the dizzying episode happen after you woke up this morning? Patient: Yes.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My mother was in good health all her life. She died of old age. She was eighty-nine years old. My father died of a stroke. He was eighty-nine years old. Doctor: Do you have any brothers and sisters? Patient: Yes, I had a brother and a sister. My sister died too young. She was only thirty years old when she died of cancer. My brother lasted until the age of seventy-four years. He had a coronary heart disease.
Do you have known drug allergies? Patient: No.

A history of heart attack? Patient: No. Doctor: Chest pain, palpitations or shortness of breath of effort? Patient: No. Doctor: What about your blood pressure? Patient: It's normal. Doctor: A swelling? Patient: No. Doctor: A history of irregular heartbeat? Patient: No.
Do you take drugs? Patient: No. Doctor: What about drinks? Do you take alcohol in any form? Patient: No, none of these.

Hello, so you are here for your follow-up? Patient: Yes, I had a surgical removal of several abscesses on my right thigh. Doctor: Okay, let me check your discharge sheet quickly. Patient: Of course. Doctor: He says that you had several subcutaneous abscesses lying on your right thigh and there was a massive open wound as well. Patient: Yes, it sounds about right! Doctor: Okay, and then they made several excisions on your thigh. Patient: Yes, on my right thigh. Doctor: Okay.

Hi Gina, how are you? Patient: I wish, I was in a better condition but yes, I'm fine. Doctor: I understand. So, you are here for your post follow up your surgeries, right? Patient: Yes, I am. Doctor: Okay, I see that you recently had your left breast removed due to cancer. Patient: Correct. Doctor: And then you also had your right knee replaced due to arthritis in your right knee? Patient: Yes, I had arthritis in my knee bone so I got it. Doctor: Hm.

person: I'm the mother of my four-year-old boy. Doctor
sentence: Hello, ma'am. What's the problem? Gest_family: We just wanted to follow after my son's visit E R. Doctor: Oh, no. What happened? Guest_family: He was playing at the park and thought it was a good idea to jump off the swing. Crazy kid, right? Doctor: He's coming. Live and learn, as they say. Do you have any information about E R. Guest_family: I gave it to the nurse. Did you not have it? Guest_clinician: Sorry. I was very busy, but here's the report. Doctor: Can you read it, please? Guest_clinician has identified you as a client.

Did you ever have lung problems? Patient: No, I didn't. Doctor: Did you have a heart surgery two months later? Patient: Yes, they had to do a cardioversion on me because of my heart rhythm disorder. Doctor: OK. Patient: And I'm taking a blood thinner right now. Doctor: Yes, I've seen you on Coumadin. Do you know any other medicines you are? Patient: Yes, I have a list with me. Look. Doctor: Wow! It's great. Thank you for being so complete. Patient: Of course. Doctor: So you're on Pacerone, Zaroxolyn, albuterol inhaler, Neurontin, Lasix, and others. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have diabetes? Patient: No, I don't do it. Doctor: Ok, have you smoked in the past? Patient: Yes, I did, but I quit a few years ago. Doctor: Ok. Have you ever had lung problems? Patient: No, I don't have it.
What are your family medical history? Patient: My uncle on my father's side has had kidney failure. I have a lot of my family members have diabetes and asthma.
