What are your family medical history? Patient: My father died of a heart attack. He was fifty nine years old. My mother died of complications with his diabetes. Doctor: Do you have siblings? Patient: Yes. My brother had a bypass with a transplant in August of ninety-five.
Hello, how are you?
What?
How are you related to the patient?
Hello doctor, I am his son.
Hello. How old is he?
He is eighty years old. He is suffering from dementia.
I see. Do you think he will be able to provide me with his medical history?
I don't think so. Sometimes he even forgets his name.
He's kidding. I know my name. I also know his kids' names. I do agree that sometimes I forget my things or feel lost.
I don't blame you. I forget my things at my age.
Yeah, it is something like episodic that he forgets everything and sometimes he's absolutely normal. On good days, he's very nice to talk to.
What is his living status?
He lives at a board and care. It is a cozier homelike place.
That's good. So what brings you here in the emergency today?

He started complaining of stomach aches. Luckily, I was there. It was very sudden at one moment he was talking to me nicely and then all of a sudden he started complaining of severe pain in his stomach area. That's when I decided to bring him here in the emergency room.
Do you have any previous reports?
I have these reports.
Do you remember when was this scan done?
I have no idea. I just had these reports with me.
Do you remember of any medical issues before?
Huh uh.

Okay, let me see what your scan says. I am reading the C T Scan report provided by the patient. It states that patient has dilated bladder with thick wall suggesting an outlet obstruction as well as bilateral hydronephrosis and hydroureter.
Hm.
I see that you have already been given some I V fluid along with antibiotics by the emergency room doctor.
Yeah.
Did he ever complain of pain during urination or nausea and vomiting?

Yes, he had fever a few days back. When we asked him about other symptoms, he said, it's hard to urinate and it is painful. Nausea and vomiting are something that I am not sure about. He was normally rushing to the restroom and every time used to say he didn't want to pee as it hurt him. He also had a few accidents in the last few days where he wet himself.
Thank you for providing me with all his history. It will be very helpful for me to treat him now.
What are your family medical history? Patient: My mother had cancer. She had several myelomas. She died at the age of eighty-three. My father died when he was eighty-one.
How are your parents? Patient: Unfortunately, they're both dead. Doctor: Oh no, I'm sorry to hear that. Patient: Thank you, it's okay, I'm on it.
What's going on? Patient: I have a stomach pain. Doctor: Since when? Patient: Oh, it's been a while now. Doctor: OK. Patient: Yes.
So you're following your high blood pressure and high cholesterol? Patient: Yes.
What's going on with you today? Patient: Oh, I have chest pain. Doctor: You have fever too? Patient: Yes, I did.

What happened and how long since he started? Patient: Oh, I don't remember. Just my head is so hurt. Guest_family: Hi doctor, it's my mother. Her dementia has progressed and most of the time she doesn't remember anything. Doctor: Oh, I see. Let me see if she can answer some questions Guest_family: Of course. Doctor: Have you had nausea or vomiting? Patient: I don't know.
Any medical history I should be aware of? Patient: No.

Do you have any allergies to medicines? Patient: Um I am allergic to Clonidine and Medifast. Doctor: What happens when you take Clonidine? Patient: I get a very bad rash. Doctor: What if you were with Medifast? Pattor: I am very tired after taking it. The last time I took it, I had trouble getting out of bed.

Do you remember the mechanism of injury to this knee? Doctor: Do you mean? Doctor: Well, was it a twist, pull, break a kind of wound? Patient: Oh, I twisted my knee. Doctor: Ok, did you see another doctor for that? Patient: Yes, and I have an MR I. Doctor: Can I see the report? Patient: Yes, you are going. Doctor: This MR I shows a tear of C L. Do you have a instability in this knee? Patient: Yes, I feel like my knee joint has been unstable for years. Doctor: Have there been dislocations? Patient: Yes, there has been this MR I shows a tear of C L. Do you have any instability in this knee? Patient: Yes, I feel like my knee joint has been unstable for years.

Can you tell me more about your family history, madam? How's your father? Patient: She died too. She had kidney and heart failure. Doctor: I'm sorry, ma'am. Patient: Oh, it's okay doctor, thank you. Doctor: Do you have any brothers and sisters? Patient: Yes, I have two brothers and five sisters. Doctor: Is this a great family, do they have any conditions you know? Patient: One of my sisters has breast cancer. Doctor: Thank you. Do you have any children? Patient: Yes, I have two sons and a daughter. Doctor: It's great. Do you have any other conditions I should know? Patient: Well, in addition to all this, there is a high cholesterol level, depression and a nervous disease.
Someone sick at home? Patient: No, fortunately. Everyone feels good.

Hello! What brings you today? Patient: I'm not feeling well. I'm tired and I feel weak. Doctor: Did you have any other symptoms? Patient: I noticed after I went to the toilet this morning, that my urine was dark. Doctor: Did you stay hydrated? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Allows to obtain a urine sample.

person: I had a pain in my back for a while. Doctor
sentence: Does the pain go into your legs? Patient: Yes, I have a pain in my right thigh too. Doctor: Is there an injury associated with this pain? Patient: Yes, I had an incident in nineteen ninety-four. Doctor: Do you have any medical documents or records of the initial injury? Patient: No sir, I don't have these today. Doctor: What are you doing to live, sir? Patient: Now I work in Taco Bell. I have an open worker claim. Doctor: Your pain came back during your work, correct? Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Have you had an allergic reaction to a medicine? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay.

Hello, how are you? Patient: I'm fine. Just here for a follow-up visit. Doctor: Are there any changes from the last visit in your social or medical history? Patient: No. Everything you wrote last time should be correct.
Are you taking medication? Patient: No. Doctor: Are you sure? Patient: Yes.
Have you had any operations in the past? Patient: No.

I would like to start with your medical history. Do you have any problems or medical conditions? Patient: I have no other medical problems than the one for which I was sent to you. Doctor: Yes. Dr. Hanine sent your recent blood test results and table notes. Did he discuss these results with you? Patient: Yes, he did. He said I have several myelomas. And that the levels of blood work are how he found it. Doctor: Yes. Levels I G show that the subtype is multiple myeloma. Patient: OK.

So how do you feel? Doctor: You came here the last time with C V On the right? Patient: Yes, I recover well. You asked me to follow for high sugar. Doctor: Oh yes, you have diabetes mellitus. Did you get a blood test before this visit? Patient: Yes, I did here is the report.
What are your family medical history? Patient: I don't know any family health problems.
What brings you here today? Patient: I have a delicate belly and the feeling that I am about to vomit all the time. Doctor: Another thing? Patient: I vomit a lot.

On average, how many cigarettes would you say you smoke? Patient: Probably three or four if I had to guess. Doctor: Any medical problems in the family? Patient: Yes, my brother had a heart attack when he was quite young. Doctor: How old was he? Patient: Fifty-two. Doctor: Oh wow, how is he doing? Patient: Well, he has to see a heart doctor at least once a year. Doctor: Does anyone else in your family have heart problems? Patient: Um my father has heart problems. He is also diabetic type 1.

Hello, Miss. How are you? Patient: I'm fine. I just have a few questions about diet and exercise. I want to get my health in order. Doctor: Okay, great. This is something we can handle today. Can you tell me about your family history? This will help me see the possible diseases that we should be watching. Patient: Yes. Let's start with my mother. She died of congestive heart failure. Doctor: What about your father? Your papers say that both parents have died. Patient: Yes, unfortunately. My father died of myocardial infarction at fifty-six years old. Not sure of my mother's age. Doctor: Your family seems to have a history of ischaemic heart disease. How are your brothers and sisters? The papers say that you have brothers. Patient: Yes. Two are alive and one died. He died of lymphoma. One brother had two angioplatias and the other brother just had asthma.
Smoking or drinking? Patient: No and no.
Are you allergic to something? Patient: No, I'm not. Doctor: And food allergies. Patient: No, I'm fine. Doctor: OK.
Do you have food allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: Drug allergies? Patient: No.
Do you smoke? Patient: Yes, I smoke grass from time to time. It helps my anxiety. Doctor: How about cigarettes? Patient: No, not least interested in cigs.

What's his age? Guest_family: He's two. He always complains about pain in his stomach and back. He's active otherwise. Doctor: Have you noticed any changes in his toilet or routine habits? Guest_family: No. Doctor: Any fever or chills or any other problem? Guest_family: No, we didn't notice any such problems, he was active and acted very normally differently. Doctor: Any change in his eating habits? Guest_family: No, he ate and drank as usual. He acted normally but we noticed a pudic smell coming from his nose. He was on antibiotics after removing this piece of cotton from his right side of the nose in our previous visit? Doctor: How is his nose now? Guest_family: He was better but now we can notice that the smell of his nose comes from his side.

Can you tell me about the medicines you are currently using? Patient: I am taking Alesse twenty-eight. Doctor: Do you know his strength? Hum, like how many milligrams? Patient: Oh yes, it is twenty M C G and I take the point ten milligrams of this one. Doctor: When did you start it? Patient: The seventh August in two thousand and one. Doctor: Who prescribed it? Patient: My O B G Y N, Doctor A.

What kind of operations did you have in the past? Patient: I don't know what operation they did today. I mean I don't know the name of that. Doctor: It's good, I know. It's Lap Band. Patient: And I did a right foot surgery in the past. Doctor: Very good. Patient: Of course.

he was exposed to drugs in the uterus while I was pregnant, and he was diagnosed with autism. Doctor: I see that he has already had an operation on the right knee, can you tell me more about it? Guest_family: He has already had a lot of trouble straightening his two legs, and since the right was worse than the left, he had an operation on the inner part of this leg. Doctor: When was this operation? Guest_family: It was in February of two thousand seven. Doctor: How did he respond to the operation? Guest_family: He answered really well, he walked much better than the left, and even came back to doing sports with the other children in the neighborhood.

Oh doc, I've had a lot of trouble breathing lately. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. We're going to get to the bottom. Patient: Yes, I'm losing my breath so quickly with only one to two flights of stairs. Doctor: When did you start to notice that? Patient: I think two weeks ago. Doctor: Any chest pain or oppression with breathlessness? Patient: No, fortunately. Doctor: Any fever, chills or sweats? Patient: No. Doctor: Any cough or cough of blood? Patient: No. Doctor: What would you say to whistle or swelling in your legs? Patient: No.

Can you tell me more about your family medical history, sir? How's your father? Patient: Well, doctor, he died. He had a mesothelioma. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that, sir. How's your mother? Patient: It's good, thank you. I lost her too. She had an L.S. doctor: I'm sorry, it must be so hard. Patient: Yes, but I'm taking care of it.
Good afternoon, who's the victim today, sir? Is it you, or your daughter?
Good afternoon, doctor. It's my daughter today.
Remind me, how old is she?
I'm thirteen, sir.
So, what happened? My nurses tell me she fell today.
Yeah, I fell off the swing at school earlier this afternoon at about one thirty.
Where does it hurt, young lady?
It's really bad here on my left elbow.
Which hand do you write with?
I use my right hand for everything, thank goodness for that.
Before seeing me, have you seen anyone else?
Yeah, we went to an Urgent Care and she had an x ray there.
What else did they do?
They said her arm was broken, and they tried to do a reduction.
Do you have those x rays with you right now?
Yeah, I have them right here, take a look, please.
Well, these x rays show an incarcerated medial epicondyle fracture, as well as a mildly angulated radial shaft break.
What does that mean?
Well, in short, you broke the inside part of your elbow. In addition to the pain, do you have any burning or tingling feelings in that arm?
Yes, I do.
Did you have this before they tried to do a reduction?
No, I didn't, this is new.
Is this feeling getting worse?
Yes, it is.
Okay, guys, there is a lot of pressure on that ulnar nerve because of the break and the attempted reduction.
What should we do?
We need to do an O R I F procedure A S A P. I'll reduce that radial shaft fracture at the same time.
O R I F? What's that
I'll put some pins in the elbow, in order to stabilize the break, and we can start the healing process.
Will this not heal on its own?
No, we need to do the surgery.
Okay, what are the risks of infection with the surgery?
Historically, its less than one percent.
How is this possible?
We use prophylactic antibiotics, this helps us control for infection the entire time.
Will she be asleep for this?
Yes, she won't feel a thing.
Will she need this hardware taken out in the future?

Yes, in about a year or two, after everything is healed up nicely. The other risks include bleeding, changes in sensation and motion of the extremity, and hardware failure. I see good results from my surgeries so I would not worry about these things, but I must disclose.
Okay, yes, we'd like to do the surgery.

So tell me if anyone in your family has idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis? Patient: In fact, my father died because of this disease. Doctor: Oh, sorry to hear that. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Anything he or another member of the family could have. Patient: Oh, he also had this problem of spastic colon and irritable intestinal syndrome. Doctor: Hm, I see. Doctor: Everything else? Patient: No.
How are you today? Patient: I'm fine. Doctor: Do you have any medical conditions? Patient: I have diabetes. Doctor: When were you diagnosed with diabetes? Patient: It was two thousand three, I think.

I don't feel swelling in your neck or in your groin area. Patient: Oh yes, I don't notice anything either. Doctor: Okay, I was just trying to look for lymph nodes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me check. Patient: Of course.

person: The results showed a high level of sensitivity. I will adjust your dose of Coumadin to a much lower dose. This will help to reduce bruising and bleeding episodes. Do you have any questions? Patient
sentence: No.

When did it all start? Guest_family: It started yesterday. Suddenly, he started complaining, saying, "Mama my nose doesn't work," and yes, I noticed that he was breathing from his mouth. Doctor: Any fever or any other symptom? Guest_family: Yes, he had a low-level fever. He looked very tired and when I asked him that he said, "I feel like I can't stay up. I don't have any energy. I just want to lie down." Doctor: I can notice that his voice is a little wrapped up. How does he eat and drink? Guest_family: He eats and drinks normally.
Do you use tobacco, alcohol or recreational drugs? Patient: No.

What is a thirty-one-year-old like you do in my office today, madam? Patient: Well, I referred to P T after I had a fall. Doctor: When was your fall? Patient: Um, it was the third two thousand eight October. Doctor: What happened when you fell? Patient: I stumbled on my dog's toy. Doctor: Did you twist your foot or ankle? Patient: Yes, my left foot reversed. Doctor: Did you make an imaging on that foot? Patient: Yes, uh, I already had x-rays and M R I. Doctor: What were the impressions of these images? Patient: They told me it was unforgivable. Doctor: How did the pain progress from the beginning? Patient: Well, after a month or two, the pain is still so bad that I can't do any of my activities.
Well, what about more illegal substances? Patient: Oh, certainly not. Doctor: What about alcohol, you drink? Patient: Well, I would say I'm an occasional drinker.

Does it bother you to develop more about your family history? Did one of your parents suffer from medical problems? Patient: Of course. My father had a heart disease. He died at seventy-five years of age. He had a diabetic sister and I think my mother also had diabetes. Doctor: I understood. Patient: My mother had a long history of mini-AV. She had no memory or dementia problems when she died at eighty-five years of age. They believe that she died due to old age. Doctor: Thank you for deepening.

A muscle pain? Patient: No, not really. Doctor: A problem in walking? Pattor: No, it's normal. Doctor: Let me check your toes and fingers. Can you move them for me? Pattor: Yes. Doctor: Everything looks good. Nails seems good too. No bluish discoloration any signs of infection. Can you push your legs against my hand. Pattor: Both legs? Pattor: Yes, both. Well, your muscle strength is equal and stable in both legs, so it's good. Motion seems right. Doctor: Any tenderness? Pattor: No. Doctor: And I don't see any swelling or accumulation of fluid. Pattor: Ok.
Do you have a known patient: allergy to medication? Doctor: Oh no, I meant family history of illness.
Have you had any headaches or power outages recently? Patient: No. Doctor: Vertigo or seizures? Patient: No. Doctor: A history of stroke? Patient: No. Doctor: Ok, good.

How do you feel today? Doctor: How old are you? Patient: I'm forty-six years old. Doctor: How is your pain in the left side? Patient: It's much better. It's more like a dull pain now. Doctor: Do you still have urine problems? Patient: It's improved but it's still a bit difficult. Doctor: Okay. It seems that Dr. X did an exam yesterday. Doctor X consulted me about your status but I have a question for you. I see in your medical file that you had a left kidney bruised bruised. Can you tell me more about the damaged kidney? Patient: Yes. I was in a car accident, years ago. The doctor told me that I had a bruised left kidney. They thought it was due to the accident, but they couldn't be sure.

Well, I have a long history of family heart problems. My mother died quite young at the age of 50 due to a heart attack and my father was detected with heart failure, he has a pacemaker. Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry to hear about your mother. Patient: Yes. Also, high blood pressure is running in my family. Doctor: Ok.

How long does it last? Patient: And how would you describe- Patient: Pain? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Hm I would describe it as a snacking sensation. Doctor: Is this feeling new? Patient: I think so. I never remember feeling that before. Doctor: No abdominal surgery past? Patient: None.

How long have you been married? Guest_family: We have been married for forty-eight years. Doctor: You live in the same house? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have a primary care doctor? Patient: No, I'm currently looking for someone. I'm also looking for someone to see for my mental health problems. Doctor: I have some recommendations I can give you if you wish. Patient: I would like your recommendations for both. Doctor: Do you currently work? Patient: No, I'm not. Doctor: I'm not. Doctor: It's good to meet you too. You're the husband, right? Guest_family: Yes. I'm the husband. Doctor: How long have you been married? Guest_family: We've been married for forty-eight years. Doctor: You live in the same house? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have a primary care doctor? Patient: No, I'm looking for someone to see for my mental health problems. Doctor: I have some recommendations I can give you if you wish. Patient: I would like your recommendations for both. Doctor: Do you currently work? Patient: No, I'm not.

Do you have a history of surgery? Patient: I had a bone fragment removed from my right arm. I had a D and C done a long time ago. It was a treatment for H P V. More recently, I had an ovarian cancer featuring biopsy. I haven't heard the results yet. I did it less than a week ago. Doctor: How do you feel after biopsy? Patient: I had a significant amount of pain for two to three days after. I feel better now.
Does anyone else in your family suffer from this disease? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay.

I have a lot of problems and problems, where do I start? Doctor: Start by saying to the one who bothers you the most. Patient: I have this pain in the right toes and I also have this feeling of numbness there. Doctor: OK and do you feel a feeling of tingling? Or do you feel like your leg gives you? Patient: Yes, I feel tingling and sometimes. I feel like my leg fell asleep. Doctor: Hm, tell me about your pain. Is it mild, moderate, or severe? Patient: Well, I'll say it's moderate. Doctor: Do you define it as acute pain or a sort of radiant pain? Patient: Maybe acute pain, but your patient doesn't know how to describe it too.
Do you have known allergies to medication? Patient: No.

It has been coughing for a week now. Doctor: What about congestion? Is it a week or more ago? Guest_family: No did I say that? I wanted to say two to three weeks. I'm so worried. It's only a year ago. Doctor: Don't worry, can you tell me everything from the start? Guest_family: Of course. It started with congestion, but it started coughing a week ago and it gets worse. Doctor: Ok, what else? Guest_family: In fact, it had Pop Can three days ago and I never wondered if he had swallowed that. Doctor: It's possible, did you see a change in his breathing? Guest_family: His breathing hasn't increased since. Doctor: Any fever? Guest_family: No. No fever. Doctor: Ok.

So I see that you recently moved to the A University of Brazil, right? Patient: Yes, about a year ago. I was an engineer manager there, but my job was so stressful that when I was admitted to the M B A program here in the states, I took it. Doctor: Wow, it's quite a move! Patient: Yes. Doctor: What would you say about your family; wife or girlfriend? Patient: I am a man a woman. I married my childhood love. Doctor: Nice. Did you travel outside the country recently or do you have a risk of exposure? Patient: No, I haven't traveled anywhere even inside the country. Doctor: Okay. Tell me something, smoke or drink? Patient: No, I don't have. Doctor: And have you used recreational or illegal drugs in the past? Patient: No, never. Doctor: Ok, good.

Do you drink, sir? Patient: No, I don't drink at all. Doctor: And tobacco? Do you smoke? Patient: Well, yes. Doctor: How much do you smoke, sir? Patient: I smoke about half a pack of cigarettes a day.

How do you feel? Have you been sick? Patient: Yes, I do not feel well for the last three days. I have a pain in the body, cough and throat. Doctor: Do you have the wet cough or it is dry? What color the sputum comes out? Patient: It is wet and green things of color comes out. Doctor: Okay, we will have to send them to the culture, maybe an infection. Doctor: How about fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea something like that? Are you sleeping well? Patient: Everything is fine except a few chills? I sleep well. Doctor: Do you need anything for cough? Patient: I don't need anything for cough. I called yesterday and I received a refill of my keflex. Then I took two keflex this morning and I feel a little better now. Doctor: Okay then why are you crying, ma'am? Patient: I'm just feeling tired: I'm sorry. I'm just feeling tired: I'm sorry.
Hi, what's going on with you? Patient: Well, I have this weird movement of my leg and arm. Doctor: Oh good, let me take a look.

person: I had a little time for myself, but I wanted to get away from a bad crowd, so I came back to live with my mother. Doctor
sentence: What do you mean, bad crowd? Patient: Well, I was addicted to drugs there, and I used to inject heroin. Doctor: Have you seen a doctor for this addiction? Patient: Yes, I saw another doctor in the city. Doctor: How did they treat you at that time? Patient: They prescribed me methadone for some time. Doctor: Was it useful at all? Patient: Honestly, no, it was not useful at all. Doctor: Have you ever tried to lose your patient when you were received? Patient: Hum, it was a patient who tried to use it.

Hello, how's it going? Guest_family: Hello doctor, I'm her son Ethan. Doctor: Nice to meet you. Doctor: So I see that your father has a history of drug abuse, right? Guest_family: Yes. Patient: No abuse, I was just doing drugs. The last time I really made a big mistake, I injected heroin directly into my two thighs and unfortunately I had those ulcers that don't go far. Doctor: Yes, it's really unhappy. I can see these wounds open, it's because of chronic abscesses. Guest_family: The right thigh seems worse than the left. Doctor: Yes, I see that. How old is your father? Guest_family: He's sixty-two years old. Doctor: Does he have any other medical problems like sugar or blood pressure? Guest_family: No. Doctor: I think we need to remove all this area from surgery and then do it all: Doctor: Do not even do it.

Do you smoke cigarettes or use tobacco products, Mademoiselle? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol and if so, how many drinks do you consume in a typical week? Patient: I don't drink. Patient: Do you use recreational drugs or other substances? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have children? Patient: Yes. I have three children. Doctor: Do your children have health problems? Patient: No. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: Yes.
How is your family? Patient: They are all good. Doctor: Are you aware of medical problems in your family? Patient: No, not to my knowledge.
Have you ever had spinal problems before? Patient: What, like an injury? Doctor: Well, it's wide. It could be a wound, or any other kind of pain. Patient: Oh, no. I've never had any problems.
No.

With ten years of worse pain, how would you rate your pain in ten today, madam? Patient: Um, out of ten, I would say it's about two. Doctor: That's good. What helps the pain to feel better? Patient: Um, it improves with elevation, and when I rest.
Nurse, did you get the documents from the patient?
I did. Here is her full history and notes from her physical examination. She also completed the patient questionnaire before arriving. You can review that.
Thank you, Nurse. What is she here for today?
She came in for a consultation because she's been experiencing difficult headaches, tunnel vision, and dizziness.
Sounds good. Was there anything else?
Oh, yeah. These are the results from her tests. She brought them so you could refer to them.
Thank you, Nurse. I'll go see her now.
Hello Doctor. I've been waiting a long time. I'm getting impatient as I get older.
What? You don't look old at all, ma'am.
Oh, wow. That's a nice compliment for a sixty year old lady.
How can I help you today?
I have these super bad headaches. Help me, please.
When did they start?
I had them since I was twenty five years old.
Oh, wow. That long? Did you get them every day since then?
Not every day. That's crazy. I did get them more when my husband died in nineteen ninety six. I was heartbroken.
I'm sorry to hear that. How did the headaches feel?
It felt like a drum in my head.
I haven't heard that description before. Would you say it was pulsating?
Something like that. Yes.
Did you take any medication?
Lots of it. My son wrote it on a paper so that I could give you the names. Here you go.
I see you were given papaverine. Did that help?
They did. My headaches would vanish.
How long did you take it for?
I think six months. My headaches stopped for a while, but they came back in two thousand and four.
How often would you say you get headaches now?
I think more than before. Like one to two per week. I also get some dizziness too. It says for two hours.
Do you take the papaverine when you feel it?
I do. My headaches vanish after thirty minutes of taking it.
I see. Did you ever experience any problems with your vision too?
Yes. A lot. There were zig zag lines coming out of nowhere. I thought I was going to die.
Oh, wow. I will do a test right now to check your vision.
Will you use a bright pen?
I will. Does it give you any discomfort?
The bright light hurts my eyes.
I see. I'll only do it to the side then. Just look forward for me, please.
Thank you.
Are you able to see the light?
What light?
It looks like you have trouble seeing things in your peripheral vision. The discomfort you experience with bright lights is also called photophobia.
That sounds scary. Will I be fine?
Yeah. You don't have to worry. Are you experiencing any dizziness or lightheadedness right now?
Now that you mentioned it, I am.
Have you ever fainted before?
I think one time. My son was there to help.
That's good to hear. I'll write down that you experienced a syncope. Did you take any medication for this?
I took some Russian medicine.
Oh, wow. Are you from Russia?
No. I'm from Ukraine.
That's wonderful. How did the medicine help?
It helped me a lot.

How would you rate your pain? Patient: It's tolerable, like five out of ten but I need some pain medications. Doctor: So why do you need more pain medications? Patient: Sometimes it gets difficult, I really need more pain medications. Doctor: Do you have morphine? Do you need more? Patient: I don't like morphine. Can you change it to Dilaudide? I like this medicine.

She has a vast history of surgery. Doctor: Yes, I am watching her reports. She had surgery for spina bifida when she was a baby and they had to put on a hunt. Guest_clinician: Yes, later she had her uterus removed and also had to undergo breast reduction surgery. Doctor: Hm.
Are you married or divorced? Patient: I am married. Doctor: OK. Patient: Hm. Doctor: Do you smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol? Patient: No, I never have.
What are your family medical history? Patient: I'm not sure. Everyone is healthy to my knowledge.

person: I did a job, I remember when your last date was? Patient
sentence: Hum, I think it was August 10, two thousand four. Patient: Well, that's what I've been doing here, so has your acne improved since your last visit? Patient: Well, not really, and I think I have a rash too. Doctor: How long have you been dealing with that? Patient: Hum, at that time, about two months ago. Doctor: Where do you see this rash? Patient: Hum, it's right here, on my chest, stomach, neck, and back, you took your medication like a patient.
It looks like your X-rays show bronchitis. Patient: Is there something I can take for that? Doctor: Yes, I'll prescribe something that will help you clean your lungs.

person: I see you're in a walking boot. What happened? Patient
sentence: I have a pain in my foot yesterday. Doctor: How did it go? Patient: Basketball. I play for Houston University. I went up for a three and I went down and fell on the foot of this guy. I was so upset. Doctor: Dang, it sucked. Did you play at home? Patient: We're traveling to Duke. We could have won the game if I hadn't been hurt. Doctor: You're going to have them next time. Did you keep playing? Patient: Yes, I did. I was recorded by the coach and I went back to the game. Doctor: I see. Who was the coach who helped you? Patient: His name is John Houston. Do you know him? Doctor: John! He's a good friend of me. Patient: He told me to come see you.

So, apart from constipation what's his problem? What's going on with his lungs? Doctor: Yes, we call it the impact of the foreign body. It mainly affects his right nostril and as you said, there is constipation.

I was working when it happened, so we're going through the comp workers. Doctor: OK. Don't worry. Let's see. Patient: Yes, this arm was a hot oil. Doctor: Yes, it's a pity, it looks like the elbow to the wrist. The whole media side is burned. Patient: I've been using cool packs since it happened. My friend has been helping me so much, he has taken me to the emergency department. Doctor: OK, how old are you? Patient: I'm forty-one years old. Doctor: What's your job? I mean you're doing? Patient: I'm a coffee cook.

Do you have any health problems I should have? Patient: Hum, I have high blood pressure and asthma. Doctor: I also see here that you have cervical cancer, can you tell me more about it? Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed at the age of 15. Doctor: How would you describe the progression of your cancer? Patient: Now, uh, I would say it's sleeping.
You can take Ibuprofen as needed for pain.
Do you take anything for acid reflux? Patient: Yes, I take Aciphex. Doctor: Is 20 M G once a day? Patient: It is. I also take a baby Aspirin in the morning.
Do you smoke? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How much do you smoke? Patient: I smoke about two packs of cigarettes a day.
Numbness or tingling? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you feel muscle weakness? Patient: No. Doctor: A walking problem, or have you lost balance or fall? Patient: No. Doctor: So your gait is good.

When did you have these surgeries? Patient: I had my gallbladder removed in O eight, appendix removed in twenty-two, and uterus removed this year. Doctor: Other medical history? Patient: My bladder was ticking the last time I saw the urologist. Doctor: Is the diagnosis of the prolapsus bladder familiar? Patient: Yes, I think so. They said it was the fourth time. Doctor: Have you followed your urologist recently? Patient: Chip Winkel? No, not like late.

Do you have allergies? How old are you, young man? Patient: Yes ragweed. I am twelve years old. Doctor: So, basically, you're just cluttered? Patient: Yes it's true. The last ten days. Doctor: Any headache? What comes out of your nose? Patient: Yes I had a little yesterday. Clear Boogers. Doctor: Do you feel warm? Patient: No. Doctor: Anyone sick at home? Guest_family: No.

Are you married? Patient: I am divorced. Doctor: Do you have children? Patient: Yes, I have two boys and they live with me. Doctor: Any abnormal pregnancy. No abortion? Patient: No, none of them. Doctor: Do you smoke or consume alcohol or have ever used illicit drugs? Patient: No.

person: I see here that you saw the dermatologist a month ago. Patient
sentence: Yes. She said I had a superactive gland. Doctor: Does Hidradenite suppurativa seem familiar to you? Patient: That's true. Doctor: I ask because it's also included in your last visit with your dermatologist. Patient: These are red bumps, that's it? Doctor: Yes. There's a note here that you could potentially have Staph with her too. Patient: Oh yes. I also had a lot of abscesses in the past. Doctor: It looks like you had them in your upper thigh, in the vulva area, and in the area between your vulva and the anus. Patient: For about two years now. Doctor: Yes. And a history of asthma? Patient: correct.

Hello, how are you? Doctor: I'm good, tell me what brings you here? Patient: I have this chest pain. I was hospitalized last year in October and at that time they put this catheter in my heart. I also had a heart scan. It's here in this report. Doctor: Yes, I see you got a nuclear and myocardial infusion scan, which was normal. They were looking for a heart artery injury but they thought it was due to spasm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's also mentioned here that you have hyperlipidemia. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And are you still smoking? Patient: Yes, I was actively smoking from three to four days because I'm really stressed. Doctor: Hm. And would you say that you've had some effort recently or had some stiff hikes or some cardio exercises that might have caused additional stress on your heart that's causing chest pain? Just don't smoke.

I'm sorry for that. Patient: Yes, for assault, that's why I was in detention. Doctor: Ok. Doctor: When was it? Patient: Around December of two thousand nine. Patient: Not sure if I'm under a legal violation right now. Doctor: Ok, so we don't know.
Do you smoke cigarettes? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: How many packages a day. Patient: Maybe one a day. Doctor: Okay, you should think about stopping.
What happens when you take Sulfa medication? Patient: Oh man, I get a very ugly rash. Doctor: I'll take note of this, so we have it in your file.
Known drug allergies? Patient: No, nothing.
Do you smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol? Patient: No.

What brings you here today? Patient: I have problems with my right hand. Doctor: What kind of problems? Patient: I have these pins and needles in my hand and it's been going on for several weeks. Sometimes I feel like it's getting numb. I think it may be a carpal tunnel, but I'm not sure. I'm just worried. Doctor: Did you do anything for that? Patient: At work, I recently moved my keyboard down. I just hope it will help. You know, I do a lot of the same kind of activities all the time. All this I type. Doctor: What is more difficult, day or night? Patient: It gets worse at night. If I sleep on it, as in a certain way, it will wake me up and it will start to hurt. These sensations of tingling are the worst.

Have you been in an accident? Patient: I was a truck driver for a while but fortunately was not in a major automobile accident. I had hit a moose once, where I hit my head but didn't remember getting hurt anywhere else. I had broken my ankle in the past. Doctor: Hm, I see here that you mentioned to the nurse, that a car fell on your chest six years back? Patient: Oh yes, I was fixing my car and it fell off the car and fell on my chest but fortunately I wasn't hurt.

Have you ever had pneumonia? Patient: No, never. Doctor: Do you have a history of lung disease? Patient: No. Doctor: History of tuberculosis? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you feel a shortness of breath or difficulty breathing? Patient: No. Doctor: All right. Do you have a wheezing? Patient: No.

Tell me about your medical history. Is there anything I should be aware of? Patient: No, I don't think so. Doctor: No known allergy? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you ever been diagnosed with diabetes or high blood pressure? Patient: Oh, last year I had some high blood pressure incidents, but I didn't take any medication for that. Doctor: Have you seen a change in your weight? Patient: How do you know? It has increased. About fourteen pounds since last year.

How did your thrombosis treatment go? I think we did it on February 19th out of two thousand seven. We finished the note the next day to send to your next doctor. Patient: The treatment went well. Thank you!

Where have you numbness? Patient: In my left hand. Doctor: And no other symptoms? No cough or chest pain? Patient: No. Just this weird feeling in my left hand. Doctor: Any visual or motor change. Patient: Nothing. Doctor: Great. What about any phlegm or shortness of breath? Patient: Nope.

You are seventy years old, that's right? Patient: When did you begin to feel joint pain? Patient: A few years ago. Patient: How did it worsen? Patient: He made me less active in general. My hands and wrists aren't as mobile. Doctor: Have you noticed an increase in swelling? Patient: No, but everything has become a little too uncomfortable. Doctor: I see here that you are taking Daypro's credits. Does that help? Patient: No. Doctor: And no redness in the bathroom, right? Patient: No. Doctor: Fever or chills? Patient: I had diarrhea for a few days, but it went much better. I also had trouble holding my bladder.

Someone in your family has been sick lately? Patient: Yes, my sister has sinus problems. She was seen today. Doctor: Okay, that means she will be treated. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And the other family members? Patient: No, my mother and my father are in good health.

Where did it hurt you? Patient: Ah, my upper part of the chest and it turned all around my right side up to my back. Doctor: Okay, how do you feel now? Patient: I feel very weak and tired, I don't feel like doing anything other than rest. Doctor: Any fever? Patient: Yes, the nurse just took my temperature at 100 points three. Doctor: Okay. Did you have these symptoms before? Patient: No, the first time. I never felt like that. Doctor: Okay. You had chills or chills? Patient: No. Doctor: When did you have your last intestinal movement? Patient: It was yesterday. Doctor: Did you notice blood in your stools or a rectum bleeding? Patient: No. Doctor: How old are you? Patient: I am twenty-eight years old. Doctor: And you had a gastric bypass, one year ago. Patient: Yes, almost a year ago.

Okay, so it seems that your blood work shows that your sodium levels are very low. This could explain some of the symptoms you've had recently. Patient: What does that mean? Why are my sodium levels so low? Doctor: It could be due to a number of patients: Should I start eating more salt? Doctor: Not necessarily. But I think it's partly because of the diuretic you've taken over the last few weeks. Your blood work also shows an anaemia. I'd like to start on some iron supplements at the moment and bring you back for another eval. Reception has access to your orders and they can print you a lab sheet. Patient: Do you think iron will help with my fatigue? I've been so exhausted and caffeine hasn't helped a bit.

So you are a cigarette smoker? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How many do you have? Pattor: Not as many as some people. Doctor: How much is it exactly? Pattor: Well, I have to buy a new pack once a week. Doctor: Ok. So it's about four packs a month and fifty packs a year. Pattor: Yes, I think so.

Are you married, sir? Patient: Yes, to my wonderful wife. Doctor: Great, can I assume that you support yourself at home? Patient: Yes, doctor, that's right. Doctor: Are you smoking or drinking, sir? Patient: Well, I don't smoke, and I don't do anything harder, either. But I drink just about every day. Doctor: How much do you drink a day? Patient: I drink maybe two or three drinks a day, so maybe four or nine a week.

Do you know if anyone in your family has a history of heart disease, attack something like this? Patient: Let me think. You mean only parents of blood? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes. We have some of these diseases in our family.
What kind of operations have you had in the past? Patient: I had cardiac bypass surgery. Doctor: Is it C A B G? Patient: Maybe. And I had my tonsils and my appendix taken out. Doctor: Of course. Ok.

What part of your back did you fall on? Patient: I fell on my bone and just at the bottom of your back. Doctor: Is this the only fall you had? Patient: No, I had another one in March of two thousand six. Doctor: What happened when you fell at that time? Patient: I was trying to qualify on the firing range with a gun, when I lost my feet. Doctor: What caused you to lose your life? Patient: I think it was more a weakness than a loss of balance. Doctor: What treatments did you have for that? Patient: Well, I was at P T, and I had, um, cauterization of some nerves in my back? Patient: I think it was more a weakness than a loss of balance.

Have you ever had surgery, ma'am? Patient: Yes, doctor, I've had a lifetime of surgery. Doctor: How many operations have you had? Patient: I've had four. Doctor: Do you know the operations you've had? Patient: Actually, I have the operating notes here. Doctor: I see, you've had a previous cervical discomia, and the merger of C three to C seven. Patient: Yes, I've had all those with Dr. L. Doctor: Do you have any children? Patient: Yes, Doctor, I have seven, but I have had three false diapers. Doctor: Was one of your children born by Sections C? Patient: No, none of them were.
Have you ever had major surgery? Patient: I had a skin label removed but not. No major surgery. Doctor: Ok.

With ten of the worst pains imaginable, out of ten, how would you describe your pain today? Patient: I would say about six out of ten today. Doctor: What makes pain worse? Patient: It's worse when I try to walk on it. Doctor: Do you have pain at night? Patient: No, fortunately I don't. Doctor: How long have you been wearing this outside knee device? Patient: Oh, for a little while now.

I have to ask you a few questions. Patient: Of course. Doctor: Do you feel weakness or fatigue? Patient: No. Doctor: No malaise or disease? Patient: No, nothing like this. Doctor: No chill or high temperature? Patient: No. Doctor: Any excessive sweating or night sweating? Patient: Um, no. Doctor: How about allergies, are you allergic to anything? Patient: No, no allergies. Doctor: Very good.
Do you smoke or drink? Patient: No. Doctor: No drug use? Patient: No.

Do you smoke? Patient: Yes! Doctor: What about alcohol, do you drink? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: And how much do you drink and is it casual or daily? Patient: Well, I love my wine, I drink about four to five glasses a day. Doctor: Wow! It's a lot.
Do you smoke cigarettes? Patient: Yes.

person: I don't remember how old he was, but I remember he had long-lasting heart problems. Doctor
sentence: And your mother? Patient: My mother's death was a mystery to all of us. She died of some complications due to dental procedures. So, never know what killed her. Doctor: Do you have children? Are they all in good health wise? Patient: I have a daughter, she is healthy.

Hello! How are you today? Patient: Hello. I am not so well. I have had this cough and pain in my stomach. Here by my belly button. Doctor: How long is it going? Patient: Two days. It was very painful. Doctor: I would like to examine your abdomen. Is it good? Patient: Yes.
Can you confirm the medicines you have already taken? Patient: Yes, I just finished the course for Minocin. I also took Duraphen II D M.

Did anyone in your family have a history of heart disease or problems? Patient: Well, yes. Actually, my father died because of heart disease. Doctor: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. Do you know what type of heart problem he had? Patient: Yes, we call him co-Doctor: Oh, coronary heart disease? Patient: Yes, exactly! Doctor: I see.

person: I haven't had a P.C. Patient yet
sentence: No, I haven't had one yet for a long time. Doctor: Are you having one? Patient: Yes, Project Access is trying to find me. Doctor: Well, uh, what's the problem today? Patient: Well, I was at the office of Doctor X Y Z today, I had an appointment, but they canceled me because I don't have the project access assurance yet. Doctor: I see, what are you going to see Doctor X Y Z for? Patient: I have a lot of pain in my foot. Doctor: Ok, have you seen Doctor X Y Z before your patient?
Do you smoke or drink? Patient: No. Doctor: Medicines? Patient: Do you mean like methamphetamine? Doctor: Yes. Patient: No, never done. Doctor: Ok.

Hello, Miss. How are you? What brings you to my office today? Patient: I'm fine. Just here for a refill on my medication. Doctor: Great. It should be easy. How will stress management control acne? Patient: It's okay. My husband was on board with my meditations and yoga. It's very favorable. Doctor: Wonderful. Are they always clean to drink and smoke? It can interact with your medications. Patient: Yes I know. I don't drink or smoke.

person: So I have here that you are taking three different medications. Patient
sentence: Yes. I take them every day as they told me. Doctor: I see. That's good. Have you filled your prescriptions with the newly revised doses? It seems they have changed the dosage of your medications at the hospital. Patient: Um I just took what I have at home. Doctor: I advise you to take the doses they prescribed. If you want me to put in a new order, please let me know. Patient: Ok, yes, that's good. I can take it on my way home. I didn't think the dosage counted as much as I took the drugs every day.
Major operations in the past? Patient: Not too much, but a catheter has been put in my heart. Doctor: Oh, if cardiac catherization, is that correct? Patient: Yes.

person: I see you've been seen for an assessment of your allergy. Can you confirm your age? Patient
sentence: Yes, it's true. Thirty-four. Doctor: I'm going to take a look at your medical records. I see you were treated at the Medical Centre A B C for an allergic reaction, correct? Patient: Yes. I was rushed to the hospital that day. After that, they told me to follow up. Doctor: Who told you to have a follow-up? Patient: One of the E R doctors and the kidney doctor. Doctor: I see. Your records indicate that you had swelling around the eye on May 3rd of two thousand eight. The cause was unknown. I see you were transferred from the Medical Centre A B to X Y Z Medical Centre that day. Patient: Yes, it sounds about this treatment.

Doctor, you have to tell her. She stopped taking her medication. And her blood pressure is out of control, she is angry all the time and not taking care of herself at all. Patient: That's not true! Doctor: Miss Tara, you have to take your medication in time. You are hypertensive and your readings don't look good. Patient: I don't want to take any more medication. I want to try some natural remedies to treat my high blood pressure. I'm not going to take any prescription medication that is quite that. Doctor: If that's the case, then I'll note in your file that you don't respect.
I think I have an allergy, my lips are swollen and it causes me difficulty swallowing. Doctor: Oh, let me take a look.

Do you take something for one or the other? Patient: Only for high blood pressure. Doctor: Have you had any operations in the past? Patient: I had an operation to get some hemorrhoids removed in two thousand ten.
Do you have a family history of medical conditions, such as diabetes or heart disease? Patient: No, nothing.

How's your family? Patient: They're fine, thank you. My three boys are all grown up. Hard to believe they live their own as young professionals. One of them is actually a G I doctor in San Diego, California. Doctor: You must be so proud of your boys. Patient: My wife and I always say how lucky we are. Doctor: I'm sure. And I have a few other questions before I finish. Patient: Go ahead. Doctor: Drink or smoke? Patient: I smoke about a third of a pack a day and I drink from time to time, but nothing crazy.

How's it going, buddy? I haven't seen you in a long time Patient: Hey, Doctor. It's been a while. I'm doing fine. Just here for my check-up. Doctor: Good. How's the family doing? Is everything okay? Patient: Yes, they're fine. No one's been sick for a while. Doctor: It's great to hear. No one has new medical conditions either, no? Patient: Not that I know. They're all fine.

So you and your husband live together, correct? Patient: Yes. It's a miracle that we've lasted so long. Guest_family: Can't argue that. Doctor: Are you able to walk any distance without assistance? Guest_family: She's more comfortable in her wheelchair, but she usually walks with a walker if she's at home. Patient: Yes, he's right. Doctor: And how many times do you walk with your walker? Pattor: If I guess, I'd say half the time. Doctor: Super. Guest_family: If I'm nearby, I like to keep an eye on her case, she feels unstable and needs help to sit down. Doctor: It's good that you're both looking out for each other. Now you go on the last questions. You smoke or drink? Pattor: No and no. Doctor: Have you smoked or drunk in the past? Pattor: No.

You don't look so good today. What's the problem? Patient: Well, I'm having trouble. My whole body hurts and I'm in pain. Doctor: Do you have a history of drug use? Patient: Well, yes. I'm detoxing. Doctor: What kind of medication have you taken? Patient: Hero. Doctor: How long have you been using? Patient: I don't feel well. Maybe a year. I can't sleep or eat. Doctor: Have you had fever, chills, vomiting or diarrhea? Patient: I think I have fever. I feel cold. I had diarrhea.

How would you assess your overall health? Patient: I have been in good enough health at least physically. I try to do frequent walks and eat a clean diet. However, there was a case where I was not mentally well. After my husband died in nineteen seventy-five years, I had what I believe to be a nervous depression. As a result, I was hospitalized for several weeks and treated with E C T. Doctor: I am sorry to hear about your husband's loss. I can't imagine how difficult it must have been. I am glad that you looked for the care you needed to feel better at that time. Did it happen when you were living in the United States or Korea? Patient: All this happened when I was living in Korea. I am grateful that I had my family and friends to support me. Doctor: Social support is very important, especially when you treat the loss of a loved one. Patient: Absolutely. Doctor: I have some questions before I pass.

Do you have headaches, or do you have a history of migraine? Patient: No. Doctor: A temporary loss of consciousness? Patient: No. Doctor: A feeling of balance or fainting? Patient: No. Doctor: A continuous noise that you can hear? Patient: No. Doctor: All right, no tinnitus. No wounds or ulcers of the mouth? Patient: Hum, no. Doctor: Have you noticed a change in your voice, a hoarseness? Patient: No, nothing like that. Doctor: Have you noticed swelling in and around your mouth? Patient: No, I didn't. Doctor: No stories of goitre or swelling of your thyroid gland? Patient: No. Doctor: Ok.

Hello, Miss. How can I help you? Patient: Well, I just turned fifty seven this year and I would like to get rid of these wrinkles on my face. I don't like them a little. Doctor: You are beautiful and actually have a lot of fullness in your face.

Oh doctor, you flatter me. I'm sixty-two years old. Doctor: Great, and you've already had a rotator wrist repair, that's right? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Well, well, what seems to be the problem today? Patient: I still have a lot of pain in this shoulder. Doctor: Oh no, did you have a recent imaging done on this shoulder? Patient: Yes, I had an MR I didn't have too long, can you take a look at it? I have it here. Doctor: Thank you, yes, this MR I show that you still tore the rotator handle. Patient: Oh no, can we do another operation to fix it again? Doctor: Yes, we will have to. Patient: What is the risk of infection of surgery? Doctor: It's less than one percent.

What brings you today? Patient: I dropped a glass and one of the broken pieces cut off my foot quite badly. There was a lot of blood. Doctor: Is the area still bleeding? Patient: I got it to stop bleeding while I was waiting for my turn. Doctor: Is there any pain in the area? Patient: No, it doesn't hurt. Doctor: Are you able to walk normally without pain or discomfort? Patient: Yes. Doctor: You experience numbness or loss of strength in the area? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have any other injuries on another part of your body? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you had recent illnesses? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have any other concerns while you are here today? Patient: No.

What are you doing to live, sir? Patient: I'm actually retired, but I'm used to working as a dock hand. Doctor: It's great, congratulations on your retirement! Patient: Thank you very much, doctor. Doctor: I just need some information about you, sir. Do you smoke? Patient: Of course, I smoke about half a pack of cigarettes a day. Doctor: Do you drink, sir? Patient: Well, not now, but I was an alcoholic.

When did you leave them? Patient: Three years ago. Male, time flies. Doctor: Did you experience post-operative complications? Patient: Nothing out of the ordinary. Doctor: Who was the surgeon who made your thyroidectomy? Pattor: Doctor X. Doctor: What was the final diagnosis? Pattor: I had a growth on my thyroid. Doctor: Was growth cancerous? Pattor: It was. I was initially reluctant to get them out, but I realized it was necessary. I didn't have much choice if I wanted to live you know. Doctor: It's understandable. I'm sorry you had to go through that. Surgery is intimidating, and even less surgery to eliminate cancer.

Thank you! It's nice to meet you. Doctor: How old is your daughter? Guest_family: She's three years old now. Doctor: Hello! Patient: Hello! Doctor: Mom I would like to start with some questions about pregnancy, childbirth, and previous children. Guest_family: Do you have any other children? Guest_family: No. It's my only child. Doctor: Have you ever had any miscarriages or abortions before you had your daughter? Guest_family: I had a very young miscarriage before I was pregnant with her. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Guest_family: Thank you. I was difficult but when I got pregnant with her, we were so happy. Doctor: Did you have any difficulties or problems during your pregnancy. Guest_family: I had the flu in my seventh or eighth month of pregnancy.

Do you work? Patient: Oh yes, I am a farmer. I have a farm and my wife, and I do agriculture. Doctor: Well, so you are a happy married couple working together. Patient: Ah yes. Doctor: And about tobacco, do you smoke or eat? Patient: Absolutely not. Doctor: Any drug or alcohol use? Patient: Drugs? Doctor: Yes, like cocaine or something like that. Patient: Oh, no. No drugs. Patient: And I don't drink either. Doctor: Okay.

Well, looking at your hand x ray, the bone looks in alignment, and I see no effusion. Doctor: Any tenderness or pain? Patient: Ah, not really! Doctor: There is no asymmetry. Can you move your hand up and down? Now rotate it. Can you move your fingers? Patient: Yes, I can do all this, no problem at all. Doctor: Can you fold your hand? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Perfect.

How about a surgical procedure in the past? Patient: Well, I had a colon surgery in nineteen ninety-nine or was it in ninety, oh yes in nineteen ninety. Doctor: OK and something else? Patient: Ah yes, I had three surgical procedures for my sinus one was the same year as my colon surgery, one before that. So, the first one was in nineteen ninety-nine I think then nineteen ninety and the last one was in two thousand five. Doctor: Wow, you also remember years. Patient: Yes, surprisingly.

What are you doing to live? Patient: I am a nurse in a nursing home right now. Doctor: Do you work the normal day work? Patient: No, I work the second shift, so I work a few late nights and early in the morning. Doctor: Are you back in Wichita State this semester? Patient: No, I decided to take some leave. Doctor: Everything's okay? Patient: Yes, I'm really tired, so I decided to move away a little bit. Doctor: It's understandable. Are you going out with me now? Patient: Yes, I've been out with my boyfriend for a while. Doctor: Is there any significant stress in your relationship? Patient: No, everything's fine.

When did you go to the dentist? Patient: What happened to the dentist? Also, sorry, but how old are you? Patient: It's after I left the dentist. I was driving home, and I was stunned. I was so dizzy that I had to withdraw. Doctor: How long did the episode go? Patient: About two to three minutes. Doctor: Is this the only time it happened? Patient: No. In November last year, I felt in the middle of breakfast when I had vertigo. I was so stunned that I was sick, and I vomited several times.

Yes, you're right about it. In my seventy-six years, I've never been piqued. It's new. Guest_family: He was piqued around noon while I was preparing lunch. Patient: Yes, they had both my hands and my right knee. These little monsters. Doctor: Have you noticed any redness and swelling right away? Patient: Um not right now. Doctor: How long did it take for your body to react? Patient: Bout 30 minutes or so. Doctor: Have you experienced shortness of breath, itching or hives? Patient: No, surprisingly. Doctor: And no swelling of the tongue or difficulty in swallowing? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you been piqued in the past? Or is it your first time? Patient: I was piqued about a month ago. No redness or swelling as I do now.
What are your family medical history? Patient: I was adopted. I don't know my family medical history.
Have you ever been diagnosed with blood or heart disease? Patient: Uh no. Doctor: Other past medical problems? Patient: No.
A major or minor operation done in the past? Guest_family: Sorry, I have no idea. Guest_family: I just started working for him.
I can see your medication list here. Doctor: Do you take Accutane and Ovcon? Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: OK. Patient: OK.
What are you taking? Patient: I take Tylenol. Doctor: Is it only for pain? Patient: Yes.

person: I'm going to tell you what happened yesterday. Doctor
sentence: Thank you, nurse. How do you feel today, miss? Welcome to the lung medicine clinic. What happened yesterday? Patient: Well, I've been doing great since the last time. My breathing problems have been great and I didn't have major difficulty breathing. Doctor: It's good to hear. What happened yesterday that made you want to enter so quickly? Patient: Yesterday I noticed that I have back and joint pain. When I breathe deeply your back hurts. Doctor: Do you suffer from cough? Patient: No, coughing at that time. Doctor: Did you produce mucus the time you're coughing? Patient: No, I've already said that I don't hurt my back.

person: I guess the last time I was here was in two thousand and two if I'm not wrong. Does your system say? Doctor
sentence: Do you think you're still working in this airline? Patient: Yes sir, still with Alaska Airlines but I was promoted and I'm working as an airplane mechanic. Doctor: It's so good for you! So, tell me how can I help you today? What brought you to our dermatology department first and first, I thought you still had the pain in my stomach on the right side and down. Doctor: It's so good for you! So, tell me how can I help you today?

Have you completed your cancer treatments? Patient: Yes. I'm in remission now. Doctor: It's great! When was your last radiation treatment? Patient: It's been more than two years than my last treatment.

Do you have plans to quit smoking? Patient: Eh not really. Doctor: As your doctor, I would advise you to consider nicotine patches and find ways to break your habit of smoking. Patient: Ok. I will see what I can do. Doctor: You drink? Patient: Socially. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: No, but I have two babies. Doctor: Aw, how old are they? Patient: I have a four-year-old child and a six-year-old child. Doctor: It's great. I'm sure they're taking you.

Of course, I'm seventy-nine years old. Doctor: Well, thank you. What is the problem today, madam? Patient: Well, I have this arthritis, as you know. Doctor: Yes, how would you describe your arthritis? Patient: Well, at this stage, I would say it's debilitating. Doctor: I see, so anti-inflammatory and rest didn't help at all? Patient: No, I haven't had any improvement, Doctor. It's still so bad. Doctor: I see, I think you would be a good candidate for a knee replacement. Patient: Yes, I thought so. What are the risks of infection for surgery? Doctor: Uh, it's less than one percent, we use prophylaxis antibiotics to control infection all the time. Patient: It's great, and about anesthesia, am I going to sleep for that? Doctor: Yes, you haven't experienced surgery, I want to.

I was born and raised in Iowa. My husband and I moved here twenty years ago, and we are here since. Doctor: This is a wonderful city. Do you have children? Patient: Yes! We have two children. Doctor: Do you have a history or current use of tobacco, alcohol and drugs or recreational substances? Patient: I have a glass of wine from time to time but not the rest.

person: A member of your family has problems like convulsions? Patient
sentence: None on my father's side, but, yes, on my mother's side some members of the family had convulsions. Like, my mother had them during her childhood. I know that my grandmother had it and my big aunt too.
Do you have pain in your throat, cough or ears? Patient: No.

Can you tell me what diseases you have been diagnosed with in the past? Patient: Of course, I have had hypertension, diabetes, asthma and cholesterol problem. Doctor: Okay, is there anything else? Patient: No. Doctor: And it's type two diabetes, right? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Thank you!

Well, um, we did a good orchiectomy because of your testicular cancer, when did you get that? Patient: Um, it was about eighteen years ago now, so it was about nineteen ninety-nine. Doctor: Well, while you are here, do you have any other conditions that I should be aware of? Patient: Of course, I have G E R D, and um, I B S. Doctor: Thank you, what about allergies, does it bother you? Patient: Yes, unfortunately I have them. Doctor: Do you have them in spring or fall? Patient: Actually, I have them in both.
Good morning, Miss X Y Z, correct?
Yes, that's me, good morning doctor.
Before we begin, I just need a few pieces of information. How old are you?
I'm forty four years young, doctor.
Good, thank you. Next, which hand do you write with?
I write with my right hand.
Finally, what do you do for a living?
I'm an aircraft mechanic.
Very nice, so, how did you get hurt?
Um, I was working on repairing an airplane at work when I fell between the plane and one of the stands.
How big was the gap that you stepped in?
Um, it was about a foot and a half.
Which knee did you hurt?
It was my left knee.
Did you have surgery after the accident?
Yes I did, I had two arthroscopies, and an, um, patellar replacement after those.
Okay, yes, I see.
Then, I had a left knee replacement on Month D D, Y Y Y Y.
Do you have any imaging of this knee?
I didn't have any x rays done, but I have an MRI report and notes from Doctor A B C D.
Can I see that report?
Yes absolutely, here.

Okay, so this M R I from September two thousand six shows some nonspecific edema anterior to the patellar tendon, but thankfully there's no evidence of fracture of ligamentous avulsion or abnormality.
What does that mean?
There's some bleeding in the bone there, but nothing is broken or out of alignment.
Oh, thank you, that's good.
Oh certainly, yes, it is. What treatments have you had for this knee, aside from surgery?
I've done a full course of PT for this.
Where is your knee pain?
Mostly, it's here in the front of the knee, and then on both sides, like the inside and outside.
Does the pain go down your leg at all?
Yes, it goes down my, is this the femur?
Yes, that's the femur.
Then this must be my tibia, it goes down the front of that too.
Does it go into your thigh at all?
Yes, it goes into the back of my thigh. I feel numbness and tingling back there.
Do you feel anything in the feet?
Nope, my feet are completely normal, thankfully.
Are you having any back pain?
A little, I feel something in my lower back, I'm not sure if it's related.
Does anything make your knee pain worse?
Yeah, I can hardly walk anymore, it hurts so bad.
What kind of symptoms do you see when you walk on this?
I feel popping and grinding, and my knee swells up.
That numbness and tingling you feel in the thigh, do you feel that in the knee at all?
Actually yes, it feels like pins and needles there.
What about this, when I touch the knee do you feel any abnormal discomfort or pain over the rest of the knee?
No, nothing out of the ordinary there.
What about this, this is the fibular head, which is where you feel the pins and needles. I'm applying pretty heavy pressure here, how would you describe what you're feeling?
Um, numbness, tingling, and then that same pins and needles feeling.
Is there any instability?
Yes, and there's pain with it too.
Are you working right now?
No, I'm not right now.
Any allergies I should know about?
Yes, actually, I'm allergic to a lot of pain medications.
Okay, have there been any changes in how you're walking?
Yes, I had to change my walking pattern to take weight off my knee, and I think that has to do with my back pain.
That's certainly a possibility. How would you describe your pain?
I'd say its constant, shooting, cramping, aching, throbbing, feels like it's being pulled, sharp, and , um, stabbing. All of those words seem fitting.
Okay, does the pain wake you up at night?
Yeah, it does occasionally.
Does anything make this feel better?
Yeah, it gets a little better if I lay down or if I keep my leg elevated.
Out of ten, with ten being the worst pain ever, how would you describe your pain on average?
Um, I'd say six out of ten. That's how it is right now, too.
What about at its worst?
Easily, its ten out of ten.
Finally, what about when the pain is at its least?
Um, when it's not too bad, I'd say it's a three out of ten. I also have this other M R I report from September of O six, here.
Thanks. I see. They said that there is nonspecific edema anterior to the patellar tendon, but there is no acute fracture or any ligament abnormalities. That's good.

person: I know I have a fracture in the lower back. Doctor
sentence: How did you manage this? Patient: Another doctor called this conservative treatment. I have rested a lot, and using anti-inflammatory drugs. Doctor: There has been an improvement? Patient: There have been several months at this stage, and honestly no, there has been no improvement. I am still in a lot of pain. Doctor: This C T Scan that you have recently shown sclerosis, with some healing of a L five compression fracture, but if you look here, the healing is not complete. Patient: What can we do about this patient?

person: I didn't do what they did, I did it. Doctor
sentence: And how old are you, dear? Patient: What is the problem today? Patient: I have a right knee pain while playing tennis, uh, it was about three days ago. It really hurts. Doctor: I see, tennis, eh? Was there a contact? Patient: No, I did a wrong step when I took a clumsy blow. Doctor: Can you stand up on that knee? Patient: Not well, it feels unstable, as I'm going to fall. Doctor: Have you ever hurt that knee before? Patient: Yes, I tore my ACL in two thousand eight. Doctor: I guess you did an operation for that? Patient: Yes, I did, with Dr. X. He called it one, uh, C L Reconstruction. Doctor: How did you recover from that? Guest_Family: She didn't do well, she didn't do what they did.

How do you feel today? Patient: Much better. Antibiotics seemed to really help. Doctor: You still feel symptoms? Patient: Uh no, fortunately. I had a little wheezing when I started antibiotics, but it's improved a ton. I don't think wheezing is still there. Doctor: Well, well.
Medical problems in the family? Patient: No, nothing comes to mind.

I fell in front and the head hit the sidewalk. The next thing I remember is that I'm all stunned and people are trying to help me. Doctor: I see, have you lost consciousness after the fall? Patient: No. Doctor: Is your head hurt? Patient: Only the right forehead where I have the scraping and my chin. Doctor: All right, any neck or back pain? Patient: No. Doctor: No stomach pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Pain elsewhere, at the ends, hand or leg? Patient: No. Doctor: And how old are you? Patient: I'm forty-two years old. Doctor: OK.

Can you tell me about any kind of medical traits in your family? Patient: I think my family has been blessed or I don't know if there are any. Doctor: What about heart disease? Patient: No. No heart disease or diabetes or any other type of problems I know about.

Hello, Nurse. Can you give me a descent on the old patient of eleven months? Guest_clinician: The patient was presented with step two neuroblastoma on the left when he was six weeks old. It was completely resected. It was shown not to be N Myc amplified and had a good Shimada histology. Doctor: Super. Did he have a follow-up after? Guest_clinician: He was a second primary in his right adrenal gland. They performed a biopsy, which was compatible with the neuroblastoma with the favorable Shimada histology. Doctor: Did he receive chemotherapy? Guest_clinician: He is now treated with it by protocol P nine six four and not under study.

How old are you now? Patient: I'm thirty-two years old now, so I've suffered since I was in my 20s. Doctor: Have you seen another doctor for that, or am I the first? Patient: Yes, uh, I saw several doctors before, the last one I saw was Doctor A B C a few weeks ago. Doctor: What did these doctors say to you? Patient: They thought it was a pain at the bottom of the back, and something called, uh, radiculopathy. Doctor: Does your pain radiate in your legs? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Was your pain present during the eight years, or did it come and passed? Patient: There has been persistent pain, and I have had difficulties since then. Doctor: The x-rays of Dr. A B C show serious degenerative changes as well as vascular necrosis of the femoral head.

Let me examine your skin. Patient: Of course. Doctor: It seems normal and well hydrated. Any excessive sweating? Patient: No, not really. Doctor: I do not see any injury or injury. Patient: Yes. Doctor: It is just a normal protocol to ask these questions for each new patient. Patient: I understand. Doctor: Thank you for your cooperation.

I feel weird. I feel confused. I don't know how I got here. Doctor: It's good. Do you remember what happened to you before you arrived here? Patient: No. Doctor: Can you tell me about your medical past? Patient: Um. Doctor: Take your time. Patient: I can't think about what it's called. It's something to do with my brain. Doctor: Ok. Patient: My doctor knows what it is. Doctor: What's your doctor's name? Patient: Dr Frank. Doctor: Doctor: Doctor: Doctor X? On the other side of the street? Patient: Yes, that's his name. I don't know if it's on the other side of the street or not. Doctor: I'm going to ask your nurse to phone him and get some basic information. Patient: Ok. Doctor: Can you call Doctor X and get Mr Jones's medical history? Guest_clinician: Yes, of course. Doctor: Thank you.
Problems from head to toe? Patient: No, everything's fine.
Hello, it's been two months already? Patient: I know well? Doctor: I feel like yesterday.
Tell me about your family medical history. Patient: No one in my family has any health problems.

And you work? What are you doing? Patient: Oh, I am a Catholic priest! Doctor: Oh wow! Patient: Yes. Doctor: And if you don't allow me to ask, you drink alcohol? Patient: Maybe it's something for my confession box but jokes except I don't drink. Doctor: Sorry I have to ask these questions is a protocol. Patient: I understand. Doctor: And can I ask here that you don't smoke or use any kind of drugs? Patient: Yes, I don't do that either. Doctor: Cool.
I live in a nursing home.

So he is Arjun, and he is thirty-seven years old and complains of chest pain. Patient: Hi Doctors, how are you? Doctor: We are good thanks to ask. Guest_clinician: Hello Arjun, I am Dr. J and I am helping Dr. Wilson today. So, chest pain huh? Patient: Yes. Guest_clinician: And I see here no cardiac excretion has been mentioned. Doctor: Yes. I suspect a coronary spasm but it is doubtful. Guest_clinician: OK. Doctor: I made an enzyme profile heart and it was negative. Guest_clinician: Okay. And he also has hyperlipidemia? Doctor: Yes, he does. Guest_clinician: Ok and did you order an E K G? Doctor: I did it, too. Guest_clinician: Don't worry Arjun, we will take it from you. Patient: Thank you.

So, do you live in the area? Patient: Yes, my husband and I have lived here for a long time. He died a few years ago. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Patient: It's good. Doctor: Are you smoking or drinking? Patient: No, I don't. Doctor: Do you use drugs or illicit substances? Patient: No, I don't do anything like that.

I take Ultracet's credits. Sometimes, I take up to four times a day. Doctor: Does this help pain? Patient: No, I'm still in quite a lot of pain, doctor. Doctor: Hello, sir. My nurse's card says you're thirty-four years old. Is that correct? Patient: Yes, doctor, that's right. Doctor: How long have you had this pain in your back? Patient: Well, it's been a while now. Doctor: Does the pain go into your legs? Patient: Yes, in the left leg, more towards the outside of my leg. Doctor: Is there an injury that started this pain? Patient: Yes, I was raising at work the twenty-seventh two thousand three when I raised something and felt a fairly acute back pain in my left leg. Doctor: Did you have a pain in your back or surgery before this injury? Patient: No, I didn't. Doctor: Do you have a weakness in your legs? Patient: Yes, I am.

person: Doctor X and I will review your medical history with you. Before you start, could you confirm your age for me? Patient
sentence: I am twenty-five years old. Doctor: Thank you. Doctor X, could you review the diagnosis of erythema nodosum? Doctor_2: She was diagnosed in two thousand and four years after a biopsy that confirmed the erythema nodosum, but the detail of the Netherlands is not so specific. Doctor: What types of procedures were done to respond to it? Doctor_2: She underwent a colonoscopy to treat secondary diseases that may have been present because of the erythema nodosum, correctly missed? Patient: Yes, that's right. Doctor: Was there any results, Doctor_2: The results were uncertain if the ileum had abnormal skin lesions.
Are you sick in your family? Patient: No. Doctor: So everyone is healthy? Patient: That's true.

Mr Sunil, your blood pressure is high, and I have noticed it for two-three times that you have been here. He has been constantly raised, you do not take it seriously. Patient: No, nothing like this Doctor! He has been well under control. I have been watching at home. Doctor: Did you rate your readings? Did you bring with you? Patient: No. I did not get the readings with me but I assure you that I take care and my BP is normal. Doctor: Well, it's up and I'm not bothered by that.

What are your family medical history? Patient: My father had colon cancer. Doctor: Did your father die of colon cancer? Patient: No. They caught him early. He died of old age. My mother died when she was in the 1990s from a stroke. Doctor: I'm sorry. Do you have a family history of neurological disorders like, M S, Alzheimer, Parkinson or epilepsy? Patient: Other times my mother had a stroke, I don't know anything else.

Hello. I see you are here for follow-up. Have you done your blood work? Patient: I did it. Here are the results. Doctor: Let me take a look. Oh, wow. It seems your blood sugar is high. You exercise every day? Patient: Not really. Is it bad? Doctor: You are at risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Have you ever had surgery? Patient: Yes, I had my gallbladder removed a few years ago. Doctor: Thank you, what other parts of the body, such as your eyes, your ears or your nose? Patient: Oh yes, I forgot. I did an eye surgery too. Doctor: Thank you, think hard, any other operation you can remember? Patient: Let me look at my notes, um, it seems that I did a dilation and a cure a little later, too. Doctor: I see. Thank you for sharing this with me.

Hi! How are you? Patient: Hum. I am very strange. Doctor: Strange how? Patient: I took Ecstasy during the weekend and I still feel weird. My heart is running. I feel restless and have had waves of sadness. I cannot shake this feeling. Doctor: When did you take ecstasy? Patient: Saturday.

person: I lost my husband because of prostate cancer last year. Doctor
sentence: Oh wow. I'm so sorry for your loss. Losing a loved one is incredibly difficult. I lost my sister because of cervical cancer two years ago. It was one of the hardest experiences of my life.
