Patient: I'm sorry for your loss as well. It helps to remember the positive memories you had with them. Doctor: Yes, certainly. How did you do otherwise? Patient: Not bad. I took care of the gardening. Doctor: Gardening is a great hobby. Patient: Yes, I really appreciate it. It brings me a lot of peace. Doctor: And like your doctor, I have to ask, but all about alcohol or drugs? Patient: No.

I'm sorry to hear it. What's going on? Patient: My parents had been fighting for a long time, and I think they're not together anymore. Doctor: It must be really hard. I'm sorry to hear that they're divorced. Who do you live with right now? Patient: I'm used to going to my father's house. I'm going to my father's house the first half of the week and spending time with his family. Then I'm going to my mother's house for the last half of the week. Doctor: It's nice. Now you can ask for more gifts during Christmas. Patient: You know what? I never thought about it. It's really a good idea.

What are you doing to live? Patient: I am a real estate agent. Doctor: How long have you been working in real estate? Patient: Almost twenty years. Doctor: Wow. I know who to go to when I'm looking to buy a house. Patient: Happy to help. Doctor: So let's see here. Do you drink or smoke? Patient: I drink socially, but it's very rare. Doctor: And I have to ask, but any drug use? Patient: No. Not now, not ever.

Do you remember the information about your operation? Patient: How do you feel today? Patient: Well, I had a lot of stress recently, and I had problems with my adjustments before. Doctor: Has there anything changed since the operation? Patient: Actually, doctor, I was in a car accident a few weeks ago, and I have problems. Doctor: What are the symptoms you are experiencing? Patient: I do not feel full. Patient: How is your appetite? Patient: I am not really hungry, but I do not feel so full. When I am hungry at night, I cannot wait until morning to eat.
So, where do you live? Patient: Ah, I now live in an assisted nursing facility. Doctor: Okay, and you drink or smoke? Patient: No, neither.
What do you mean by that? Doctor: Does anyone in your family or extended family have any medical problems for which he was treated? Patient: I am not aware of such a thing in my family.

Thank you. It's nice to meet you. Doctor: Are you married? Patient: Yes. We've just been touched last year. Doctor: Congratulations! Patient: Thank you. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol? Patient: No, I don't drink. Doctor: Smoking cigarettes? Patient: Yes. I know it's bad for me. Doctor: How much do you smoke a day? Patient: About one package a day. Doctor: Okay. I have a lot of tools to help you quit smoking that we can talk about. Patient: Okay.

You have plans to follow up and remove staples in a week with Dr. X Y Z. Do you have any instructions for wound care? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Do you have any questions? Patient: No. Doctor: If you have any questions or concerns that may arise, do not hesitate to call the office. Patient: OK. Doctor: If you develop a fever greater than one hundred and one point four, chills, nausea, vomiting, or persistent diarrhea, please call the office.
Because it's more allergic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we call it allergic rhinitis. Patient: Is it different from sinus infection? Doctor: Yes, it's different. Patient: Okay.
She has a rare case of thrombocytopenia. I would like her to come for a consultation. Guest_clinician: Other medical history? Doctor: No, just thrombocytopenia.

And what is it? Patient: You know, a little discomfort that I have on the right side. I have felt that since I had a stroke five years ago. Doctor: All right. We have made an E M G right? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And none of the medicines that we have tried to help? Patient: No, I have also seen a neurologist, but nothing helps Doctor: Okay, and you monitor your sugar regularly? Patient: Oh yes, every day at least two to three times a day. Doctor: And what dose of insulin tip? Patient: Oh, that I adjust myself. Doctor: Well, I have reverified all the symptoms and everything looks good. I see nothing incompatible, but we will keep control. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you don't smoke or drink again are you? Patient: No, not since I had stroke. Doctor: In the past you must have a history of smoking. In the past you have had a history of alcohol.
What is the strength of your Omeprazole? Patient: It is 40 M G and I take it just once a day. Doctor: Any herbal medicine? Patient: No I don't take anything like that.

So, to check, you have a history of hay fever and asthma, right? Patient: Yes. I was also recently diagnosed with cervical dysplasia. I discovered shortly after my last visit O B G Y N. Doctor: And do you intend to follow your O B G Y N in the coming months? Patient: Yes, the next visit is scheduled and everything.
So, do you have a family history of arthritis? Patient: Fortunately, no, not what I know. Doctor: So, as far as you know, no one has had a joint replacement? Patient: No, it doesn't sound at all.

I'm sorry, it must be difficult. Patient: Thank you, but I'm taking care of it. Doctor: What about your joints? How do you move? Patient: Oh yes, I also have arthritis. I also had sciatic pains a long time ago, and a herniated disk. Doctor: Have you ever had neurological symptoms, such as headaches, blurred vision, or weakness? Patient: In fact, I have migraines when I have my menses.

Do you have a history of psychiatric treatment of struggles? Patient: I had extreme fatigue in 19 years. I was in therapy for six years. They got me on Prozac. I took for six years while I was in therapy. When I started Prozac, I had just started working again. The stress at work was overwhelming. Doctor: Was it the first time you had feelings of fatigue and depression? Patient: No. I always had a bit of sadness or depression in my life but it had been manageable before all the stress at work started. Doctor: How do you feel these days? Patient: I become a little sad from time to time but I don't dwell on things anymore. Doctor: Do you ever have thoughts of self-harm or suicidal thoughts? Patient: No.

How many other children do you have? Guest_family: My husband and I have three children, your patient today, and another boy, and daughter. Doctor: How everyone is doing? Guest_family: They're all fine, thank you for asking. Doctor: Do you live here in Easton? Guest_family: Yes, born and raised. Doctor: Well, do you have animals? Guest_family: We have four dogs, three cats and three mules. Doctor: What, no deer? Guest_family: No, no deer, at least no more. Doctor: In what class are you, young man? Patient: I'm in second year, doctor. Doctor: Good, how do you like P E? Are you able to play without problems? Patient: Yes, I love P E. I have no problem there.

person: I didn't have a job. I sent you a year and a half. I fell down trying to walk from my bed to the living room. Doctor
sentence: Did you have a clear mind before? Patient: Uh yes, I had a lightness and I was a little confused. I was aware of my environment though. I just gave my legs and the following thing I knew I was on the floor. Doctor: I see. Have you lost consciousness? Patient: No, thank you goodness. Guest_family: He got up by himself and felt good after. Patient: Yes. I was good until my legs gave me things to day O eight. Doctor: Have you experienced the same lightness as before? Patient: Not this time. Guest_family: We had to rush him to the hospital after that. Patient: I was diagnosed with pneumonia.

Are you still doing aerobics? Patient: Yes, I've been in the pool for five days. Doctor: How do you feel? Have you noticed any changes in energy and strength? Patient: I feel a little stronger now than when I started.

Do you have a history of chronic pain? Patient: I had a car accident a long time ago and I always had neck pain. Doctor: Okay. Any other pain in the whole body? Patient: Sometimes I have back pain. Doctor: Okay.

How is your pain today? Patient: Eh it was a little harder a few days that is sure. The pain started almost instantly. Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Did you take something for him? Patient: I actually saw a chiropractician the other day. My neck pain was unbearable. Doctor: Is the pain located in one area? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And he didn't irradiated to another part of your body? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have a feeling of needles and pins at all? Patient: Not yet. Patient: Any pain on the back? Patient: Oh yes. I would say it's even worse than my neck pain. The pain starts in my lower back and radiates in both legs. Doctor: Any pins and needles following this pain on the back? Patient: No, no pins and needles all the time.

person: I agree with Dr. Jones that your lungs show no signs of infection or loss of lung capacity. Patient
sentence: OK.

person: I think I was in Seattle, I thought time wasn't for me. That's why I intend to come here, but my allergies don't leave me either. Doctor
sentence: What did you take for your allergies before? Patient: Claritin and Zyrtec. Doctor: What was their effectiveness? Patient: They seemed to work for a while, but now I feel like nothing is more effective. Doctor: Have you ever tried Allegra? Patient: Yes, I tried last summer and I started it again two weeks ago. But again, the story is the same. They work for a while and now it doesn't seem to work anymore. Doctor: Have you ever tried Allegra? Patient: Yes, I tried it last summer and I started it again as it was two weeks ago.

Hello, ma'am. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: So, do you have any medical problems I should know. Patient: Actually, yes. I have some. I have hyperthyroidism, and I have gallbladder problems for some time now. Doctor: I see. How is your blood pressure? Patient: Oh, uh, I also have high blood pressure.

Are you a smoker, sir? Patient: Yes, I smoke about a pack, a pack and a half-day for more than forty years now. Doctor: What about alcohol, do you drink? Patient: Yes, I drink a pack of beer a day, doctor. Doctor: What about drugs? Do you use illicit substances? Patient: No, I never used anything like that.

I would like her to come see you tomorrow for a consultation. Guest_clinician: How long has she been suffering from migraines with aura? Doctor: About five years now. Guest_clinician: Does she have a neurologist she sees regularly? Doctor: Not since she arrived here.

What have you done to make a living? Patient: I was a Pepsi Cola truck driver, but fortunately, I'm retired. Doctor: Congratulations on your retirement. What seems to be the problem today? Patient: Thank you, it's nice to be done with that. Years have taken their toll however, I have a lot of pain in my back and knees. Doctor: Ah, yes, these years of sitting up and getting up end up catching everyone.
Tell me about your family medical history. Patient: The only thing I know is that my grandmother is diabetic.

Hello, Mr. G, how are you doing today? Patient: I am a good doctor thank you for asking. I am here to tell you about my will. Doctor: Yes, the nurse informed me. So, tell me how can I help you? Patient: As you know, I have terminal cancer. I decided I don't want to be revived. I appointed my daughter as legal health care agent and she respects my wish. Doctor: Tell me what I can do to make you comfortable? Patient: Honestly doctor you have done enough and I'm so grateful for that. I just want to spend my last days at home surrounded by relatives. I have my nurse, she takes care of me. I think I'm fine! Doctor: Okay my friend.
Do you smoke? Patient: No. Doctor: What about alcohol? Or any drugs? Patient: No.
History of illness, intervention or hospitalization? Patient: I dislocated my wrist when I was a child, but that's all.

Pain during pissing? Patient: No. Doctor: Any change in frequency or feeling of urgency to pee? Patient: No. Doctor: And bladder control, accidents? Patient: No. Doctor: A history of syphilis or any other S T D? Patient: No, never. Doctor: OK.
Is there a history of heart disease in your family? Patient: Yes, my father and brother had a type of cardiac blockage in their 40s.

If I understand correctly, you suffered an elbow injury during a fight with other children in the miner's room? Patient: Yes. My left elbow kills me. Doctor: How old are you? Patient: Seventeen years old. Doctor: Do you have pain elsewhere? Patient: Yes. My left ankle also hurts. Doctor: Are you able to walk without difficulty? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Knee pain? Patient: Not immediately, but I have a knee pain in the past. Doctor: Have you lost your head or injured your neck in any way? Patient: I did not faint. I hit my head against the ground when one of the children tried to nail me. Doctor: Do you have headaches, nausea or blurred vision? Patient: No. Doctor: And no chest or abdominal pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Was there weapons like knives or weapons used during the fight? Patient: No.

Hello. Before starting your visit, I noticed missing information. Can I check the information with you? Patient: Of course. Doctor: Does your family have a history of health problems? Patient: Oh, yeah. Many of my family have heart problems and cancer. Doctor: I see. Do you know what type of cancer? Patient: I'm not sure, but my wife can know it. She's here with me right now. Doctor: Great. I'll bring her. Guest_family. Hello. I'm his wife. Doctor: Do you know what type of cancer is running in his family? Guest_family: I know it.
Okay I am looking at you for multiple issues today. One of the biggest being swelling on your left leg. Can you tell me more about that?

Yes sure. I got this swelling for almost three years now, and it has been worse for the past two to three months. Sometimes it gets better in the morning when I get up, but then throughout the day it begins to swell again.  Lately it is staying bigger, and it feel uncomfortable with it being so large.  The right leg also swells, but not nearly like the left leg.
How old are you, miss?
I am forty four. My biggest problem is this pain in my left shoulder. I feel as if this low back pain is due to a poor mattress.
Did you hurt your shoulder?

No, I don't remember hurting shoulder, but gradually I am losing some mobility.  It is hard for me to get my hands behind my back or behind my head.  I am losing strength in the left shoulder gradually for the last year.
Ok let's look at your labs.
So far white counts are high. In April two thousand five Doctor X Y Z was asked to look at my high white count, but she thought it wasn't a problem and asked me to come for follow up.
Any other complaints?

I have a lot of frequency with urination, and I get up to pee at night at least two to three times.   Also, I have gained weight, I think about twelve pounds since March.  Right now, I am two eighty four pounds.
Okay. So, I can see that your blood pressure is staying stable.  You do take Atenolol twelve point five M G per day and Lasix as needed.
Yes, that's correct. It makes me pee so much. I do not take it.
How about chest pain or shortness of breath?
No chest pain, but I am gradually feeling short of breath.
What work you do?
I work for the city of Wichita as bus dispatcher. My work demands sitting a lot, and just really does not move around much.  But towards the end of the day my leg swells up.
Okay that's okay.
I need cholesterol check right?
Yes, you do, but all the other labs are normal.
What are you doing to live? Patient: I am an officer in the U.S. Navy's office, specialist in artillery repair. Doctor: Do you drink alcohol? Patient: I drink socially but I stopped two years ago.
How are you today? Patient: I am good. Doctor: What is your medical past? Patient: I have no health problems. Not yet at least. Doctor: Let's try to keep it this way. Patient: Yes please.
Well, I'm looking at your ultrasound report and honestly the only important discovery in this area is that it shows being related to the bone. Patient: Oh okay.

Tell me about your family. Did anyone have any medical problems? Patient: My father is alive. He is now sixty-nine years old. He has had some cerebral accidents in the past. My mother died at the age of sixty-two many kinds of heart disease. Doctor: And your grandparents? Patient: My maternal grandfather also had heart problems and he died of a heart attack.

How long have you had the wounds? Patient: They started about ten to twelve days ago. Doctor: We are treating your rheumatoid arthritis with methotrexate? How long have you had the wounds? Patient: Yes, we have tried a lot of different treatments and methotrexate is working well. I have been on it for ten years now. I have taken about twenty or twenty-five MG a week. Doctor: Have you recently increased your dose? I see in your file that we have changed your dose a few times. Patient: About a year ago we lowered the dose from twenty-five MG to twenty but my arthritis fainted while we went to twenty-two five.

person: I think I'm a strong German woman and I hate how something as small as allergies gets the best of me. Doctor
sentence: Why did you move in here? Patient: I wanted to experience different cities since I'm only twenty-three years old. Doctor: This seems exciting. Back to your allergies now. Are you taking medication to relieve your symptoms? Patient: Here's a list of past and current medicines that I'm taking. Doctor: Thank you. Let me take a look. I see you took Claritin and Zyrtec in the past, right? Did that help you? Patient: Yes, that's correct. They worked for a little, but then they stopped working after a while. Doctor: I see. Your notes say you took Allegra after, correct? Patient: I tried to get Allegra out of the patient's condition.

How are you young man? Patient: I'm good. Thank you. Doctor: Let's see how your chest is. Patient: All right. Doctor: The chest measurements are nice. No problem there. The contour also looks great. Also, there is no turning back?

I see here that Doctor- Patient: Yes, Doctor X has sent me away. My thyroid is an absolute disorder. I have never been so in pain for seventy years. Doctor: I am so sorry to hear that. I hope we are able to get you the care you need. Patient: I have coughed a storm. It has become far too big. Doctor: It is good that you are here today to roll the operation. Patient: I have signed the paperwork and everything. Doctor: I will review the risk and benefits once again.
Are you allergic to medicines? Patient: No, I am not allergic to any medicines. Doctor: Okay. Are you sure? Patient: Yes.

I see here that you are allergic to grapefruit and peanuts. Are you allergic to all the medicines you have taken in the past? Patient: Nah, just allergic to grapefruit and peanuts. Doctor: Gotcha. Do you wear an ear pen with you? Patient: I try to bring it everywhere with me.
So tell me about your family, any illness or anything in the family. Patient: Uh, not what I know. Doctor: Okay.
Medical problems in the past? Patient: No, I have a very clean past. Doctor: It's good for you. Any kind of surgery or hospitalization? Patient: No.

Let's talk a little about your family, okay? Doctor: Did anyone in your family have any medical problems? Patient: Yes, my parents died of cancer. Doctor: What cancer? How old were they? Patient: I don't know what cancer they were, but my mother was forty-two years old and my father was sixty-two years old. Doctor: Who else is there in the family? Patient: Oh, I have a big family. I have four sisters, one brother and two half-brothers. One of my half-brothers has asthma.

So, tell me something, is asthma running in your family? Patient: No, I think I'm the only one who has it. Even my parents were surprised when I developed it, as no one else has it. Doctor: Yes, it happens.

What is your medical past? Patient: I underwent surgery on my shoulder thirteen years ago and after the operation I lost my sense of smell. I still can't feel. I can't see as well in my right eye. Doctor: How old are you? Patient: I am seventy-six years old. Doctor: Do you have headaches? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you have nasal drainage? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you ever experienced weakness or numbness in a body area. Patient: No. Doctor: Have you had weight loss? Patient: No.
Are thyroid problems in your family? Patient: No.
Just Tylenol for my pain.

I'm not as young as I was. Doctor: What is the problem today, sir? Patient: I have a pain in my right hand, and it's been there for a while. Doctor: Do you have numbness, sir? Patient: Yes, and I can't move it very well either. Doctor: What fingers do you have these symptoms? Patient: Well, I told you it's in your right hand, but it's in the index finger and the middle fingers. Doctor: Have you seen another doctor for that? Patient: Yes, I had an E M G and it showed, um, carpal tunnel on both hands. Doctor: I only had one patient in both hands.

You have children? Patient: Yes, I had a son, but unfortunately, he died in a car accident. It was five years ago. Doctor: Where do you work? Patient: I work in a pharmaceutical company as a seller. Doctor: You smoke or drink or at any time have tried an illicit drug? Patient: No, I never smoked. I tried a beer once, but I never liked it. Doctor: What about drugs? Patient: No, I never did that.

Will you go to rehab? Patient: Yes, what choice do I have? Doctor: Yes, go to Mercy Manor for PT and rehab. Patient: Yes, I will. Doctor: This will help your pain on the right side of the hip. Patient: I think so too.
Can you tell me about your Immunities? Patient: Yes, I had them all. Doctor: Well, it looks like you're up to date.

Welcome to the clinic. How do you feel today? Patient: Thank you. I'm doing better. Doctor: It seems that we are following your severe osteoarthritis in both knees. And you also experienced some bending contraction limitations. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: How is your physiotherapy? Patient: He's going very well. She kicks my buttocks but he seems to help. Doing my exercises at home really helps. Doctor: Did you not do them at first? Pattor: No, I wasn't. She started doing them and I certainly saw the difference. Doctor: Have you experienced a worsening of the pain since your last visit? Pattor: Well, the right knee is worse than the left? It often hurts after physical therapy. Doctor: Can you describe what the pain brings you down? Pattor: He seems to have a pain in the body.

Hello, what's going on? Guest_family: She's doing great until this morning, but now she can barely move her right arm and has speech problems. She doesn't seem to understand the words. I think it's a stroke. Doctor: We see this a lot at the Medical Center A B C. I'm glad you came. Did you just see Doctor H, right? Guest_family: Yes. We did a head scanner and labs. Doctor: Okay. Where does she live? With you? Guest_family: No. She's at the Life Care Center. Doctor: Ma'am, do you have a headache or chest pain? Patient: What?

I think you have muscle tension. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So pressure on the right side of the shoulder and maybe some nerve compression. Pattor: Oh really! Doctor: Maybe. I'm going to do more evaluation and treatment. Pattor: Ok.

Can you tell me more about your daughter, madam? Guest_family: Yes, she had a lipomyomeningocele repair when she was about three days old, then once again when she was three and a half years old. Doctor: When was she her last operation? Guest_family: Um, it was in March of nineteen-five. Doctor: How did she follow the second operation? Guest_family: She did well, honestly. Doctor: So, what brings you to a visit today? Patient: Well, I had some leg pain on my side of my legs. Doctor: How long did you have this pain? Patient: It's been several months at that time. Doctor: When is your pain the worst? Patient: Well, I have to take medication for pain. Doctor: What are you taking? Patient: She doesn't feel any problems like pain.
How's the patient's condition now? Doctor: Well, he's improved clinically but would need acute care. Guest_clinician: Oh, I see.
Good morning, ma'am. Can you confirm your age for me, please?
Good morning, I'm sixty five years old, doctor.
How are you recovering from your operation?
I'm doing okay. Can you remind me what operation I had?
Um, we did a left upper lobectomy for your stage I A non small cell lung cancer.
Thank you, doctor.
Absolutely, do you have the results of your pelvic C T?
Yes, I have the report right here.
Thank you, so this shows an enlarging simple cyst of the left kidney.
What can we do about this?
Well, that's why we did the barium swallow, which showed a small hiatal hernia with minimal reflux.
Oh, yeah, I remember that.
So, I have your x rays from November twenty third two thousand nine here, we did an A P and lateral view, and they're normal.
Oh, well that's good too.
Are you having any pain with swallowing food?
Yes, I get some chest pain, but I'd say it's pretty mild. Look at my calf, doctor, it's much bigger than the right one.
Chest pain is probably due to tertiary contractions with some delayed emptying. Is it tender?
No, there's no real tenderness.
How long has this calf been enlarged?
Um, it's been several months at this point.
Have you ever had D V T?
Yes, um, in nineteen seventy five, and in nineteen eighty five.
Are you having any abnormal weight loss?
No, everything is normal there, and I'm eating normally.
What about any cold or flu symptoms? Any fever or chills?
No, that's all fine too.
Any new aches or pains?
No, all my muscles feel pretty good.
Have you had a cough, or coughed up any blood.
That's a negative, doctor.
What about shortness of breath while at rest or difficulty breathing with exercise?
No, that's normal too. I'm breathing just fine.

Let's talk about your family's medical history. Patient: Hm, my father and my brother had colon cancer. My daughter was detected with breast cancer. Doctor: Do you remember her age? Patient: Yes, she was forty. Doctor: I see. Another thing? Patient: Well, I have a heart condition and high blood pressure. I also had a stroke. Doctor: Ok.

Have you noticed any blood in your stools? Patient: No, nothing like that. Patient: Have you noticed any blood in the urine or painful urinations? Patient: No. Patient: Okay, chest pain? Patient: Hum, no. Patient: Shortness of breath, cough or cold like symptoms? Patient: No. Patient: No problem with diabetes or thyroid, right? Patient: Absolutely not! Patient: It looks like you have no history of C V A or stroke. Patient: Correct. Patient: Everything else looks good. Patient: Cool. Patient: Your eyes, nose and throat look good.

How are you going to miss it? How does your sugar number happen? Patient: I do well. Thank you. Sugar has always been one hundred and thirty-five or less. Doctor: How are you checking it? Patient: I have a glucose monitor at home that I only use. Doctor: Nice. Have you eaten anything in the morning today? Patient: No, I fast for my test. Doctor: Okay, let's see. We have an Accu Chek here in our office. I'm going to do a quick sugar test for you, and it will be a fasting sugar test. It will just be a quick bite on your finger. Patient: Don't worry doctor. I'm used to poaching my finger all the time. Doctor: Let's see what we have here. Your reading says one hundred and twenty. I'm going to write it for my file. Are you active? Patient: Yes, I do exercise three times a week.

How did your last visit take place with the cardiologist? Patient: Good. Doctor: It looks like they diagnosed you with a sick sinus syndrome. Do you have any questions about this new diagnosis? Patient: No, she explained everything to me. I intend to follow with her in the next two weeks. Doctor: Great. So, it seems that your medical past is the same? Nothing new than sick sinus syndrome.

So Mr. J, where are you staying? Patient: Oh, I'm staying in an ease of care. It's very close to your clinic. Have you heard about this place called South Valley Care Center? Doctor: Oh yes, I've heard about it.
How are you Mr James? Patient: I was better! Doctor: Oh, tell me what's going on with you? Patient: I have this pain in my leg on my left side. Doctor: Hm, pain in my left leg? Patient: Yes.
Have you ever had an allergic reaction to the medicines you have taken in the past? Patient: More than once. I have reacted badly to sulfa drugs, penicillin and some mycins.

Hey, do you smoke cigarettes? Patient: Yes I smoke. You? Doctor: No. Do you plan to quit smoking? Patient: No, I just smoke one pack a day, it's not bad. Doctor: Oh my God. No. It's bad. You should think about quitting. Patient: Ok, I'll think about it. Doctor: Where do you work? Patient: I work at the local Christmas farm.

Are you still working? Patient: Retired some time ago. Doctor: What was your profession? Patient: I was working in a car repair shop called Champion Automotive Company. Doctor: Nice. How did you like the job? Patient: I liked it a lot, but there came a time when I knew it was the end of the road for me. I'm really enjoying the retirement. Doctor: I bet. I have a cousin who owns a car repair shop. He's almost always busy. Patient: Yes, he can be a lot sometimes. Doctor: All smoking, drinking, or hard drugs? Patient: I can say with confidence not to everyone. Doctor: Great to hear.

Do you have all his medical history? Doctor: Yes, I confirmed with his wife. He had a CABG made in ninety-one. He has a history of radical prostate cancer for which he had a radical prostatectomy and a nephrectomy. Guest_clinician: Additional surgeries? Doctor: Yes. He had a lumbar surgery twice before. He suffered from lumbar stenosis many years ago in the sixties and seventies. He is actually due for another lumbar surgery with Dr. Y. He takes Percocet daily for his back pains. He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Guest_clinician: I think I did everything low.
Do you have a history of major surgery? Patient: No. Nothing major.
Hello, sir. Patient: Hello, doctor. Doctor: Before you started, have you ever had an operation? Patient: Yes, I had a vasectomy some time ago.

person: I prescribed eight hundred milligrams of Ibuprofen to take every eight hours necessary with Tylenol number three every six hours as needed. Patient
sentence: What does the number three represent? Doctor: Tylenol number three is combined with codeine. Patient: Okay, I see. Doctor: And finally, I prescribe Methocarbamol seven fifty milligrams that must be taken four times a day for maximum relief. Do you have any questions for me? Patient: No, I think you all answered them.
How are you doing today, sir?
Honestly, I'm pretty sick today. I've got a lot going on.
How long have you been feeling this way?
Well, it's been off and on for about a month now.
Has it been getting worse recently?
Yeah, it has over the last couple weeks.
What are your symptoms?
Well, I'm coughing up this yellow phlegm. It feels like everything is in my chest.
What medications have you been taking for this?
I've been taking Allegra D sometimes, but I'm almost out. I need a refill.
What other problems are you having?
My foot keeps breaking out.
Has this improved at all?
Well, it was for a while, but now it's really bad again.
Have you been diagnosed with any conditions before?
I had, um, tinea pedis before.
How was this treated?
They gave me Nizoral cream.
It has been getting warmer recently, I don't think that this isn't necessarily a coincidence that you're having these symptoms now.
Yeah, I work in the flint and it's really hot and humid down there.
What else are you dealing with, sir?
I have this wart on my right middle finger, are you able to freeze it off?
Have you ever done that before?
Yeah, you have done it before, and it went away.
If we've done it before, we can do it again.
Cool, can we do blood work, too? I want to check on my prostate.
Well, that's called P S A.
Can I have that done? I'm concerned. I am fifty after all.
Sure, we can check your cholesterol too. I know you have history of it being high.
You know, I've been working on that. I quit smoking for a while, but I got back into it.
That's good, it's really hard to quit.
Yeah, I tried chewing tobacco, but it's not the same.
Be sure to keep trying to quit smoking.

It seems that time warms up, which is pleasant. Patient: Yes, I can't wait to spend a little time with my children this afternoon. Doctor: Aw, how many children do you have? Patient: Two. Doctor: And are you single, dating, married? Patient: I have been married to my wife for ten years now. Doctor: Congratulations! It's a decade, my friend. Patient: Hah, that's sure. Patient: Are you from the area? Patient: I was born in Oklahoma. Patient: I was born in Oklahoma. Doctor: How long-Patient: I moved here to O Sept. Doctor: Impressive. I moved here to O Nine, so two years after you. Patient: No way! How funny. From where? Doctor: I'm from Kentucky. And I have to do the routine ask, but drink, smoke, or illicit use of drugs? Patient: No to all that above. Doctor: I got it.

It looks like the nurse came to ask you everything. Ah, she documented everything here, but I'm going to ask you again. So, tell me, where do you live? Patient: Oh, this is an old people's house. They have a lot of nurses there. Doctor: Do you smoke? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you work? Patient: Ah, right now I can't because of this disability, but I was working as a security guard.
